episodes.title: Introduction to ITIL Intermediate
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:03.873
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:03.873 --> 00:00:07.709
Hi and welcome to ITPRO.TV,
my name is Jo Peacock, and

3
00:00:07.709 --> 00:00:13.190
I'm going to be taking you through
an introduction to your ITIL Intermediate.

4
00:00:14.320 --> 00:00:18.543
So let's take a look then at
our first slide here coming up.

5
00:00:18.543 --> 00:00:22.418
And we have our introduction
to our Intermediate class and

6
00:00:22.418 --> 00:00:27.730
exactly what content is going to be found
in this upcoming Intermediate class.

7
00:00:27.730 --> 00:00:32.340
You will see what we will cover
is an introduction to the class,

8
00:00:32.340 --> 00:00:37.100
followed by the principles and
the processes of the Lifecycle phase.

9
00:00:37.100 --> 00:00:40.550
Then we'll take a look at organizing for
that Lifecycle phase.

10
00:00:40.550 --> 00:00:43.500
And also the technology considerations,

11
00:00:43.500 --> 00:00:48.270
especially those that we need when
we're implementing the phase itself.

12
00:00:48.270 --> 00:00:52.528
Then we'll take a look at the challenges
and the critical success factors and

13
00:00:52.528 --> 00:00:57.110
all of the risks that are associated
with a particular Lifecycle phase.

14
00:00:57.110 --> 00:01:00.850
And most importantly of course for
you, is that preparation for

15
00:01:00.850 --> 00:01:04.980
the exam that's going to be coming up
when you have completed your class.

16
00:01:05.980 --> 00:01:10.670
So let me take a look now then at how
we're going to approach this particular

17
00:01:10.670 --> 00:01:11.790
Intermediate class.

18
00:01:14.250 --> 00:01:17.230
We're going to be doing
some presentation work,

19
00:01:17.230 --> 00:01:22.550
obviously you're going to be watching us
on screen, both myself and my colleagues.

20
00:01:22.550 --> 00:01:27.110
And we're going to be taking you through
the course materials for the class.

21
00:01:27.110 --> 00:01:31.450
And then there are going to be some
discussions and some exercises that

22
00:01:31.450 --> 00:01:38.140
are going to be based primarily in our
chatrooms and also in our forums as well.

23
00:01:38.140 --> 00:01:42.530
And we're also available if you want
to undertake any of the assessments.

24
00:01:42.530 --> 00:01:45.970
Then please feel free to come
back to us via the forums and

25
00:01:45.970 --> 00:01:49.270
we will be able to help
you out in any way we can.

26
00:01:49.270 --> 00:01:51.950
Also provided in the course
material which is available for

27
00:01:51.950 --> 00:01:57.390
you to download, are mock tests or
exams if you prefer to use that word.

28
00:01:57.390 --> 00:02:02.720
And we will be conducting a run
through of that mock exam for you,

29
00:02:04.530 --> 00:02:08.770
so where are we then at
ITIL Intermediate level?

30
00:02:08.770 --> 00:02:13.460
Well, you'll see in using Bloom's
taxonomy that we are actually at level

31
00:02:13.460 --> 00:02:15.090
four analyzing.

32
00:02:15.090 --> 00:02:19.860
In other words, we've done a foundation
level, we've done the remembering and

33
00:02:19.860 --> 00:02:23.470
the understanding of those
concepts within ITIL.

34
00:02:23.470 --> 00:02:27.160
And we're actually moving through
applying those concepts to

35
00:02:27.160 --> 00:02:29.020
analyzing those concepts.

36
00:02:29.020 --> 00:02:33.240
And being able to apply
the ITIL processes and

37
00:02:33.240 --> 00:02:39.080
also the concepts at a real world
level in a real world situation, okay.

38
00:02:40.488 --> 00:02:43.590
So where does ITIL come from then,
well let me give you a little

39
00:02:43.590 --> 00:02:48.330
bit of a background, it's actually
owned by a company called Axelos.

40
00:02:48.330 --> 00:02:54.361
And it was first published in
the mid-1980s by the UK Government,

41
00:02:54.361 --> 00:03:00.910
and the Office of Government Commerce
owned ITIL for a very, very long time.

42
00:03:00.910 --> 00:03:06.346
And we developed ITIL right,
way back from the 1980s through it's

43
00:03:06.346 --> 00:03:12.430
Version 2 in the mid 1990's to
Version 3 which was released in 2007.

44
00:03:12.430 --> 00:03:16.652
And then there was
an update to Version 3 in

45
00:03:16.652 --> 00:03:21.598
2011 which is exactly
where we are right now.

46
00:03:21.598 --> 00:03:23.410
It is copyrighted,

47
00:03:23.410 --> 00:03:28.670
it is trademark protected,
it's a framework for managing services.

48
00:03:28.670 --> 00:03:32.160
And as such,
it is a flexible framework that

49
00:03:32.160 --> 00:03:37.000
we would expect any organization
to adapt as a framework, but

50
00:03:37.000 --> 00:03:41.680
then to adapt it to suit your needs, okay.

51
00:03:41.680 --> 00:03:47.773
ITIL was born way back in the 1980s out
of a desire to be able to demonstrate

52
00:03:47.773 --> 00:03:54.340
value for money and efficiency for
the use of taxpayers money within the UK.

53
00:03:54.340 --> 00:03:58.860
Way back in the 1980s, these things
started appearing on desks and

54
00:03:58.860 --> 00:03:59.900
quite frankly.

55
00:03:59.900 --> 00:04:05.368
We didn't know how to manage these
in an unbiased, in an impartial and

56
00:04:05.368 --> 00:04:10.420
in an efficient and effective way,
and thus ITIL was born.

57
00:04:10.420 --> 00:04:15.167
And ITIL was born from a group of
industry experts that went out

58
00:04:15.167 --> 00:04:17.093
into the big wide world.

59
00:04:17.093 --> 00:04:21.785
And analyzed various organizations from
various different industry sectors,

60
00:04:21.785 --> 00:04:26.690
not just government, but we're talking
finance, we're talking retail and etc.

61
00:04:26.690 --> 00:04:31.238
And they came back with
a set of best practices

62
00:04:31.238 --> 00:04:35.188
that they observed in the real world for

63
00:04:35.188 --> 00:04:40.223
managing our IT services,
and thus we have ITIL.

64
00:04:40.223 --> 00:04:44.770
As I've already said,
we've had subsequent revisions, and

65
00:04:44.770 --> 00:04:47.800
now we're off to Version 3, 2011.

66
00:04:47.800 --> 00:04:56.240
So we work on the understanding that
we have to every single service.

67
00:04:57.500 --> 00:05:00.960
And we start off with a concept
in service strategy and

68
00:05:00.960 --> 00:05:07.600
then we take that concept and
we design it, and then we develop it.

69
00:05:07.600 --> 00:05:11.360
And we deploy it as a service
into a live environment,

70
00:05:11.360 --> 00:05:14.520
which is where we operate and
where we maintain it.

71
00:05:14.520 --> 00:05:18.310
And we continually seek to ensure that we

72
00:05:18.310 --> 00:05:22.780
are aligned with the needs
of the organization in CSI.

73
00:05:24.960 --> 00:05:29.040
So you're attending this class
because you probably want

74
00:05:29.040 --> 00:05:33.040
to achieve an ITIL Intermediate
qualification.

75
00:05:34.180 --> 00:05:37.920
So you can see that if we were
to start off right at the very,

76
00:05:37.920 --> 00:05:40.280
very top, you'll see where I am.

77
00:05:40.280 --> 00:05:46.560
I am an accredited ITIL trainer working
with an accredited training organization.

78
00:05:46.560 --> 00:05:52.830
I'm also an accredited examiner and
proctor or invigilator for these exams.

79
00:05:52.830 --> 00:05:57.020
And work very, very closely with
the official ITIL accreditor and

80
00:05:57.020 --> 00:06:00.560
also Axelos who owns the ITIL copyright.

81
00:06:02.100 --> 00:06:07.080
Now, in terms of ITIL, where can you
go with your qualification level?

82
00:06:07.080 --> 00:06:13.130
Well, we start off with ITIL Foundation,
and ITIL Foundation would traditionally be

83
00:06:13.130 --> 00:06:20.020
a three-day classroom experience where
we learn the foundations of ITIL.

84
00:06:20.020 --> 00:06:23.640
And we learn all the terminology and all
of the definitions to that terminology,

85
00:06:23.640 --> 00:06:28.900
there's roughly round about 75 that we
learn within the ITIL Foundation class.

86
00:06:28.900 --> 00:06:31.560
And then, as we move through, we can

87
00:06:31.560 --> 00:06:36.710
either take an ITIL Practitioner class
which can be taken at any point in time.

88
00:06:36.710 --> 00:06:40.820
Throughout the progression
of your career within ITIL

89
00:06:40.820 --> 00:06:46.220
because ITIL practitioner focuses
on the implementation of ITIL.

90
00:06:46.220 --> 00:06:50.210
Whereas if we take a look at the more
advanced intermediate classes,

91
00:06:50.210 --> 00:06:55.040
you are at this moment
in a Lifecycle module.

92
00:06:55.040 --> 00:06:59.543
And those Lifecycle modules consist
of service strategy, service design,

93
00:06:59.543 --> 00:07:04.208
service transition, service operation and
continual service improvement.

94
00:07:04.208 --> 00:07:05.891
And that's where we focus on,

95
00:07:05.891 --> 00:07:09.076
those lifecycles that we've
just looked at previously.

96
00:07:09.076 --> 00:07:14.351
Okay, and on the right-hand side then,
we have our Capability modules.

97
00:07:14.351 --> 00:07:22.283
And these Capability modules really focus
on specific areas within ITIL such as RCV,

98
00:07:22.283 --> 00:07:27.253
which focuses on release,
control and validation.

99
00:07:27.253 --> 00:07:32.063
And these classes, you will notice that
every single one of these classes has

100
00:07:32.063 --> 00:07:34.430
got a score right beside each one.

101
00:07:34.430 --> 00:07:39.286
So we've got a number 2 for
Hill Foundation and we've got a three for

102
00:07:39.286 --> 00:07:44.159
Lifecycle modules and we've got a four for
our Capability modules.

103
00:07:44.159 --> 00:07:49.364
Now what we need to do is
ensure that we have achieved

104
00:07:49.364 --> 00:07:55.055
a minimum of 15 credits at
both either the Lifecycle or

105
00:07:55.055 --> 00:07:57.852
Capability module level.

106
00:07:57.852 --> 00:08:03.312
In order to be able to qualify to sit
the managing cross the Lifecycle class and

107
00:08:03.312 --> 00:08:08.665
therefore subsequently,
the test that goes along with that class.

108
00:08:08.665 --> 00:08:13.065
So we need to take two from the ITIL
Foundation, that's a prerequisite,

109
00:08:13.065 --> 00:08:14.905
we have to do the foundation.

110
00:08:14.905 --> 00:08:19.500
And then we need to add in
another 15 scores from either,

111
00:08:19.500 --> 00:08:22.650
as I've said, the Lifecycle or
the Capability stream.

112
00:08:22.650 --> 00:08:24.960
Now you can interchange, you can mix and

113
00:08:24.960 --> 00:08:29.100
match, you do not have to stick
to one stream or the other.

114
00:08:29.100 --> 00:08:33.215
Once you've got that 17 in total scores

115
00:08:33.215 --> 00:08:37.165
that are needed to be able to sit
managing across the Lifecycle.

116
00:08:37.165 --> 00:08:41.345
You're perfectly able to sit
that Lifecycle class and

117
00:08:41.345 --> 00:08:43.845
to be able to take that test afterwards.

118
00:08:43.845 --> 00:08:48.145
And as soon as you've taken that test
you will be awarded those five credits,

119
00:08:48.145 --> 00:08:52.535
which will mean that you
have achieved ITIL expert.

120
00:08:52.535 --> 00:08:57.240
Now ITIL expert is allocated
as soon as you have passed

121
00:08:57.240 --> 00:09:02.510
the Managing across the Lifecycle test and
have achieved 22 credits.

122
00:09:02.510 --> 00:09:05.770
Both of those must happen in order for
you to achieve ITIL expert.

123
00:09:07.380 --> 00:09:10.090
Now, we have the ITIL Master
qualification,

124
00:09:10.090 --> 00:09:14.630
and the ITIL Master is
a completely different beast,

125
00:09:14.630 --> 00:09:19.220
the ITIL Master is
a two-year qualification.

126
00:09:19.220 --> 00:09:25.750
And during that two years, you will be
expected to submit various white papers

127
00:09:25.750 --> 00:09:31.500
on specific topics within
the ITIL qualification scheme.

128
00:09:31.500 --> 00:09:35.166
So, these could be topics
on activities within ITIL,

129
00:09:35.166 --> 00:09:38.830
these could be topics or
processes within ITIL.

130
00:09:38.830 --> 00:09:43.810
These could be topics on implementation
of various aspects of ITIL.

131
00:09:43.810 --> 00:09:46.860
But you will be required to sit
a number of white papers or

132
00:09:46.860 --> 00:09:51.410
submit a number of white papers
over the period of two years.

133
00:09:51.410 --> 00:09:56.520
At the end of those two years once
you have submitted the prerequisite

134
00:09:56.520 --> 00:10:01.260
white papers, then you will be
asked to attend a panel interview.

135
00:10:01.260 --> 00:10:06.220
And during that panel interview you
will be assessed not only on your white

136
00:10:06.220 --> 00:10:11.597
papers but also on your experience
within the IT service management arena.

137
00:10:11.597 --> 00:10:15.330
And at the end of that panel
interview then if successful,

138
00:10:15.330 --> 00:10:18.020
you will be awarded
the status of IT Master.

139
00:10:20.060 --> 00:10:21.700
So the qualification scheme,

140
00:10:21.700 --> 00:10:25.340
I'm going to take this back
now to Bloom's Taxonomy then.

141
00:10:25.340 --> 00:10:29.360
And just very, very quickly look at
the fact that in ITIL Foundation, and

142
00:10:29.360 --> 00:10:32.560
I know that I've already covered
this in a previous slide.

143
00:10:32.560 --> 00:10:36.700
We just looked at understanding
the terminology and

144
00:10:36.700 --> 00:10:39.150
the concepts of ITIL Foundation.

145
00:10:39.150 --> 00:10:41.300
And then in that Lifecycle Modules,

146
00:10:41.300 --> 00:10:45.750
we're looking at implementing those
processes contained within ITIL.

147
00:10:45.750 --> 00:10:50.990
And in Capability, we're looking at
actually undertaking those processes and

148
00:10:50.990 --> 00:10:55.330
managing those processes,
was Managing across the Lifecycle.

149
00:10:55.330 --> 00:11:02.090
This is for senior management, this is at
CIO level and at senior management level.

150
00:11:02.090 --> 00:11:05.905
And in MALC,
as we like to abbreviate it to,

151
00:11:05.905 --> 00:11:10.475
you're concerned with leading
IT service management.

152
00:11:10.475 --> 00:11:15.385
So I mentioned right at the very beginning
of all of this that we had a test

153
00:11:15.385 --> 00:11:20.735
to go along with every single
Lifecycle phase and there is.

154
00:11:20.735 --> 00:11:25.429
And we will be conducting a session to
go all over this particular test or

155
00:11:25.429 --> 00:11:27.631
at least a sample of these tests.

156
00:11:27.631 --> 00:11:32.960
Just to give you some preparation for
the actual test itself.

157
00:11:32.960 --> 00:11:37.600
So, your test is conducted online,
it's conducted virtually,

158
00:11:39.160 --> 00:11:46.390
it is an eight multiple choice question
test, it's complex multiple choice.

159
00:11:46.390 --> 00:11:49.440
You get an hour and a half for
this particular test and

160
00:11:49.440 --> 00:11:53.640
with every single question,
you will be given a scenario.

161
00:11:53.640 --> 00:11:59.910
And then you will be given four possible
options for possible answers for

162
00:11:59.910 --> 00:12:04.548
the question that is posed
along with that scenario.

163
00:12:04.548 --> 00:12:09.176
You get five points for the best fit
answer, now it mentions up there, the most

164
00:12:09.176 --> 00:12:13.910
correct, I always call it the best fit
because every single question asks.

165
00:12:13.910 --> 00:12:19.300
What is the best answer,
given the scenario and given the question?

166
00:12:19.300 --> 00:12:23.350
Don't be alarmed if you don't see
an answer that you think is 100% correct

167
00:12:24.870 --> 00:12:29.380
because the question is asking you for
the best fit.

168
00:12:29.380 --> 00:12:33.080
And for that best fit,
you're gonna get five points, for

169
00:12:33.080 --> 00:12:35.630
the next best fit, you're gonna get three.

170
00:12:35.630 --> 00:12:40.740
For the next one, which we've
considered to be the least correct,

171
00:12:40.740 --> 00:12:45.070
you're gonna get 1, and for
the next one, you're gonna get a 0.

172
00:12:45.070 --> 00:12:50.110
Now it mentions up on that slide there
that the next one is 0 marks for

173
00:12:50.110 --> 00:12:51.080
incorrect.

174
00:12:51.080 --> 00:12:55.802
In the industry, us and all,
we like to call that the distractor, and

175
00:12:55.802 --> 00:13:00.600
we call it the distractor for
a reason, cuz it distracts.

176
00:13:00.600 --> 00:13:02.727
And quite often, what you will find is,

177
00:13:02.727 --> 00:13:05.810
[LAUGH] With your distractor,
a lot of the words in the terminology.

178
00:13:05.810 --> 00:13:10.810
That are taken straight of the ITIL books,
straight out of the publications,

179
00:13:10.810 --> 00:13:15.298
and are input into that zero pointer
because it's there to distract.

180
00:13:15.298 --> 00:13:20.797
And it sounds great, but
more often than not, that distractor

181
00:13:20.797 --> 00:13:26.600
has absolutely no relevance to
the scenario or to the question.

182
00:13:26.600 --> 00:13:31.480
So you have to be incredibly careful with
that, it's so easy to be distracted.

183
00:13:32.800 --> 00:13:38.370
You have to get 28 out of a possible
40 in order to be able to pass and

184
00:13:38.370 --> 00:13:44.540
achieve accreditation at
any lifecycle test, okay.

185
00:13:44.540 --> 00:13:48.640
If English is not your first language,
you are allowed a paper dictionary.

186
00:13:48.640 --> 00:13:53.386
But you will be asked to show that
to the proctor at the time that

187
00:13:53.386 --> 00:13:55.650
you take your test.

188
00:13:55.650 --> 00:14:02.579
And as I've already said, you have to
have an ITIL Foundation in Version 3 or

189
00:14:02.579 --> 00:14:09.310
Version 3 2011 or an ITIL Version
2 Foundation Bridge to Version 3.

190
00:14:10.650 --> 00:14:15.450
I will be very, very honest with you,
there are not that many people that have

191
00:14:15.450 --> 00:14:18.580
attained the Version 2
to Version 3 Bridge.

192
00:14:18.580 --> 00:14:25.800
And most people will have the Version
3 2011 ITIL Foundation certificate.

193
00:14:27.540 --> 00:14:31.572
You will be required to
upload that certificate to

194
00:14:31.572 --> 00:14:36.378
the examining board prior to
sitting your lifecycle test.

195
00:14:36.378 --> 00:14:38.847
So be prepared with that,

196
00:14:38.847 --> 00:14:44.134
you will need to have it at hand and
saved as a PDF as well.

197
00:14:44.134 --> 00:14:49.635
So when we come to the end of
every single lifecycle class and

198
00:14:49.635 --> 00:14:56.410
this one's no exception,
we'll be going over a sample test for you.

199
00:14:56.410 --> 00:14:59.670
And during that sample test I'll
be giving you lots of hints and

200
00:14:59.670 --> 00:15:04.150
tips on how to select that
best fit possible answer.

201
00:15:04.150 --> 00:15:08.090
And also how to ensure that you read
the full question, how to relax.

202
00:15:08.090 --> 00:15:13.200
And to make sure that you
approach it with an open mind but

203
00:15:13.200 --> 00:15:16.100
you consider relevance
in every single answer.

204
00:15:17.590 --> 00:15:21.610
Ultimately, we wanna get you
pass the test just as much as

205
00:15:21.610 --> 00:15:23.760
you want to achieve that accreditation.

206
00:15:24.970 --> 00:15:31.550
So just to sum up, what we will
be doing over the next few shows

207
00:15:31.550 --> 00:15:37.460
is encouraging you to take your
ITIL Lifecycle Intermediate classes.

208
00:15:37.460 --> 00:15:41.992
And feel free to join us in the forums for
any questions that you may have.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo begin the foundation refresher.  Jo reviews the key aspects of ITIL foundation by describing the 5 core volume service lifecycles: service strategy, service design, service transition, service operation, and continual service improvement.  She also defines what ITIL means by a Service and Service Management.  Also the key terms that define value: Utility and Warranty by Jo.
episodes.title: ITIL Foundation Refresher

458
00:27:38.203 --> 00:27:43.320
which is just further classification
of our services, to be honest.

459
00:27:43.320 --> 00:27:47.537
We split our services down, believe it or
not, into those that are core,

460
00:27:47.537 --> 00:27:51.905
those that are enabling services, and
those that are enhancing services.

461
00:27:51.905 --> 00:27:56.362
Now we've got pizza delivery example
up there on the screen in front of you.

462
00:27:56.362 --> 00:27:59.520
I wanna give you an IT example,
for instance.

463
00:27:59.520 --> 00:28:04.780
So let's think about our email service.

464
00:28:04.780 --> 00:28:10.045
So the core service in an email service is
that ability to send and receive email.

465
00:28:10.045 --> 00:28:12.708
That's our core service.

466
00:28:12.708 --> 00:28:17.665
Now the enabling service is a service
that's a service in it's own right, but

467
00:28:17.665 --> 00:28:19.855
that underpins the core service.

468
00:28:19.855 --> 00:28:23.974
And that would be our infrastructure,
it's a service in its own right,

469
00:28:23.974 --> 00:28:28.580
but without it email's not going
to be able to be sent or received.

470
00:28:28.580 --> 00:28:32.960
And then an enhancing
service is an optional extra.

471
00:28:32.960 --> 00:28:37.355
Something that we can do that maybe
sets us apart from our competitors or

472
00:28:37.355 --> 00:28:41.764
something that we just choose to do,
it's optional for our business.

473
00:28:41.764 --> 00:28:45.580
And that would be something like
a shared calendar, for instance, okay?

474
00:28:45.580 --> 00:28:50.921
So something that is an optional extra
that's our email, that's our shared,

475
00:28:50.921 --> 00:28:55.600
directory, shared calendar is
the word I'm looking for, okay?

476
00:28:55.600 --> 00:29:00.934
So these are our core and
our enabling and our enhancing services.

477
00:29:00.934 --> 00:29:06.053
Now, I asked you about
value a little earlier on.

478
00:29:06.053 --> 00:29:09.460
And about what we perceive as value.

479
00:29:09.460 --> 00:29:14.088
So I'm just gonna wrap up this
section by going over a couple of

480
00:29:14.088 --> 00:29:17.658
slides that look over
the definition of value.

481
00:29:17.658 --> 00:29:22.381
Now, you will see that in
the bottom of this particular slide

482
00:29:22.381 --> 00:29:24.418
right in front of you now,

483
00:29:24.418 --> 00:29:30.084
you will see that the diagram that you
saw in your ITIL foundation class.

484
00:29:30.084 --> 00:29:33.683
And that is that diagram that always
looks very, very complicated and

485
00:29:33.683 --> 00:29:37.045
everybody always says to me,
how am I supposed to remember this?

486
00:29:37.045 --> 00:29:40.087
Well, it's really easy
because you just need

487
00:29:40.087 --> 00:29:43.450
to remember the concepts of utility and
warranty.

488
00:29:44.530 --> 00:29:47.899
So the concept of utility is very,
very simply,

489
00:29:47.899 --> 00:29:50.457
does it do what it's supposed to do?

490
00:29:50.457 --> 00:29:52.580
And that's its fitness for purpose.

491
00:29:52.580 --> 00:29:55.360
Does that service send and receive email?

492
00:29:55.360 --> 00:29:56.110
Yes, it does.

493
00:29:56.110 --> 00:29:57.980
Okay then, it has utility.

494
00:29:57.980 --> 00:30:02.170
And you can have a web-based email service
that will do exactly that for you.

495
00:30:02.170 --> 00:30:03.580
It will deliver that email.

496
00:30:04.710 --> 00:30:08.864
But can I ask you,
in a business perspective then, Ronnie,

497
00:30:08.864 --> 00:30:13.263
would a web-based email deliver
you levels of security that you

498
00:30:13.263 --> 00:30:16.377
would feel comfortable with, do you think?

499
00:30:16.377 --> 00:30:22.224
>> Yeah, not necessarily, especially if
I'm actually using a public provider and

500
00:30:22.224 --> 00:30:28.360
not my own, as far as a portal that allows
me access just inside of my own network.

501
00:30:28.360 --> 00:30:31.990
>> Yeah, right, so
what you're saying is then,

502
00:30:31.990 --> 00:30:36.630
in effect, is that that service
provides utility, which it does.

503
00:30:36.630 --> 00:30:39.860
But it doesn't provide warranty aspect.

504
00:30:39.860 --> 00:30:42.475
And if we look at the warranty aspect,

505
00:30:42.475 --> 00:30:47.465
you will see that those warranty
aspects are availability, capacity,

506
00:30:47.465 --> 00:30:51.660
security, which is one that I mentioned,
and continuity.

507
00:30:51.660 --> 00:30:57.070
And so both utility and warranty have to
exist in order for us to perceive value.

508
00:30:58.110 --> 00:31:00.530
So let's go through
those warranty aspects.

509
00:31:01.530 --> 00:31:03.945
Is that service available enough?

510
00:31:03.945 --> 00:31:08.930
Well, okay, an Internet, so
an Internet based web mail service might

511
00:31:08.930 --> 00:31:12.932
be available enough, but
does it have enough capacity?

512
00:31:12.932 --> 00:31:15.434
Mm, guarantee when you try and
send some files,

513
00:31:15.434 --> 00:31:18.260
it'll tell you that they're too big.

514
00:31:18.260 --> 00:31:19.587
Does it have continuity?

515
00:31:19.587 --> 00:31:23.410
Well it might do, but
we don't have any assurance of that.

516
00:31:23.410 --> 00:31:27.490
And that's the key thing about
warranty is that we have assurance.

517
00:31:27.490 --> 00:31:31.350
And we certainly don't have
any assurance for security.

518
00:31:31.350 --> 00:31:36.430
So you see, both utility and warranty
need to exist for us to perceive value.

519
00:31:36.430 --> 00:31:41.412
It's not just good enough for us to have a
service that does what it says on the can.

520
00:31:41.412 --> 00:31:43.760
We've gotta be able to use it as well.

521
00:31:45.030 --> 00:31:46.450
And this next slide,

522
00:31:46.450 --> 00:31:51.090
which is something that I'm going
to use to wrap up this session.

523
00:31:51.090 --> 00:31:56.230
If you look, the utility effect
in that bottom left-hand corner

524
00:31:56.230 --> 00:32:01.030
is all about increasing
the probability and

525
00:32:01.030 --> 00:32:05.440
maintaining that probability
of that service working.

526
00:32:05.440 --> 00:32:10.530
In other words, that service
will do what it says on the can,

527
00:32:10.530 --> 00:32:11.560
without a shadow of a doubt.

528
00:32:12.610 --> 00:32:19.059
But the warranty effect has to actually
decrease variances in availability,

529
00:32:19.059 --> 00:32:24.030
and in capacity, and
in continuity, and in security.

530
00:32:24.030 --> 00:32:29.620
Because what we actually want to do is we
want to ensure that we have all of those.

531
00:32:29.620 --> 00:32:32.680
So we want to decrease, and

532
00:32:32.680 --> 00:32:37.980
we want to decrease the uncertainty
of providing those aspects.

533
00:32:37.980 --> 00:32:41.774
As we've said,
we have got to have both utility and

534
00:32:41.774 --> 00:32:45.401
warranty in order for
anyone to perceive value.

535
00:32:45.401 --> 00:32:49.876
So for now, we're going to wrap
up this particular session,

536
00:32:49.876 --> 00:32:54.140
which is part one of our
recap of our ITIL foundation.

537
00:32:54.140 --> 00:32:57.670
And in our next section, we're going
to look further into our assets and

538
00:32:57.670 --> 00:33:00.730
into our resources and capabilities, etc.

539
00:33:00.730 --> 00:33:06.634
And we're also going to look at processes,
and we're going to look at roles,

540
00:33:06.634 --> 00:33:11.653
and we're going to look at all of
our responsibilities, etc too.

541
00:33:11.653 --> 00:33:13.636
>> All right Jill,
well thank you again for

542
00:33:13.636 --> 00:33:15.975
helping us out with this
part of the refresher.

543
00:33:15.975 --> 00:33:19.908
There's a lot more for us to cover, but
that means we're gonna go ahead and

544
00:33:19.908 --> 00:33:21.670
end this episode then.

545
00:33:21.670 --> 00:33:25.715
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

546
00:33:25.715 --> 00:33:27.260
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

547
00:33:27.260 --> 00:33:31.829
Stay tuned right here for
another ITIL foundation refresher.

548
00:33:31.829 --> 00:33:37.839
[MUSIC]

549
00:33:37.839 --> 00:33:39.715
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo continue with the foundation refresher.  Jo reviews asset, resource, capabilities and processes from the ITIL perspective.  She emphasizes the process model and roles associated with processes.  Lastly, she describes the accountability that belongs to the service owner as well.
episodes.title: ITIL Foundation Refresher Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:03.205
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.205 --> 00:00:07.369
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.369 --> 00:00:08.518
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.518 --> 00:00:12.373
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.373 --> 00:00:15.070
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.070 --> 00:00:20.520
You're watching the ITIL Foundation
Refresher for your intermediate class.

7
00:00:20.520 --> 00:00:24.560
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and
we're taking a look at another foundation

8
00:00:24.560 --> 00:00:29.320
refresher, a part two to help us to
round out those skills that we need.

9
00:00:29.320 --> 00:00:34.640
And here to help us of course is going
to be our ITIL virtuoso, Ms Jo Peacock.

10
00:00:34.640 --> 00:00:36.230
Jo, welcome back to the show.

11
00:00:36.230 --> 00:00:37.790
>> Thank you for having me back, Ronnie.

12
00:00:37.790 --> 00:00:38.890
How are you doing?

13
00:00:38.890 --> 00:00:40.659
>> Doing great, taking look and

14
00:00:40.659 --> 00:00:45.191
remembering all those different terms
that I've seen in the foundation and

15
00:00:45.191 --> 00:00:49.812
now getting those things kind of brought
back up has really starting to help.

16
00:00:49.812 --> 00:00:52.470
So what do we actually have left to do,
where are we gonna begin?

17
00:00:52.470 --> 00:00:56.865
>> Yeah, I mean it's, this foundation
material that we're recapping over,

18
00:00:56.865 --> 00:00:58.610
there's so much information-
>> Right.

19
00:00:58.610 --> 00:01:01.170
>> To absorb, so much information.

20
00:01:01.170 --> 00:01:03.265
And trust me, you're not the only one.

21
00:01:03.265 --> 00:01:07.463
Because we have delegates that
leave foundation class and

22
00:01:07.463 --> 00:01:11.834
the feedback that they'll give
you sometimes is that whoa,

23
00:01:11.834 --> 00:01:14.928
it's just so much information to absorb.

24
00:01:14.928 --> 00:01:18.877
And it really is, and the unfortunate
thing is that we have to get through

25
00:01:18.877 --> 00:01:23.346
the foundation, you have to understand all
of the concepts in the foundation to be

26
00:01:23.346 --> 00:01:25.910
able to then delve deeper
into the processes.

27
00:01:25.910 --> 00:01:31.640
And until we can understand really what
a process is, or really what a functional

28
00:01:31.640 --> 00:01:37.060
area is and what a role should do,
then it's difficult to apply that concept.

29
00:01:37.060 --> 00:01:39.660
And so
what we're learning here is concepts.

30
00:01:39.660 --> 00:01:41.935
And I will admit that
there is a lot to learn.

31
00:01:41.935 --> 00:01:44.040
[LAUGH]
>> All right, Jo, so

32
00:01:44.040 --> 00:01:48.030
just take us a little bit through
what we reviewed last time and

33
00:01:48.030 --> 00:01:50.750
then where we're going to
be heading from there.

34
00:01:50.750 --> 00:01:51.480
>> Okay.
So in part one,

35
00:01:51.480 --> 00:01:54.510
we actually looked at
the concept of a service.

36
00:01:54.510 --> 00:01:56.220
And the concept of a service is,

37
00:01:56.220 --> 00:02:01.080
a service is a means of delivering value
by facilitating the outcomes that our

38
00:02:01.080 --> 00:02:05.730
customers want to achieve without
the ownership of specific costs and risks.

39
00:02:05.730 --> 00:02:08.440
Now, you know value is perceived.

40
00:02:08.440 --> 00:02:11.880
As I mentioned, we all have
a different perception of value and

41
00:02:11.880 --> 00:02:16.460
even in a business environment our
perception of value is still different.

42
00:02:16.460 --> 00:02:19.590
No matter how much we
would like to try and

43
00:02:19.590 --> 00:02:24.250
deliver a one size fits all
approach to our services,

44
00:02:24.250 --> 00:02:28.590
to our businesses, we can't do
that because value is perceived.

45
00:02:28.590 --> 00:02:32.410
So we looked at that and we looked
at the fact that service management,

46
00:02:32.410 --> 00:02:37.890
which ITIL is a framework is a set of
specialized organizational capabilities

47
00:02:37.890 --> 00:02:42.410
for delivering value to customers
in the form of goods or services.

48
00:02:42.410 --> 00:02:47.040
Now I know that I just rattled off two
descriptions, two definitions to you.

49
00:02:47.040 --> 00:02:50.440
And now that's made me
look like a bit of a nerd.

50
00:02:50.440 --> 00:02:54.270
[LAUGH] I'm fully aware of that, okay.

51
00:02:54.270 --> 00:03:00.160
And we also looked at the concept of
value being broken down into utility and

52
00:03:00.160 --> 00:03:01.290
warranty and

53
00:03:01.290 --> 00:03:06.570
the fact that it's not just about us
being able to do what it says on the can.

54
00:03:06.570 --> 00:03:09.970
We've gotta be able to send and receive
email but we've gotta do it in a way that

55
00:03:09.970 --> 00:03:15.610
we can assure our customers of
levels of utility and warranty and

56
00:03:15.610 --> 00:03:20.620
availability and capacity and
service continuity and security.

57
00:03:20.620 --> 00:03:23.550
So we're gonna need both that utility and

58
00:03:23.550 --> 00:03:27.320
warranty to be present in order for
them to perceive value.

59
00:03:27.320 --> 00:03:32.010
And so in this particular section we're
gonna start off just by going over

60
00:03:32.010 --> 00:03:33.860
what our service assets were.

61
00:03:33.860 --> 00:03:39.820
I mentioned them very,
very briefly in the last section about

62
00:03:39.820 --> 00:03:44.390
tangible and our intangible assets and
how we use those to deliver our services.

63
00:03:45.572 --> 00:03:48.220
>> All right, so
let's go ahead and begin, then.

64
00:03:48.220 --> 00:03:50.440
So where are we picking up from there?

65
00:03:50.440 --> 00:03:54.230
>> So as I said,
we begin with our service assets and

66
00:03:54.230 --> 00:03:59.680
our assets are what we use
within our organization to

67
00:03:59.680 --> 00:04:04.098
deliver value by way of goods or
services, as we say.

68
00:04:04.098 --> 00:04:07.135
And an asset is described there,
you've got some definitions there.

69
00:04:07.135 --> 00:04:10.540
An asset is defined as a resource or
a capability.

70
00:04:10.540 --> 00:04:13.540
And a resource is what we
consider to be a tangible asset,

71
00:04:13.540 --> 00:04:16.250
something that you touch and feel.

72
00:04:16.250 --> 00:04:20.780
Such as, as mentioned there,
money, our infrastructure itself,

73
00:04:20.780 --> 00:04:25.960
the software that we have, the actual
data that we have, our hardware.

74
00:04:25.960 --> 00:04:27.650
These are tangible assets.

75
00:04:27.650 --> 00:04:32.750
You'll notice that people span
both capabilities and resources.

76
00:04:32.750 --> 00:04:36.030
So then our tangible assets,
something that you can touch and feel.

77
00:04:36.030 --> 00:04:38.620
But I gave you that warning
in that first section.

78
00:04:38.620 --> 00:04:40.310
Don't you do that too much.

79
00:04:40.310 --> 00:04:45.000
And then [LAUGH] and
people are also intangible assets.

80
00:04:45.000 --> 00:04:48.150
And you know what,
under the intangible assets,

81
00:04:48.150 --> 00:04:51.450
soft assets as they mention
there our capabilities.

82
00:04:51.450 --> 00:04:55.240
We've got things like how we're managed,
who manages us?

83
00:04:55.240 --> 00:04:58.900
We've got the organization itself,
how well organized we are.

84
00:04:58.900 --> 00:05:02.750
If there's complete chaos going on then
we're never gonna be able to deliver value

85
00:05:02.750 --> 00:05:03.800
to our customers, are we?

86
00:05:03.800 --> 00:05:07.820
Our processes have to be efficient and
effective.

87
00:05:07.820 --> 00:05:10.710
And if our processes don't do
what they're supposed to do and

88
00:05:10.710 --> 00:05:13.450
they're not efficient and
they're not effective, then you know what?

89
00:05:13.450 --> 00:05:18.260
They're not going to deliver value
to our business, to our users and

90
00:05:18.260 --> 00:05:19.735
then our knowledge.

91
00:05:19.735 --> 00:05:24.160
And, that underneath people,
we've got experience and skills, too.

92
00:05:24.160 --> 00:05:27.931
And knowledge can be quantified.

93
00:05:27.931 --> 00:05:30.175
We should document our knowledge.

94
00:05:30.175 --> 00:05:34.105
And then it becomes information that we
can put into our knowledge management

95
00:05:34.105 --> 00:05:39.085
system, so a knowledge though is
also our experience and our skills.

96
00:05:39.085 --> 00:05:41.325
And believe it or not, our attitude and

97
00:05:41.325 --> 00:05:45.027
attitude fall under these soft assets,
the capabilities.

98
00:05:45.027 --> 00:05:48.855
Like morale,
I expect to see morale in there as well,

99
00:05:48.855 --> 00:05:53.619
which is why as we've moved through
the service operation class,

100
00:05:53.619 --> 00:05:59.339
you'll see that we put a huge emphasis on
people and on morale and on attitudes.

101
00:05:59.339 --> 00:06:03.307
And on understanding sort of
organizational change management and

102
00:06:03.307 --> 00:06:07.832
the people aspect because our people
are what's going to enable us to deliver

103
00:06:07.832 --> 00:06:12.740
value, but they're also what's going to
hinder us from delivering value, too.

104
00:06:12.740 --> 00:06:14.480
Look at our soft skills,

105
00:06:14.480 --> 00:06:19.560
look at our capabilities there and
how well we are organized.

106
00:06:19.560 --> 00:06:24.190
Well, that is, worst it might be,
you might consider it to be

107
00:06:24.190 --> 00:06:27.570
driven by management cuz management
set our organizational structures.

108
00:06:27.570 --> 00:06:29.538
But it's also driven by people,

109
00:06:29.538 --> 00:06:33.950
too as to how collaborative they
are within that organizational.

110
00:06:33.950 --> 00:06:35.620
And think about management.

111
00:06:37.040 --> 00:06:38.240
I know I asked you.

112
00:06:38.240 --> 00:06:40.680
I put you on the spot last time,
didn't I, Ronnie?

113
00:06:40.680 --> 00:06:43.820
I said to you do you get on with
your managers all the time?

114
00:06:43.820 --> 00:06:47.080
And the simple fact of the matter
is there are always going

115
00:06:47.080 --> 00:06:48.482
to be interpersonal conflicts.

116
00:06:48.482 --> 00:06:54.250
There are always going to be interpersonal
issues and so we've got to accept that.

117
00:06:54.250 --> 00:06:56.900
That even if we've got good management,

118
00:06:56.900 --> 00:06:59.570
then there may be
interpersonal issues there.

119
00:06:59.570 --> 00:07:03.860
And certainly, I know that we've
all worked in environments where

120
00:07:03.860 --> 00:07:07.280
there may be a siloed
mentality between teams.

121
00:07:08.810 --> 00:07:12.230
And it doesn't matter how
good our processes are.

122
00:07:12.230 --> 00:07:14.730
If our people do not have
the right attitude or

123
00:07:14.730 --> 00:07:18.440
don't have the right experience to
be able to follow those processes,

124
00:07:18.440 --> 00:07:20.570
then they're never gonna deliver value.

125
00:07:20.570 --> 00:07:23.020
It's really as simple as that,
so people are very,

126
00:07:23.020 --> 00:07:26.630
very important to this,
incredibly important.

127
00:07:26.630 --> 00:07:28.870
So I mentioned processes.

128
00:07:28.870 --> 00:07:31.240
Well, let's take a look at a process.

129
00:07:31.240 --> 00:07:35.920
I have mentioned in other sessions
that we look at in service operations,

130
00:07:35.920 --> 00:07:39.520
that a process is a set
of structured activities,

131
00:07:39.520 --> 00:07:42.630
designed to accomplish
a specific objective.

132
00:07:42.630 --> 00:07:45.610
And it takes an input and
turns it into an output.

133
00:07:45.610 --> 00:07:48.042
And I think I remember I've said that, and

134
00:07:48.042 --> 00:07:50.891
we've had that [LAUGH] discussion before,
okay?
