in service level management and
with our customer as well.

366
00:22:38.370 --> 00:22:41.170
So, I expect the service owner
to be present with that.

367
00:22:41.170 --> 00:22:45.510
Ultimately the service owner takes
accountability for a service.

368
00:22:47.080 --> 00:22:49.170
So, in this particular section here, then,

369
00:22:49.170 --> 00:22:53.490
well in the last two sections we've
done a very, very brief overview.

370
00:22:53.490 --> 00:22:59.199
Of some of the fundamentals that we
learned within our IT foundation class.

371
00:23:00.380 --> 00:23:04.300
Now, I do understand that
there is a lot to learn there,

372
00:23:04.300 --> 00:23:08.780
so please feel free to browse
further the IT foundation

373
00:23:08.780 --> 00:23:13.300
material that is available
here through ITPRO.TV.

374
00:23:13.300 --> 00:23:17.820
But, what I would ask you to do know
is obviously to move in to your service

375
00:23:17.820 --> 00:23:23.610
operation material and to take a look
at our other service operation modules.

376
00:23:23.610 --> 00:23:27.550
Alright, Jo, well thank you again for
helping us out and reminding us of some of

377
00:23:27.550 --> 00:23:32.090
those foundational concepts that we may
be a little bit weak on, but now with

378
00:23:32.090 --> 00:23:37.440
this refresher, it means we're ready
to head on to our ITIL intermedia show.

379
00:23:37.440 --> 00:23:39.520
Well, great place for us to sign off then.

380
00:23:39.520 --> 00:23:42.480
For IT pro TV, I'm your host Ronny Wong.

381
00:23:42.480 --> 00:23:43.680
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

382
00:23:43.680 --> 00:23:48.382
>> Stay turned now for
your ITIL intermedia introduction.

383
00:23:48.382 --> 00:23:54.442
[MUSIC]

384
00:23:54.442 --> 00:23:57.451
>> Thank you for watching itpro.tv.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo look into the value of service strategy for the organization.  Jo describes the purpose, objectives and overall value that it brings to organizational and how it influences the other lifecycle phases.  It is here in service strategy that we define the perspective, position, plans and patterns that will facilitate the outcomes we want within our organization, she says.  It is the directional lifecycle phase that is an input to all other lifecycle phases, according to Jo.
episodes.title: Service Strategy Value
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.250 --> 00:00:06.092
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.092 --> 00:00:07.881
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:07.881 --> 00:00:12.045
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:12.045 --> 00:00:14.626
>> Hello and welcome to ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:14.626 --> 00:00:18.590
You're watching the ITIL
Intermediate Service Strategy show.

6
00:00:18.590 --> 00:00:20.910
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and today,

7
00:00:20.910 --> 00:00:24.300
we're gonna be taking a look
at service strategy values.

8
00:00:24.300 --> 00:00:29.080
And here to help us get started right is
gonna be our ITIL master, Jo Peacock.

9
00:00:29.080 --> 00:00:30.764
Jo, welcome to the show.

10
00:00:30.764 --> 00:00:31.840
>> Thank you for having me Ronnie.

11
00:00:31.840 --> 00:00:32.790
How are you?

12
00:00:32.790 --> 00:00:36.770
>> I'm doing fine Jo, and I hope you are
doing well as we get started into service

13
00:00:36.770 --> 00:00:39.650
strategy and
talking about the values here.

14
00:00:39.650 --> 00:00:44.870
So Jo in terms of talking about value of
service strategy, why is it so important.

15
00:00:44.870 --> 00:00:46.630
We understand that we need a strategy.

16
00:00:46.630 --> 00:00:49.515
What is the true value and
nature of what we're talking about?

17
00:00:49.515 --> 00:00:53.978
>> Well, server strategy is a first
life cycle phase within ITIL, and

18
00:00:53.978 --> 00:00:57.816
of course everybody has seen
the ITIL foundation shows and

19
00:00:57.816 --> 00:01:01.435
have take the ITIL foundation
test in order to be here.

20
00:01:01.435 --> 00:01:04.490
And so we know that this
is where the magic starts.

21
00:01:04.490 --> 00:01:07.610
This is where we come up with
our ideas for our new services.

22
00:01:07.610 --> 00:01:10.530
This is also where we liaise
with our business and

23
00:01:10.530 --> 00:01:13.400
where we get to understand
exactly how they work.

24
00:01:13.400 --> 00:01:17.938
This is where we define our strategies for
how we govern within IT.

25
00:01:17.938 --> 00:01:22.553
And this is also where we ensure that our
strategy matches the business strategy, so

26
00:01:22.553 --> 00:01:25.414
that we're both heading in
the same direction, and

27
00:01:25.414 --> 00:01:28.240
not in two opposite directions.

28
00:01:28.240 --> 00:01:32.550
>> All right, so Jo, when it comes down
to a value, and we talk about service

29
00:01:32.550 --> 00:01:37.410
strategy value here, where are we
going to begin looking at this value?

30
00:01:37.410 --> 00:01:38.990
>> Well let's first look at the purpose.

31
00:01:38.990 --> 00:01:40.550
Let's look at why we're here.

32
00:01:40.550 --> 00:01:43.090
What is the purpose of service strategy?

33
00:01:43.090 --> 00:01:46.390
And we can sum this up in four Ps,
as we call them.

34
00:01:46.390 --> 00:01:50.550
Now these are our four Ps of service
strategy, not to be confused with the four

35
00:01:50.550 --> 00:01:55.000
ps of service design that you
learnt in your foundation class and

36
00:01:55.000 --> 00:01:58.330
then we'll cover it again in
the E-service Design class.

37
00:01:58.330 --> 00:02:02.558
So the four Ps of service strategy
are perspective, position, plans, and

38
00:02:02.558 --> 00:02:03.226
patterns.

39
00:02:03.226 --> 00:02:04.870
And what does that actually mean?

40
00:02:04.870 --> 00:02:08.850
It says here that the purpose
is to define the four Ps

41
00:02:08.850 --> 00:02:11.670
that we need a service provider,
that's us,

42
00:02:11.670 --> 00:02:16.650
needs to be able to execute to meet
the organization's business outcomes.

43
00:02:16.650 --> 00:02:18.630
Don't forget a service.

44
00:02:18.630 --> 00:02:23.263
The definition of a service is a means of
delivering value by facilitating outcomes

45
00:02:23.263 --> 00:02:28.930
that the customer wants to achieve without
the ownership of specific costs and risks.

46
00:02:28.930 --> 00:02:32.290
So in other words,
we want to facilitate business outcomes,

47
00:02:32.290 --> 00:02:36.281
we don't want to deliver those
outcomes because we can't.

48
00:02:36.281 --> 00:02:38.829
We're facilitating in outcomes.

49
00:02:38.829 --> 00:02:42.810
And a service isn't about an application.

50
00:02:42.810 --> 00:02:45.130
A service is not Microsoft Outlook,

51
00:02:45.130 --> 00:02:49.190
the service is actually the ability
to send and receive email.

52
00:02:49.190 --> 00:02:53.460
Now we won't receive that email for
you, we wont read it for

53
00:02:53.460 --> 00:02:56.240
you, we can't type that email for you.

54
00:02:56.240 --> 00:02:59.190
What we can do is facilitate that outcome.

55
00:02:59.190 --> 00:03:03.060
But then yet at the end of the day,
the business still has to sit down,

56
00:03:03.060 --> 00:03:04.930
type that email and press Send.

57
00:03:04.930 --> 00:03:06.910
We will just facilitate it.

58
00:03:06.910 --> 00:03:10.040
And we will provide absolutely
everything that's needed

59
00:03:10.040 --> 00:03:12.900
in order to be able to
facilitate that outcome.

60
00:03:12.900 --> 00:03:17.890
So to help you in the business, sit
down and type the email and press send.

61
00:03:17.890 --> 00:03:22.390
So, then, if what we want to do is meet
those outcomes or facilitate those

62
00:03:22.390 --> 00:03:26.870
outcomes, then we have to understand what
the outcomes are that the business wants,

63
00:03:26.870 --> 00:03:30.720
and we have to understand what
direction the business is going in.

64
00:03:31.850 --> 00:03:34.820
So let's take a look
then at our perspective.

65
00:03:34.820 --> 00:03:40.179
What perspective is our organization going
in, and how does that translate to us?

66
00:03:41.600 --> 00:03:44.889
So we look at this from
a very high level view point.

67
00:03:44.889 --> 00:03:46.934
I hate to use the word perspective again,

68
00:03:46.934 --> 00:03:50.620
but from a very high level view point
,what is our organization doing?

69
00:03:50.620 --> 00:03:52.140
And we split this into three.

70
00:03:52.140 --> 00:03:55.821
So we split this into,
we have acronyms cuz we like acronyms.

71
00:03:55.821 --> 00:03:57.246
>> Right.
>> This is ITIL, right?

72
00:03:57.246 --> 00:04:01.320
So we have RTB, GTB, and TTB.

73
00:04:01.320 --> 00:04:03.933
RTB means simply, run the business.

74
00:04:03.933 --> 00:04:09.597
And run the business is a strategy for an
organization that is not looking to grow.

75
00:04:09.597 --> 00:04:13.341
So these are strategies that
are generally, and I say generally, but

76
00:04:13.341 --> 00:04:15.790
it really depends on the organization.

77
00:04:15.790 --> 00:04:19.240
They're generally used for
not-for-profit organizations, for

78
00:04:19.240 --> 00:04:20.530
government organizations,

79
00:04:20.530 --> 00:04:25.780
government departments as well, where
they simply just want to tread water.

80
00:04:25.780 --> 00:04:28.640
They want to just maintain the status quo.

81
00:04:28.640 --> 00:04:32.482
Now, there are other organizations
that use that strategy as well or

82
00:04:32.482 --> 00:04:35.130
that have that perspective as we'd say.

83
00:04:35.130 --> 00:04:38.955
Because some organizations might want
to take a breather before they want to

84
00:04:38.955 --> 00:04:39.740
grow anymore.

85
00:04:39.740 --> 00:04:41.510
Maybe they want to consolidate.

86
00:04:41.510 --> 00:04:45.901
Maybe they're grown very rapidly and
they just need to sit down, just maintain

87
00:04:45.901 --> 00:04:50.176
the status quo for a year or two before
they launch any further growth, okay?

88
00:04:50.176 --> 00:04:52.040
So that's run the business.

89
00:04:52.040 --> 00:04:57.172
Now that translates to
us in a way that we have

90
00:04:57.172 --> 00:05:01.902
to be able to support that perspective.

91
00:05:01.902 --> 00:05:05.160
And that perspective is just
to maintain the status quo.

92
00:05:05.160 --> 00:05:06.410
Well of course,

93
00:05:06.410 --> 00:05:09.570
you might think that that means that we
in IT then don't have to do anything.

94
00:05:09.570 --> 00:05:12.020
We just have to sit back and
maintain a stable enviroment.

95
00:05:12.020 --> 00:05:13.820
Well, that's not true.

96
00:05:13.820 --> 00:05:18.259
Cuz even an organization that just wants
to maintain the status quo has still gotta

97
00:05:18.259 --> 00:05:18.782
change.

98
00:05:18.782 --> 00:05:22.270
Windows 95 is not gonna be
supported forever, okay?

99
00:05:22.270 --> 00:05:25.190
So we still have to make changes.

100
00:05:25.190 --> 00:05:29.201
We're not trying to be innovative
in that particular environment, but

101
00:05:29.201 --> 00:05:30.920
we still have to make changes.

102
00:05:30.920 --> 00:05:34.308
And then we have the organizational
perspective of grow the business,

103
00:05:34.308 --> 00:05:35.780
which is a fairly obvious one.

104
00:05:35.780 --> 00:05:37.550
That's where our business wants to grow.

105
00:05:38.640 --> 00:05:44.290
And in that perspective then we in IT
have to support that by being innovative.

106
00:05:44.290 --> 00:05:49.360
By looking for new ways to
facilitate business outcomes and

107
00:05:49.360 --> 00:05:52.483
to facilitate change in business outcomes.

108
00:05:52.483 --> 00:05:55.530
And then we have the perspective
of transforming the business,

109
00:05:55.530 --> 00:06:01.430
which is doing something completely
different outside of our industry sector.

110
00:06:02.790 --> 00:06:06.430
I think of one particular organization
that's very, very good at transforming and

111
00:06:06.430 --> 00:06:09.450
they do it through acquisitions and
through franchises but

112
00:06:09.450 --> 00:06:12.980
nevertheless they started
off with airplanes or

113
00:06:12.980 --> 00:06:16.530
I think they may have started
off with transatlantic flights.

114
00:06:16.530 --> 00:06:20.250
Anyway, they transformed and
they produce or

115
00:06:20.250 --> 00:06:25.610
they perform finances now, and
so they have credit cards etc.

116
00:06:25.610 --> 00:06:30.070
They're a very big player
in fibre optical cables and

117
00:06:30.070 --> 00:06:35.895
fibre optic provisions, TV provision and
internet provision within the UK.

118
00:06:35.895 --> 00:06:40.635
They also perform well,
cellular services as well.

119
00:06:40.635 --> 00:06:46.252
So provide cellphones, mobile telephones
and various countries around the world.

120
00:06:46.252 --> 00:06:51.260
And every time they've grown, and I think
we're now in to space exploration as well.

121
00:06:51.260 --> 00:06:54.130
Every time they've grown
they have transformed.

122
00:06:54.130 --> 00:06:59.941
They have stepped outside of their comfort
zone and outside of their industry sector.

123
00:06:59.941 --> 00:07:04.430
Now we'll look further at that as we
move through service strategy and

124
00:07:04.430 --> 00:07:06.510
what that actually means to IT.

125
00:07:06.510 --> 00:07:11.370
But, right now that means that
we've got to be really innovative.

126
00:07:11.370 --> 00:07:14.299
We've got to not just be
reactive to the business, but

127
00:07:14.299 --> 00:07:16.855
we've got to be very proactive as well,
okay?

128
00:07:16.855 --> 00:07:20.897
Cuz we have to understand that the
business could change at any moment and

129
00:07:20.897 --> 00:07:22.230
we've got to be there.

130
00:07:22.230 --> 00:07:25.290
We've got to drive that transformation.

131
00:07:25.290 --> 00:07:27.750
So that's the perspective
of the organization.

132
00:07:27.750 --> 00:07:29.680
And that's how we have to react to it.

133
00:07:29.680 --> 00:07:31.520
But then what about the position?

134
00:07:31.520 --> 00:07:35.310
Well, the position is very simply
where are we in the world against our

135
00:07:35.310 --> 00:07:36.090
competition?

136
00:07:37.255 --> 00:07:40.855
Now if we're talking about government
environment, government department,

137
00:07:40.855 --> 00:07:44.035
then obviously where we are in
the world against that competition

138
00:07:44.035 --> 00:07:45.460
is probably not that important.

139
00:07:45.460 --> 00:07:49.735
But if you're talking about
an organization that is making a profit,

140
00:07:49.735 --> 00:07:54.597
that is looking to grow, then that
position actually could be very important.

141
00:07:54.597 --> 00:07:59.059
And so if our competitors, sorry,
are at second in the world and

142
00:07:59.059 --> 00:08:04.114
we're at number three then we probably
wanna get to number one, right?

143
00:08:04.114 --> 00:08:07.986
Which then,
these two perspective impositions,

144
00:08:07.986 --> 00:08:13.820
will drive what the plans are for
the future, for the organization.

145
00:08:13.820 --> 00:08:17.090
And therefore that has to drive our plans.

146
00:08:17.090 --> 00:08:21.740
So the organization, well that will
dictate how our four P's look.

147
00:08:22.810 --> 00:08:26.750
So the perspective and the organization.

148
00:08:26.750 --> 00:08:30.720
Well, that drives the plans,
the plans that they have for the future.

149
00:08:30.720 --> 00:08:35.350
And therefore the perspective and position
that we have within our IT service

150
00:08:35.350 --> 00:08:39.870
provider that has to drive our plans,
they have to be aligned to the business.

151
00:08:39.870 --> 00:08:43.670
And then of course it's our plans
that then drive our patterns,

152
00:08:43.670 --> 00:08:45.860
our patterns of activity.

153
00:08:45.860 --> 00:08:49.780
And we look more into those when we take
about patterns of business activity within

154
00:08:49.780 --> 00:08:51.230
demand management.

155
00:08:51.230 --> 00:08:54.180
But our patterns are actually what we do.

156
00:08:54.180 --> 00:08:59.750
And it's those patterns and we're going
to take this arrow, this arrow here from

157
00:08:59.750 --> 00:09:03.870
our patterns, and we're going to go right
the way back to the beginning as well.

158
00:09:03.870 --> 00:09:09.340
Because you see, it's our plans that drive
our patterns, the way that we behave.

159
00:09:09.340 --> 00:09:10.410
And it's our patterns,

160
00:09:10.410 --> 00:09:13.980
the way that we behave that will
actually drive our position.

161
00:09:15.160 --> 00:09:18.780
So we come right the way
back the way that we behave,

162
00:09:18.780 --> 00:09:23.360
our patterns will drive our position
in the marketplace, and that will drive

163
00:09:23.360 --> 00:09:27.699
our organization to go from number
three right the way up to number one.

164
00:09:28.940 --> 00:09:30.370
So these are our four Ps.

165
00:09:30.370 --> 00:09:34.320
And it's really important that we
understand the four Ps as the organization

166
00:09:34.320 --> 00:09:37.680
as well as how that translates to us

167
00:09:37.680 --> 00:09:41.230
within our IT service provider and
environment.

168
00:09:41.230 --> 00:09:45.170
So what do we have to do here in
service strategy that is really,

169
00:09:45.170 --> 00:09:47.480
clearly identifying those four Ps.

170
00:09:47.480 --> 00:09:52.240
And clearly identify who our customers
are, who our organization is.

171
00:09:52.240 --> 00:09:54.030
What services they want.

172
00:09:54.030 --> 00:09:58.710
Remember, service is a means
of facilitating an outcome.

173
00:09:58.710 --> 00:10:02.900
It's not actually about delivery outlook,

174
00:10:02.900 --> 00:10:08.960
it's about facilitating the outcome,
which is to send and receive email.

175
00:10:08.960 --> 00:10:13.570
So here in service strategy, we've got
to understand what services we have.

176
00:10:13.570 --> 00:10:19.620
What new services would fit into that
environment to help us with those four Ps.

177
00:10:19.620 --> 00:10:23.220
We have to understand what value
means to the organization.

178
00:10:23.220 --> 00:10:25.970
And we have to also understand a very,

179
00:10:25.970 --> 00:10:29.950
very clear provisioning
model as it says there.

180
00:10:29.950 --> 00:10:33.290
What that means is how our services
hang together and how we provide them.

181
00:10:34.350 --> 00:10:37.640
We have shared components to our services.

182
00:10:37.640 --> 00:10:43.580
And we'll look at that in a lot more depth
later, but you don't have one network for

183
00:10:43.580 --> 00:10:48.420
email, and another network for office,
and another network for your Internet.

184
00:10:48.420 --> 00:10:49.430
You have one network.

185
00:10:50.930 --> 00:10:55.067
So if we take a look at our
triangles as we have them here,

186
00:10:55.067 --> 00:10:59.890
on the left-hand side we have
the organization and the organization,

187
00:10:59.890 --> 00:11:04.320
well the CEO will tend to
feed down into the customers.

188
00:11:04.320 --> 00:11:07.620
Now a customer is a stakeholder and

189
00:11:07.620 --> 00:11:12.950
a customer is somebody who has influence
over whether the money is spent.

190
00:11:12.950 --> 00:11:18.190
And in IT terms,
a customer can be external but

191
00:11:18.190 --> 00:11:21.160
let's just look at this from
an internal perspective right now.

192
00:11:21.160 --> 00:11:24.910
It's generally a business unit manager or
a cross center manager,

193
00:11:24.910 --> 00:11:29.970
somebody who can influence
whether IT budget is given to us.

194
00:11:29.970 --> 00:11:31.770
And then we have users.

195
00:11:31.770 --> 00:11:34.820
And users are people
that use the services.

196
00:11:34.820 --> 00:11:38.920
Now the CEO,
treats everybody exactly the same.

197
00:11:38.920 --> 00:11:41.060
So in terms of IT,

198
00:11:41.060 --> 00:11:45.660
well we're just another business unit,
if we're an internal service provider.

199
00:11:45.660 --> 00:11:48.800
So the CEO will not differentiate and

200
00:11:48.800 --> 00:11:53.170
will not tell us exactly
what our strategy should be.

201
00:11:53.170 --> 00:11:57.550
It's up to us within IT
to understand how our

202
00:11:57.550 --> 00:12:01.860
strategy fits in and
helps us achieve the business strategy.

203
00:12:01.860 --> 00:12:04.770
So the CEO is concerned
with the customers and

204
00:12:04.770 --> 00:12:08.670
the users within
the organization as a whole.

205
00:12:08.670 --> 00:12:11.970
Where as the CIO,
the Chief Information Officer,

206
00:12:11.970 --> 00:12:17.470
well, he is concerned with IT.,
with us as a service provider.

207
00:12:17.470 --> 00:12:22.590
So at the tactical level, he has
the service managers, the service owners,

208
00:12:22.590 --> 00:12:25.940
those people who take responsibility for
the services.

209
00:12:25.940 --> 00:12:28.980
And also our process owners
will sit at this level as well.

210
00:12:30.150 --> 00:12:33.330
And underneath we have our
operational staff and so

211
00:12:33.330 --> 00:12:36.900
we've got a service desk
there as an example.

212
00:12:36.900 --> 00:12:41.660
Now the arrow on the left hand side
talks about the volume of communication.

213
00:12:41.660 --> 00:12:46.240
What that really means is that I
don't expect somebody at CEO or

214
00:12:46.240 --> 00:12:51.670
CIO level, to be talking directly
to somebody at the end user level,

215
00:12:51.670 --> 00:12:54.700
or to somebody at the analyst level.

216
00:12:54.700 --> 00:12:58.120
Because, they're gonna be communicating
something completely different.

217
00:12:58.120 --> 00:12:59.360
So we've got to be very careful.

218
00:12:59.360 --> 00:13:05.630
We'll talk about communication a lot later
on in future episodes in service strategy,

219
00:13:05.630 --> 00:13:08.830
but I don't expect that that the CIO and

220
00:13:08.830 --> 00:13:15.130
the CEO are going to communicate
at an operational level.

221
00:13:15.130 --> 00:13:19.230
So we have to understand
where our relationships lie,

222
00:13:19.230 --> 00:13:21.640
and who we have a relationship with.

223
00:13:21.640 --> 00:13:25.160
And our analysts will have
a relationship with the end users, but

224
00:13:25.160 --> 00:13:28.800
our process managers, such as our
business relationship managers,

225
00:13:28.800 --> 00:13:32.190
while they will have
a relationship with the customers.

226
00:13:32.190 --> 00:13:33.810
The people who have the purse strings.

227
00:13:35.730 --> 00:13:37.810
So what does service strategy do?

228
00:13:37.810 --> 00:13:42.110
Well, service strategy as I've said,
this is where the magic starts.

229
00:13:42.110 --> 00:13:45.210
This is where we decide on our direction.

230
00:13:45.210 --> 00:13:48.660
Our direction in terms of how
we're going to be governed and

231
00:13:48.660 --> 00:13:50.440
what services we're going to provide.

232
00:13:51.550 --> 00:13:54.460
And whether we're an internal or
an external service provider,

233
00:13:54.460 --> 00:13:58.180
and I've already mentioned the word
internal, just on the last slide,

234
00:13:58.180 --> 00:14:01.110
well of course we covered
that during foundation.

235
00:14:01.110 --> 00:14:04.060
But doesn't matter what type
of service provider we are,

236
00:14:04.060 --> 00:14:06.010
we still have to know our direction.

237
00:14:06.010 --> 00:14:09.550
We still have to understand
who our customer is and

238
00:14:09.550 --> 00:14:13.560
show that we are aligned
to their direction.

239
00:14:13.560 --> 00:14:19.380
And so what we also do is well we provide
guidance for those that are well,

240
00:14:19.380 --> 00:14:23.510
as it says in profit seeking
service provision and for

241
00:14:23.510 --> 00:14:26.010
those that aren't in profit seeking.

242
00:14:26.010 --> 00:14:31.698
In other words what that
really means is that we do

243
00:14:31.698 --> 00:14:36.260
not look to make a profit
ourselves within IT.

244
00:14:36.260 --> 00:14:40.730
What we do is seek to be
aligned to the organization.

245
00:14:40.730 --> 00:14:43.500
And it doesn't matter whether
the organization is what we call

246
00:14:43.500 --> 00:14:47.990
a not-for-profit so a government
organization, or maybe a charity.

247
00:14:47.990 --> 00:14:52.110
Or whether our organization is
a profit generating organization that

248
00:14:52.110 --> 00:14:54.300
may be seeking to grow.

249
00:14:54.300 --> 00:15:00.190
Well, we will support, we will be aligned
to the needs of the organization.

250
00:15:00.190 --> 00:15:02.940
So what about our aspect
of service strategy?

251
00:15:02.940 --> 00:15:04.484
Well, I've already covered them, okay?

252
00:15:04.484 --> 00:15:08.743
This is about defining what services
we are going to provide to meet

253
00:15:08.743 --> 00:15:10.880
the organizations objectives.

254
00:15:10.880 --> 00:15:12.188
That is number one.

255
00:15:12.188 --> 00:15:17.570
And number two is all about, well,
how we're going to deliver those services?

256
00:15:17.570 --> 00:15:20.521
So how we're gonna govern ourselves?

257
00:15:20.521 --> 00:15:25.850
How we are going to direct and
control and manage our IT services.

258
00:15:27.720 --> 00:15:32.516
So the value to the business then of
service strategy should be fairly

259
00:15:32.516 --> 00:15:36.250
self-explanatory, given what I've said,
okay.

260
00:15:36.250 --> 00:15:40.050
What we want to do is to ensure
that all of our services and

261
00:15:40.050 --> 00:15:46.180
all of our activities have a direct
connection to the organization.

262
00:15:46.180 --> 00:15:52.444
In other words we understand exactly what
value we're providing to the business.

263
00:15:52.444 --> 00:15:57.317
There's something in the ITIL
publications, in the ITIL books,

264
00:15:57.317 --> 00:16:02.625
that talks about everybody understanding
exactly what their role is and

265
00:16:02.625 --> 00:16:07.759
everyone within the IT service
provider understanding how their role

266
00:16:07.759 --> 00:16:13.000
contributes To the ability of
the business to achieve their outcomes.

267
00:16:14.240 --> 00:16:16.750
Now, that's quite a challenge in one.

268
00:16:16.750 --> 00:16:21.330
And I'm gonna ask you,
Ronnie, how often do

269
00:16:21.330 --> 00:16:26.270
you think it is that I could go into an
organization and I can say to an analyst,

270
00:16:26.270 --> 00:16:30.540
hey, do you know exactly what you
do in relation to the organization?

271
00:16:30.540 --> 00:16:33.349
What do you think they say to me?

272
00:16:33.349 --> 00:16:37.008
>> I would assume that they would think
that they would but they overall, once you

273
00:16:37.008 --> 00:16:40.502
actually ask them and they answer,
they probably know what their job is but

274
00:16:40.502 --> 00:16:44.600
they don't know what its relationship
to the entire organization is.

275
00:16:44.600 --> 00:16:50.050
>> You're right and this is something
that we do have to get better at,

276
00:16:50.050 --> 00:16:52.360
within IT as a whole.

277
00:16:52.360 --> 00:16:58.310
Because we do tend to be very
explicit in job descriptions and

278
00:16:58.310 --> 00:17:04.250
in roles and responsibilities,
and we do allow people to

279
00:17:04.250 --> 00:17:09.190
contribute to their own job descriptions,
and their own roles and responsibilities.

280
00:17:09.190 --> 00:17:13.169
But how often do we actually
put that in the context

281
00:17:13.169 --> 00:17:16.211
of what it means to the organization?

282
00:17:16.211 --> 00:17:22.268
I wonder and I sometimes ask, if I'm in
an organization advising on ISO 2000 and

283
00:17:22.268 --> 00:17:26.192
we're preparing for an audit and
I will say to people,

284
00:17:26.192 --> 00:17:29.980
do you know what your role
is in the organization?

285
00:17:29.980 --> 00:17:35.685
If you weren't here tomorrow,
what impact would it have to the business?

286
00:17:35.685 --> 00:17:38.320
Now, what impact would it have
to the rest of your team,

287
00:17:38.320 --> 00:17:41.350
what impact would it have to the business?

288
00:17:41.350 --> 00:17:45.199
And you'd be surprised how many people
are not able to answer that question.

289
00:17:46.350 --> 00:17:50.340
And one of the things that we say in
I2 is that we should all be aware

290
00:17:50.340 --> 00:17:53.840
of how our role contributes
to the organization and

291
00:17:53.840 --> 00:17:58.720
how our role contributes to
facilitating those outcomes.

292
00:17:58.720 --> 00:18:01.890
If we feel valuable,
we're going to contribute more.

293
00:18:01.890 --> 00:18:06.170
If we don't feel valuable,
then sometimes it can be difficult for

294
00:18:06.170 --> 00:18:08.120
us to maintain morale.

295
00:18:08.120 --> 00:18:10.830
So this is why we'll say,
we need to understand,

296
00:18:10.830 --> 00:18:13.010
we're about delivering
value to the business.

297
00:18:13.010 --> 00:18:14.710
So we need to know what
the business values, and

298
00:18:14.710 --> 00:18:17.660
we need to know that we
are making a difference.

299
00:18:17.660 --> 00:18:20.480
And, exactly as it says in
that second bullet point,

300
00:18:20.480 --> 00:18:24.710
it is that understanding within
us as a service provider,

301
00:18:24.710 --> 00:18:28.030
of exactly what makes our
organization successful.

302
00:18:29.640 --> 00:18:31.680
We have to know our organization.

303
00:18:31.680 --> 00:18:36.580
And when we talk about responding quickly
to their changing needs, wouldn't it be

304
00:18:36.580 --> 00:18:41.490
absolutely perfect if actually we knew
what their needs were before they changed?

305
00:18:41.490 --> 00:18:47.990
Or even if we were to drive that change,
because we had prepared for this.

306
00:18:47.990 --> 00:18:49.650
We were proactive and

307
00:18:49.650 --> 00:18:52.020
we actually understood what
they needed before they did.

308
00:18:53.520 --> 00:18:55.928
That's really where we'd
like to get as an ideal.

309
00:18:55.928 --> 00:19:00.451
And we'll talk a little bit more about
proactive versus reactive relationship

310
00:19:00.451 --> 00:19:01.270
management.

311
00:19:02.300 --> 00:19:06.540
But what we want to do is service
strategy, and what we have to do in order

312
00:19:06.540 --> 00:19:12.790
to be a aligned to the organization is
to keep that communication line open.

313
00:19:12.790 --> 00:19:17.500
>> Now, Jo, before we move on, on this
point that you were making about ensuring

314
00:19:17.500 --> 00:19:22.920
that everybody actually understood what
their role was in your experience.

315
00:19:22.920 --> 00:19:25.950
I know that this is kinda a little
bit outside of the realm of ITIL.

316
00:19:25.950 --> 00:19:30.870
But is there something that you've seen
in which a company is very easily been

317
00:19:30.870 --> 00:19:34.940
able to take the person that really didn't
know and next time you came back, or

318
00:19:34.940 --> 00:19:38.260
just a few months later, you came back and
the person knew exactly what his role was?

319
00:19:39.270 --> 00:19:44.140
>> So is there a magical formula to this?

320
00:19:44.140 --> 00:19:44.951
No.

321
00:19:44.951 --> 00:19:47.825
>> Right.
>> There's definitely not.

322
00:19:47.825 --> 00:19:52.170
There's a TV program that's out
in TV around the world actually,

323
00:19:52.170 --> 00:19:57.230
it's not just in the US, it's in the UK
and in other countries, as well.

324
00:19:57.230 --> 00:19:59.870
Where we see somebody
from a board of directors

325
00:19:59.870 --> 00:20:03.210
who has pretty much lost touch with
the way that the organization works.

326
00:20:03.210 --> 00:20:10.140
And they go and they spend some
time working with employees.

327
00:20:10.140 --> 00:20:11.656
>> Right.

328
00:20:11.656 --> 00:20:15.700
>> And that's something that is a really,
really, really good technique.

329
00:20:15.700 --> 00:20:17.285
Now, I'm not saying
that you go undercover.

330
00:20:17.285 --> 00:20:21.370
[LAUGH] I'm not saying that, that should
happen but one of the first question that

331
00:20:21.370 --> 00:20:25.590
I would ask if I'm doing some sort of
preparation for an audit, I will ask

332
00:20:25.590 --> 00:20:29.490
people what do they know what that role
is, what do they know how it contributes.

333
00:20:29.490 --> 00:20:33.250
And I'll actually ask them whether they've
spent any time with their end users and

334
00:20:33.250 --> 00:20:34.780
with their customers.

335
00:20:34.780 --> 00:20:39.640
And it doesn't surprise me at all when I
hear that, well, no, I've never done that.

336
00:20:39.640 --> 00:20:41.630
>> Right.
>> Or it's been quite a while since

337
00:20:41.630 --> 00:20:42.540
I've done that.

338
00:20:42.540 --> 00:20:45.490
You only understand how your role
contributes if you understand what

339
00:20:45.490 --> 00:20:46.350
they do.

340
00:20:46.350 --> 00:20:48.630
And we always advocate going and

341
00:20:48.630 --> 00:20:52.710
spending time with your users
understanding how they work.

342
00:20:52.710 --> 00:20:53.470
>> Okay.

343
00:20:53.470 --> 00:20:55.430
>> Now,
this is not about doing their job for

344
00:20:55.430 --> 00:20:59.998
them but it's understanding how
you can help them do their job.

345
00:20:59.998 --> 00:21:01.620
We're supposed to deliver value and

346
00:21:01.620 --> 00:21:06.320
we want to deliver value in a way
that can facilitate their outcomes.

347
00:21:06.320 --> 00:21:09.270
But if you don't know how they achieve
their outcomes then how can you

348
00:21:09.270 --> 00:21:10.510
facilitate them?

349
00:21:10.510 --> 00:21:16.130
So whilst there's no magic pill
that can fix absolutely everything,

350
00:21:16.130 --> 00:21:19.320
the first step I would always
encourage everybody to do is to

351
00:21:19.320 --> 00:21:22.620
get off their bums and go and
see what's really going on.

352
00:21:22.620 --> 00:21:26.335
Now, that does involve having
senior management commitment.

353
00:21:26.335 --> 00:21:26.865
>> Right.

354
00:21:26.865 --> 00:21:30.355
>> Because that involves having
people out of their seats, and

355
00:21:30.355 --> 00:21:32.635
going and seeing what's happening.

356
00:21:32.635 --> 00:21:36.745
And, of course, if you're not around for
a day because you're going to spend

357
00:21:36.745 --> 00:21:40.910
time on a customer site, then someone's
gonna have to cover your old for that day.

358
00:21:40.910 --> 00:21:43.540
So we have to have the senior
management commitment.

359
00:21:43.540 --> 00:21:47.280
But with the right commitment,
it helps us in so many ways.

360
00:21:47.280 --> 00:21:49.650
And it's not just understanding
how you contribute but

361
00:21:49.650 --> 00:21:51.860
it's also building up a relationship.

362
00:21:51.860 --> 00:21:55.230
>> Right.
>> I'm going back to that slide there.

363
00:21:55.230 --> 00:21:58.523
Look at the bottom bullet point there
about opening up solid lines of

364
00:21:58.523 --> 00:21:59.870
communication.

365
00:21:59.870 --> 00:22:04.330
If you've got an interpersonal
relationship with people within IT and

366
00:22:04.330 --> 00:22:09.080
the business, then you'll find
that actually it works wonders for

367
00:22:09.080 --> 00:22:10.340
the value perception.

368
00:22:10.340 --> 00:22:13.440
And we'll talk a lot more about
value perception a little bit later.

369
00:22:14.990 --> 00:22:20.800
So let's just move on, if I may, if that's
okay, with the other life cycle phases.

370
00:22:20.800 --> 00:22:24.590
Now, everybody's covered the other
life cycle phases and foundation.

371
00:22:24.590 --> 00:22:27.120
But let's just look at what
service strategy does for

372
00:22:27.120 --> 00:22:28.549
the other life cycle phases.

373
00:22:29.620 --> 00:22:33.050
We already know that service strategy
is where we come up with the ideas for

374
00:22:33.050 --> 00:22:34.240
new services.

375
00:22:34.240 --> 00:22:35.990
Well, it's not where we come up with them,

376
00:22:35.990 --> 00:22:38.840
because CSI has some input into that,
as well.

377
00:22:38.840 --> 00:22:41.620
Continual service improvement,
as does anybody.

378
00:22:41.620 --> 00:22:46.200
But service strategy is
where we store these ideas,

379
00:22:46.200 --> 00:22:48.150
where we evaluate these ideas.

380
00:22:48.150 --> 00:22:51.770
But service strategy also
provides the direction for

381
00:22:51.770 --> 00:22:53.310
all there are the life cycle phases.

382
00:22:54.340 --> 00:22:58.120
So service strategy to service design,
well,

383
00:22:58.120 --> 00:23:02.970
not only provides the business context and
the business objectives but

384
00:23:02.970 --> 00:23:08.590
also provides them with the new services,
with the approved business cases.

385
00:23:08.590 --> 00:23:12.511
And it provides service
design with guidance and

386
00:23:12.511 --> 00:23:17.206
with policies, but
within which we should be operating.

387
00:23:17.206 --> 00:23:20.100
With service transition, again,
we're providing those policies.

388
00:23:21.180 --> 00:23:26.812
And we are providing guidance on how
to transition from service design,

389
00:23:26.812 --> 00:23:31.891
from that design stage right away
through into the development,

390
00:23:31.891 --> 00:23:35.492
the build, the test,
the implementation and

391
00:23:35.492 --> 00:23:40.232
the eventual early life support
into service operation,.

392
00:23:40.232 --> 00:23:43.153
And then, of course,
with service operation, well,

393
00:23:43.153 --> 00:23:47.130
service strategy provides the policies for
how are we going to operate, for

394
00:23:47.130 --> 00:23:49.760
how we're going to manage
our business as usual.

395
00:23:50.760 --> 00:23:55.870
We also provide here in service
strategy that articulation of value.

396
00:23:55.870 --> 00:23:59.160
What value really means
because service operation,

397
00:23:59.160 --> 00:24:01.910
well, they need to be able
to deliver that value.

398
00:24:03.130 --> 00:24:04.254
And then, CSI.

399
00:24:04.254 --> 00:24:09.870
Well, CSI is the life cycle phase that has
its tendrils into absolutely everything.

400
00:24:09.870 --> 00:24:13.150
So CSI is always looking for
opportunities for

401
00:24:13.150 --> 00:24:17.400
improvement and service strategy
tells CSI how we work right now.

402
00:24:17.400 --> 00:24:20.576
This is how we govern right
at this moment in time.

403
00:24:20.576 --> 00:24:24.340
And CSI will be continually
checking that we are aligned

404
00:24:24.340 --> 00:24:26.510
with the needs of the business.

405
00:24:26.510 --> 00:24:30.030
And we'll be making recommendations
to service strategy.

406
00:24:30.030 --> 00:24:34.160
A service strategy, in turn,
tells us where the business is going,

407
00:24:34.160 --> 00:24:37.340
in what direction
the business is going in.

408
00:24:37.340 --> 00:24:40.250
So that's sort of
a strategy in a nutshell.

409
00:24:40.250 --> 00:24:42.830
This is why we need service strategy.

410
00:24:42.830 --> 00:24:47.050
Without service strategy having
the synergy between IT and

411
00:24:47.050 --> 00:24:49.640
the business can be very, very difficult.

412
00:24:49.640 --> 00:24:53.760
And we have to first and foremost
understand what direction our business

413
00:24:53.760 --> 00:24:57.970
is going in,
because that directs us within IT.

414
00:24:59.280 --> 00:25:00.050
>> All right, Jo.

415
00:25:00.050 --> 00:25:04.350
Well, thank you again for helping
us to at least understand the value

416
00:25:04.350 --> 00:25:09.620
that we can find in service strategy to
help us to get started in these different

417
00:25:09.620 --> 00:25:13.040
parts of ITIL that we need for
our organizations, as well.

418
00:25:13.040 --> 00:25:15.126
Remember, this is really
kinda the starting point.

419
00:25:15.126 --> 00:25:20.323
It's what Jo said that, this is really
kind of the key that begins everything.

420
00:25:20.323 --> 00:25:24.770
All right, this is a great place for
us to also end this episode.

421
00:25:24.770 --> 00:25:27.950
For ITProTv, I've been your host,
Ronnie Wong,

422
00:25:27.950 --> 00:25:29.120
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

423
00:25:29.120 --> 00:25:33.349
>> Stay tuned right here for more ITIL
intermediate service strategy shows.

424
00:25:33.349 --> 00:25:39.284
[MUSIC]

425
00:25:39.284 --> 00:25:42.506
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo discuss a basic service strategy approach.  Jo mentions that we must think about the competition against us as part of the strategy we take as well as opposing dynamics.  These opposing dynamics need to be balanced for a strategy to be effective, says Jo.  She also helps us by describing a service in the context of strategy too.

And here to help us, of course, is gonna

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo discuss value creation in service strategy.  Jo reminds us that value is perceived and that strategy is helping us to create the value that we want realized.  We do this by understanding that value changes over time, it is measured against our competitors and against the uniqueness that we provide as a service, says Jo.  She also reminds us that its not so much that spending helps us to create value as much as it is the customers perception on whether we fulfilled the customers expectation.

By looking at some of the simple
things such as our competitors and

476
00:28:50.820 --> 00:28:51.640
where they are.

477
00:28:51.640 --> 00:28:54.570
As well as the uniqueness
that we've offered and

478
00:28:54.570 --> 00:28:58.100
even over time what our particular
service provides as well.

479
00:28:58.100 --> 00:28:59.810
So there are many things for
us to consider,

480
00:28:59.810 --> 00:29:02.630
and Jo has helped us to understand
all those different things to.

481
00:29:02.630 --> 00:29:07.298
And that's a great place for
us to take a break at this point.

482
00:29:07.298 --> 00:29:11.295
So signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

483
00:29:11.295 --> 00:29:12.295
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

484
00:29:12.295 --> 00:29:17.002
>> Stay tuned right here for more ITIL
intermediate service strategy shows.

485
00:29:17.002 --> 00:29:22.965
[MUSIC]

486
00:29:22.965 --> 00:29:26.262
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo look into the utility and warranty.  Jo reminds us that value is not perceived without both utility and warranty being present.  She reminds us that service performs well at a high value when we can operate within the warranty which includes the assurances of availability, capacity, reliability, continuity and security.
episodes.title: Service Strategy Principles - Utility and Warranty
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:03.492
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.492 --> 00:00:05.817
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:05.817 --> 00:00:08.324
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.324 --> 00:00:11.993
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.993 --> 00:00:15.100
>> Welcome back to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.100 --> 00:00:19.570
You're watching the ITIL
Intermediate Service Strategy show.

7
00:00:19.570 --> 00:00:21.270
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and

8
00:00:21.270 --> 00:00:26.050
today we're gonna be taking
a look at utility and warranty.

9
00:00:26.050 --> 00:00:31.330
And here to help us out of course is gonna
be our ITIL top dog herself, Jo Peacock.

10
00:00:31.330 --> 00:00:32.310
Jo, welcome back to the show.

11
00:00:32.310 --> 00:00:34.520
>> Thanks for having me Ronnie.

12
00:00:34.520 --> 00:00:35.710
>> All right Jo.

13
00:00:35.710 --> 00:00:39.990
We're taking a look of course at
different service strategy principles.

14
00:00:39.990 --> 00:00:44.375
We're now come to this part on utility and
warranty.

15
00:00:44.375 --> 00:00:46.730
Jo, they sound the same.

16
00:00:46.730 --> 00:00:48.140
So, help us out here.

17
00:00:48.140 --> 00:00:51.190
>> Well we're going to continue
our theme from our last episode,

18
00:00:51.190 --> 00:00:52.880
where we started looking at warranty.

19
00:00:52.880 --> 00:00:55.510
And we looked at warranty
as being perceived.

20
00:00:55.510 --> 00:00:58.720
But now I want us to actually,
so we looked at value.

21
00:00:58.720 --> 00:01:00.770
>> Value.
>> Value as being perceived.

22
00:01:00.770 --> 00:01:04.150
And now I want to take value and
I actually want to break it down and

23
00:01:04.150 --> 00:01:06.390
look at what value really means.

24
00:01:06.390 --> 00:01:08.040
Now we know that value is perceived.

25
00:01:08.040 --> 00:01:12.040
And in our last episode we took
a look at different cars and

26
00:01:12.040 --> 00:01:15.520
what type of car we would want
based on our preferences.

27
00:01:15.520 --> 00:01:21.060
And yet the fact that we could change
our perception, in this case based on

28
00:01:21.060 --> 00:01:24.980
cost and actual physical outlay to you.

29
00:01:26.310 --> 00:01:32.010
But that still doesn't mean that that car
can sacrifice on meeting the outcome.

30
00:01:32.010 --> 00:01:34.170
We have to be able to meet the outcome.

31
00:01:34.170 --> 00:01:37.070
And, of course, the outcome for
the car was getting from A to B.

32
00:01:38.220 --> 00:01:43.280
Well, utility and warranty really
takes a look at that outcome

33
00:01:43.280 --> 00:01:47.830
in a little bit more depth as well as
looking at the whole concept of value.

34
00:01:48.920 --> 00:01:55.110
Because value is split into two,
it's split into both utility and warranty.

35
00:01:55.110 --> 00:01:59.370
And both must be present in order for
value to be perceived.

36
00:02:00.530 --> 00:02:01.700
So what does that mean?

37
00:02:01.700 --> 00:02:02.800
And I mean, these terms.

38
00:02:02.800 --> 00:02:07.340
You might think to yourself, you know,
warranties about the guarantee, isn't it?

39
00:02:07.340 --> 00:02:10.610
It's something that you get
when you buy a brand new TV.

40
00:02:10.610 --> 00:02:12.000
Well, no it's not.

41
00:02:13.430 --> 00:02:15.280
There is no guarantee, all right?

42
00:02:15.280 --> 00:02:17.680
We're in IT, okay,
we can't guarantee anything.

43
00:02:17.680 --> 00:02:19.750
And that's the first thing
that we've gotta remember.

44
00:02:19.750 --> 00:02:26.040
We like to ensure and we like to assure,
but we certainly don't guarantee anything.

45
00:02:26.040 --> 00:02:29.740
And the diagram that is shown on the
bottom of the screen is one that you've

46
00:02:29.740 --> 00:02:30.850
seen before.

47
00:02:30.850 --> 00:02:34.400
This is one that you saw in
your foundation material.

48
00:02:34.400 --> 00:02:38.770
And it really just looks at
the fact that both utility and,

49
00:02:38.770 --> 00:02:42.520
there's an and here,
right here utility and

50
00:02:42.520 --> 00:02:47.040
warranty have to be present in order for
value to be perceived.

51
00:02:48.620 --> 00:02:50.530
So what do we mean by utility?

52
00:02:50.530 --> 00:02:54.440
Well utility means fit for purpose And
warranty means fit for use.

53
00:02:55.680 --> 00:02:57.220
Okay, is that any clearer to you?

54
00:02:58.480 --> 00:03:00.055
>> Hm, a little bit more.

55
00:03:00.055 --> 00:03:00.750
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

56
00:03:02.030 --> 00:03:05.770
>> So what we mean by fit for purpose is,
does it do what it's supposed to do?

57
00:03:05.770 --> 00:03:07.860
Does it do what it says on the can?

58
00:03:07.860 --> 00:03:09.310
Does it do what is says on the team?

59
00:03:10.380 --> 00:03:16.880
And warranty means can I be
assured of certain levels?

60
00:03:16.880 --> 00:03:19.735
Let's expand this and
I'm gonna to a comparison.

61
00:03:19.735 --> 00:03:25.545
Okay,and if I take, let's say my
outcome that I want to facilitate

62
00:03:25.545 --> 00:03:29.485
is the ability to send and receive email
and it's an outcome that I'll use as

63
00:03:29.485 --> 00:03:34.315
an example throughout service strategy as
we go into all of our different episodes.

64
00:03:34.315 --> 00:03:37.800
Let's say I want to send and
receive email.

65
00:03:37.800 --> 00:03:41.470
Well the first thing I need to do is have
the ability to send and receive email.

66
00:03:41.470 --> 00:03:46.320
So I need to have performance supported
and I need to have my constraints removed.

67
00:03:46.320 --> 00:03:48.430
So I need to be able to access it.

68
00:03:48.430 --> 00:03:50.430
So let's take a look at Gmail.

69
00:03:50.430 --> 00:03:52.980
Gmail, for instance,
provides us with the utility.

70
00:03:54.340 --> 00:03:55.730
It gives us that performance.

71
00:03:55.730 --> 00:03:57.500
So it supports the performance.

72
00:03:57.500 --> 00:04:00.020
It allows us to send and receive email.

73
00:04:00.020 --> 00:04:02.640
And it does it in a way where
my constraints are removed.

74
00:04:02.640 --> 00:04:03.640
I have my password.

75
00:04:03.640 --> 00:04:07.000
And I can log in, and
my constraints are removed.

76
00:04:07.000 --> 00:04:10.210
Now do I perceive value in Gmail?

77
00:04:10.210 --> 00:04:14.792
Well, you can say well it depends on
what it is you're looking for and that's

78
00:04:14.792 --> 00:04:19.744
exactly right, because as my free email
service, then yes I perceive value in it.

79
00:04:19.744 --> 00:04:25.188
But that's because I'm not expecting
certain levels of availability,

80
00:04:25.188 --> 00:04:28.701
capacity, security and service continuity,

81
00:04:28.701 --> 00:04:34.160
which of course if you see they are the
four levels that we see in warranty.

82
00:04:35.260 --> 00:04:39.340
So the four levels that we see in
warranty are the availability, capacity,

83
00:04:39.340 --> 00:04:40.890
continuity, and security.

84
00:04:40.890 --> 00:04:45.230
Now you'll notice, if you remember from
your foundation that we have processes

85
00:04:45.230 --> 00:04:47.990
that look at each of those four elements.

86
00:04:47.990 --> 00:04:52.350
Gmail's not going to assure me
of a level of availability.

87
00:04:52.350 --> 00:04:56.520
So if Gmail's not available
when I log into my Gmail,

88
00:04:56.520 --> 00:04:59.870
if the server happens to be unavailable,
well,

89
00:04:59.870 --> 00:05:04.760
then I don't perceive value in it anymore,
because it's not there when I want it.

90
00:05:04.760 --> 00:05:10.550
If it doesn't have enough capacity,
if I have tried to send an attachment and

91
00:05:10.550 --> 00:05:14.090
that attachment is too big,
if it doesn't have enough capacity.

92
00:05:14.090 --> 00:05:20.070
If it doesn't allow me to store as many
emails then am I going to perceive value?

93
00:05:20.070 --> 00:05:24.510
What about continuity and
what about things like security?

94
00:05:24.510 --> 00:05:28.750
Can I be assured of a certain
level of security on Gmail?

95
00:05:28.750 --> 00:05:32.620
Well let's face it,
I use my password and that's it.

96
00:05:32.620 --> 00:05:35.720
That's the level of security
that exists on there.

97
00:05:35.720 --> 00:05:39.460
And sure we've got basic sort
of spam filters etc, but

98
00:05:39.460 --> 00:05:42.280
that's the level of security that exists.

99
00:05:42.280 --> 00:05:44.050
Now do I perceive value in that?

100
00:05:44.050 --> 00:05:49.080
Well, from a personal perspective, yes I

101
00:05:49.080 --> 00:05:53.880
do because I understand the levels
of warranty that I'm going to get.

102
00:05:55.080 --> 00:06:00.630
So even though the levels of warranty
aren't particularly high for

103
00:06:00.630 --> 00:06:03.060
instance, because then, you see,

104
00:06:03.060 --> 00:06:08.740
don't forget we've got this balance
of outcomes versus perceptions versus

105
00:06:08.740 --> 00:06:13.590
the perspective here,
the perceived and the, my preferences.

106
00:06:13.590 --> 00:06:18.270
Well, my preferences are in this
instance that because it's free I don't

107
00:06:18.270 --> 00:06:22.450
really need to have those
increased levels of warranty.

108
00:06:22.450 --> 00:06:27.570
The increased levels of availability and
capacity and security and continuity.

109
00:06:27.570 --> 00:06:33.330
I understand that anything that I got on
Gmail, I could lose at any moment in time,

110
00:06:33.330 --> 00:06:37.080
because I don't know what
that level of continuity is.

111
00:06:38.230 --> 00:06:42.050
So then, let's take a look at then
what we do then with an organization

112
00:06:42.050 --> 00:06:46.450
because this is on care on a personal
level but with an organization,

113
00:06:46.450 --> 00:06:50.680
Gmail will still provide with
the warranty, but will an organization

114
00:06:50.680 --> 00:06:55.820
perceive value in a free
web mail based service?

115
00:06:55.820 --> 00:06:56.590
Probably not.

116
00:06:57.820 --> 00:07:02.690
Because we don't have the assured levels
of availability, capacity, continuity, and

117
00:07:02.690 --> 00:07:03.380
security.

118
00:07:04.720 --> 00:07:08.940
So with an organization,
an organization is more likely to look for

119
00:07:08.940 --> 00:07:15.840
an email service that is either in house
or is managed as a service in itself.

120
00:07:17.380 --> 00:07:21.130
And so an organization will
want to pay for that service.

121
00:07:21.130 --> 00:07:24.850
And they will pay to have
increased levels of warranty.

122
00:07:26.000 --> 00:07:31.060
So it's not just enough for
a service to do what it says on the team.

123
00:07:32.360 --> 00:07:37.510
It has to have an assured level
of availability, continuity,

124
00:07:37.510 --> 00:07:41.650
capacity and security in order for
us to perceive value.

125
00:07:43.270 --> 00:07:47.615
We don't perceive value
where there is only utility.

126
00:07:47.615 --> 00:07:52.525
And we certainly wouldn't perceive value
if we had assured levels of security, but

127
00:07:52.525 --> 00:07:57.506
it wasn't actually very reliable, in other
words, they weren't assured levels of

128
00:07:57.506 --> 00:08:02.277
availability or if we had an assured level
of continuity But it didn't actually do

129
00:08:02.277 --> 00:08:05.941
what it was supposed to do and
when we pressed Send on the email,

130
00:08:05.941 --> 00:08:09.570
we were never completely convinced
that it sent all the time.

131
00:08:11.020 --> 00:08:15.810
So, a service has to be both fit for
purpose, it has to have utility and

132
00:08:15.810 --> 00:08:20.570
it has to be fit for use,
in order for us to perceive value.

133
00:08:20.570 --> 00:08:23.840
So let's look at this effect
of improved warranty.

134
00:08:23.840 --> 00:08:30.000
And really, what we're saying here is
that if we look at the green, okay?

135
00:08:30.000 --> 00:08:37.070
The green is where we don't have
any assured levels of warranty.

136
00:08:37.070 --> 00:08:40.750
If we don't have an assured
level of warranty then,

137
00:08:40.750 --> 00:08:43.420
well we don't have optimum performance.

138
00:08:43.420 --> 00:08:48.100
What we want to do is we
want to reduce deviation.

139
00:08:48.100 --> 00:08:50.700
So we want to actually get a peek here.

140
00:08:50.700 --> 00:08:52.870
We want to have that warranty.

141
00:08:52.870 --> 00:08:58.510
We want to perform, most of the time,
within the performance threshold.

142
00:08:58.510 --> 00:09:01.730
And not outside of these
performance thresholds.

143
00:09:03.240 --> 00:09:07.600
If we don't have warranty,
if we just focus purely on utility,

144
00:09:07.600 --> 00:09:09.580
then there's a deviation there.

145
00:09:10.660 --> 00:09:16.280
We cannot assure ourselves that we'll
always going to be able to perform.

146
00:09:16.280 --> 00:09:19.970
Don't forget utility is about
the ability to send and receive email.

147
00:09:19.970 --> 00:09:23.150
But if we're not assured that it's
gonna be available when we need it

148
00:09:23.150 --> 00:09:28.240
then performance then falls
outside of the agreed threshold.

149
00:09:28.240 --> 00:09:32.400
Now, these agreed thresholds are what
we find in our service level agreement.

150
00:09:32.400 --> 00:09:37.383
So, actually, where we want to be is,
we want to move from, sort of having

151
00:09:37.383 --> 00:09:43.070
unassured levels, so having that
deviation we wanna move from that

152
00:09:43.070 --> 00:09:48.530
to always having this peak,
to always having this warranty effect.

153
00:09:48.530 --> 00:09:51.284
So we have to have no just the utility,
but

154
00:09:51.284 --> 00:09:54.053
we also have to have the warranty as well.

155
00:09:55.905 --> 00:09:59.450
Now, we've gotta be able to communicate
this, and this can be a challenge.

156
00:09:59.450 --> 00:10:02.290
I mean even just talking about
the different levels of utility and

157
00:10:02.290 --> 00:10:04.009
warranty right now is a challenge.

158
00:10:05.600 --> 00:10:08.250
And quite often, when we first,
as a service provider,

159
00:10:08.250 --> 00:10:11.870
go to a customer, an internal customer or

160
00:10:11.870 --> 00:10:15.630
an external customer, the first
thing that concerns them is cost.

161
00:10:17.290 --> 00:10:19.750
That's the first thing that concerns them.

162
00:10:19.750 --> 00:10:24.680
And sometimes, and we all make these
decisions every day in our lives.

163
00:10:24.680 --> 00:10:27.060
We decide whether we don't
want to spend money.

164
00:10:27.060 --> 00:10:30.620
And therefore, we're going to sacrifice,
perhaps, on availability or

165
00:10:30.620 --> 00:10:35.190
we're going to sacrifice on reliability,
which is all about availability.

166
00:10:35.190 --> 00:10:39.220
So we have to be able to
articulate to our customers

167
00:10:39.220 --> 00:10:43.080
exactly what levels of utility and
warranty we are able to provide.

168
00:10:44.480 --> 00:10:50.610
Bearing in mind, that value is about not
just being able to deliver the outcome,

169
00:10:50.610 --> 00:10:53.450
but also on preferences and perception.

170
00:10:53.450 --> 00:10:57.880
And so we have to be able to articulate
exactly what levels of utility and

171
00:10:57.880 --> 00:11:02.210
warranty we can provide that
will meet their preferences.

172
00:11:03.320 --> 00:11:06.310
And that may influence their perception.

173
00:11:06.310 --> 00:11:10.030
Remember we talked about cost
earlier on in a previous session?

174
00:11:10.030 --> 00:11:13.270
Well, costs are really important and
there's an assumption there that if we

175
00:11:13.270 --> 00:11:17.190
spend more money, then we can
increase the level of warranty.

176
00:11:17.190 --> 00:11:19.150
We can increase availability and

177
00:11:19.150 --> 00:11:24.520
we can increase an assured level of
security, and we can increase capacity.

178
00:11:24.520 --> 00:11:28.500
But it's not just about spending money,
it's also about our technology and

179
00:11:28.500 --> 00:11:31.120
it's about our experience as well.

180
00:11:31.120 --> 00:11:36.860
Now, our technology and our experience
will help us with those warranty aspects.

181
00:11:36.860 --> 00:11:40.960
The service itself will
provide the utility,

182
00:11:40.960 --> 00:11:44.760
that outcome, the ability to send and
receive email.

183
00:11:44.760 --> 00:11:46.230
But it's our experience,

184
00:11:46.230 --> 00:11:50.810
and it's the tools that we use that will
help us to deliver the warranty elements.

185
00:11:51.930 --> 00:11:58.080
And of course, if we look in the service
provider articulations on risk mitigation,

186
00:11:58.080 --> 00:12:01.400
well, we've got to understand
what the impact is of not

187
00:12:01.400 --> 00:12:03.460
achieving those warranty elements too.

188
00:12:03.460 --> 00:12:07.470
And that enables us to
perform risk management and

189
00:12:07.470 --> 00:12:09.770
risk mitigation, if necessary.

190
00:12:11.080 --> 00:12:15.935
In utility we go back to, and I just
wanna go back to this particular slide.

191
00:12:15.935 --> 00:12:22.790
In utility it mentions performance
supported and constraints removed.

192
00:12:22.790 --> 00:12:26.620
So, not only have we gotta provide them
with the ability to send and receive

193
00:12:26.620 --> 00:12:31.720
email, but we've also got to remove any
constraints that might get in the way too.

194
00:12:31.720 --> 00:12:36.650
Removing those constraints means that
our firewall must be in a position

195
00:12:36.650 --> 00:12:41.490
where it allows an email to be sent and
it it'll house us to receive an email.

196
00:12:41.490 --> 00:12:46.270
We have to be in a position where our
passwords are secure, but not too secure.

197
00:12:46.270 --> 00:12:47.820
You know the old adage.

198
00:12:47.820 --> 00:12:50.670
You know, we get so
secure that we become insecure.

199
00:12:50.670 --> 00:12:53.810
Where we have a password policy that is so
secure that

200
00:12:53.810 --> 00:12:57.480
what happens is everybody writes their
password down on a sticky note and

201
00:12:57.480 --> 00:13:01.520
then puts it somewhere on their screen,
cuz they're not going to remember it.

202
00:13:01.520 --> 00:13:05.640
So we have to be able to remove any
constraints and deliver service.

203
00:13:05.640 --> 00:13:07.350
That's what utility is about.

204
00:13:09.260 --> 00:13:13.950
So, let's take a look then at
that removing constraints.

205
00:13:13.950 --> 00:13:15.370
Because, what we want to do is,

206
00:13:15.370 --> 00:13:18.390
on the left-hand side,
it's about outcomes supported.

207
00:13:18.390 --> 00:13:19.140
It's about.

208
00:13:20.360 --> 00:13:21.840
here's some examples here.

209
00:13:21.840 --> 00:13:24.930
Field staff securely
accessing applications,

210
00:13:24.930 --> 00:13:29.760
or loan officers determining
the credit rating of applicants.

211
00:13:29.760 --> 00:13:35.365
So we want to offer that ability
to perform that outcome but

212
00:13:35.365 --> 00:13:41.395
we want to remove constraints,
we want to decrease constraints.

213
00:13:41.395 --> 00:13:46.225
Constraints that are mentioned here
such as time, just the fact that our

214
00:13:46.225 --> 00:13:50.535
network might be slow, for instance,
we want to remove that constraint.

215
00:13:50.535 --> 00:13:52.925
We wanna remove
the constraint of failures.

216
00:13:54.190 --> 00:13:56.710
So we wanna deliver performance.

217
00:13:56.710 --> 00:13:58.360
But we want to remove constraints.

218
00:13:58.360 --> 00:14:02.250
And of course availability is going
to help us with that enormously.

219
00:14:02.250 --> 00:14:06.860
So our four elements of
warranty then are availability,

220
00:14:06.860 --> 00:14:11.830
capacity, continuity and security.

221
00:14:11.830 --> 00:14:14.940
Now reliability is mentioned in there too.

222
00:14:14.940 --> 00:14:19.440
And reliability actually forms
part of availability management.

223
00:14:19.440 --> 00:14:22.430
So as we look at service design,

224
00:14:22.430 --> 00:14:26.700
you'll see that availability management
is a process within service design.

225
00:14:26.700 --> 00:14:31.965
And reliability, how often something
falls, how often something breaks or

226
00:14:31.965 --> 00:14:36.015
fails, well,
that's part of availability management.

227
00:14:36.015 --> 00:14:40.430
Availability is about
ensuring that a service is

228
00:14:40.430 --> 00:14:44.960
available when the customer
needs that service.

229
00:14:44.960 --> 00:14:50.689
You see, if I go back to my
free web mail based service.

230
00:14:50.689 --> 00:14:56.376
What level of assurance do I have,
that if I'm traveling and

231
00:14:56.376 --> 00:15:02.190
I want to access my email at,
say 2 AM in the morning in India.

232
00:15:02.190 --> 00:15:07.550
Which is where I am right now,
then can I access that service?

233
00:15:07.550 --> 00:15:08.690
Well, I have no assurance.

234
00:15:10.500 --> 00:15:13.890
I mean I might be able to,
but I might not.

235
00:15:13.890 --> 00:15:15.380
And what do I do if I can't?

236
00:15:16.630 --> 00:15:18.806
And what about capacity?

237
00:15:18.806 --> 00:15:25.108
How much assurance do I have with that
free web mail based service on capacity?

238
00:15:25.108 --> 00:15:29.068
How much assurance do I have that
I can receive all of my emails,

239
00:15:29.068 --> 00:15:32.120
because my mailbox is big enough?

240
00:15:32.120 --> 00:15:37.040
Or what about the attachments, how much
assurance do I have that that attachment

241
00:15:37.040 --> 00:15:41.460
that I sent with my email
is actually going to send?

242
00:15:41.460 --> 00:15:43.660
Cuz you know, we all do this right?

243
00:15:43.660 --> 00:15:48.460
We all send an email with an attachment
and then we kind of close our laptops and

244
00:15:48.460 --> 00:15:50.290
then go on to something else.

245
00:15:50.290 --> 00:15:51.929
And it's not until an hour or

246
00:15:51.929 --> 00:15:56.095
two later when you open up your laptop
that you see that email come back and

247
00:15:56.095 --> 00:15:59.937
it said, this didn't send because
the attachment was too big.

248
00:15:59.937 --> 00:16:05.456
So how much assurance do I have
that that's not going to happen?

249
00:16:05.456 --> 00:16:10.090
Well, with my free web map based service,
I don't have that assurance.

250
00:16:10.090 --> 00:16:13.680
I don't have the assurance
on the reliability.

251
00:16:13.680 --> 00:16:16.950
And I certainly don't have
any assurance on continuity.

252
00:16:16.950 --> 00:16:20.249
And that's because, yes,
I still perceive value in this,

253
00:16:20.249 --> 00:16:23.046
because this is the level
of service that I agreed.

254
00:16:23.046 --> 00:16:26.137
But I need to have in my business email,

255
00:16:26.137 --> 00:16:29.804
I need to have an assured
level of continuity.

256
00:16:29.804 --> 00:16:35.681
If there is a disaster that
my data is still saved, okay?

257
00:16:35.681 --> 00:16:40.653
And that I can support the business as
a service provider throughout any major

258
00:16:40.653 --> 00:16:41.640
failure.

259
00:16:41.640 --> 00:16:43.450
The data's not going to be lost.

260
00:16:43.450 --> 00:16:47.290
Your business wants that assurance.

261
00:16:47.290 --> 00:16:49.650
Now of course don't forget security.

262
00:16:49.650 --> 00:16:52.730
Security, think about CIA, and

263
00:16:52.730 --> 00:16:58.640
CIA is confidentiality,
integrity and availability of data.

264
00:16:58.640 --> 00:17:03.970
So we want our services to remain
confidential within the organization,

265
00:17:03.970 --> 00:17:07.670
we want to ensure
the integrity of the data.

266
00:17:07.670 --> 00:17:11.594
And we also want assurance that that data
is only gonna be available to those that

267
00:17:11.594 --> 00:17:14.360
need to have access to it and
not to anybody else as well.

268
00:17:16.040 --> 00:17:22.880
So again, do I have that assurance
with one particular web mail service?

269
00:17:22.880 --> 00:17:27.790
Or do I have to use another service
in order to get that assurance?

270
00:17:28.920 --> 00:17:34.104
The choice is up to you, and
it really is down to the organization

271
00:17:34.104 --> 00:17:37.852
to decide on what level
of warranty they want.

272
00:17:37.852 --> 00:17:40.800
But we do need to have
a level of warranty.

273
00:17:40.800 --> 00:17:42.070
Ronnie, can I ask you a question?

274
00:17:42.070 --> 00:17:44.700
>> Sure.
>> So these levels of warranty that we're

275
00:17:44.700 --> 00:17:48.810
talking about,
they've gotta be agreed with the business.

276
00:17:48.810 --> 00:17:50.950
>> Right.
>> So where do you think, then,

277
00:17:50.950 --> 00:17:54.259
that we might actually agree and
articulate those levels?

278
00:17:54.259 --> 00:17:56.771
>> I'm gonna say the service
level agreement.

279
00:17:56.771 --> 00:17:58.523
>> Exactly, yep, spot on.

280
00:17:58.523 --> 00:18:00.820
>> Okay [LAUGH]
>> That's exactly,

281
00:18:00.820 --> 00:18:05.560
as we move into service design
we're gonna talk more about

282
00:18:05.560 --> 00:18:08.580
the service level agreements,
service level management process.

283
00:18:08.580 --> 00:18:12.390
And the service level agreement contains
absolutely everything that we agree with

284
00:18:12.390 --> 00:18:13.520
our business.

285
00:18:13.520 --> 00:18:17.850
And of course if we look at these
components to warranty of availability and

286
00:18:17.850 --> 00:18:22.850
capacity and security and continuity,
we're gonna have targets for all of these.

287
00:18:22.850 --> 00:18:26.140
And these are gonna be contained
within our service level agreement.

288
00:18:26.140 --> 00:18:30.970
So when I talk about different levels of
utility and different levels of warranty.

289
00:18:30.970 --> 00:18:35.490
Well, I expect to see those
warranty levels agreed in the SLA.

290
00:18:35.490 --> 00:18:39.080
Right now,
I perceive value in my free email service.

291
00:18:39.080 --> 00:18:43.270
Even though it doesn't give me
the levels of warranty that

292
00:18:44.580 --> 00:18:48.880
I may get from a paid email service,
but that's because it's free.

293
00:18:48.880 --> 00:18:50.961
So I still perceive value in it.

294
00:18:50.961 --> 00:18:55.517
Now the levels of warranty that your
organization require are gonna vary from

295
00:18:55.517 --> 00:18:57.760
organization to organization.

296
00:18:57.760 --> 00:19:00.400
So we have to agree them and
of course that has to be

297
00:19:00.400 --> 00:19:04.590
in that service level agreement,
that's why we have the agreement.

298
00:19:05.690 --> 00:19:11.990
So designing the utility and
warranty for any given service

299
00:19:11.990 --> 00:19:16.870
is something that we start off by
articulating in service strategy.

300
00:19:16.870 --> 00:19:19.980
When we first come up with the idea for
that new service,

301
00:19:19.980 --> 00:19:24.160
this is where we, working with
business relationship management,

302
00:19:24.160 --> 00:19:28.550
understand the levels of utility and
warranty that are required.

303
00:19:29.780 --> 00:19:31.820
Bearing in mind that it's going to cost.

304
00:19:31.820 --> 00:19:33.940
Remember I talked about email services.

305
00:19:33.940 --> 00:19:37.160
And I said yeah, but
this is okay cuz it's free, okay?

306
00:19:37.160 --> 00:19:41.385
In previous sessions we've looked
at cost and affordability, and

307
00:19:41.385 --> 00:19:45.980
about how perception changes
based on cost and affordability.

308
00:19:45.980 --> 00:19:47.610
And that's exactly right.

309
00:19:47.610 --> 00:19:51.340
And it's something that we accept
throughout our day-to-day lives.

310
00:19:51.340 --> 00:19:56.790
And its something that we have to
negotiate with our organization.

311
00:19:56.790 --> 00:19:59.963
So the service that meets
the needs of the organization,

312
00:19:59.963 --> 00:20:02.884
well it's gonna be something
that they can afford.

313
00:20:02.884 --> 00:20:07.280
But we have to have that
agreed level of utility and

314
00:20:07.280 --> 00:20:12.720
warranty in order for
our customers to perceive value.

315
00:20:12.720 --> 00:20:15.740
Because overall as we
said value is perceived.

316
00:20:17.410 --> 00:20:21.760
So now that we've looked at value and we
spent two sessions looking at value now,

317
00:20:21.760 --> 00:20:27.290
I want you to go over value perception.

318
00:20:27.290 --> 00:20:30.190
I want you to take a look
again at utility and

319
00:20:30.190 --> 00:20:34.830
warranty and make sure that you've
got a complete understanding of both.

320
00:20:34.830 --> 00:20:39.698
Because in our next session, if I can
put my teeth in [LAUGH] we're going

321
00:20:39.698 --> 00:20:43.674
to look at what actually,
physically, creates value.

322
00:20:43.674 --> 00:20:46.782
And we're going to look
at our service assets.

323
00:20:46.782 --> 00:20:48.814
>> All right Jo, well thank you again for

324
00:20:48.814 --> 00:20:53.140

325
00:20:53.140 --> 00:20:57.379
And how they both combine to help us to
make sure that we communicate the value

326
00:20:57.379 --> 00:21:01.035
that we also need for, of course,
our service strategy as well.

327
00:21:01.035 --> 00:21:03.970
Well that's a great place for
us to end this episode then.

328
00:21:03.970 --> 00:21:07.780
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

329
00:21:07.780 --> 00:21:08.770
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

330
00:21:08.770 --> 00:21:13.309
>> Stay tuned right here for more of the
ITIL Intermediate Service Strategy shows.

331
00:21:13.309 --> 00:21:19.204
[MUSIC]

00:21:19.204 --> 00:21:22.259
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo help to identify and explain service assets.  Jo describes the service assets as being resources (tangible) and capabilities (intangible).  For an organization to see IT as a strategic asset to the business, the IT service provider must help the customer remove constraints and increase performance through its outcomes, explains Jo.  Also, she tells us that competitive advantage to our assets is when we can combine our resources with different capabilities.
episodes.title: Service Strategy Principles - Service Assets

If the drinks were awful,

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo dive into service provisioning.  They look at who provides the service, what service should we provide and defining the services we provide. 479
00:30:23.230 --> 00:30:27.172

00:30:27.172 --> 00:30:31.087

what types of roles that we have,

their capabilities are,

486

capable of delivering.

00:30:56.630 --> 00:30:58.456

00:30:58.456 --> 00:31:02.060

489
00:31:02.060 --> 00:31:04.200
>> All right, thank you again, Jo, for

00:31:04.200 --> 00:31:07.610

service provisioning here.

00:31:11.080 --> 00:31:16.470

00:31:16.470 --> 00:31:19.760

00:31:19.760 --> 00:31:23.070
to actually figuring what we wanna

495
00:31:23.070 --> 00:31:26.888
But there is more to come on service

496
00:31:26.888 --> 00:31:30.840
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

497
00:31:30.840 --> 00:31:31.920
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

498
00:31:31.920 --> 00:31:36.492

00:31:36.492 --> 00:31:42.365

00:31:42.365 --> 00:31:45.968
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo explain the service provision concepts of understanding opportunities (marketing spaces) and define services based on outcomes.  She emphasizes the use of service definitions and models too.  She explains the creation of service models are based around moments of truth and how the service must be able to figure out how to satisfy each moment of truth.

00:20:26.720 --> 00:20:32.350
It's a service in it's own right, like our

00:20:32.350 --> 00:20:38.635

00:20:46.815 --> 00:20:50.839

directory or instant messaging,

Our service package here

All right, Jo, you are going to go

12

So, where are we gonna begin?

[LAUGH]
>> Well,

14
00:00:51.928 --> 00:00:53.366
it always boils down to the money, right?

15

16
00:00:54.650 --> 00:00:57.440
>> And

17
00:00:57.440 --> 00:00:58.750
It boils down to the money.

18
00:00:58.750 --> 00:01:04.027
We talked about, in previous sessions,
we talked about value, and value

19
00:01:04.027 --> 00:01:09.660
as being perceived, and value as being
a mixture of outcomes and preferences.

20
00:01:09.660 --> 00:01:13.053
And, if you remember in one previous

21
00:01:13.053 --> 00:01:16.141
if I gave you 20 grand to go and

22

would you perceive value in it

23
00:01:19.490 --> 00:01:20.240
And you said?

24

25
00:01:20.760 --> 00:01:21.360
>> Yeah, right.
>> [LAUGH]

26
00:01:21.360 --> 00:01:22.240
>> Because

27
00:01:22.240 --> 00:01:24.370

28
00:01:24.370 --> 00:01:29.510
And the simple fact is that value is

29
00:01:29.510 --> 00:01:35.150
We've got to facilitate
the organization in making a profit

30
00:01:35.150 --> 00:01:38.050
