31
00:01:38.050 --> 00:01:40.140
Now, and
this is where it gets interesting,

32
00:01:40.140 --> 00:01:43.970
because ITIL came from the Office
of Government Commerce.

33
00:01:43.970 --> 00:01:47.338
ITIL came from the UK government.

34
00:01:47.338 --> 00:01:52.240
And in fact, that's exactly where I came
from, the Office of Government Commerce.

35
00:01:52.240 --> 00:01:57.252
And so, ITIL was created out of a need

36
00:01:57.252 --> 00:02:06.004
to be able to justify our expenditure
within the UK government.

37
00:02:06.004 --> 00:02:10.960
Because we're spending taxpayer's money,
and of course we had to be

38
00:02:10.960 --> 00:02:15.832
able to justify what do we spend our
money on, how we spent our money.

39
00:02:15.832 --> 00:02:19.631
We had to ensure that we spend our
money in an impartial way, and

40
00:02:19.631 --> 00:02:23.933
we had to ensure that we were
delivering our services, and therefore,

41
00:02:23.933 --> 00:02:28.400
using taxpayer's money in the most
efficient and effective way, okay?

42
00:02:28.400 --> 00:02:30.660
So this is where ITIL came from.

43
00:02:30.660 --> 00:02:36.119
It came out of that need to justify
our expenditure of taxpayer's money.

44
00:02:37.430 --> 00:02:40.190
And so, we talk about making a profit, but

45
00:02:40.190 --> 00:02:42.180
it's not necessarily
about making a profit.

46
00:02:42.180 --> 00:02:44.440
It's about being efficient and
effective with our money.

47
00:02:44.440 --> 00:02:46.600
And service economics?

48
00:02:46.600 --> 00:02:48.870
Well, that's what it's about.

49
00:02:48.870 --> 00:02:53.700
It's about understanding how much it's
going to cost to deliver a service,

50
00:02:53.700 --> 00:02:57.600
what value that service gives us,
and what returns,

51
00:02:57.600 --> 00:03:01.970
if any, that service will
actually give the organization.

52
00:03:01.970 --> 00:03:04.378
Now, those returns don't have
to be financial returns.

53
00:03:04.378 --> 00:03:11.683
Those returns could be value-driven
returns such as legislative adherence,

54
00:03:11.683 --> 00:03:18.570
or any form of competitive advantage,
or maybe even just speed to market.

55
00:03:18.570 --> 00:03:22.490
It makes a huge difference whether an
internal or an external service provider,

56
00:03:22.490 --> 00:03:24.490
because as an external service provider,

57
00:03:24.490 --> 00:03:29.450
we ourselves as the service provider
have to make a profit on our services.

58
00:03:29.450 --> 00:03:31.831
As an internal service provider,

59
00:03:31.831 --> 00:03:37.083
we have to facilitate the organization's
ability to either make a profit or

60
00:03:37.083 --> 00:03:42.350
to be able to demonstrate efficient use
of the budget that they have, okay?

61
00:03:42.350 --> 00:03:46.876
So we have to understand not only what
services we provide, which is in our

62
00:03:46.876 --> 00:03:52.410
portfolio, but how much money we've got
and what return we get on that investment.

63
00:03:52.410 --> 00:03:57.020
And what the impact to the business will
be if any one of those services fail.

64
00:03:58.610 --> 00:04:01.630
So, when we come up with an idea for
any new service,

65
00:04:01.630 --> 00:04:04.310
then we have to create a business case.

66
00:04:04.310 --> 00:04:06.990
And we'll talk about
a business case in a second.

67
00:04:06.990 --> 00:04:12.272
Part of that business case
we have to articulate

68
00:04:12.272 --> 00:04:17.826
the return that we expect on that service,
okay?

69
00:04:17.826 --> 00:04:20.550
And we all like to think about money,
and we really, really do.

70
00:04:20.550 --> 00:04:24.667
And so ROI, return on investment,
is used as a measure

71
00:04:24.667 --> 00:04:30.110
to demonstrate whether we
are actually delivering value or not.

72
00:04:30.110 --> 00:04:32.208
If an organization sees a return,

73
00:04:32.208 --> 00:04:37.600
then obviously we're delivering value,
that service is delivering value.

74
00:04:37.600 --> 00:04:42.030
Be careful with that assumption, though,
because this only works in organizations

75
00:04:42.030 --> 00:04:45.930
that want to grow and
organizations that want to transform.

76
00:04:45.930 --> 00:04:50.550
Organizations that are not for profit,
for instance, or organizations that

77
00:04:50.550 --> 00:04:54.570
are government agencies,
they're not interested in making a profit.

78
00:04:54.570 --> 00:04:57.290
What they want to do
is ensure that we have

79
00:04:57.290 --> 00:05:02.700
efficient use of the money that we have,
so that we're cost effective, okay?

80
00:05:02.700 --> 00:05:05.810
Now, sometimes it's very difficult for
us to get funding for

81
00:05:05.810 --> 00:05:08.530
implementing service management,
for instance,

82
00:05:08.530 --> 00:05:13.040
because they don't necessarily see
the return on that investment.

83
00:05:13.040 --> 00:05:14.920
So that's something in itself.

84
00:05:14.920 --> 00:05:17.850
Even if we're bringing in service
management, it's an improvement, and

85
00:05:17.850 --> 00:05:21.710
we have to make sure that we can
articulate the benefits there.

86
00:05:21.710 --> 00:05:26.670
So, as we've already said,
we'll have to compile a business case for

87
00:05:26.670 --> 00:05:28.168
any new initiative.

88
00:05:28.168 --> 00:05:33.144
And that business case needs to
include both the pre-program ROI and

89
00:05:33.144 --> 00:05:37.718
pre-program estimation of any
value on investments as well.

90
00:05:37.718 --> 00:05:44.120
Now, the post-program ROI is something
that we calculate after we've implemented.

91
00:05:44.120 --> 00:05:48.802
In other words, the pre-program ROI,
that's how much money do we expect

92
00:05:48.802 --> 00:05:53.126
to get back and post-program ROI is,
or how much did we make, okay?

93
00:05:53.126 --> 00:05:57.016
So the business case
is a justification for

94
00:05:57.016 --> 00:06:01.020
a significant item of expenditure, okay?

95
00:06:01.020 --> 00:06:03.788
Which means that we have
to have the document.

96
00:06:03.788 --> 00:06:07.121
When we want to spend any
significant amount of money,

97
00:06:07.121 --> 00:06:11.687
we have to have the document created
by financial management that outlines

98
00:06:11.687 --> 00:06:14.960
the objectives that we
are trying to facilitate.

99
00:06:14.960 --> 00:06:18.977
In other words,
where we want to add value and

100
00:06:18.977 --> 00:06:23.966
the impact of us not
implementing that service, okay?

101
00:06:23.966 --> 00:06:27.264
So it's critical, absolutely critical,

102
00:06:27.264 --> 00:06:32.697
that our business case is built on not
only the value to the business, but

103
00:06:32.697 --> 00:06:39.130
also the impact of not implementing that
particular service to the business, okay?

104
00:06:39.130 --> 00:06:42.463
So the business case, and
there's a template here for

105
00:06:42.463 --> 00:06:45.400
what might be included in a business case.

106
00:06:45.400 --> 00:06:48.720
There is no right or wrong here,
but I will tell you that, yes,

107
00:06:48.720 --> 00:06:51.300
we should have business impacts in there.

108
00:06:51.300 --> 00:06:53.156
We definitely should mention the risks.

109
00:06:53.156 --> 00:06:58.371
And also we will definitely have to
have recommendations in there as well,

110
00:06:58.371 --> 00:07:01.120
what we would recommend as a solution.

111
00:07:02.280 --> 00:07:06.501
Now, what I do wanna tell you there's
no mention of ROI on there within that

112
00:07:06.501 --> 00:07:08.046
business case structure.

113
00:07:08.046 --> 00:07:13.733
I would expect ROI to be seen onto
the business impact section, okay?

114
00:07:13.733 --> 00:07:16.070
So pre-program ROI, then.

115
00:07:16.070 --> 00:07:22.318
That's what we want to see
within our business case, okay?

116
00:07:22.318 --> 00:07:25.720
And that is a, well, it says pre-program.

117
00:07:25.720 --> 00:07:31.550
It's an estimation of exactly what
returns we expect to see, okay?

118
00:07:31.550 --> 00:07:35.704
And those returns then will
allow us to make decisions.

119
00:07:35.704 --> 00:07:40.249
And we have, as we say in the second
half of this screen here,

120
00:07:40.249 --> 00:07:43.830
budgeting decisions that
fall into two types.

121
00:07:43.830 --> 00:07:45.112
We have two types of decisions.

122
00:07:45.112 --> 00:07:47.400
We have screening decisions.

123
00:07:47.400 --> 00:07:54.142
So that's a decision where we say, okay,
yes, I quite like this initiative, okay?

124
00:07:54.142 --> 00:07:56.007
That's a screening decision.

125
00:07:56.007 --> 00:07:57.893
Does it meet a certain prerequisite?

126
00:07:57.893 --> 00:08:01.310
And then we have a what we
call preference decisions.

127
00:08:01.310 --> 00:08:04.848
Preference decisions are,
well, it's a preference.

128
00:08:04.848 --> 00:08:08.900
I prefer this one or
I prefer this particular type, okay?

129
00:08:08.900 --> 00:08:10.735
So we have two different
types of decisions.

130
00:08:10.735 --> 00:08:16.110
As we say, the screening decision is yes,
I definitely want to go down this road.

131
00:08:16.110 --> 00:08:19.670
Or as the preference decision is, well,
I prefer this one or I prefer this one.

132
00:08:20.810 --> 00:08:22.944
Now, we're gonna get into
some financial terms.

133
00:08:22.944 --> 00:08:25.549
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Cuz I know we always like that.

134
00:08:25.549 --> 00:08:27.180
>> Bravo.
>> Yeah, right?

135
00:08:27.180 --> 00:08:30.890
[LAUGH] So screening decisions are about,
well, Net Present Value.

136
00:08:30.890 --> 00:08:33.807
And we're gonna abbreviate that to NPV.

137
00:08:33.807 --> 00:08:39.584
Net Present Value basically takes
our inflow and looks at our outflow.

138
00:08:39.584 --> 00:08:42.620
But Ian says, did we make a profit?

139
00:08:42.620 --> 00:08:44.550
And that's it, simple as that.

140
00:08:44.550 --> 00:08:46.910
It sounds complex, but it's really not.

141
00:08:46.910 --> 00:08:49.130
Did we make a profit, yes or no?

142
00:08:49.130 --> 00:08:53.030
If the Net Present Value is negative,
in other words, we didn't make a profit or

143
00:08:53.030 --> 00:08:55.120
we're not going to make a profit.

144
00:08:55.120 --> 00:08:58.580
Then, we have to ask the question,
why are we spending the money?

145
00:08:58.580 --> 00:09:02.150
Why do you think we would spend the money
then if we're not gonna make a profit?

146
00:09:02.150 --> 00:09:05.980
>> Well, we may be investing into
a future part of the infrastructure, and

147
00:09:05.980 --> 00:09:10.090
just taking a loss for now or it could be
considered a loss leader of something?

148
00:09:10.090 --> 00:09:12.230
>> Right, I love that, yeah.

149
00:09:12.230 --> 00:09:15.650
A loss leader gives us
a competitive advantage.

150
00:09:15.650 --> 00:09:19.990
So an advantage over our customers,
over our competitors rather.

151
00:09:19.990 --> 00:09:23.120
Now, a loss leader is something
that's not going to make a profit,

152
00:09:23.120 --> 00:09:24.930
not in the short term.

153
00:09:24.930 --> 00:09:29.622
But in the long term, I expect that
to evolve into new customers, okay,

154
00:09:29.622 --> 00:09:32.030
most definitely soon.

155
00:09:32.030 --> 00:09:34.222
So that's a screening decision.

156
00:09:34.222 --> 00:09:39.661
And a preference decision, well,
that is a decision that allows us to,

157
00:09:39.661 --> 00:09:44.119
or rather, it's a tool that
allows us to make a decision for

158
00:09:44.119 --> 00:09:47.790
one particular service
provider over another.

159
00:09:47.790 --> 00:09:52.751
Now, that might be based on profit, but
a preference decision is also based on

160
00:09:52.751 --> 00:09:57.262
other factors such as the credibility
of a supplier, for instance, or

161
00:09:57.262 --> 00:09:59.464
the credibility of a tool, okay?

162
00:09:59.464 --> 00:10:06.746
And we've got lots of other tools that
can help us in making those decisions.

163
00:10:06.746 --> 00:10:14.420
You see, not all opportunities can pass
this particular screening decision.

164
00:10:14.420 --> 00:10:17.962
Not all opportunities will actually
give us that Net Present Value.

165
00:10:17.962 --> 00:10:20.275
So therefore, not all opportunities and

166
00:10:20.275 --> 00:10:24.400
not all new services that we see
actually get to the preference decision.

167
00:10:24.400 --> 00:10:27.552
The screening decision happens first,
that's the yes or no.

168
00:10:27.552 --> 00:10:29.600
Are we gonna go with this?

169
00:10:29.600 --> 00:10:31.844
And then, the preference
decision happens afterwards.

170
00:10:31.844 --> 00:10:35.911
And the preference decision is,
which one are we going to go with?

171
00:10:35.911 --> 00:10:40.740
And we might look at suppliers and
tools that may offer us discount,

172
00:10:40.740 --> 00:10:42.320
as we say, okay?

173
00:10:42.320 --> 00:10:45.040
We might look at other
financial constraints.

174
00:10:45.040 --> 00:10:47.540
We might look at preferred
suppliers as well.

175
00:10:49.070 --> 00:10:53.630
So this is what's contained
in our business case.

176
00:10:55.040 --> 00:10:58.132
After we have implemented a new service,

177
00:10:58.132 --> 00:11:02.738
we need to then work out what
we call the Post-Programme ROI.

178
00:11:02.738 --> 00:11:07.694
And the Post-Programme ROI
is what return did

179
00:11:07.694 --> 00:11:12.905
we actually realize from that new service.

180
00:11:12.905 --> 00:11:17.525
So what we'll do is we take
the program objectives.

181
00:11:17.525 --> 00:11:21.063
And if we're here on the left-hand side,

182
00:11:21.063 --> 00:11:26.078
we take these program objectives and
we'll actually try and

183
00:11:26.078 --> 00:11:31.525
identify, put a quantitative
term on those objectives, okay?

184
00:11:31.525 --> 00:11:35.230
But first of all, well,
we understand the costs.

185
00:11:35.230 --> 00:11:39.200
Okay, how much did that new
service actually cost us?

186
00:11:39.200 --> 00:11:43.936
We want to isolate actually
the effects of that new service and

187
00:11:43.936 --> 00:11:47.868
then convert the data into
a monetary conversion.

188
00:11:47.868 --> 00:11:50.430
Okay, so, well,
that's what convert means, yeah.

189
00:11:50.430 --> 00:11:52.020
[LAUGH] We convert the data into money.

190
00:11:52.020 --> 00:11:54.220
So just how much money did we make?

191
00:11:54.220 --> 00:11:56.370
That's the return on the investment.

192
00:11:56.370 --> 00:12:00.590
And then these qualitative benefits,
well, we've got to make them quantitative.

193
00:12:00.590 --> 00:12:03.880
Did we actually achieve our objective?

194
00:12:03.880 --> 00:12:07.819
Maybe our objective was to
make our organization number

195
00:12:07.819 --> 00:12:11.184
two in the world instead
of being number three.

196
00:12:11.184 --> 00:12:13.580
So did we achieve that?

197
00:12:13.580 --> 00:12:17.280
It's not just about the profit,
it's the value on investment as well.

198
00:12:17.280 --> 00:12:21.440
And if we achieve the return on
investment, if we achieved our

199
00:12:21.440 --> 00:12:25.140
qualitative benefits, in other words,
we moved up in the marketplace.

200
00:12:25.140 --> 00:12:29.680
But then at that point in time,
then we want to communicate those results.

201
00:12:29.680 --> 00:12:31.280
Of course, we want to tell everybody.

202
00:12:32.380 --> 00:12:34.740
So let me ask you another question then,
Ronnie.

203
00:12:34.740 --> 00:12:36.380
Do we communicate where we failed?

204
00:12:37.570 --> 00:12:39.440
>> Yes, we should.

205
00:12:39.440 --> 00:12:41.480
>> Yeah, we definitely should.

206
00:12:41.480 --> 00:12:46.466
We'll tell you right away throughout
ITIL that we have to have an open and

207
00:12:46.466 --> 00:12:48.602
collaborative environment.

208
00:12:48.602 --> 00:12:53.140
And in fact, governance is about
control with fairness and transparency.

209
00:12:53.140 --> 00:12:55.999
So yes, we communicate our successes, but

210
00:12:55.999 --> 00:13:00.106
we also communicate the areas
where we could do better as well.

211
00:13:00.106 --> 00:13:06.610
So yes, we do communicate when we didn't
quite do as well as we expected because

212
00:13:06.610 --> 00:13:12.810
that feedback and those results,
well, we can use them in the future.

213
00:13:12.810 --> 00:13:16.120
Those are lessons learnt for
us to taken into the future and

214
00:13:16.120 --> 00:13:19.840
apply to new projects and
new initiatives and new services.

215
00:13:21.540 --> 00:13:26.660
So just to go back to that particular
slide then, you'll see here that

216
00:13:26.660 --> 00:13:32.460
the calculation of that post-programme
ROI means that we look at the objectives,

217
00:13:32.460 --> 00:13:38.130
which may be to move from being third
to being second in our marketplace.

218
00:13:38.130 --> 00:13:42.920
We collect data on exactly how many sales
we've made as a result of implementing

219
00:13:42.920 --> 00:13:44.470
that new service.

220
00:13:44.470 --> 00:13:46.630
We isolate the effects of the program.

221
00:13:46.630 --> 00:13:47.810
In other words, we say, okay,

222
00:13:47.810 --> 00:13:52.770
well, how many of these new sales
were just down to this new service?

223
00:13:52.770 --> 00:13:55.230
And then we convert that into money.

224
00:13:55.230 --> 00:13:59.010
We determine how much the actual
new service cost us to implement,

225
00:13:59.010 --> 00:14:00.810
that's our program costs.

226
00:14:00.810 --> 00:14:06.220
And then we calculate the ROI, and
we then identify any quality as well.

227
00:14:06.220 --> 00:14:09.700
In other words, did we get from
number two to number three?

228
00:14:11.260 --> 00:14:15.878
Now, something else that we need to put
into our business case is our business

229
00:14:15.878 --> 00:14:17.448
impact analysis, okay?

230
00:14:17.448 --> 00:14:20.093
And the business impact analysis, well,

231
00:14:20.093 --> 00:14:23.480
we identify our vital business functions,
okay?

232
00:14:23.480 --> 00:14:26.370
What is it that our
business has to achieve?

233
00:14:27.520 --> 00:14:31.260
And then, we look at our proposals for
our new services, and

234
00:14:31.260 --> 00:14:34.540
we say, bearing in mind,
there are vital business functions,

235
00:14:34.540 --> 00:14:38.930
bearing in mind the outcomes that our
organization wants to facilitate.

236
00:14:38.930 --> 00:14:45.960
If we bring this new service in,
what will the impact to the business be?

237
00:14:47.110 --> 00:14:52.140
How much will it cost us as
a business if that service fails?

238
00:14:53.160 --> 00:14:55.506
What is the cost of the outage?

239
00:14:55.506 --> 00:15:00.562
Okay, business impact analysis is about
identifying whether a new service

240
00:15:00.562 --> 00:15:05.382
will not only be a benefit to
the organization, but whether that service

241
00:15:05.382 --> 00:15:10.690
needs to have additional redundancy,
reliability measures in place as well.

242
00:15:12.520 --> 00:15:17.269
So this is about informing everybody
who reads the business case.

243
00:15:17.269 --> 00:15:21.130
Well, this is what new
service I recommend.

244
00:15:21.130 --> 00:15:24.598
This is gonna be the positive impact
to the organization, and otherwise,

245
00:15:24.598 --> 00:15:25.984
here's my value statement.

246
00:15:25.984 --> 00:15:30.270
But then also, this is gonna be the
negative impact if something goes wrong.

247
00:15:30.270 --> 00:15:33.171
So this is really how valuable
it is to the business.

248
00:15:33.171 --> 00:15:35.379
Because if it's going to have a huge,

249
00:15:35.379 --> 00:15:39.037
big impact to the organization
once it's been implemented and

250
00:15:39.037 --> 00:15:43.591
if the impact is gonna be negative when
there's a failure, then we definitely

251
00:15:43.591 --> 00:15:47.955
need to put some more money in and
add in redundancy to that service, okay?

252
00:15:47.955 --> 00:15:52.011
So what type of things are we
doing in business impact analysis?

253
00:15:52.011 --> 00:15:56.305
Well, Financial management's
going to help us with that.

254
00:15:56.305 --> 00:15:59.694
We've got to do this in
conjunction with the business and

255
00:15:59.694 --> 00:16:04.580
it has to be done in conjunction with
business relationship management.

256
00:16:04.580 --> 00:16:08.350
So we have to identify analysis points for
assessments and again,

257
00:16:08.350 --> 00:16:11.020
that's something that we do with
business relationship management.

258
00:16:11.020 --> 00:16:14.760
And we have to then wait to
these particular elements,

259
00:16:14.760 --> 00:16:17.580
these analysis points, and

260
00:16:17.580 --> 00:16:22.740
score our vulnerabilities
against those elements.

261
00:16:24.180 --> 00:16:27.310
So how likely is this to fail?

262
00:16:27.310 --> 00:16:30.988
And how important will
this be to the business?

263
00:16:30.988 --> 00:16:35.860
And if this were to fail, then how
long do you think it would fail for?

264
00:16:35.860 --> 00:16:40.790
And a lot of these what if questions
because let's face it if we're bringing in

265
00:16:40.790 --> 00:16:45.190
a new service, how on earth do
we find the answer to these?

266
00:16:45.190 --> 00:16:48.958
Well, our suppliers could help,
especially with a new service,

267
00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:54.070
we'll ask our suppliers to tell us what's
happened with their current customers.

268
00:16:54.070 --> 00:16:56.018
We'll ask them for reference sites.

269
00:16:56.018 --> 00:17:01.223
We'll ask them for details of when
there was an impact or life service,

270
00:17:01.223 --> 00:17:07.980
and maybe when there was an impact during
the implementation of a service as well.

271
00:17:07.980 --> 00:17:11.920
Business impact analysis is
not something that we want to

272
00:17:11.920 --> 00:17:16.760
conduct when we think of that service
as being in place in ten years time,

273
00:17:16.760 --> 00:17:19.170
I'm not interested in
the impact in ten years time.

274
00:17:19.170 --> 00:17:23.590
I'm interested in what the impact to the
business will be in six months time and

275
00:17:23.590 --> 00:17:24.520
in a year's time.

276
00:17:24.520 --> 00:17:30.140
In a previous session, we looked at value
realized when we first implement a service

277
00:17:30.140 --> 00:17:34.830
versus value realized once that
service has been embedded and

278
00:17:34.830 --> 00:17:37.520
once it's been used for a while.

279
00:17:37.520 --> 00:17:39.340
I'm looking at impact to the business,

280
00:17:39.340 --> 00:17:43.670
if this service fails,
both when it's implemented and

281
00:17:43.670 --> 00:17:47.430
in six months time or in two years
time as well, so I'm looking for both.

282
00:17:48.620 --> 00:17:52.943
And I need to ensure that I have that
information at hand in my business case

283
00:17:52.943 --> 00:17:57.894
because if I don't when I present it
to the group, they're gonna say to me,

284
00:17:57.894 --> 00:18:00.782
there's not enough
information in there John.

285
00:18:00.782 --> 00:18:06.110
I'm sorry but we can't approve
it because we need to understand

286
00:18:06.110 --> 00:18:12.240
what value the business is going to
place on that particular new service.

287
00:18:13.930 --> 00:18:16.422
You know what it's like yourself.

288
00:18:16.422 --> 00:18:18.780
You go out, you get your new cellphone,
we all do it.

289
00:18:18.780 --> 00:18:23.573
Yeah we get our new cell phone and
before you know it that cell phone is so

290
00:18:23.573 --> 00:18:27.570
much a part of you that you
can't bear to be parted from it.

291
00:18:29.050 --> 00:18:32.850
Now I don't know about you Ronnie but
I know when I leave my cell phone at home,

292
00:18:32.850 --> 00:18:36.510
it feels like there's
a piece of me missing.

293
00:18:36.510 --> 00:18:37.400
>> I understand.

294
00:18:37.400 --> 00:18:41.900
>> Right [LAUGH] and so this is
exactly the same with our services.

295
00:18:41.900 --> 00:18:44.621
When we implement a service
into our organization and

296
00:18:44.621 --> 00:18:48.371
into the live environment then we want
the business to feel as though hey,

297
00:18:48.371 --> 00:18:51.710
if that service is not around then
there's a piece of me missing.

298
00:18:52.970 --> 00:18:55.390
The problem is that we've
gotta prepare for that.

299
00:18:55.390 --> 00:18:59.900
And it's really difficult here in
service strategy to actually quantify

300
00:18:59.900 --> 00:19:02.300
just what that impact will be.

301
00:19:02.300 --> 00:19:05.620
So business impact analysis is
not something that's easy to do.

302
00:19:05.620 --> 00:19:09.390
And this is why I said, we do get
our suppliers to help us with this.

303
00:19:11.130 --> 00:19:15.380
Now, what I'd like you to do right now
is I would like you to take a look

304
00:19:15.380 --> 00:19:19.530
at the materials that you've
downloaded along with this course.

305
00:19:19.530 --> 00:19:23.130
And there was an exercise in
there in actually undertaking

306
00:19:23.130 --> 00:19:25.240
a business impact analysis.

307
00:19:25.240 --> 00:19:29.480
So it goes through just the steps
that we've already looked at

308
00:19:29.480 --> 00:19:31.650
that are on the slide in
front of you right now.

309
00:19:32.930 --> 00:19:35.950
And I would like you to go
through that exercise for

310
00:19:35.950 --> 00:19:38.490
yourself based on the case
study that you have.

311
00:19:39.610 --> 00:19:42.200
As always, I'm available on the forum, so

312
00:19:42.200 --> 00:19:46.340
if you have any questions to do
with that business impact analysis,

313
00:19:46.340 --> 00:19:51.070
then please come back to me and
we will help you as best as we can.

314
00:19:51.070 --> 00:19:53.890
But for now, as I said,
I'd like you to undertake this exercise.

315
00:19:53.890 --> 00:19:57.430
It should take you around
about 30 to 45 minutes to do.

316
00:19:57.430 --> 00:19:59.640
>> All right, Jo.

317
00:19:59.640 --> 00:20:01.030
Well, thank you again for

318
00:20:01.030 --> 00:20:05.000
helping us to understand more about
the idea of these service economics.

319
00:20:05.000 --> 00:20:09.320
Things that we may not think about because
we're really focused in on IT, but

320
00:20:09.320 --> 00:20:12.080
this helps us to be able
to justify the need of

321
00:20:12.080 --> 00:20:15.360
the way that the money is gonna be
used in our organization as well.

322
00:20:15.360 --> 00:20:18.060
Well that's a great place for
us to end this episode then.

323
00:20:18.060 --> 00:20:21.860
Signing off for ITPRO TV,
I'm your hose Ronnie Wong.

324
00:20:21.860 --> 00:20:22.930
>> And I"m Jo Peacock.

325
00:20:22.930 --> 00:20:27.329
>> Stay tuned right here for more
ITIL Intermediate Service Strategy shows.

326
00:20:27.329 --> 00:20:33.254
[MUSIC]

327
00:20:33.254 --> 00:20:36.250
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo look into the different options to sourcing: outsourcing, insourcing, co-sourcing and partnerships.  An organizations needs is rarely met by a single delivery strategy, according to Jo.  She describes the sourcing governance and CFS.
episodes.title: Service Strategy Principles - Sourcing Strategies
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.006 --> 00:00:03.646
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.646 --> 00:00:07.421
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:07.421 --> 00:00:12.405
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:12.405 --> 00:00:15.160
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:15.160 --> 00:00:18.680
You're watching the ITIL
Intermediate Service Strategy Show,

6
00:00:18.680 --> 00:00:20.344
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:20.344 --> 00:00:25.690
Today, we're gonna actually be looking at,
well, sourcing strategies as well.

8
00:00:25.690 --> 00:00:31.440
And here to help us out is gonna
be our ITIL herself, Jo Peacock.

9
00:00:31.440 --> 00:00:32.710
Jo, welcome back to the show.

10
00:00:32.710 --> 00:00:34.720
>> Thanks very much, Ronnie, how are you?

11
00:00:34.720 --> 00:00:35.510
>> I am doing fine.

12
00:00:35.510 --> 00:00:40.015
Now Jo, when we start to take a look
here at sourcing strategies and we're

13
00:00:40.015 --> 00:00:45.520
ready talking about service strategies,
you've got me tongue tied right now.

14
00:00:45.520 --> 00:00:47.530
What are we actually gonna
be talking about, Jo?

15
00:00:47.530 --> 00:00:53.370
>> In all of our previous sections,
we've looked at value creation,

16
00:00:53.370 --> 00:00:58.740
we've looked at the perception of value,
we've looked at what makes up value.

17
00:00:58.740 --> 00:01:03.593
And then we've looked at what makes up
a service, how we define a service,

18
00:01:03.593 --> 00:01:06.367
how we identify who our customers are, and

19
00:01:06.367 --> 00:01:10.640
what market spaces we want to fill,
etc., or exploit.

20
00:01:10.640 --> 00:01:14.420
And then, of course, in the last section
we looked at we turn on investment and

21
00:01:14.420 --> 00:01:17.180
how we actually justify a new service.

22
00:01:17.180 --> 00:01:22.790
Well, now we're looking at how
we source a new service, and

23
00:01:22.790 --> 00:01:24.495
how we support a new service as well.

24
00:01:24.495 --> 00:01:29.640
There's an assumptions so far I guess,
that as a service provider

25
00:01:29.640 --> 00:01:34.050
that we are going to create
of our services ourselves and

26
00:01:34.050 --> 00:01:37.980
then deliver them to the business sales,
but you know what, that's not the case.

27
00:01:37.980 --> 00:01:43.095
And in fact the conversation that we
had earlier on was based on value for

28
00:01:43.095 --> 00:01:48.637
money, return on investment, and
sometimes, well the fact that skills may

29
00:01:48.637 --> 00:01:53.946
lie outside of our environment, and
outside of us as a service provider.

30
00:01:53.946 --> 00:01:57.334
And it might actually be better for
us and more efficient for

31
00:01:57.334 --> 00:02:00.030
us to source these skills elsewhere.

32
00:02:00.030 --> 00:02:03.510
And so that's what we're gonna be looking
at in this section is really just,

33
00:02:03.510 --> 00:02:05.270
when we make these decisions and

34
00:02:05.270 --> 00:02:08.690
what type of sourcing options
we've got available to us.

35
00:02:08.690 --> 00:02:09.290
>> All right, Jo.

36
00:02:09.290 --> 00:02:12.960
So it sounds like a topic that we really
need to understand what's gonna be

37
00:02:12.960 --> 00:02:15.730
the best strategy for our organization.

38
00:02:15.730 --> 00:02:17.180
So where are we gonna begin?

39
00:02:17.180 --> 00:02:18.970
>> Well, we're just gonna look
at the different options.

40
00:02:18.970 --> 00:02:22.400
That's what we're going to do, and
we're just gonna go through these options.

41
00:02:22.400 --> 00:02:24.610
And just really outline at a very,

42
00:02:24.610 --> 00:02:29.580
very high level what would drive
a decision to move to each option.

43
00:02:29.580 --> 00:02:35.110
When we go and we find a, let's say we
wanted to buy a cell phone, for instance.

44
00:02:35.110 --> 00:02:39.340
We would go out and we would, well,
I don't know if you're anything like me.

45
00:02:39.340 --> 00:02:42.240
But I'd certainly,
I'd be researching on the internet, and

46
00:02:42.240 --> 00:02:46.690
I'd be looking to see what handsets
would deliver the best functionality for

47
00:02:46.690 --> 00:02:50.750
me and then I'd be looking at where
I could get these handsets from.

48
00:02:50.750 --> 00:02:54.630
Then, what service provider would
provide me with the best service.

49
00:02:54.630 --> 00:02:59.000
Including things like coverage,
cell phone coverage and

50
00:02:59.000 --> 00:03:04.130
what provider is best in the area that I
live in, also the areas that I travel to.

51
00:03:04.130 --> 00:03:06.590
As well as things like what
about roaming options and

52
00:03:06.590 --> 00:03:11.110
international options cuz obviously you
and I have both got different accents.

53
00:03:11.110 --> 00:03:13.380
We're not from the same place,
and one of us travels,

54
00:03:13.380 --> 00:03:16.540
so I need to have that ability.

55
00:03:16.540 --> 00:03:21.360
And all of those elements to me will
define my sourcing strategy and

56
00:03:21.360 --> 00:03:26.490
they will define where I buy my handset
from or where I lease my handset

57
00:03:26.490 --> 00:03:32.630
from, or
what service provider I actually use.

58
00:03:32.630 --> 00:03:35.600
So, we've gotta get away from
the assumption that we need to do

59
00:03:35.600 --> 00:03:36.750
everything in-house.

60
00:03:36.750 --> 00:03:39.130
We don't need to do everything in-house.

61
00:03:39.130 --> 00:03:43.630
And certainly, when you look at
a lot of our services that we

62
00:03:43.630 --> 00:03:48.440
provide to our organization well,
not all of them are specialist.

63
00:03:48.440 --> 00:03:52.270
And quite a lot of them are very generic
services, such as an email service,

64
00:03:52.270 --> 00:03:52.810
for instance.

65
00:03:52.810 --> 00:03:57.640
It's not a specialist service,
it's not something that we have to

66
00:03:57.640 --> 00:04:01.210
build in-house and
we have to deliver to our business.

67
00:04:01.210 --> 00:04:05.160
In fact, the organization that
builds an email service in house is

68
00:04:05.160 --> 00:04:07.980
probably the one that's very, very unique.

69
00:04:07.980 --> 00:04:09.640
And pretty much an anomaly.

70
00:04:09.640 --> 00:04:13.940
I don't know of any organization that's
actually built their own email service.

71
00:04:13.940 --> 00:04:16.870
Not unless it was an experiment,
not unless there was

72
00:04:16.870 --> 00:04:21.170
an innovative tech company who wants to
come up with a new way of doing things.

73
00:04:21.170 --> 00:04:26.570
We don't generally tend to do that,
and so outsourcing really means

74
00:04:26.570 --> 00:04:31.730
looking at other alternatives
outside of the organization for

75
00:04:31.730 --> 00:04:35.690
the delivery of some of our services,
it's as simple as that.

76
00:04:35.690 --> 00:04:39.710
So when we decide on a sourcing strategy,
we have to decide whether we want

77
00:04:39.710 --> 00:04:44.140
to in-source or whether we want to
outsource, whether we want to go outside.

78
00:04:45.360 --> 00:04:47.460
Think about specialty.

79
00:04:47.460 --> 00:04:51.990
Think about what services we
provide to our organization or

80
00:04:51.990 --> 00:04:56.930
what services they want us to provide and
whether we actually have the skills and

81
00:04:56.930 --> 00:04:59.640
whether it's going to be cost
effective for us to develop and

82
00:04:59.640 --> 00:05:01.840
then support that service in-house.

83
00:05:01.840 --> 00:05:04.840
In a lot of instances,
it's not cost effective for

84
00:05:04.840 --> 00:05:08.900
us to do that, especially when
you think about the fact that,

85
00:05:08.900 --> 00:05:11.980
I mentioned in previous sessions,
we're in the 21st century.

86
00:05:11.980 --> 00:05:13.240
And technology moves so

87
00:05:13.240 --> 00:05:18.740
quickly, if we develop something in-house
will we be able to keep up with that pace?

88
00:05:18.740 --> 00:05:22.200
What happens when our operating
system needs upgrading?

89
00:05:23.400 --> 00:05:28.210
If we have developed
a particular service for

90
00:05:28.210 --> 00:05:32.930
our organization and then we have
to upgrade our operating system.

91
00:05:32.930 --> 00:05:37.690
Well, how soon do we get hold of that
operating system because we then have to

92
00:05:37.690 --> 00:05:41.480
update the actual application
that we've developed ourselves.

93
00:05:41.480 --> 00:05:44.080
So we need to get hold of
the operating system early on so

94
00:05:44.080 --> 00:05:48.450
that we can develop that new
application on a new platform or

95
00:05:48.450 --> 00:05:51.070
the existing application
on a new platform.

96
00:05:51.070 --> 00:05:53.102
And what about increased functionality?

97
00:05:53.102 --> 00:05:57.030
Our end-users expect to see new
functionality in our services almost on

98
00:05:57.030 --> 00:05:59.170
a monthly basis nowadays.

99
00:05:59.170 --> 00:06:01.670
We always expect things to change.

100
00:06:01.670 --> 00:06:04.310
So what about our resources and
our capabilities,

101
00:06:04.310 --> 00:06:09.640
how much do we have in terms of skills and
experience to be able to keep up?

102
00:06:11.250 --> 00:06:13.140
It was probably the norm I would say,

103
00:06:13.140 --> 00:06:18.230
20 years ago as we started to move
away from mainframe services.

104
00:06:18.230 --> 00:06:21.470
We learned a lot of developer skills.

105
00:06:21.470 --> 00:06:26.030
And it was the norm to develop
a lot of services in house.

106
00:06:26.030 --> 00:06:31.090
Whereas now the commercial off-the-shelf
products, well, they're widely available.

107
00:06:31.090 --> 00:06:32.520
And because a lot of these are so

108
00:06:32.520 --> 00:06:36.420
easily configurable, then it's no
longer the norm to develop in house.

109
00:06:36.420 --> 00:06:40.480
And that's considered to be
something of a specialist skill.

110
00:06:40.480 --> 00:06:43.930
And so
therefore not all organizations do that.

111
00:06:43.930 --> 00:06:47.920
And we have to consider all of these
elements when we're looking to outsource.

112
00:06:47.920 --> 00:06:50.570
So look at the questions that we ask here.

113
00:06:50.570 --> 00:06:56.340
Do the services, well if we were
to bring in that service in-house,

114
00:06:56.340 --> 00:06:59.770
would it improve our resources and
our capabilities?

115
00:06:59.770 --> 00:07:02.420
What about our competition?

116
00:07:02.420 --> 00:07:07.870
Our competition building their services
in-house or do they outsource themselves?

117
00:07:07.870 --> 00:07:11.330
So does it provide us as a business
with a competitive edge to

118
00:07:11.330 --> 00:07:12.699
build the service in-house?

119
00:07:13.880 --> 00:07:18.370
And what about interactions with service
providers, other suppliers for instance?

120
00:07:19.800 --> 00:07:25.530
As I've mentioned, if we have to
interact with the operating system,

121
00:07:25.530 --> 00:07:28.950
which we all do, we've all got
an operating system on our desktops.

122
00:07:28.950 --> 00:07:32.650
If we have to interact with them and
that operating system is updated,

123
00:07:32.650 --> 00:07:37.940
then, how do we get access to the early
version of the operating system, and

124
00:07:37.940 --> 00:07:42.670
how do we ensure that our service
that we have built in-house

125
00:07:42.670 --> 00:07:47.820
is upwards compatible and compatible with
new versions of the operating system.

126
00:07:47.820 --> 00:07:49.936
We can't really.

127
00:07:49.936 --> 00:07:54.847
If we take a look at the bottom
part of the slide, you have to ask

128
00:07:54.847 --> 00:08:01.370
yourselves Why wouldn't our customers

But they will also be able to provide you
with demo versions of that software and

357
00:22:08.500 --> 00:22:15.340
If they're a very young company, and
they're willing to be a supplier to you.

358
00:22:15.340 --> 00:22:17.950
Then they're going to
give you a trial version.

359
00:22:17.950 --> 00:22:19.260
And not just a trial but

360
00:22:19.260 --> 00:22:23.510
a trial sort of period of time
where you can test things out.

361
00:22:23.510 --> 00:22:26.500
They're going to work
with your developers and

362
00:22:26.500 --> 00:22:30.340
they're going to give you
opportunity to probably make tweaks,

363
00:22:30.340 --> 00:22:35.050
and actually customize that piece
of software to your requirements.

364
00:22:35.050 --> 00:22:39.180
So, this is a perfect time to be
working with people like that.

365
00:22:39.180 --> 00:22:44.790
Now, organizations that have a strategy of
just running the business I would say that

366
00:22:44.790 --> 00:22:49.620
I wouldn't advice them to avoid
that type of sourcing strategy, but

367
00:22:49.620 --> 00:22:54.150
I certainly advise them to think twice and
think about the viability of that.

368
00:22:54.150 --> 00:22:56.520
But organizations that want to grow and

369
00:22:56.520 --> 00:23:01.590
want to transform most definitely
should be involve here, so

370
00:23:01.590 --> 00:23:04.700
they mentioned here, underneath
where it says managed out source and

371
00:23:04.700 --> 00:23:09.830
it mentions the requirement for a single
interface for all related vendors.

372
00:23:09.830 --> 00:23:16.560
And I did mention that most service
management tools nowadays actually have

373
00:23:16.560 --> 00:23:23.350
service provider interfaces and they will
integrate with well, most of the tools.

374
00:23:23.350 --> 00:23:28.540
And you'll find that a lot of suppliers
are using the same tools that we are.

375
00:23:28.540 --> 00:23:31.240
Which makes it very,
very easy from one perspective, but

376
00:23:31.240 --> 00:23:34.480
from another perspective,
it makes it very difficult.

377
00:23:34.480 --> 00:23:37.420
And we have to think about how
we're going to manage this.

378
00:23:37.420 --> 00:23:41.750
Because the perspective that I'm
thinking of is the security perspective.

379
00:23:41.750 --> 00:23:43.380
Who owns the data?

380
00:23:43.380 --> 00:23:44.720
If we're outsourcing.

381
00:23:44.720 --> 00:23:47.840
Lets say we're outsourcing our
service desk for instance.

382
00:23:47.840 --> 00:23:50.000
Then who owns the data about our people?

383
00:23:51.130 --> 00:23:51.637
Is that their data?

384
00:23:51.637 --> 00:23:55.622
Can they then sell that on to
somebody else for marketing purposes?

385
00:23:55.622 --> 00:23:56.846
Or is it our data?

386
00:23:56.846 --> 00:24:00.608
Because if it's our data it's
sitting on their server.

387
00:24:00.608 --> 00:24:05.391
Think about how we pass calls to and
from that service desk, that service desk

388
00:24:05.391 --> 00:24:09.750
takes a call, it passes it to our
second level of our desktop support.

389
00:24:10.850 --> 00:24:13.160
What's that interface going to look like?

390
00:24:13.160 --> 00:24:16.610
What are the integration
points going to look like and

391
00:24:16.610 --> 00:24:18.804
what about the security implications?

392
00:24:18.804 --> 00:24:22.390
Yeah, we might all be using
exactly the same tool and

393
00:24:22.390 --> 00:24:24.550
that's perfectly feasible nowadays.

394
00:24:24.550 --> 00:24:27.080
We could all be using the same tool.

395
00:24:27.080 --> 00:24:30.860
But, we have to think about how we get
data from one to the other because

396
00:24:30.860 --> 00:24:32.340
we've still got firewalls and

397
00:24:32.340 --> 00:24:37.160
we've still got security implications
here that we have to consider.

398
00:24:37.160 --> 00:24:40.180
And like I said,
what about owning the ship of data?

399
00:24:40.180 --> 00:24:41.750
That's really key.

400
00:24:41.750 --> 00:24:44.760
What are you going to
do with my information?

401
00:24:44.760 --> 00:24:50.670
Everywhere around the world, we have
lost governing data protection about

402
00:24:50.670 --> 00:24:57.320
what you can do to with my information and
what I can do with your information.

403
00:24:57.320 --> 00:25:02.230
So if we're using an outsourced
service desk who happens to

404
00:25:02.230 --> 00:25:05.930
be in a different country,
then whose laws apply?

405
00:25:07.380 --> 00:25:11.190
Is it their laws that apply,
or is it my laws that apply?

406
00:25:11.190 --> 00:25:12.540
Now you might turn around and say, well,

407
00:25:12.540 --> 00:25:16.260
it's my laws that apply because I'm the
customer, but that's not strictly true,

408
00:25:16.260 --> 00:25:21.860
because if the data is sitting
4,000 miles away on a server there,

409
00:25:21.860 --> 00:25:25.900
then actually it's not our laws that
apply, it's their laws that apply.

410
00:25:25.900 --> 00:25:27.920
So all of this has to be considered and

411
00:25:27.920 --> 00:25:31.850
all of this has to be
part of the contract.

412
00:25:31.850 --> 00:25:35.970
And like I said, roles and
responsibilities are very important.

413
00:25:35.970 --> 00:25:38.760
It's got to be water tight
in that contract, but

414
00:25:38.760 --> 00:25:42.220
we're not just talking about laws and
responsibilities with people.

415
00:25:42.220 --> 00:25:46.510
But we're talking about
the responsibility with our data as well.

416
00:25:46.510 --> 00:25:50.250
And that's all part of our
sourcing governance, our policies.

417
00:25:50.250 --> 00:25:54.589
And these are the policies not
by which we're operating but

418
00:25:54.589 --> 00:25:58.420
also the policies by which
we manage our suppliers.

419
00:25:58.420 --> 00:26:00.655
Governance is not the same
as supplier management.

420
00:26:00.655 --> 00:26:04.540
Supplier management is about managing
the supplies on a day to day basis,

421
00:26:04.540 --> 00:26:07.940
whereas governance, well,
that's about control.

422
00:26:07.940 --> 00:26:12.950
That's about setting policies for
how long we negotiate

423
00:26:12.950 --> 00:26:17.680
our contract for,
who actually manages our contracts.

424
00:26:17.680 --> 00:26:22.672
If we're talking about countries, then
who will be managing those contracts and

425
00:26:22.672 --> 00:26:24.057
what policies apply?

426
00:26:24.057 --> 00:26:28.910
What laws in what country
apply to the data?

427
00:26:28.910 --> 00:26:32.730
What laws apply to
the transfer of information?

428
00:26:32.730 --> 00:26:33.780
Okay.

429
00:26:33.780 --> 00:26:37.450
It says here that the governance is the
weakest link in the sourcing strategy and

430
00:26:37.450 --> 00:26:40.840
it is really is because quite often
we forget about having policies.

431
00:26:42.240 --> 00:26:43.170
It's really easy.

432
00:26:43.170 --> 00:26:46.180
I come from a government background and

433
00:26:46.180 --> 00:26:51.670
it's really easy because I can turn
around and say, well you know I'm used to

434
00:26:53.070 --> 00:26:57.420
negotiating contracts for five years
at a time and to go out to tender and

435
00:26:57.420 --> 00:27:01.190
follow the tender process and
that's part of the governance policies.

436
00:27:01.190 --> 00:27:03.400
Those governments policies are there.

437
00:27:03.400 --> 00:27:08.030
They're cast in stone and they got nothing
to do with IT, it's everything to do

438
00:27:08.030 --> 00:27:13.990
with the department and
the fact that we're in government, okay.

439
00:27:13.990 --> 00:27:14.660
That's great.

440
00:27:14.660 --> 00:27:16.130
That's easy for me.

441
00:27:16.130 --> 00:27:21.250
What about those organizations where we
don't have those policies in place and

442
00:27:21.250 --> 00:27:22.930
we don't have that governance?

443
00:27:22.930 --> 00:27:27.220
And the contract that you have with Ronnie
you've negotiated for one year, but

444
00:27:27.220 --> 00:27:31.110
the contract that you've got with me
you've negotiated for five years.

445
00:27:31.110 --> 00:27:34.850
And then what happens at the end of
that one year or that five years there?

446
00:27:34.850 --> 00:27:37.560
How do we re-negotiate or
are you just gonna sign it again?

447
00:27:39.080 --> 00:27:41.670
We need to have very clear roles and
responsibilities and

448
00:27:41.670 --> 00:27:44.360
there has to be clear governance.

449
00:27:44.360 --> 00:27:48.740
IT is about efficiency and effectiveness
and it's certainly not going to be

450
00:27:48.740 --> 00:27:54.370
efficient to have an inconsistent or
an ad hoc way to manage your suppliers,

451
00:27:54.370 --> 00:27:59.800
which is why we need governance because
governance gives us that consistency.

452
00:27:59.800 --> 00:28:03.610
But then we still have to
have suppliermanagement.

453
00:28:03.610 --> 00:28:06.860
Supplier management,
well, that is the process

454
00:28:06.860 --> 00:28:11.550
that will manage those suppliers
on a day-to-day basis.

455
00:28:13.650 --> 00:28:15.960
So what do we have to
achieve with sourcing?

456
00:28:15.960 --> 00:28:19.348
Well, we've gotta meet
the outcomes of the organization.

457
00:28:19.348 --> 00:28:24.432
And we've got to ensure that
we can deliver our services to

458
00:28:24.432 --> 00:28:30.910
the organization in a way that
delivers value that doesn't hinder.

459
00:28:30.910 --> 00:28:34.380
We have to meet utility and
we have to meet warranty.

460
00:28:34.380 --> 00:28:39.690
And we have to do it in a way that is
cost effective to our organization.

461
00:28:39.690 --> 00:28:43.930
Whether that be by outsourcing to
somebody as it says there offshore or

462
00:28:43.930 --> 00:28:49.580
whether that be insourcing and
providing a service in house.

463
00:28:49.580 --> 00:28:53.530
So at this point in time, what I'd
like you to do now is I'd like you to

464
00:28:53.530 --> 00:28:58.210
take a look at the sourcing strategy
exercise that you have in your materials.

465
00:28:58.210 --> 00:29:01.640
And this should take you
around about 30 minutes.

466
00:29:01.640 --> 00:29:02.760
So review, please,

467
00:29:02.760 --> 00:29:07.610
all of the sourcing strategies that we've
just covered and undertake that exercise.

468
00:29:07.610 --> 00:29:11.270
If you've got any questions,
then please come back to us.

469
00:29:11.270 --> 00:29:13.870
We're available by the chat, by the forum.

470
00:29:13.870 --> 00:29:17.118
And I'll be more than happy to help you.

471
00:29:17.118 --> 00:29:21.430
>> All right Jo, well thank you again for
helping us to take a look at this idea of

472
00:29:21.430 --> 00:29:26.230
sourcing and recognizing that the need
may not always be fulfilled by one.

473
00:29:26.230 --> 00:29:29.250
We may actually find out that we have
to go outside our organization or

474
00:29:29.250 --> 00:29:33.900
we may choose to stay inside or
even a blend of both to help us out

475
00:29:33.900 --> 00:29:37.840
to achieve what we really
want to in our service here.

476
00:29:37.840 --> 00:29:41.570
Well, that's a great place to also
sign off for this episode, then.

477
00:29:41.570 --> 00:29:45.020
Signing off for IT Pro TV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

478
00:29:45.020 --> 00:29:46.050
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

479
00:29:46.050 --> 00:29:50.203
>> Stay right here for more
ITIL Intermediate Service Strategy shows.

480
00:29:50.203 --> 00:29:56.635
[MUSIC]

481
00:29:56.635 --> 00:29:59.569
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo discuss strategy management for it services.  Jo describes the purpose and objectives of strategy management.  Then she explains the service management process path: strategy assessment, generation, execution, evaluation and measurement too.
episodes.title: Strategy Management for IT Services

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.220 --> 00:00:01.180
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.180 --> 00:00:03.453
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3

>> [CROSSTALK]

[MUSIC]

5
00:00:07.408 --> 00:00:10.922
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:10.922 --> 00:00:14.820
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

7
00:00:14.820 --> 00:00:18.900
You're watching the ITIL
Intermediate Service Strategy show.

8
00:00:18.900 --> 00:00:20.310
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

9
00:00:20.310 --> 00:00:25.240
And today we are going to take a look at
strategy management for IT services and

10
00:00:25.240 --> 00:00:30.020
here to help us is going to be our
ITIL magnet herself Jo Peacock,

11
00:00:30.020 --> 00:00:31.240
Jo welcome to the show.

12
00:00:31.240 --> 00:00:33.450
>> Thanks very much for
having me Ronnie, how are you?

13
00:00:33.450 --> 00:00:34.620
>> I am doing fine Jo and

00:00:34.620 --> 00:00:40.740
I hope you're doing well too as we get
into the realm of strategy management.

15
00:00:40.740 --> 00:00:45.300
Now, Jo, I understand the idea of setting
a strategy, and even coming up with

16
00:00:45.300 --> 00:00:51.350
a strategy, but strategy management in
itself, how do we manage strategies?

17
00:00:51.350 --> 00:00:52.550
That's a little bit harder.

18
00:00:52.550 --> 00:00:58.840
>> Well you'd just mentioned the idea
of coming up with a strategy and

19
00:00:58.840 --> 00:01:02.500
working towards the strategy and working
with the strategy and the policies.

20
00:01:02.500 --> 00:01:04.460
Well, somebody's got to manage that.

21
00:01:04.460 --> 00:01:05.400
Somebody's gotta do it.

22
00:01:05.400 --> 00:01:10.310
Somebody's got to set the strategy,
somebody has got to deliver the policies.

23
00:01:10.310 --> 00:01:16.340
And somebody's got to make sure that that
strategy is relevant, and that it's valid,

24
00:01:16.340 --> 00:01:21.010
and that it's, well, that we maintain our
alignment with the business strategy.

25
00:01:21.010 --> 00:01:25.336
In previous episodes we looked at the high
level business strategies of running

26
00:01:25.336 --> 00:01:29.348
the business, or growing the business,
or transforming the business.

27
00:01:29.348 --> 00:01:34.639
Well, here in Strategy Management for
IT, we look at how we take that business

28
00:01:34.639 --> 00:01:40.172
strategy and then how we create policies
and strategies that will align ourselves

29
00:01:40.172 --> 00:01:46.280
with the business strategy, but will
also allow us to govern going forward.

30
00:01:46.280 --> 00:01:48.990
>> All right, so Jo,
when we start to talk about that,

31
00:01:48.990 --> 00:01:54.870
that actually sounds like quite a bit to
try and get in this single episode here,

32
00:01:54.870 --> 00:01:58.520
so we might be actually going into,
I'm assuming, some multiple parts here.

33
00:01:58.520 --> 00:02:00.790
So Joe, where are we gonna get started?

34
00:02:00.790 --> 00:02:04.840
>> Well, you're right, this first process
that we look at within service strategy,

35
00:02:04.840 --> 00:02:07.620
we're probably gonna have
a couple of episodes on this, and

36
00:02:07.620 --> 00:02:10.310
we probably are with all of
our other processes as well.

37
00:02:10.310 --> 00:02:14.310
So, if that's okay, there's a lot to
cover in our processes to really,

38
00:02:14.310 --> 00:02:16.930
really understand what our
processes are about, and

39
00:02:16.930 --> 00:02:20.880
to be able to manage and
define our processes.

40
00:02:20.880 --> 00:02:24.120
Then, obviously,
we've gotta get into the details.

41
00:02:24.120 --> 00:02:27.710
So with strategy management
this is where we start.

42
00:02:27.710 --> 00:02:33.690
This is about understanding how we,
in IT as a service provider because

43
00:02:33.690 --> 00:02:38.330
we provided a service, are actually going
to align ourselves with the organization.

44
00:02:38.330 --> 00:02:42.750
How we are going to help the organization
achieve their objectives.

45
00:02:42.750 --> 00:02:48.730
Now notice I say help or assist or maybe
I like to the use of the word facilitate.

46
00:02:48.730 --> 00:02:53.000
Remember the definition of a service, a
service is a means of delivering value by

47
00:02:53.000 --> 00:02:56.750
facilitating outcomes that
customers want to achieve.

48
00:02:56.750 --> 00:03:01.650
So we're not going to achieve
these business outcomes for

49
00:03:01.650 --> 00:03:04.550
our organization, but
we're going to facilitate that.

50
00:03:04.550 --> 00:03:09.410
You know, many many years ago,
20, 30 years ago

51
00:03:09.410 --> 00:03:13.550
IT was seen as something that
happened in the background.

52
00:03:13.550 --> 00:03:18.230
It was something that helped us do
things like manage our finances etc.

53
00:03:18.230 --> 00:03:22.190
And that was okay, 30 years ago.

54
00:03:22.190 --> 00:03:26.780
But now, IT is a part of
absolutely everything that we do.

55
00:03:26.780 --> 00:03:31.717
Do you know that I have even got a toaster
in my home that's Wi-Fi enabled?

56
00:03:31.717 --> 00:03:33.090
>> [LAUGH] A toaster?

57
00:03:33.090 --> 00:03:34.050
>> Right, yeah.

58
00:03:34.050 --> 00:03:34.816
>> Okay.

59
00:03:34.816 --> 00:03:36.850
[LAUGH]
>> I have seen [LAUGH] so many gadgets.

60
00:03:36.850 --> 00:03:39.300
Kitchen gadgets in the home.

61
00:03:39.300 --> 00:03:41.800
And yeah, that are Wi-Fi enabled now.

62
00:03:41.800 --> 00:03:44.500
That you can control with your cellphone.

63
00:03:44.500 --> 00:03:45.410
Let's face it.

64
00:03:45.410 --> 00:03:48.400
The majority of things
that we do in the office.

65
00:03:48.400 --> 00:03:51.000
The majority of things that
our organizations does

66
00:03:51.000 --> 00:03:53.080
are completely controlled by IT.

67
00:03:53.080 --> 00:03:55.215
From getting in through the front door.

68
00:03:55.215 --> 00:03:59.490
All the way through of going to
the machine, the vending machine and

69
00:03:59.490 --> 00:04:02.570
getting a cup of coffee or
getting a can of drink.

70
00:04:03.790 --> 00:04:07.368
Everything we do is controlled by IT.

71
00:04:07.368 --> 00:04:10.767
So of course we've got to align
ourselves with the organization,

72
00:04:10.767 --> 00:04:13.758
because the organization
completely depends on us.

73
00:04:13.758 --> 00:04:17.960
If IT is not there then nowadays
the organization is simply not there.

74
00:04:17.960 --> 00:04:22.450
There's absolutely nothing nowadays
in this 21st century that we can do

75
00:04:22.450 --> 00:04:23.340
without IT.

76
00:04:23.340 --> 00:04:26.710
Even our cars,
you can't service your cars without IT.

77
00:04:26.710 --> 00:04:30.940
Because the first thing that
a mechanic will do is plug it

78
00:04:30.940 --> 00:04:36.240
in when you go to a dealer or
a workshop to get it serviced.

79
00:04:36.240 --> 00:04:40.910
So here in IT,
we really have to or in strategy,

80
00:04:40.910 --> 00:04:45.760
we really have to manage that
relationship with the organization.

81
00:04:45.760 --> 00:04:48.670
And we have to I mentioned in
the previous session about

82
00:04:48.670 --> 00:04:53.570
a having a marketing mindset, and
we have to work with the business.

83
00:04:53.570 --> 00:04:56.820
So that the business understands
our true involvement and

84
00:04:56.820 --> 00:05:01.660
that our business will understands that
we will facilitate their strategy.

85
00:05:01.660 --> 00:05:06.120
But we can only facilitate their strategy
if they tell us what their strategies are.

86
00:05:06.120 --> 00:05:08.240
So, it's really important for

87
00:05:08.240 --> 00:05:13.900
us to take those four Ps that we looked at
in a previous episode, the perspective,

88
00:05:13.900 --> 00:05:18.110
position, plans and patterns and
we take those from the organization and

89
00:05:18.110 --> 00:05:23.030
then we apply them to our services and
to the way that we work.

90
00:05:23.030 --> 00:05:26.620
It's all about making sure that we
are aligned to the organization.

91
00:05:28.240 --> 00:05:33.430
So we will do analysis of both
our internal environment,

92
00:05:33.430 --> 00:05:38.650
here within IT, and also the external
environment in the business.

93
00:05:38.650 --> 00:05:43.110
And that analysis will include
analyzing what we're capable of.

94
00:05:43.110 --> 00:05:45.410
And we looked at that
in a previous episode,

95
00:05:45.410 --> 00:05:49.710
looking at what we're capable of and
the sort of skills that we have and

96
00:05:49.710 --> 00:05:55.000
marrying them to the skills that
the business require us to have.

97
00:05:55.000 --> 00:05:57.520
Well, this is where we do that.

98
00:05:57.520 --> 00:06:02.060
Those exercises that we looked
in the previous episodes,

99
00:06:02.060 --> 00:06:05.350
this is the process that
undertakes all of that.

100
00:06:05.350 --> 00:06:08.680
This is the process that looks
at the business strategy and

101
00:06:08.680 --> 00:06:13.450
