your assessment was a little bit off.

329
00:21:31.772 --> 00:21:34.717
Because now I've taken a look
at our perspective, and

330
00:21:34.717 --> 00:21:37.352
whilst you've analyzed
the external factors.

331
00:21:37.352 --> 00:21:42.225
And the external factors were
such that the industry is fairly

332
00:21:42.225 --> 00:21:47.110
stagnated at the moment and
they need somebody to drive this.

333
00:21:47.110 --> 00:21:51.030
The perspective of completely transforming
the business if not really one that's

334
00:21:51.030 --> 00:21:52.213
going to work right now.

335
00:21:52.213 --> 00:21:56.018
So we're going to look more at growth
within our sector first of all,

336
00:21:56.018 --> 00:22:00.487
because we believe there are market
spaces there that you haven't identified.

337
00:22:00.487 --> 00:22:05.196
So with every single
stage we are able to feed

338
00:22:05.196 --> 00:22:09.660
back into the previous, so as this says.

339
00:22:09.660 --> 00:22:14.335
The diagram on the last page that
we looked at just shows the process

340
00:22:14.335 --> 00:22:17.098
activities for strategy management.

341
00:22:17.098 --> 00:22:22.176
So this assessment is about our current
situation, the generation is about

342
00:22:22.176 --> 00:22:27.827
generating the strategy and the execution
is simply about executing the strategy.

343
00:22:27.827 --> 00:22:31.768
And then of course we
evaluate as part of CSI,

344
00:22:31.768 --> 00:22:37.905
that our strategy is always aligned
to the needs of the organization.

345
00:22:37.905 --> 00:22:42.420
Now at this point in time, and Ronnie
mentioned a little while ago that this is

346
00:22:42.420 --> 00:22:45.142
probably going to be
split into two episodes.

347
00:22:45.142 --> 00:22:48.505
And you're right it is because
at this point in time,

348
00:22:48.505 --> 00:22:51.507
you have an exercise as
part of your materials.

349
00:22:51.507 --> 00:22:55.783
And you have an exercise on
strategy management for IT and

350
00:22:55.783 --> 00:23:01.944
given a specific case study, you're going
to be asked to come up with a strategy.

351
00:23:01.944 --> 00:23:07.370
And that's a strategy for services and
also a strategy for service management.

352
00:23:07.370 --> 00:23:12.034
So a strategy for services is about
identifying market spaces and looking for

353
00:23:12.034 --> 00:23:12.760
services.

354
00:23:12.760 --> 00:23:16.680
To fill those market spaces but
also the strategy for

355
00:23:16.680 --> 00:23:19.361
service management is looking at.

356
00:23:19.361 --> 00:23:24.739
What processes we need to fulfill
those services to deliver

357
00:23:24.739 --> 00:23:29.373
the services that facilitate
business outcomes.

358
00:23:29.373 --> 00:23:32.117
Now as always, I'm available,

359
00:23:32.117 --> 00:23:37.611
we have our forum if you have any queries,
then please let us know.

360
00:23:37.611 --> 00:23:42.531
And I'll be happy to help you with any
questions that you may have, but for now,

361
00:23:42.531 --> 00:23:46.073
I'd like you to take at least
an hour to an hour and a half.

362
00:23:46.073 --> 00:23:50.509
So 60 to 90 minutes to take a look
at that particular case study and

363
00:23:50.509 --> 00:23:52.046
that exercise, okay?

364
00:23:52.046 --> 00:23:55.734
And I'd really like you to do that
in-depth just to get to understand

365
00:23:55.734 --> 00:23:57.012
strategy management.

366
00:23:57.012 --> 00:24:00.697
And when we come back in the next episode,
then we'll carry on and

367
00:24:00.697 --> 00:24:02.774
just take a further in-depth look.

368
00:24:02.774 --> 00:24:05.207
At exactly what you did
in your exercise and

369
00:24:05.207 --> 00:24:07.928
how we move forward with
strategy management.

370
00:24:07.928 --> 00:24:12.446
>> All right Jo, well thank you again for
helping us to understand a little bit more

371
00:24:12.446 --> 00:24:16.709
about this process of strategy management
and getting through it as well.

372
00:24:16.709 --> 00:24:18.799
Remember what we took a look at here,
right,

373
00:24:18.799 --> 00:24:22.432
a little bit at the beginning of taking
a look at the assessment of where we are.

374
00:24:22.432 --> 00:24:26.821
And then of course, the strategy
generation as well as its execution,

375
00:24:26.821 --> 00:24:29.248
but we don't finish with that as well.

376
00:24:29.248 --> 00:24:33.183
We actually do have to go back and
add in some evaluation and some testing,

377
00:24:33.183 --> 00:24:36.682
make sure everything is actually
done the way that it needs to be.

378
00:24:36.682 --> 00:24:40.310
Also take a look at that, make sure
that all that stuff is in your head and

379
00:24:40.310 --> 00:24:43.690
that you're ready to move
forward before moving forward.

380
00:24:43.690 --> 00:24:46.670
That's a great place for us to end
this episode then, signing off for

381
00:24:46.670 --> 00:24:49.870
ITProTV, I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

382
00:24:49.870 --> 00:24:51.130
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

383
00:24:51.130 --> 00:24:55.528
>> Stay tuned right here for more
ITIL Intermediate Service Strategy shows.

384
00:24:55.528 --> 00:25:01.320
[MUSIC]

385
00:25:01.320 --> 00:25:04.831
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo continue with strategy management.  Jo describes the triggers for strategy management.  She also shows where strategy management influences and touch all other ITIL processes and lifecycle phases.  Jo explains the key importance of the CSFs and KPIs for Strategy Management and the challenges and risks.
episodes.title: Strategy Management for IT Services Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:01.240
Welcome on IT PRO TV.

2
00:00:01.240 --> 00:00:06.387
I'm your host-
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.387 --> 00:00:08.384
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.384 --> 00:00:12.196
>> You're watching IT PRO.TV.

5
00:00:12.196 --> 00:00:14.640
>> Welcome to another great
episode here on ITPRO TV.

6
00:00:14.640 --> 00:00:18.683
You're watching the ITIL
Intermediate Service Strategy Show,

7
00:00:18.683 --> 00:00:20.453
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:20.453 --> 00:00:27.110
And today we're diving into a part two
on Strategy Management for IT Services.

9
00:00:27.110 --> 00:00:30.570
And here to help us is going to be our,
let's say,

10
00:00:30.570 --> 00:00:34.045
ITIL Duchess herself again, Jo Peacock.

11
00:00:34.045 --> 00:00:35.210
Jo, welcome back to the show.

12
00:00:35.210 --> 00:00:36.708
>> Thanks very much for having me, Ronnie.

13
00:00:36.708 --> 00:00:40.364
>> All right, Jo, there's a lot for
us to actually think about after we

14
00:00:40.364 --> 00:00:44.655
talked a little bit about the process in
getting the service strategy started and

15
00:00:44.655 --> 00:00:46.123
everything we're doing.

16
00:00:46.123 --> 00:00:47.472
So where are we picking up today?

17
00:00:47.472 --> 00:00:52.576
>> In this episode where we left off
the last episode I asked everybody to

18
00:00:52.576 --> 00:00:59.070
go away and to look at an exercise based
on the strategy management process itself.

19
00:00:59.070 --> 00:01:02.610
Which involved as you see on
the screen there just as a refresher,

20
00:01:02.610 --> 00:01:08.000
the strategic assessment, stresses
generation and strategy execution as well.

21
00:01:08.000 --> 00:01:11.700
And so now what we're going
to do is we're going to

22
00:01:11.700 --> 00:01:15.810
pick up here by looking at
inputs into service strategy.

23
00:01:15.810 --> 00:01:18.650
So what actually starts
off service strategy?

24
00:01:18.650 --> 00:01:22.120
What starts off our
strategy management itself?

25
00:01:22.120 --> 00:01:27.240
Now I looked or I mentioned when we talked
at the beginning of the last session.

26
00:01:27.240 --> 00:01:31.020
I mentioned the fact that we should
be reviewing our strategies at

27
00:01:31.020 --> 00:01:32.810
least once a year.

28
00:01:32.810 --> 00:01:37.600
And we've got up here on our
screen an annual planning cycle.

29
00:01:37.600 --> 00:01:41.060
There's an assumption there that,
as an organization,

30
00:01:41.060 --> 00:01:45.600
you will look and review your
strategies at least once a year.

31
00:01:45.600 --> 00:01:47.990
And you'll make plans for
the future at least once a year.

32
00:01:47.990 --> 00:01:50.940
Now, just because it says an annual
planning cycle doesn't mean it

33
00:01:50.940 --> 00:01:52.940
has to happen at every year.

34
00:01:52.940 --> 00:01:55.040
It could happen every six months.

35
00:01:55.040 --> 00:02:00.000
But it has to be at least annually,
at least once a year.

36
00:02:00.000 --> 00:02:04.950
If it's not at minimum every year,
then your organization is going to

37
00:02:04.950 --> 00:02:09.830
start to fall back in terms
of competitive advantage.

38
00:02:09.830 --> 00:02:14.760
So we will tell you at least once a year
you should be reviewing your strategies.

39
00:02:14.760 --> 00:02:17.680
Now other changes to strategies
come along because of

40
00:02:17.680 --> 00:02:21.810
maybe new business opportunities,
such as mergers and acquisitions.

41
00:02:21.810 --> 00:02:23.750
That's a new business opportunity.

42
00:02:23.750 --> 00:02:27.900
Or maybe the business has identified
a market space themselves and

43
00:02:27.900 --> 00:02:30.480
they want to move into that market space.

44
00:02:30.480 --> 00:02:35.120
If you're in an organization that
is continually transforming.

45
00:02:35.120 --> 00:02:40.120
And then of course new opportunities
are coming along on a regular basis.

46
00:02:40.120 --> 00:02:47.020
So we have to, in IT, we have to be able
to adapt to that on a regular basis.

47
00:02:47.020 --> 00:02:50.060
Quite frequently in some organizations.

48
00:02:50.060 --> 00:02:53.630
And then of course we've got changes
to internal or external environments.

49
00:02:53.630 --> 00:02:55.680
You know, let's not belittle,

50
00:02:55.680 --> 00:02:59.880
let's not put down the fact that
sometimes we move buildings.

51
00:02:59.880 --> 00:03:05.610
Sometimes we might expand and
we might move or open another location.

52
00:03:05.610 --> 00:03:08.080
Sometimes we might close locations.

53
00:03:08.080 --> 00:03:12.670
Internal and external environments are the
things that happen within or outside of

54
00:03:12.670 --> 00:03:19.000
an organization that are not part of
necessarily the business strategy, itself.

55
00:03:19.000 --> 00:03:22.980
But are something that we do
kind of on the side, really.

56
00:03:22.980 --> 00:03:28.230
So as I say, things like opening up
a new location, maybe we reorganize cuz

57
00:03:28.230 --> 00:03:32.505
we're looking to make efficiency savings,
and we're looking for effectiveness.

58
00:03:32.505 --> 00:03:36.030
And maybe we want to make better
use of our skills elsewhere.

59
00:03:36.030 --> 00:03:37.250
These are all internal and

60
00:03:37.250 --> 00:03:40.410
external factors that will
influence our strategies.

61
00:03:42.190 --> 00:03:43.920
So when we define [INAUDIBLE] strategy for

62
00:03:43.920 --> 00:03:48.250
both a new service and for
management of our services as well, and

63
00:03:48.250 --> 00:03:50.920
strategy management,
what kind of inputs do we need?

64
00:03:52.130 --> 00:03:56.630
Well, we need to think about our plans,
both our existing plans and our new plans.

65
00:03:56.630 --> 00:04:01.400
What about what's happening in the outside
world, and these are our research reports.

66
00:04:01.400 --> 00:04:07.050
What's happening in the industry sector
itself and where do we need to be?

67
00:04:07.050 --> 00:04:11.700
And that's part of our perspective and
our position and our plans.

68
00:04:11.700 --> 00:04:13.210
What's happening outside?

69
00:04:14.490 --> 00:04:17.550
Let's not dismiss our suppliers.

70
00:04:17.550 --> 00:04:21.160
Our suppliers don't always
do what we want them to do.

71
00:04:22.390 --> 00:04:24.810
Especially the large suppliers.

72
00:04:24.810 --> 00:04:26.670
And I mentioned in previous episodes,

73
00:04:26.670 --> 00:04:29.680
I said Windows 95 is not going
to be supported forever.

74
00:04:29.680 --> 00:04:33.470
And it's quite possible
that at some point in time,

75
00:04:33.470 --> 00:04:37.580
a supplier like Microsoft is gonna come
along and say hey look, do you know what?

76
00:04:37.580 --> 00:04:41.500
We're not supporting that particular
operating system anymore.

77
00:04:41.500 --> 00:04:44.470
Or maybe a hardware supplier
is coming along and saying

78
00:04:44.470 --> 00:04:49.220
that model of laptop that you've given to
everybody, we don't produce that anymore.

79
00:04:49.220 --> 00:04:52.160
So vendor strategies, supplier strategies,

80
00:04:52.160 --> 00:04:56.330
and their product roadmaps
will have an influence on us.

81
00:04:56.330 --> 00:04:59.640
It's not very often that we
have an influence on them.

82
00:04:59.640 --> 00:05:03.460
It's very, very difficult to turn
around to a hardware manufacturer and

83
00:05:03.460 --> 00:05:06.430
say, well you know what,
I really like that model of laptop, so

84
00:05:06.430 --> 00:05:09.720
I want you to continue making it for
the next ten years.

85
00:05:09.720 --> 00:05:10.930
That's not going to happen.

86
00:05:11.930 --> 00:05:15.540
So, we've got to be aware
that our suppliers will

87
00:05:15.540 --> 00:05:18.160
influence our direction too.

88
00:05:18.160 --> 00:05:21.980
Whether we like that or not and
then what about customer interviews.

89
00:05:21.980 --> 00:05:27.660
In a previous session within service
strategy I mentioned the fact

90
00:05:27.660 --> 00:05:34.060
that when I'm going in and I'm assessing
an organization for strategic direction,

91
00:05:34.060 --> 00:05:38.200
and I want to assess a service
provider for strategic direction.

92
00:05:38.200 --> 00:05:43.380
I will go back to all of our individuals
within our service provider.

93
00:05:43.380 --> 00:05:47.230
And when was the last time you went and
sat with the organization?

94
00:05:47.230 --> 00:05:50.410
When was the last time you
understood the organization?

95
00:05:50.410 --> 00:05:55.940
I will also go and I will sit with
the executives in an organization and

96
00:05:55.940 --> 00:05:59.770
ask them what their
strategic direction is.

97
00:05:59.770 --> 00:06:02.470
And then I'll come back to IT and I'll ask

98
00:06:02.470 --> 00:06:07.830
the board within IT the student group
within IT what the executive direction is.

99
00:06:07.830 --> 00:06:11.160
You'll be surprised how frequently

100
00:06:11.160 --> 00:06:15.580
when I'm doing the strategic
assessment I get two different answers.

101
00:06:15.580 --> 00:06:20.000
Because the executive board and the
organization are going in one direction

102
00:06:20.000 --> 00:06:22.450
but IT think we're going
in another direction.

103
00:06:23.710 --> 00:06:26.870
And so
we do what we call customer interviews.

104
00:06:26.870 --> 00:06:31.395
Business relationship management will help
us with this, but interviews not just with

105
00:06:31.395 --> 00:06:36.380
the customers as in a business unit heads
but also with the executive board as well.

106
00:06:36.380 --> 00:06:39.460
We have to make sure that
we're continually aligned and

107
00:06:39.460 --> 00:06:43.310
as well business relationship management
we've got continuous service improvement

108
00:06:43.310 --> 00:06:46.280
as well that they will help us with this.

109
00:06:46.280 --> 00:06:49.890
So we take the strategic plans
not just from the business but

110
00:06:49.890 --> 00:06:52.090
also from IT as well.

111
00:06:52.090 --> 00:06:56.960
What our existing plans were we
might actually need to change them.

112
00:06:56.960 --> 00:07:02.410
Because those plans that we were
heading towards six months ago,

113
00:07:02.410 --> 00:07:03.740
they might not be right anymore.

114
00:07:03.740 --> 00:07:05.860
They might not be relevant anymore.

115
00:07:07.040 --> 00:07:10.940
We'll also take into consideration
what's in our service portfolio.

116
00:07:10.940 --> 00:07:13.570
Or more importantly,
what's in our pipeline.

117
00:07:13.570 --> 00:07:14.650
So what's in our pipeline?

118
00:07:14.650 --> 00:07:16.870
These are our new ideas for services.

119
00:07:16.870 --> 00:07:18.050
Are they relevant?

120
00:07:18.050 --> 00:07:20.330
Are they what our customers need?

121
00:07:20.330 --> 00:07:24.720
And also, what's in our catalogue right
now, that's part of our portfolio?

122
00:07:24.720 --> 00:07:28.740
And does that need to be retired,
is it still relevant.

123
00:07:28.740 --> 00:07:30.758
We have to ask that question.

124
00:07:30.758 --> 00:07:35.350
And then audit reports, now whether
you're auditing against Corbet or

125
00:07:35.350 --> 00:07:40.790
whether you're auditing against
something like ISO 20000 or ISO 27002.

126
00:07:40.790 --> 00:07:44.049
We'll still take those audit reports and
we will take the,

127
00:07:44.049 --> 00:07:46.265
I don't like to call them failures, but

128
00:07:46.265 --> 00:07:50.892
let's just say the areas where we're not
quite meeting the standard and we'll take

129
00:07:50.892 --> 00:07:55.090
those and we'll say, okay, that's got
to be part of our strategy as well.

130
00:07:55.090 --> 00:07:57.272
If you want to achieve ISO 20000,

131
00:07:57.272 --> 00:08:01.782
then you can't do that if you've got
a particular area that needs improvement.

132
00:08:01.782 --> 00:08:06.566
So you have to make that improvement So
what comes out of strategy management

133
00:08:06.566 --> 00:08:10.640
then are our plans, our strategic and
our tactical plans.

134
00:08:10.640 --> 00:08:15.131
Also what comes out of our schedules,
how often we review our strategy.

135
00:08:15.131 --> 00:08:20.002
Ours tell you at least once a year but
maybe that's not frequent enough.

136
00:08:20.002 --> 00:08:24.057
For an organization that's rapidly
growing, or an organization that's

137
00:08:24.057 --> 00:08:28.495
transforming, I would challenge you that
once a year is definitely not enough and

138
00:08:28.495 --> 00:08:31.730
that we should be looking at
that at least every six months.

139
00:08:32.860 --> 00:08:35.820
What about our vision and
our mission statements?

140
00:08:35.820 --> 00:08:39.040
The vision statement where do we want
to be, and the mission statement,

141
00:08:39.040 --> 00:08:42.980
how are we going to get there,
what about those?

142
00:08:42.980 --> 00:08:47.369
If your mission statement incorporates
the words by being open and collaborative,

143
00:08:47.369 --> 00:08:51.410
then we have to make sure that our
strategies are open and collaborative too.

144
00:08:51.410 --> 00:08:55.890
And we quite often in an organization will
combine our vision and mission statements.

145
00:08:55.890 --> 00:08:58.940
So they will say something
along the lines of,

146
00:08:58.940 --> 00:09:03.400
to become world leaders in our field
by being open and collaborative,

147
00:09:03.400 --> 00:09:07.810
that's our vision and our mission,
how we're going to get there as well.

148
00:09:07.810 --> 00:09:12.820
Well, that has to feature in absolutely
every element of our strategy too.

149
00:09:13.840 --> 00:09:17.780
Because that's not just the vision for
the organization, that's a vision for us.

150
00:09:17.780 --> 00:09:23.600
Even as an external provider, then an
external service provider has to align to

151
00:09:23.600 --> 00:09:28.420
the needs of their customer's organization
and to their customer's vision.

152
00:09:28.420 --> 00:09:33.200
And if an external provider is
very focused on security and

153
00:09:33.200 --> 00:09:39.510
deals in areas of high security, but
they have a client whose vision is to be

154
00:09:39.510 --> 00:09:44.520
open and collaborative,
then that external service provider

155
00:09:44.520 --> 00:09:49.900
will need to consider how they're going to
achieve the open and collaborative nature.

156
00:09:49.900 --> 00:09:54.130
Given that they concentrate
very much on security, and

157
00:09:54.130 --> 00:09:58.250
they have the data of other clients that
they have to be very concerned about.

158
00:09:59.660 --> 00:10:04.040
So all of our policies as well,
how we're going to govern within IT,

159
00:10:04.040 --> 00:10:07.820
that comes out of service strategy.

160
00:10:07.820 --> 00:10:10.880
As well as any requirements
from any new services as well.

161
00:10:12.930 --> 00:10:16.360
So here in this particular slide,

162
00:10:16.360 --> 00:10:20.310
we look at the interfaces
between all of our processes.

163
00:10:20.310 --> 00:10:24.730
Now, there's absolutely no process
that is not affected by strategy,

164
00:10:24.730 --> 00:10:28.850
because strategy tells us
how we are going to govern.

165
00:10:28.850 --> 00:10:32.640
Strategy also tells us our vision and
our mission, and

166
00:10:32.640 --> 00:10:37.270
our vision is what our organization,
and therefore us within IT,

167
00:10:37.270 --> 00:10:40.230
want to achieve and
what we will facilitate.

168
00:10:41.420 --> 00:10:43.078
So service portfolio management,

it's entirely up to you
what it looks like.

394
00:25:39.070 --> 00:25:43.100
We'll tell you,
you have to have strategy management.

395
00:25:43.100 --> 00:25:43.970
Well, of course you do.

396
00:25:43.970 --> 00:25:47.400
Somebody's got to tell you what
the direction is but you know what?

397
00:25:47.400 --> 00:25:51.040
If that starts off as a very simple
word document then we're okay with that

398
00:25:51.040 --> 00:25:55.190
because you've got the process in mind and
you can build on that process.

399
00:25:56.630 --> 00:26:00.260
>> All right Jo, so I've kind of
mentioned one of the challenges there,

400
00:26:00.260 --> 00:26:01.690
where somebody over thinks it.

401
00:26:01.690 --> 00:26:03.060
What are some of the other challenges and

402
00:26:03.060 --> 00:26:05.100
risks that we're trying
to think about here?

403
00:26:05.100 --> 00:26:07.289
>> Well we've got a list
of challenges here.

404
00:26:07.289 --> 00:26:08.315
>> Nice!

405
00:26:08.315 --> 00:26:10.470
>> [LAUGH] And, yeah, so again,

406
00:26:10.470 --> 00:26:13.520
that first one which is exactly
what we're talking about,

407
00:26:13.520 --> 00:26:19.970
is doing it at the wrong level is over
engineering the process, start off small.

408
00:26:19.970 --> 00:26:23.580
When it talks about lack of appropriate
tools, if you start it off small,

409
00:26:23.580 --> 00:26:28.370
you don't need a lot of
sophisticated tools,

410
00:26:28.370 --> 00:26:31.860
you need a Word document,
a PDF document, okay.

411
00:26:31.860 --> 00:26:36.040
Yes, you need document control because
you need know which one is the most up

412
00:26:36.040 --> 00:26:38.730
to date and
which one is the valid document.

413
00:26:38.730 --> 00:26:43.430
But nevertheless keep it simple,
start off small.

414
00:26:43.430 --> 00:26:45.464
You need to have the support
of the stakeholders.

415
00:26:45.464 --> 00:26:48.174
But I will challenge everybody and
I always do,

416
00:26:48.174 --> 00:26:52.442
I will ask questions like what's your
strategy and when I get an answer

417
00:26:52.442 --> 00:26:57.140
well I'm not too sure, I say well okay
what's stopping you from doing this?

418
00:26:57.140 --> 00:27:01.020
Because it will take you maybe
an hour to devise a document that

419
00:27:01.020 --> 00:27:04.980
contains your strategy, okay,
maybe it might take a little bit longer,

420
00:27:04.980 --> 00:27:08.050
it depends on the size
of the organization.

421
00:27:08.050 --> 00:27:11.910
But this is all down to support, and
this is all down to visibility and

422
00:27:11.910 --> 00:27:16.900
we'll tell you to keep it simple and to
ensure that they're visible improvements.

423
00:27:16.900 --> 00:27:19.070
So make something visible.

424
00:27:19.070 --> 00:27:21.830
If you don't create a document and

425
00:27:21.830 --> 00:27:25.930
you don't make the document visible
then you're never gonna get buy in.

426
00:27:25.930 --> 00:27:29.240
You're not gonna get buy in for
something that nobody can see.

427
00:27:30.380 --> 00:27:33.870
And this is how get that
support from our stakeholders.

428
00:27:33.870 --> 00:27:38.390
And sure, when we start off small,
lack of accurate information can

429
00:27:38.390 --> 00:27:42.350
be a challenge but you're not gonna get
people to help you with the information if

430
00:27:42.350 --> 00:27:44.880
they don't know that you're looking for
that information.

431
00:27:46.060 --> 00:27:49.957
So start off small,
get everybody involved.

432
00:27:49.957 --> 00:27:53.897
But then look at what can happen, look at
what can go wrong if we look at the risks

433
00:27:53.897 --> 00:27:56.380
once we've got strategy in place.

434
00:27:56.380 --> 00:28:01.423
Again, it goes back to information, and
about not having sufficient information,

435
00:28:01.423 --> 00:28:05.848
and then, again, it goes back to,
you know, having the wrong strategy.

436
00:28:05.848 --> 00:28:09.160
You know, making sure we're going in
the wrong, in the right direction.

437
00:28:09.160 --> 00:28:11.240
It's a line to the organization.

438
00:28:11.240 --> 00:28:15.550
And I said that right the way throughout
our service strategy sessions.

439
00:28:15.550 --> 00:28:19.890
We have to make sure we are in the same
direction of the organization.

440
00:28:19.890 --> 00:28:22.870
Now the risk of flawed governance

441
00:28:22.870 --> 00:28:25.890
goes back to exactly what
we were just talking about.

442
00:28:25.890 --> 00:28:31.000
About over engineered processes,
you know, if we have

443
00:28:31.000 --> 00:28:35.880
a governance model that is too
prescriptive, that is too rigid,

444
00:28:35.880 --> 00:28:42.480
that is almost very almost dictatorial
then we don't have that flexibility

445
00:28:42.480 --> 00:28:47.530
to be able to bring in new services and
to be able to manage with common sense.

446
00:28:47.530 --> 00:28:49.716
We can't ignore common sense, okay?

447
00:28:49.716 --> 00:28:52.476
[LAUGH] We all need common sense, and

448
00:28:52.476 --> 00:28:57.639
we really do apply this in service
management in ITIL, we have to.

449
00:28:57.639 --> 00:29:01.870
If we don't apply common sense,
if we over-engineer, then we don't have

450
00:29:01.870 --> 00:29:06.047
an efficient process and we're not
going to get the right results either.

451
00:29:06.047 --> 00:29:10.963
>> All right, Jo, well thank you again for
helping us to understand a little

452
00:29:10.963 --> 00:29:16.054
bit more about this idea of strategy
management as well for our IT services.

453
00:29:16.054 --> 00:29:18.723
And we took a look at the idea
of the triggers that we have

454
00:29:18.723 --> 00:29:20.012
to actually think about.

455
00:29:20.012 --> 00:29:24.192
As well as where it influences
all of the other processes and

456
00:29:24.192 --> 00:29:25.954
life cycles along ITIL.

457
00:29:25.954 --> 00:29:30.331
And of course even here at the end
when we talked about the CSFs and

458
00:29:30.331 --> 00:29:33.680
KPIs to think about and
challenges and risks.

459
00:29:33.680 --> 00:29:36.960
There's a lot of material right here for
you to consider as you continue

460
00:29:36.960 --> 00:29:40.980
to move forward with, of course,
service and strategy management here.

461
00:29:40.980 --> 00:29:43.900
Well this is a great place for
us to end this episode then.

462
00:29:43.900 --> 00:29:47.660
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

463
00:29:47.660 --> 00:29:48.790
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

464
00:29:48.790 --> 00:29:52.328
>> Stay tune right here for more
ITIL Immediate Service Strategy shows.

465
00:29:52.328 --> 00:29:59.400
[MUSIC]

466
00:29:59.400 --> 00:30:01.980
Thank you for watching ITPro TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo take a look at the service portfolio.  Jo defines and describes the service portfolio.  She helps us to understand that it is defined in pipeline, catalogue and retired services).  She describes its purpose to to offer the right mix of services in terms of the value to the business.  Jo tells how it adds value to the organization. pipeline to add services.
episodes.title: Service Portfolio Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.250 --> 00:00:03.414
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.414 --> 00:00:03.959
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:03.959 --> 00:00:07.181
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:07.181 --> 00:00:10.831
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:10.831 --> 00:00:15.501
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.501 --> 00:00:20.020
You're watching the ITIL
Intermediate Service Strategy Show.

7
00:00:20.020 --> 00:00:21.530
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:21.530 --> 00:00:26.425
And today, we're gonna be taking a look
at Service Portfolio Management.

9
00:00:26.425 --> 00:00:28.610
It's a lot of words there for us.

10
00:00:28.610 --> 00:00:33.058
And here to help us to understand that
better is gonna be our ITIL Chancellor

11
00:00:33.058 --> 00:00:34.655
herself, Ms Jo Peacock.

12
00:00:34.655 --> 00:00:35.860
Jo, welcome back to the show.

13
00:00:35.860 --> 00:00:36.600
>> Thanks very much.

14
00:00:36.600 --> 00:00:38.964
This service strategy episode,
they're killing you, aren't they?

15
00:00:38.964 --> 00:00:40.700
[LAUGH]
>> They really are.

16
00:00:40.700 --> 00:00:44.337
There's a lot of different things
that we actually have in place here.

17
00:00:44.337 --> 00:00:49.810
So, let's talk about this idea of the
Service Portfolio Management a little bit.

18
00:00:49.810 --> 00:00:54.381
I understand the term service,
I understand the term portfolio, but

19
00:00:54.381 --> 00:00:58.188
how do they fit together,
what are we talking about here?

20
00:00:58.188 --> 00:01:03.271
>> Well, we're talking about at
database at least in its very,

21
00:01:03.271 --> 00:01:10.230
very basic form as spreadsheet of services
that we provide to our customers, okay?

22
00:01:11.800 --> 00:01:14.932
We all have, we all understand
the concept of online shopping.

23
00:01:14.932 --> 00:01:16.194
>> Right.
>> And we go to a store,

24
00:01:16.194 --> 00:01:20.766
an online store and we have a selection
of goods that we choose from, okay.

25
00:01:20.766 --> 00:01:21.610
>> Right.

26
00:01:21.610 --> 00:01:26.030
>> And we click on those goods and it will
tell us, it will give us a definition,

27
00:01:26.030 --> 00:01:31.990
etc., of what it is, and then,
we then can choose based on things like

28
00:01:31.990 --> 00:01:37.120
the cost and the delivery and
any prerequisites.

29
00:01:37.120 --> 00:01:40.210
Sometimes they'll put in there,
well, if you've bought these,

30
00:01:40.210 --> 00:01:41.260
you probably need these.

31
00:01:42.400 --> 00:01:44.810
Batteries not included,
that sort of thing.

32
00:01:44.810 --> 00:01:48.355
And so,
that's what we call a service catalogue.

33
00:01:48.355 --> 00:01:52.520
Well, a service portfolio is
incorporates the service catalogue, but

34
00:01:52.520 --> 00:01:56.490
it's kind of like the service
catalogue with a beginning and an end.

35
00:01:56.490 --> 00:01:57.269
>> Okay.

36
00:01:57.269 --> 00:02:02.025
>> In the service catalogue, what you've
got, and when you go to your online

37
00:02:02.025 --> 00:02:06.650
shopping is you've got a list of goods
that are available for you to buy.

38
00:02:07.870 --> 00:02:15.150
But somebody's got to make that
decision to sell that particular good.

39
00:02:15.150 --> 00:02:18.340
So let's say you were looking for cameras,
for instance, so you were looking to

40
00:02:18.340 --> 00:02:23.510
purchase a camera, somebody somewhere,
at that particular company, has got to

41
00:02:23.510 --> 00:02:29.480
make the decision that we are going to
stop and we're going to sell that camera.

42
00:02:29.480 --> 00:02:32.750
So the first thing that happens is that,
somebody comes up with an idea for

43
00:02:32.750 --> 00:02:34.246
that service, for that camera.

44
00:02:34.246 --> 00:02:37.930
And they say,
I quite like the look of this camera.

45
00:02:37.930 --> 00:02:42.011
So what they do is,
they put that into the database.

46
00:02:42.011 --> 00:02:44.967
And then,
they start to build on that idea.

47
00:02:44.967 --> 00:02:45.817
So they say, okay,

48
00:02:45.817 --> 00:02:48.721
I'm gonna find out a little bit
more information about that camera.

49
00:02:48.721 --> 00:02:53.947
So that's when they add in things
like the dimensions and the size,

50
00:02:53.947 --> 00:02:58.713
the size of the memory,
the size of the actual camera itself,

51
00:02:58.713 --> 00:03:01.870
how many mega pixels it will take, etc.

52
00:03:01.870 --> 00:03:04.930
And then they build on things like
what accessories you can have.

53
00:03:04.930 --> 00:03:08.967
And then it some point in time,
somebody says, you know what,

54
00:03:08.967 --> 00:03:14.146
should we make this live or not, should
we make this available to our customers,

55
00:03:14.146 --> 00:03:16.520
should we offer it to our customers?

56
00:03:17.800 --> 00:03:20.950
At that point in time,
the decision is made, yes.

57
00:03:20.950 --> 00:03:25.720
And so simply what we do is in that
database, we just check or tick a box and

58
00:03:25.720 --> 00:03:28.100
then it's live for our customers.

59
00:03:28.100 --> 00:03:32.039
Now sometimes we don't have any stock of
it, so we'll turn around and say, okay,

60
00:03:32.039 --> 00:03:36.038
then it's gonna be live for our customers,
but it's going to have a release date and

61
00:03:36.038 --> 00:03:39.849
it's going to be live from the 1st
of January 2020, for instance, okay?

62
00:03:39.849 --> 00:03:44.623
So the first part,
is what we call a pipeline, and

63
00:03:44.623 --> 00:03:50.993
the first portion there where
we're thinking about offering that

64
00:03:50.993 --> 00:03:56.353
particular camera for sale,
it's still just an idea.

65
00:03:56.353 --> 00:03:58.940
We haven't evaluated it yet.

66
00:03:58.940 --> 00:04:02.577
But it doesn't make any sense to
keep that in a separate database.

67
00:04:02.577 --> 00:04:06.164
We might as well keep it all in
one database, and then as we build

68
00:04:06.164 --> 00:04:10.768
up the information in that database, then
all we need to do is just simply check or

69
00:04:10.768 --> 00:04:12.959
tick a box to say, yes, make it live.

70
00:04:14.300 --> 00:04:17.110
And then is available for
our customers to buy.

71
00:04:17.110 --> 00:04:21.840
So the first part is what we call our
pipeline, the second part is what we call

72
00:04:21.840 --> 00:04:25.020
our catalogue, and
that whats available for our customers.

73
00:04:25.020 --> 00:04:28.087
And then this is third part of this and
called our retired services.

74
00:04:28.087 --> 00:04:33.430
And these are the services that are no
longer available for the customers to buy.

75
00:04:33.430 --> 00:04:36.274
So at some point in time,
that camera's gonna reach its end of life.

76
00:04:36.274 --> 00:04:39.546
And so,
we're going to uncheck that box and

77
00:04:39.546 --> 00:04:43.000
we're going to change
its status to retired.

78
00:04:43.000 --> 00:04:46.656
In other words,
that it's still kept in that database.

79
00:04:46.656 --> 00:04:51.031
Because we might still need to refer to
its information at some point in time,

80
00:04:51.031 --> 00:04:53.610
like why we decided to retire it?

81
00:04:53.610 --> 00:04:55.295
But it's no longer visible
to customers to buy.

82
00:04:56.434 --> 00:04:58.640
And that's the portfolio.

83
00:04:58.640 --> 00:05:03.480
So the portfolio is a database
that's split into three.

84
00:05:03.480 --> 00:05:06.831
And those three sections are the pipeline,
that's where we have the ideas for

85
00:05:06.831 --> 00:05:07.507
our services.

86
00:05:07.507 --> 00:05:11.439
The catalogue, which is where
our services are enlisted for

87
00:05:11.439 --> 00:05:14.020
our customers to be able to see.

88
00:05:14.020 --> 00:05:21.360
And then our retired services,
which is where services go to be retired.

89
00:05:21.360 --> 00:05:24.580
I was gonna say, where they go to die,
but that sounds mean and cruel.

90
00:05:24.580 --> 00:05:26.690
[LAUGH] So I won't do that.

91
00:05:26.690 --> 00:05:29.570
But that's in our retired services part,
okay?

92
00:05:29.570 --> 00:05:32.902
So that's what our portfolio is,
it's very, very simply, and

93
00:05:32.902 --> 00:05:34.427
this part is simplest terms.

94
00:05:34.427 --> 00:05:38.418
It could be a list, it could be
an Excel spreadsheet, for instance, or

95
00:05:38.418 --> 00:05:42.940
it could be and more likely than not, it's
going to be a database where we keep all

96
00:05:42.940 --> 00:05:45.420
the information about all of our services.

97
00:05:46.460 --> 00:05:50.480
So when we look at the purpose of Service
Portfolio Management, it talks about

98
00:05:50.480 --> 00:05:57.050
allowing the service provider to
offer the right mix of services.

99
00:05:57.050 --> 00:06:02.400
That's what we talk about, we talk about
mix of services to allow the organization

100
00:06:02.400 --> 00:06:07.768
to achieve the business outcomes.

101
00:06:07.768 --> 00:06:11.290
So, Service Portfolio Management
is not just about the pipeline,

102
00:06:11.290 --> 00:06:15.304
it's not just about coming up with
the ideas, but it is also about evaluating

103
00:06:15.304 --> 00:06:18.979
everything that's in the catalogue and
saying at some point in time.

104
00:06:18.979 --> 00:06:21.854
Do you know what,
we sold that for 20 years now,

105
00:06:21.854 --> 00:06:24.125
we don't need to sell it anymore.

106
00:06:24.125 --> 00:06:27.345
We never get any orders in for
that particular model of catalogue, so

107
00:06:27.345 --> 00:06:29.820
we're not going to sell that anymore.

108
00:06:29.820 --> 00:06:32.330
That's what
Service Portfolio Management does.

109
00:06:32.330 --> 00:06:36.615
So when it talks about investing
throughout the lifecycle of a service,

110
00:06:36.615 --> 00:06:39.788
that means that,
we're tracking that investment.

111
00:06:39.788 --> 00:06:44.668
So we're looking right at the very
start as to whether it's a good idea,

112
00:06:44.668 --> 00:06:47.628
and whether it will be a viable service,
and

113
00:06:47.628 --> 00:06:52.800
then once it's in the catalogue,
we monitoring our popularities.

114
00:06:52.800 --> 00:06:56.510
For instance, whether it meets the needs
of the business, and then in some point in

115
00:06:56.510 --> 00:07:02.600
time, we make the decision to
retire that particular service.

116
00:07:02.600 --> 00:07:03.328
>> All right, Jo.

117
00:07:03.328 --> 00:07:05.848
So I like the definition that you gave,
and

118
00:07:05.848 --> 00:07:08.660
I think I understand two-thirds of it,
okay.

119
00:07:08.660 --> 00:07:12.297
So I understand the idea of the pipeline,
making sure that we got that ready to go.

120
00:07:12.297 --> 00:07:14.918
The idea of the catalogue,
the offering that we want, but

121
00:07:14.918 --> 00:07:18.679
why is it important that I keep the stuff
that I'm saying, I'm gonna remove that?

122
00:07:18.679 --> 00:07:21.590
Why is it so
important that I have that there?

123
00:07:21.590 --> 00:07:24.270
Is there something I'm gonna be able to
use that's gonna help me out in the future

124
00:07:24.270 --> 00:07:26.070
or what's the point here?

125
00:07:26.070 --> 00:07:27.240
>> Yes, most definitely.

126
00:07:27.240 --> 00:07:32.758
Now when we look at certain services,
for instance, financial management.

127
00:07:32.758 --> 00:07:36.817
Now every single country, it doesn't
matter wherever you are in the world,

128
00:07:36.817 --> 00:07:39.876
every single country has got
a law in place that says that,

129
00:07:39.876 --> 00:07:43.460
you have to retain tax information for
a certain period of time.

130
00:07:43.460 --> 00:07:45.605
It's usually run about ten years or
something like that.

131
00:07:45.605 --> 00:07:53.170
Now, who do you know that has retained
a financial package for ten years?

132
00:07:54.274 --> 00:07:56.209
Not many organizations.

133
00:07:56.209 --> 00:08:00.033
But if you have to be able to
access that data for ten years,

134
00:08:00.033 --> 00:08:04.720
it's quite possible that your tax
authority could come along and say,

135
00:08:04.720 --> 00:08:09.824
I need access to your tax data from Ten
years ago, or nine and a half years ago.

136
00:08:09.824 --> 00:08:13.925
Now, if you don't have that service
available on your network, you need to

137
00:08:13.925 --> 00:08:18.330
know what it is you need to get hold
of to be able to retrieve that data.

138
00:08:18.330 --> 00:08:19.850
So, that's one reason.

139
00:08:19.850 --> 00:08:23.100
Another reason why we keep that is,
because at some point in time

140
00:08:23.100 --> 00:08:27.383
somebody within the organization, and I
was gonna say, somebody like [INAUDIBLE].

141
00:08:27.383 --> 00:08:27.892
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

142
00:08:27.892 --> 00:08:29.530
>> Might come along and say, hey,

143
00:08:29.530 --> 00:08:30.660
look, you know,

144
00:08:30.660 --> 00:08:36.250
we had this free web mail based service at
one point in time and we got rid of it.

145
00:08:36.250 --> 00:08:40.137
I'd like to go back to using that web
mail based service, because it's free.

146
00:08:40.137 --> 00:08:44.854
At which point in time we can look
back at that and we can say, okay,

378
00:22:40.130 --> 00:22:45.350
what applications we need specifically
to deliver those services.

379
00:22:45.350 --> 00:22:48.560
Now, we also have our Customer Portfolio,

380
00:22:48.560 --> 00:22:53.002
in other words maybe a CRM database,
who are customers are.

381
00:22:53.002 --> 00:22:57.223
And the agreement portfolio which
is where we keep our service level

382
00:22:57.223 --> 00:22:58.715
agreements with them.

383
00:22:58.715 --> 00:23:01.461
Of course we have our project portfolio,
and

384
00:23:01.461 --> 00:23:05.593
our project portfolio is where we
keep a list of all of our projects.

385
00:23:05.593 --> 00:23:10.376
And our service models, we looked at
that in a previous episode, is where we

00:23:10.376 --> 00:23:15.329
understand those moments of truth,
those contact points for every service.

387
00:23:15.329 --> 00:23:17.958
Now, of course, if it's a new service,

388
00:23:17.958 --> 00:23:22.468
you wouldn't have a service model in
place, but we can look at existing

389
00:23:22.468 --> 00:23:27.228
service models to see exactly how some
of our existing services will work.

390
00:23:27.228 --> 00:23:29.950
Now we should also have a database or

391
00:23:29.950 --> 00:23:35.397
at least a register somewhere where
we have our defined market spaces,

392
00:23:35.397 --> 00:23:39.329
where we understand where
our opportunities are.

393
00:23:39.329 --> 00:23:43.315
And, we should have some
form of database or, again,

394
00:23:43.315 --> 00:23:48.428
register that allows us to see which
one of our service assets are being

395
00:23:48.428 --> 00:23:54.432
used to deliver which services, because
we may not use all of our service assets.

396
00:23:54.432 --> 00:23:59.509
You remember our capabilities and our
resources to deliver all of our service,

397
00:23:59.509 --> 00:24:04.832
to deliver all of our services, we need to
ensure that we can map them to each other.

398
00:24:04.832 --> 00:24:05.462
Okay.
So

399
00:24:05.462 --> 00:24:10.408
service portfolio management is about
managing a service and its viability and

400
00:24:10.408 --> 00:24:15.150
its relevance to the business across
the entire service lifecycle, okay?

401
00:24:16.180 --> 00:24:21.191
It represents all of our resources
throughout all of the stages of the life,

402
00:24:21.191 --> 00:24:25.736
through service strategy,
through design, through transition,

403
00:24:25.736 --> 00:24:29.437
and throughout its operation
into retirement as well.

404
00:24:29.437 --> 00:24:33.730
And, of course, any changes are governed
by change of management policies.

405
00:24:33.730 --> 00:24:39.130
So, visually then, what I was talking
about just a little while ago,

406
00:24:39.130 --> 00:24:41.120
here is our service portfolio.

407
00:24:41.120 --> 00:24:42.090
It's a database.

408
00:24:42.090 --> 00:24:44.060
It's split into three.

409
00:24:44.060 --> 00:24:46.169
Our pipeline is where we have our ideas.

410
00:24:47.390 --> 00:24:51.030
Catalogue is where we
have our live services.

411
00:24:51.030 --> 00:24:55.716
And our retired services, well, they're
those services that have been retired.

412
00:24:55.716 --> 00:24:59.382
And we get the information from
the configuration management

413
00:24:59.382 --> 00:25:03.694
system which in turn pulls information
from other data sources as well.

414
00:25:03.694 --> 00:25:06.609
And I think the only one that we
haven't looked at is the supply and

415
00:25:06.609 --> 00:25:09.110
contract management information system.

416
00:25:09.110 --> 00:25:13.120
And well, very similar to our customer
agreement portfolio where we keep our

417
00:25:13.120 --> 00:25:17.660
service level agreements, our supplier and
contract management information system

418
00:25:17.660 --> 00:25:21.870
is where we keep our contracts,
funnily enough.

419
00:25:21.870 --> 00:25:26.473
And all of the performance reviews that
we conduct on our suppliers as well.

420
00:25:28.270 --> 00:25:32.740
So as it says in the bottom here,
the pipeline is fed by the strategy.

421
00:25:34.370 --> 00:25:38.040
It looks at having good service design,

422
00:25:38.040 --> 00:25:43.990
it looks at having continual
service improvement as an input,

423
00:25:43.990 --> 00:25:47.260
in other words we know how our
services are being designed, and

424
00:25:47.260 --> 00:25:51.650
CSI recommends new opportunities for

425
00:25:51.650 --> 00:25:56.640
improvement, and therefore new
services this is potentially, okay?

426
00:25:56.640 --> 00:26:03.910
We also in our service pipeline
will have a, I guess a field,

427
00:26:03.910 --> 00:26:08.600
for want of a better word, I would
use the word field, where we document

428
00:26:08.600 --> 00:26:13.540
not only how much budget we'll need for
any new service but also the expected,

429
00:26:13.540 --> 00:26:19.130
intended ROI, that's what we call the pre
program ROI for any new service, okay.

430
00:26:19.130 --> 00:26:23.390
So our pipeline is our representative
of our overall health,

431
00:26:23.390 --> 00:26:27.500
because it displays what new
ideas we're coming up with.

432
00:26:27.500 --> 00:26:32.020
If we've got nothing in our pipeline, if
we've got no ideas, then that suggests to

433
00:26:32.020 --> 00:26:39.010
me that overall we don't really
know what our services are about,

434
00:26:39.010 --> 00:26:44.640
what our service management is doing and
we don't really understand our business.

435
00:26:44.640 --> 00:26:48.660
If we don't have any ideas to
meet the needs of our business.

436
00:26:48.660 --> 00:26:50.810
Now I've had people that have
turned around to me and said,

437
00:26:50.810 --> 00:26:52.870

ideas in our pipeline,

438
00:26:52.870 --> 00:26:56.510
then that means we're all ready
meeting the needs of the business.

439
00:26:56.510 --> 00:27:00.900
If a business wants to grow and
we don't have any new ideas to help

440
00:27:00.900 --> 00:27:04.430

certainly not meeting their needs.

441
00:27:06.520 --> 00:27:09.475
And of course I already asked

442
00:27:09.475 --> 00:27:12.230
[LAUGHTER] How do we

00:27:12.230 --> 00:27:15.340

come up with an idea.

444
00:27:15.340 --> 00:27:17.020
Absolutely anybody.

445
00:27:17.020 --> 00:27:18.460
It can be customary requests,

446
00:27:18.460 --> 00:27:22.850
it can be under served business outcomes,
it can be new technology.

447
00:27:22.850 --> 00:27:25.840
Absolutely anybody can
come up with our ideas.

448
00:27:27.460 --> 00:27:32.270
So what I'd like you to do is at
the moment we have just taken a look

449
00:27:32.270 --> 00:27:36.440

451
00:27:39.740 --> 00:27:46.820
And I would just like you just to
review these particular notes and

00:27:46.820 --> 00:27:52.740

453
00:27:52.740 --> 00:27:56.090

454
00:27:56.090 --> 00:27:57.620

455
00:27:57.620 --> 00:28:01.480

456
00:28:01.480 --> 00:28:05.900
But in our next episode, we're gonna
be expanding on the service catalog and

457
00:28:05.900 --> 00:28:08.500
also on the retired services section.

458
00:28:08.500 --> 00:28:09.450
Of our service portfolio.

459
00:28:10.550 --> 00:28:14.860
>> All right Jo, well, thank you again for
helping us out in understanding

00:28:14.860 --> 00:28:18.770

461
00:28:18.770 --> 00:28:22.700

as well as our catalog of services and

462
00:28:22.700 --> 00:28:26.880

463
00:28:26.880 --> 00:28:29.630

464
00:28:29.630 --> 00:28:33.240
A great deal of information that

00:28:33.240 --> 00:28:35.980

00:28:35.980 --> 00:28:39.870

00:28:39.870 --> 00:28:43.200
There's a lot more that's actually right

468
00:28:43.200 --> 00:28:46.450

00:28:46.450 --> 00:28:50.480

00:28:50.480 --> 00:28:51.620

00:28:51.620 --> 00:28:56.762

375
00:23:31.090 --> 00:23:36.030

377
00:23:39.980 --> 00:23:44.796

378

every single service in our

380

382

effective within ITIL.

385
00:24:15.780 --> 00:24:19.940

it's certainly never gonna be effective

to have duplicate data
sources with duplicate data.

387
00:24:24.020 --> 00:24:30.240

390
00:24:40.540 --> 00:24:45.100

395
00:24:59.830 --> 00:25:04.393

396

got a link from our service portfolio

the information that we have

more about financial management,

174
00:10:37.940 --> 00:10:41.975
because we are gonna cover that in a
different episode within service strategy.

175
00:10:41.975 --> 00:10:44.065
I am gonna look at service
level Management then.

176
00:10:44.065 --> 00:10:48.445
Because I mentioned here
in the service catalog or

177
00:10:48.445 --> 00:10:52.845
in the service portfolio in the pipeline,
it's the first place where we start to

178
00:10:52.845 --> 00:10:58.495
articulate a particular service in terms
of value delivery to the business.

179
00:10:58.495 --> 00:11:01.455
And in the catalog we're going
to evolve that as we build,

180
00:11:01.455 --> 00:11:04.315
and we test that particular service.

181
00:11:04.315 --> 00:11:09.290
But service level management
will have a input into this

182
00:11:09.290 --> 00:11:13.750
because service level management is where
we negotiate the service level targets.

183
00:11:13.750 --> 00:11:18.195
In other words, the parameters within
which we are going to deliver the service

184
00:11:18.195 --> 00:11:19.466
to the organization.

185
00:11:19.466 --> 00:11:22.830
Now, there's a little bit of
a sanity check here as well.

186
00:11:22.830 --> 00:11:27.027
Because if I'm looking to see where
the service portfolio management is

187
00:11:27.027 --> 00:11:31.513
working efficiently, I'm gonna check
all of my service level agreements.

188
00:11:31.513 --> 00:11:35.249
Because every single service that
have a service level agreement,

189
00:11:35.249 --> 00:11:38.338
well that service should be
mentioned in my portfolio.

190
00:11:38.338 --> 00:11:40.691
And every single service
that's in my portfolio,

191
00:11:40.691 --> 00:11:42.999
well I should have an agreement for
that service.

192
00:11:44.160 --> 00:11:46.020
So, it's kind of just that sanity check,

193
00:11:46.020 --> 00:11:51.390
just to allow me to check that both of
these processes are working together.

194
00:11:51.390 --> 00:11:55.000
That they're both working efficiently and
effectively and

195
00:11:55.000 --> 00:11:57.290
that there is a relationship between them.

196
00:11:58.600 --> 00:12:01.270
Think about security when we're
bringing in any new service.

197
00:12:01.270 --> 00:12:02.890
Of course we have to do that, and

198
00:12:02.890 --> 00:12:08.320
we may have to consider any security
applications over new services.

199
00:12:08.320 --> 00:12:12.768
And of course new services mean
potentially an increase or

200
00:12:12.768 --> 00:12:17.215
a decrease if we are making
a service redundant then we need

201
00:12:17.215 --> 00:12:20.682
an increase in capacity or
in availability.

202
00:12:20.682 --> 00:12:24.570
And of course, any new service that
we bring in has to be part, then,

203
00:12:24.570 --> 00:12:25.990
of our continuity plan.

204
00:12:27.070 --> 00:12:31.250
So, let's move on to critical
success factors, then, the CSF.

205
00:12:31.250 --> 00:12:37.330
Now again, as with every other process
that we have within our episodes here and

206
00:12:37.330 --> 00:12:41.750
within our life cycle phases,
these are just examples.

207
00:12:41.750 --> 00:12:46.694
And the critical success factors that
you will have for your organization may

208
00:12:46.694 --> 00:12:50.813
well be completely different to
the examples that we have here.

209
00:12:50.813 --> 00:12:56.790
And this we mentioned in a previous
episode, it will start off simple, okay?

210
00:12:56.790 --> 00:13:00.770
The smaller the organization, the more
immature the implementation of service

211
00:13:00.770 --> 00:13:05.670
portfolio management is,
well, then the simpler I

212
00:13:05.670 --> 00:13:11.430
expect your CSF to be and
the least number of CSF I expect to see.

213
00:13:11.430 --> 00:13:14.170
So, let us take a look at our
critical success factors then.

214
00:13:14.170 --> 00:13:17.910
Well, for example what we have
here are formal processes that

215
00:13:17.910 --> 00:13:19.940
will decide what services we offer.

216
00:13:19.940 --> 00:13:25.931
So that process that you saw that looked
at the initiation and then define and

217
00:13:25.931 --> 00:13:31.265
analyze and then charter, well,
that particular process I expect

218
00:13:31.265 --> 00:13:37.182
to see some documentation that outlines
that particular process, okay?

219
00:13:37.182 --> 00:13:41.772
And then we want models to
analyze return on investment.

220
00:13:41.772 --> 00:13:44.268
So the KPIs that I'm [INAUDIBLE] that,

221
00:13:44.268 --> 00:13:48.400
the KPIs that will tell us
whether we're achieving that.

222
00:13:48.400 --> 00:13:52.450
Well again, they should be
relevent to your organization.

223
00:13:52.450 --> 00:13:56.930
We've got a CSF here about the ability
to document each service and

224
00:13:56.930 --> 00:13:58.448
the outcomes that it supports.

225
00:13:58.448 --> 00:14:02.870
And again, the KPIs that you see under
here about documented processes, and

226
00:14:02.870 --> 00:14:05.780
services being linked
to business outcomes.

227
00:14:05.780 --> 00:14:11.250
Well yet again,
I am expecting you to articulate,

228
00:14:11.250 --> 00:14:15.010
by way of the KPIs,
whether we have achieved each CSF.

229
00:14:16.940 --> 00:14:21.168
And then look at all the CSFs that we've
got helping out the organization achieve

230
00:14:21.168 --> 00:14:23.070
the objectives.

231
00:14:23.070 --> 00:14:30.110
Every single service in our portfolio
must be listed in terms of the value

232
00:14:30.110 --> 00:14:34.890
that it delivers to the organization and
the outcomes that it facilitates.

233
00:14:35.950 --> 00:14:41.360
So both of those CSFs really refer
to exactly the same thing and

234
00:14:41.360 --> 00:14:43.971
the KPIs do exactly the same.

235
00:14:43.971 --> 00:14:48.655
Now, CSF about the ability to change
the service influence by internal and

236
00:14:48.655 --> 00:14:49.930
external factors.

237
00:14:49.930 --> 00:14:54.897
But that's a CSF based on flexibility and
based on our ability

238
00:14:54.897 --> 00:14:59.630
to adapt our existing services and
adopt new services.

239
00:14:59.630 --> 00:15:04.586
So again those KPIs should
show a demonstration of

240
00:15:04.586 --> 00:15:07.800
our achievement of that CSF.

241
00:15:07.800 --> 00:15:11.500
So even things like customer surveys and
customer satisfaction.

242
00:15:11.500 --> 00:15:15.359
If our customers aren't happy with us,
if they don't think

243
00:15:15.359 --> 00:15:19.989
that we are reactive enough,
then we're not going to achieve that CSF.

244
00:15:19.989 --> 00:15:24.859
And notice, by the way, when we went back
and we looked at that particular process

245
00:15:24.859 --> 00:15:27.613
itself, you'll notice
that the triggers and

246
00:15:27.613 --> 00:15:30.450
the inputs came from a lot
of different places.

247
00:15:31.620 --> 00:15:34.820
So, I don't expect all of our ideas for

248
00:15:34.820 --> 00:15:38.170
new services to come
from the organization.

249
00:15:38.170 --> 00:15:42.932
And in fact, I expect us to be more
proactive at recommending ideas for

250
00:15:42.932 --> 00:15:46.903
new services,
then being reactive to the organization.

251
00:15:46.903 --> 00:15:50.958
We have to be reactive,
we have to respond to them, but

252
00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:53.701
we also should be proactive as well.

253
00:15:53.701 --> 00:15:57.084
So we should have tools that
allow us to track our investment.

254
00:15:57.084 --> 00:16:01.860
And again, the KPIs underpinning
that will concentrate on finances,

255
00:16:01.860 --> 00:16:06.717
concentrate on return on investment,
and concentrate on budgeting and

256
00:16:06.717 --> 00:16:09.600
accounting for each service.

257
00:16:09.600 --> 00:16:13.855
And then we really do need to have,
out of all of our CSFs,

258
00:16:13.855 --> 00:16:18.907
we need to have a CSF that's going
to allow us to assess the ability or

259
00:16:18.907 --> 00:16:21.319
the viability of our services.

260
00:16:21.319 --> 00:16:25.794
In other words, whether our
services are still relevant, and

261
00:16:25.794 --> 00:16:31.540
continual service improvement relies on
that CSF in this particular instance,

262
00:16:31.540 --> 00:16:33.750
for this particular service.

263
00:16:35.540 --> 00:16:38.460
So what is it then that
we have to achieve?

264
00:16:38.460 --> 00:16:44.252
What do we have to overcome in order to
implement service portfolio management?

265
00:16:44.252 --> 00:16:45.781
Well, if you notice,

266
00:16:45.781 --> 00:16:50.530
what we have in these challenges
are a lack of formal approaches.

267
00:16:50.530 --> 00:16:53.375
And without a formal
approach to any process,

268
00:16:53.375 --> 00:16:58.590
whether it be change or project
managements or portfolio managements,

269
00:16:58.590 --> 00:17:03.390
without a formal approach then
it's going to be difficult for

270
00:17:03.390 --> 00:17:11.120
us to assess in a consistent way the
viability and relevance of new services.

271
00:17:11.120 --> 00:17:13.560
We also have a lack of
customer information here.

272
00:17:13.560 --> 00:17:16.600
And I will tell you that business
relationship management has a lot

273
00:17:16.600 --> 00:17:18.000
to play into this.

274
00:17:18.000 --> 00:17:23.220
And business relationship management
is going to be key in providing

275
00:17:23.220 --> 00:17:28.480
that customer information and also the
business information on the strategy and

276
00:17:28.480 --> 00:17:31.040
what the business is trying to achieve.

277
00:17:31.040 --> 00:17:35.080
Because it's by understanding
business outcomes that we

278
00:17:35.080 --> 00:17:39.440
are then able to define services
to meet those outcomes.

279
00:17:40.520 --> 00:17:45.257
And just be careful, we shouldn't be
making decisions to implement new

280
00:17:45.257 --> 00:17:49.307
services without understanding
the complete information.

281
00:17:49.307 --> 00:17:53.747
And that's not just about what
the service is supposed to do, but

282
00:17:53.747 --> 00:17:57.313
also about what outcome
it's supposed to fulfill.

283
00:17:57.313 --> 00:18:01.158
There's a big difference between
the functionality of a service and

284
00:18:01.158 --> 00:18:03.344
what the service is supposed to do, and

285
00:18:03.344 --> 00:18:06.141
the business outcome that
we need to facilitate.

286
00:18:06.141 --> 00:18:10.217
Because you see the business outcome
that we need to facilitate might

287
00:18:10.217 --> 00:18:15.750
not actually match what that particular
service or particular application does.

288
00:18:15.750 --> 00:18:17.800
So be very careful,
we've got to think about both.

289
00:18:18.810 --> 00:18:21.550
And we've also got to think about how
we're going to measure each service.

290
00:18:21.550 --> 00:18:25.002
When we bring a new service
into the environment,

291
00:18:25.002 --> 00:18:30.262
you gotta be able to measure whether
it works and whether it delivers value,

292
00:18:30.262 --> 00:18:35.110
and whether it is going to carry on
delivering value in an ongoing basis

293
00:18:35.110 --> 00:18:38.913
through however long the life
of that service will be.

294
00:18:38.913 --> 00:18:43.908
And one more point I want to mention
about bringing in any new service,

295
00:18:43.908 --> 00:18:48.734
is that when we bring in any new service
we must have an idea of how long

296
00:18:48.734 --> 00:18:53.180
that service is going to be
in our live environment for.

297
00:18:53.180 --> 00:18:56.670
In other words,
the expected life of that service.

298
00:18:56.670 --> 00:18:59.170
I'm not expecting us to be
accurate at that point in time.

299
00:18:59.170 --> 00:19:02.340
I'm not expecting us to turn around and
say, right, we're gonna have this

300
00:19:02.340 --> 00:19:06.680
service for five years and then that's it,
after five years it's going.

301
00:19:06.680 --> 00:19:08.172
I expect us to have some idea.

302
00:19:08.172 --> 00:19:10.880
Is it one that's going to
be around indefinitely?

303
00:19:10.880 --> 00:19:14.615
Or is it a service that's
going to require upgrades and

304
00:19:14.615 --> 00:19:18.846
updates on a frequent basis,
maybe every six months, okay?

305
00:19:18.846 --> 00:19:22.104
I expect us to know when
we bring in a new service,

306
00:19:22.104 --> 00:19:26.230
what the anticipated life
span of that service is.

307
00:19:26.230 --> 00:19:29.264
Let's face it, we all go out and
we buy a new phone every year.

308
00:19:29.264 --> 00:19:32.037
And we now know that we expect
it to last us a year, and

309
00:19:32.037 --> 00:19:35.960
after a year we wanna trade it in and
we wanna get a new one, okay?

310
00:19:35.960 --> 00:19:40.710
We all have that in mind, we need to
do exactly the same with our services.

311
00:19:41.970 --> 00:19:42.521
>> All right, Jo.

312
00:19:42.521 --> 00:19:47.176
Well, thank you again for helping us
here understand more about, of course,

313
00:19:47.176 --> 00:19:51.620
the service portfolio management when
we talked about the triggers that we

314
00:19:51.620 --> 00:19:56.345
actually need to take a look at here, as
well as the critical success factors and

315
00:19:56.345 --> 00:19:57.590
the KPIs, too.

316
00:19:57.590 --> 00:20:01.850
And then lastly, the challenges and
risks that we have to also face, too.

317
00:20:01.850 --> 00:20:05.100
Well, that's a great place for
us to sign off for this episode.

318
00:20:05.100 --> 00:20:08.150
For ITProTV, I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

319
00:20:08.150 --> 00:20:09.220
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

320
00:20:09.220 --> 00:20:13.461
>> Stay tuned right here for
more ITIL Intermediate Strategy shows.

321
00:20:13.461 --> 00:20:19.318
[MUSIC]

322
00:20:19.318 --> 00:20:22.642
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo discuss financial management for IT services.  Jo helps us to understand that we must justify the value to the business that IT service gives to the company.  She also describes the objects, scope, values and policies associated.  Lastly, she looks at spending.
episodes.title: Financial Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.250 --> 00:00:02.092
Welcome to ITPro.TV.

2
00:00:02.092 --> 00:00:06.743
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.743 --> 00:00:08.615
[MUSIC]

00:00:08.615 --> 00:00:11.669

>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:14.759 --> 00:00:19.260
You're watching the ITIL
Intermediate Service Strategy Show.

7
00:00:19.260 --> 00:00:20.800
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and

8
00:00:20.800 --> 00:00:24.480
today we're gonna be taking
a look at financial management.

9
00:00:24.480 --> 00:00:27.370
And here to help us out is gonna be, well,

00:00:27.370 --> 00:00:31.020
I'm gonna cal her the ITIL queen

11
00:00:31.020 --> 00:00:31.870
Jo, welcome back to the show.

12
00:00:31.870 --> 00:00:33.054
[LAUGH]
>> Thank you, Ronnie.

13
00:00:33.054 --> 00:00:35.084
Wow, I've had some names.

14
00:00:35.084 --> 00:00:36.300
Don't know what to say.

15
00:00:36.300 --> 00:00:38.339
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Jo,

16
00:00:38.339 --> 00:00:41.884
we're moving into this realm
of financial management.

17
00:00:41.884 --> 00:00:45.100
It doesn't really seem to fit very well,
Jo.

18
00:00:45.100 --> 00:00:46.570
I'm an IT guy.

19
00:00:46.570 --> 00:00:48.920
I like doing the stuff that I like doing.

20
00:00:48.920 --> 00:00:53.070
But finances, I kind of think
that belongs to somebody else.

21
00:00:53.070 --> 00:00:55.303
So Jo help us out here.

22
00:00:55.303 --> 00:00:57.050
>> Well, and that's the problem Ronnie.

23
00:00:57.050 --> 00:00:58.630
That's exactly the problem.

24
00:00:58.630 --> 00:01:00.059
Here we are in IT, okay?

25
00:01:00.059 --> 00:01:03.591
And I don't of anyone in
IT that likes finances.

26
00:01:03.591 --> 00:01:05.705
Now, I know everybody in IT likes money.

27
00:01:05.705 --> 00:01:08.340
[LAUGH]
>> We love it.

28
00:01:08.340 --> 00:01:11.361
>> Yeah,
we all like to have it in our accounts and

29
00:01:11.361 --> 00:01:16.022
even at work, we all like to have it
to spend We don't like managing it.

30
00:01:16.022 --> 00:01:19.270
And we brought in financial management as,
well,

31
00:01:19.270 --> 00:01:23.292
just wanna line the fact that
we've gotta manage our budgets.

32
00:01:23.292 --> 00:01:25.439
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] We don't have a bottomless

33
00:01:25.439 --> 00:01:29.170
pit of money to spend and
we've got to manage our budgets somehow.

34
00:01:29.170 --> 00:01:31.400
But it's not just about
managing our budgets.

35
00:01:31.400 --> 00:01:36.820
It's also about that common sense factor
of being able to justify why we're here.

36
00:01:38.120 --> 00:01:43.380
Most organizations around the world are
here because they want to make a profit.

37
00:01:43.380 --> 00:01:46.137
If it's a government organization,
which is where ITIL came from.

38
00:01:46.137 --> 00:01:47.840
ITIL came from the government.

39
00:01:47.840 --> 00:01:51.560
And in a government organization, we want
to be able to justify that we're making

40
00:01:51.560 --> 00:01:55.340
the most efficient and
impartial use of taxpayer's money.

41
00:01:55.340 --> 00:01:57.170
Again, it's back down to money.

42
00:01:57.170 --> 00:02:02.520
So we have to be able to justify
that there is a quantifiable value

43
00:02:02.520 --> 00:02:04.820
in the services that we provide.

44
00:02:04.820 --> 00:02:08.360
So whether we like it or not,
we can't run away from it.

45
00:02:08.360 --> 00:02:10.640
We've got to manage our money.

46
00:02:10.640 --> 00:02:15.030
>> All right, so when we start taking,
we got it from a perspective of ITIL then.

47
00:02:15.030 --> 00:02:18.410
Once again,
knowing that it's not really prescriptive,

48
00:02:18.410 --> 00:02:23.010
how does ITIL really help us out here
in this financial management then?

49
00:02:23.010 --> 00:02:25.940
>> Well, I'm glad you mentioned that it's
not prescriptive, but it's not just that.

50
00:02:25.940 --> 00:02:30.473
You see, your organization, and
I mean, every single organization,

51
00:02:30.473 --> 00:02:35.083
all the way around the world,
has completely different perspectives and

52
00:02:35.083 --> 00:02:39.116
a completely different view on
how they manage their finances.

53
00:02:39.116 --> 00:02:43.537
And when we looked in previous episodes
at the perspective of the organization,

54
00:02:43.537 --> 00:02:48.284
the strategy of the organization, is it to
run the business like a not-for-profit or

55
00:02:48.284 --> 00:02:50.230
a government organization?

56
00:02:50.230 --> 00:02:53.360
Or to grow the business or
even to transform the business?

57
00:02:53.360 --> 00:02:57.091
Every single organization everywhere
around the world has a completely

58
00:02:57.091 --> 00:02:59.174
different way of managing their money.

59
00:02:59.174 --> 00:03:04.634
And therefore in IT every single
organization, every single service

60
00:03:04.634 --> 00:03:11.520
provider has to be able to justify how we
spend our money in a different way, okay?

61
00:03:11.520 --> 00:03:15.350
And we do this in alignment
with the organization.

62
00:03:15.350 --> 00:03:19.228
The organization is gonna tell
us how to account for our money.

63
00:03:19.228 --> 00:03:22.760
The organization is gonna tell us how
much money we've got to spend and

64
00:03:22.760 --> 00:03:27.130
it really is down to us to just justify
the money that we are spending.

65
00:03:27.130 --> 00:03:30.680
And there is no right or
wrong way of doing this.

66
00:03:30.680 --> 00:03:33.910
I'm gonna give you some principles
over the next couple of episodes,

67
00:03:33.910 --> 00:03:35.640
this episode and the next.

68
00:03:35.640 --> 00:03:37.420
I'm going to give you some principles.

69
00:03:37.420 --> 00:03:41.100
I'm going to throw some
terminology at you as well.

70
00:03:41.100 --> 00:03:44.000
And I'm really just gonna give
you the basics for finance.

71
00:03:44.000 --> 00:03:49.590
But I know, okay, you're in good hands
here, cuz I know I'm an IT person too.

72
00:03:49.590 --> 00:03:52.373
Nobody likes to deal with finance.

73
00:03:52.373 --> 00:03:53.363
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

74
00:03:53.363 --> 00:03:56.303
one of the first things that we'll tell
you when it comes to financial management,

75
00:03:56.303 --> 00:03:58.830
is actually we've gotta find somebody
with the right level of skills.

76
00:03:59.870 --> 00:04:00.690
That's a big challenge.

77
00:04:01.800 --> 00:04:03.280
You don't like finances.

78
00:04:03.280 --> 00:04:05.260
>> Right.
