then that's also $500 for the five years'
worth of support that you're going to get.

311
00:17:49.954 --> 00:17:51.677
That's also $500 for

312
00:17:51.677 --> 00:17:57.070
all of the licenses of all of the services
that we're putting onto that PC.

313
00:17:57.070 --> 00:17:59.885
And then that's also another 250 for

314
00:17:59.885 --> 00:18:03.783
all of the build time that
we've taken to build that PC.

315
00:18:03.783 --> 00:18:06.960
We're not very good at articulating that.

316
00:18:06.960 --> 00:18:09.790
This is why we have to
have financial management.

317
00:18:09.790 --> 00:18:13.800
Otherwise, the perception can be,
and it is for

318
00:18:13.800 --> 00:18:19.810
the most part, that the organization
is paying too much for IT.

319
00:18:19.810 --> 00:18:22.840
But, we're not very good at
articulating the cost breakdown,

320
00:18:24.230 --> 00:18:28.490
which is why we have to have an agreed
framework if we're going to recover costs.

321
00:18:28.490 --> 00:18:32.660
If we're not going to recover costs, we
still have to have an agreed framework for

322
00:18:32.660 --> 00:18:35.020
what we call accounting.

323
00:18:35.020 --> 00:18:37.105
In other words,
tracking where the money is spent.

324
00:18:37.105 --> 00:18:41.341
Because we don't transfer
specific costs and

325
00:18:41.341 --> 00:18:46.780
in some instances,
we don't work out the specific costs.

326
00:18:47.800 --> 00:18:52.210
Because look how difficult it was and
there's only two of us in this room.

327
00:18:52.210 --> 00:18:56.671
And yet look how difficult it was to
work out specific costs for one service.

328
00:18:56.671 --> 00:19:01.510
And yet, there's only two of us with
five services and that was difficult.

329
00:19:01.510 --> 00:19:09.100
Now, imagine when you've got 20,000 users,
and you've got 132 services, for example.

330
00:19:09.100 --> 00:19:11.020
Then it gets difficult,

331
00:19:11.020 --> 00:19:15.180
which is why we need somebody with
those specialist skills to help us.

332
00:19:15.180 --> 00:19:19.860
Now, underneath charging, you've got we
call recovery models or charging models.

333
00:19:21.340 --> 00:19:24.679
And charging is cost, cost +,
market rate, or going rate.

334
00:19:24.679 --> 00:19:28.764
And what that basically
means is that if we charge,

335
00:19:28.764 --> 00:19:34.278
I might choose to charge just a nominal
fee to Ronnie for the service.

336
00:19:34.278 --> 00:19:36.704
I might charge him at cost.

337
00:19:36.704 --> 00:19:41.941
I might charge him at cost +, which
means adding a percentage on to cover,

338
00:19:41.941 --> 00:19:46.860
sort of the variables,
things like the electricity, for instance.

339
00:19:46.860 --> 00:19:51.090
I don't know how much he's going to use
next month, so I might charge at cost +.

340
00:19:51.090 --> 00:19:53.830
And I put on a percentage uplift,
as we call it,

341
00:19:53.830 --> 00:19:58.990
to transfer a cost to Ronnie, so
that I can recover that money back.

342
00:19:58.990 --> 00:20:03.660
And make sure I cover the fact that he
might be using that PC 24 hours a day and

343
00:20:03.660 --> 00:20:06.300
then using up all the electricity.

344
00:20:06.300 --> 00:20:09.510
We also might charge at market rate or
a going rate.

345
00:20:10.590 --> 00:20:13.820
You can charge at cost- as well.

346
00:20:13.820 --> 00:20:16.982
And you can charge just a nominal fee,
which is what I agreed to do.

347
00:20:16.982 --> 00:20:21.339
That was my recovery model
that I agreed with Ronnie.

348
00:20:22.600 --> 00:20:28.090
Where charging is more appropriate
is with our external customers.

349
00:20:28.090 --> 00:20:31.880
With an internal customer,
not necessarily appropriate.

350
00:20:31.880 --> 00:20:36.750
Although we still have to be able to
articulate how much money we spent on

351
00:20:36.750 --> 00:20:40.240
our services, we don't always
necessarily want to charge.

352
00:20:40.240 --> 00:20:44.173
But with our external customers, and
especially in environments where we've got

353
00:20:44.173 --> 00:20:47.898
a mixture of both external and internal
customers, then we will be charging.

354
00:20:47.898 --> 00:20:52.275
Which means that the charging
model has to be worked out and

355
00:20:52.275 --> 00:20:56.250
agreed for
exactly how we're going to charge.

356
00:20:56.250 --> 00:21:01.240
And don't forget there are two types of
cost, as far as your customer is concerned

357
00:21:01.240 --> 00:21:06.170
it's the cost to them,
and then the cost to you.

358
00:21:06.170 --> 00:21:10.179
So I might have paid $500 for this PC, but

359
00:21:10.179 --> 00:21:13.914
I'm gonna charge Ronnie $2,000.

360
00:21:13.914 --> 00:21:19.540
So the cost to me is $500 but
the cost to him is 2,000,

361
00:21:19.540 --> 00:21:24.040
and I have to be able to justify
why there is a difference there.

362
00:21:24.040 --> 00:21:25.980
Which is why, as it says in the bottom,

363
00:21:25.980 --> 00:21:29.960
absolutely everything that I've said
up till now, is the fact that we have

364
00:21:29.960 --> 00:21:34.790
to have somebody with the appropriate
skills to be able to do this.

365
00:21:36.840 --> 00:21:39.646
So obviously,
the value to the business here, well,

366
00:21:39.646 --> 00:21:42.033
it's about being financially responsible.

367
00:21:42.033 --> 00:21:46.647
But it's also about understanding
how much money IT costs, and

368
00:21:46.647 --> 00:21:52.390
it enables us to make better decisions,
certainly within our business cases.

369
00:21:53.990 --> 00:21:57.290
So enterprise financial management
is what I've already said,

370
00:21:57.290 --> 00:22:00.225
this is to do with the organization.

371
00:22:00.225 --> 00:22:05.350
And we've already mentioned these,
what CIs are considered to be assets?

372
00:22:05.350 --> 00:22:09.370
How we work out, how we calculate
depreciation, for instance.

373
00:22:09.370 --> 00:22:14.407
How we report on costs and
how we charge if we are going to charge.

374
00:22:14.407 --> 00:22:17.964
Think about, though, the bottom bullet
point about regulatory requirements there.

375
00:22:17.964 --> 00:22:23.060
And that sometimes, we have regulatory
requirements if we work in highly

376
00:22:23.060 --> 00:22:29.144
controlled industries, such as financial
industry or maybe in the medical industry,

377
00:22:29.144 --> 00:22:34.090
then we may have to account for
certain costs in a certain way.

378
00:22:34.090 --> 00:22:39.220
Now, also think about disposal and
disposal of equipment, in a lot of

379
00:22:39.220 --> 00:22:43.910
countries around the world, now we
have laws to do with recycling, etc.

380
00:22:43.910 --> 00:22:46.435
And it's not sufficient just to say okay,

381
00:22:46.435 --> 00:22:50.517
that particular piece of hardware
has depreciated down to zero now.

382
00:22:50.517 --> 00:22:54.786
Now, I'm able to go and
buy a new piece of hardware,

383
00:22:54.786 --> 00:23:00.840
I still have to then pay to have
that old piece of hardware recycled.

384
00:23:00.840 --> 00:23:06.950
So all of those have to be factors
into your finance framework,

385
00:23:06.950 --> 00:23:10.270
and that will become part of,
the recycling policy, for instance,

386
00:23:10.270 --> 00:23:13.230
will become part of your
enterprise financial management.

387
00:23:13.230 --> 00:23:16.965
Because that applies to fridges,
and cookers,

388
00:23:16.965 --> 00:23:22.820
in exactly the same as it applies to PCs,
laptops, and servers as well.

389
00:23:24.500 --> 00:23:28.957
So think about how we get money
in then from our organization.

390
00:23:28.957 --> 00:23:34.379
And sometimes, as I've already mentioned,
we'll get our money indirectly

391
00:23:34.379 --> 00:23:40.260
from our external customer and that's
what we consider to be external funded.

392
00:23:40.260 --> 00:23:43.170
So that's revenue
generated from selling and

393
00:23:43.170 --> 00:23:48.650
then there's internal funding which is how
a lot of us get our funding to be honest.

394
00:23:48.650 --> 00:23:52.600
The organization will allocate
us with a budget, and

395
00:23:52.600 --> 00:23:56.050
then we may get budget for
individual projects.

396
00:23:56.050 --> 00:23:59.340
We may just get an overall IT budget.

397
00:23:59.340 --> 00:24:01.334
That's down to your organization and

398
00:24:01.334 --> 00:24:04.583
down to the agreements that you
have with your organization.

399
00:24:04.583 --> 00:24:09.461
Most organizations adopt a fairly common
practice of internal funding where

400
00:24:09.461 --> 00:24:13.287
a budget is given, and
then an additional budget is given for

401
00:24:13.287 --> 00:24:18.239
new projects You have to bear in mind that
when an additional budget is given for

402
00:24:18.239 --> 00:24:24.010
new projects, eventually, that new service
is going to become business as usual.

403
00:24:24.010 --> 00:24:27.940
So we need to incorporate
an additional operating budget for

404
00:24:27.940 --> 00:24:33.060
that new service in our future budgets.

405
00:24:33.060 --> 00:24:39.080
Then we've got a rolling plan funding,
which is just basically as one cycle ends,

406
00:24:39.080 --> 00:24:44.970
then as it says, another begins, so
we just get funding on a regular basis.

407
00:24:44.970 --> 00:24:49.610
We get trigger-based funding, which as
I've said, is the project type funding,

408
00:24:49.610 --> 00:24:53.200
so as a project starts,
we get funding for that project.

409
00:24:53.200 --> 00:24:57.871
But remember, that then as the project
moves into business as usual,

410
00:24:57.871 --> 00:25:00.967
we have to move into
the rolling plan funding.

411
00:25:00.967 --> 00:25:03.475
And then we've got zero based funding.

412
00:25:03.475 --> 00:25:08.102
And zero based funding is where
we give in a budget that is only

413
00:25:08.102 --> 00:25:12.571
allocated to cover the costs
of delivery of the services.

414
00:25:12.571 --> 00:25:16.832
And we should get down to zero at
the end of that funding cycle, and

415
00:25:16.832 --> 00:25:22.680
once we've used up our budget,
then we will be allocated another budget.

416
00:25:22.680 --> 00:25:27.240
A lot of organizations will run
on zero based funding, however,

417
00:25:27.240 --> 00:25:31.250
what I tend to see more often than
not is a mixture of all of them,

418
00:25:31.250 --> 00:25:35.440
a mixture of zero based and
trigger based and rolling plan as well.

419
00:25:35.440 --> 00:25:40.210
So I expect your organization to tell you

420
00:25:40.210 --> 00:25:45.030
exactly how they're going
to work with the budgeting.

421
00:25:45.030 --> 00:25:46.250
Because that's what this is,

422
00:25:46.250 --> 00:25:50.041
funding is about budgeting,
how much money have I got to spend.

423
00:25:51.650 --> 00:25:55.130
So let's take a look then,
just to wrap up this session.

424
00:25:55.130 --> 00:25:58.920
All right, some basic concepts for
Financial Management.

425
00:25:58.920 --> 00:26:03.690
We've already talked about the fact
that we have to be able to

426
00:26:03.690 --> 00:26:08.720
justify our value to the business and,

427
00:26:08.720 --> 00:26:14.440
in most cases, the business want to see
that justification as a bottom-line,

428
00:26:14.440 --> 00:26:19.090
as a pound sign or a dollar sign
at the bottom of a spreadsheet.

429
00:26:19.090 --> 00:26:23.120
So we have to ensure, and we work with
business-relationship management and

430
00:26:23.120 --> 00:26:29.690
strategy management that we are able
to justify, in a financial term,

431
00:26:29.690 --> 00:26:34.490
for how much money we spent, and how much
value we are delivering to the business.

432
00:26:35.690 --> 00:26:38.590
Now we can, if we so choose,

433
00:26:38.590 --> 00:26:44.655
as an IT organization to work towards
compliance with standards such as COBIT,

434
00:26:44.655 --> 00:26:47.765
for Financial Management which should,
it's a strategy.

435
00:26:49.075 --> 00:26:53.620
We can also work to standards
such as ISO 20,000 or sorry,

436
00:26:53.620 --> 00:26:57.410
I'll give it it's full title ISO/IEC20000,

437
00:26:57.410 --> 00:27:00.790
which is the standard for
service management.

438
00:27:00.790 --> 00:27:06.116
And then we've also got other standards
here and frameworks such as managements

439
00:27:06.116 --> 00:27:10.906
of risk which is another OGC,
the low standard for risk management too.

440
00:27:10.906 --> 00:27:15.725
There your organisation will tell you
whether you need to be compliant to

441
00:27:15.725 --> 00:27:20.702
any one of these standards, and
a lot of service management organizations

442
00:27:20.702 --> 00:27:25.369
will actually work towards ISO20000,
sorry, achievements.

443
00:27:25.369 --> 00:27:30.264
So for the moment, I have thrown a lot
of financial terms at you, okay,

444
00:27:30.264 --> 00:27:32.304
a lot of technical terms, and

445
00:27:32.304 --> 00:27:37.687
I've given you quite a bit to get your
head around so what I'd like you to do is,

446
00:27:37.687 --> 00:27:42.535
I would like you to go back over
the notes that you've just taken.

447
00:27:42.535 --> 00:27:45.735
Hopefully, to do with this
particular section and

448
00:27:45.735 --> 00:27:48.710
I'd like you to review
what we've gone over.

449
00:27:48.710 --> 00:27:54.260
And in our next episode, we're gonna
expand further into Financial Management

450
00:27:54.260 --> 00:27:58.640
and we're going to look at the
relationships between other processes and

451
00:27:58.640 --> 00:28:01.250
the inputs and
outputs to Financial Management.

452
00:28:02.298 --> 00:28:06.960
>> All right Jo, well, thank you again for
helping us at least to get the terminology

453
00:28:06.960 --> 00:28:12.400
and to get some of the general concepts
down what we took a look at here in terms

454
00:28:12.400 --> 00:28:17.770
of Financial Management, where we did
talk about the basic purpose as well as,

455
00:28:17.770 --> 00:28:22.580
the idea of justifying to our
organization the business value of IT.

456
00:28:22.580 --> 00:28:24.870
Took a look at the scope as well and

457
00:28:24.870 --> 00:28:29.140
even covered some of the other
items that we needed consider too,

458
00:28:29.140 --> 00:28:33.710
such as the objectives, you name it,
we've actually started covering them here,

459
00:28:33.710 --> 00:28:37.850
but there's actually more to come and
we're gonna save that for another episode.

460
00:28:37.850 --> 00:28:40.160
So great place for us to sign off.

461
00:28:40.160 --> 00:28:43.330
For ITProTV, I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

462
00:28:43.330 --> 00:28:44.440
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

463
00:28:44.440 --> 00:28:48.980
>> Stay tuned here for more of the ITIL
Intermediate Service Strategy shows

464
00:28:48.980 --> 00:28:54.821
[MUSIC]

465
00:28:54.821 --> 00:28:57.885
>> Thank you, for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo continue with the financial management discussion.  Jo dives deeply into the activities of Budgeting, Accounting and Chargining.  she also discusses the input and outputs of BAC.  Jo takes a moment to look at the triggers to financial management and the css and kpis.  Lastly, she addresses the challenges and risks.

You're watching the ITIL

8
00:00:20.170 --> 00:00:22.552
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and today,

9
00:00:22.552 --> 00:00:26.340
we're taking a look at a part
two on financial management.

10
00:00:26.340 --> 00:00:31.575
And here to help us out is gonna be our
ITIL Emperador herself, Jo Peacock.

11
00:00:31.575 --> 00:00:32.900
Jo, welcome back to the show.

12
00:00:32.900 --> 00:00:35.601
>> Did you say empanada or
I've just got food on my mind?

13
00:00:35.601 --> 00:00:38.478
>> Empanada is not exactly what I said.

14
00:00:38.478 --> 00:00:40.190
>> [LAUGH]
>> [INAUDIBLE] [LAUGH] All right.

15
00:00:40.190 --> 00:00:41.270
So Jo, here we are.

16
00:00:41.270 --> 00:00:44.450
We're taking a look at more
of these financial terms.

17
00:00:44.450 --> 00:00:49.749
We talked a lot about it briefly,
and really kinda great

18
00:00:49.749 --> 00:00:54.821
key that I took away from that
was the idea of needing to

19
00:00:54.821 --> 00:00:59.690
justify the value of IT
service to the business..

20
00:00:59.690 --> 00:01:02.020
See, I'm starting to actually change
the words around a little bit more.

21
00:01:02.020 --> 00:01:03.174
>> [LAUGH]
>> But Jo,

22
00:01:03.174 --> 00:01:05.351
what else do we need to do here?

23
00:01:05.351 --> 00:01:08.556
>> Well, we looked in the last
episode at the concept of accounting,

24
00:01:08.556 --> 00:01:09.940
budgeting, and charging.

25
00:01:09.940 --> 00:01:10.480
And actually,

26
00:01:10.480 --> 00:01:14.380
what we're gonna do is we're just gonna
expand on on those a little bit more.

27
00:01:14.380 --> 00:01:18.418
I talked about charging earlier
on in our last episode, and

28
00:01:18.418 --> 00:01:21.250
I looked at charging models, etc.

29
00:01:21.250 --> 00:01:23.820
But here,
if we take a look at our first slide,

30
00:01:23.820 --> 00:01:28.499
what we've done is we've literally
just split out accounting, budgeting,

31
00:01:28.499 --> 00:01:33.530
charging, and we just put a few more words
in there, really, and just to explain what

32
00:01:33.530 --> 00:01:37.988
these three particular sections of
financial management are about.

33
00:01:37.988 --> 00:01:43.880
So what I'd like to do, and I know that
it sits in the middle, but I'd like to

34
00:01:43.880 --> 00:01:48.440
look at budgeting, first of all, because I
always think of budgeting as coming first.

35
00:01:48.440 --> 00:01:50.600
Budgeting is how much
money we've got to spend,

36
00:01:50.600 --> 00:01:53.280
whereas accounting is
how much have we spent.

37
00:01:53.280 --> 00:01:57.460
So I like to think of budgeting
as coming before accounting.

38
00:01:57.460 --> 00:02:01.380
But I know some people prefer to think of
it the other way around and that's okay.

39
00:02:01.380 --> 00:02:04.131
I'm easy with any of those.

40
00:02:04.131 --> 00:02:07.786
So budgeting then,
that bit in the middle there,

41
00:02:07.786 --> 00:02:11.013
looks at how much money
have we got to spend.

42
00:02:11.013 --> 00:02:14.401
And what we'll do,
when we're trying to allocate a budget,

43
00:02:14.401 --> 00:02:17.500
is we look at the analysis
of our previous budget.

44
00:02:17.500 --> 00:02:21.750
And that means, actually, and this is
why people like to put accounting first,

45
00:02:21.750 --> 00:02:24.320
that means analyzing our
previous year's account.

46
00:02:24.320 --> 00:02:27.510
How much money did we spend and
where did we spend it?

47
00:02:27.510 --> 00:02:32.370
And then, we need to take a look at
any changes to our future budget, so

48
00:02:32.370 --> 00:02:37.960
many plans that are coming in, new
services, changes to existing services,

49
00:02:37.960 --> 00:02:43.420
etc., and that allows us then to estimate
how much money we need going forward for

50
00:02:43.420 --> 00:02:44.910
the following year.

51
00:02:44.910 --> 00:02:48.040
Now, I say the following year, but
it might not necessarily be a year.

52
00:02:48.040 --> 00:02:51.250
Some people budget every three months,
some people budget every six months.

53
00:02:52.720 --> 00:02:57.360
So let's roll the clock forward then,
and now, we're at the end of the year.

54
00:02:57.360 --> 00:03:00.940
And again, this might be every three
months, it might be every six months,

55
00:03:00.940 --> 00:03:03.190
it might be at the end of every year.

56
00:03:03.190 --> 00:03:08.486
Can I just say that we're in IT, and this
is kind of just a little bit of a warning

57
00:03:08.486 --> 00:03:14.218
really, we're in IT, and let's face it,
Ronnie, we don't like finances in IT.

58
00:03:14.218 --> 00:03:14.746
>> Mm-hm.

59
00:03:14.746 --> 00:03:17.969
>> And there's always a great
tendency to leave our accounting

60
00:03:17.969 --> 00:03:19.369
until the end of the year.

61
00:03:19.369 --> 00:03:20.472
>> Right.
[LAUGH]

62
00:03:20.472 --> 00:03:21.082
>> Yeah.

63
00:03:21.082 --> 00:03:22.100

00:17:50.050 --> 00:17:52.831
And this is about having
the right information available at

294
00:17:52.831 --> 00:17:55.284
the right time to enable
informed decision making.

295
00:17:55.284 --> 00:18:00.852
Now, if we've got financial management
policies that come from our organization,

296
00:18:00.852 --> 00:18:06.110
and they've given us a financial
management or an accounting package.

297
00:18:06.110 --> 00:18:10.430
Then as long as we keep up
to date with the process,

298
00:18:10.430 --> 00:18:12.670
then we'll have all of this information.

299
00:18:12.670 --> 00:18:16.070
We'll have financial reports
available at our fingertips.

300
00:18:16.070 --> 00:18:20.030
This goes back to what I was saying about
don't do your accounts once a year.

301
00:18:20.030 --> 00:18:23.810
If you do your accounts once a year,
then this becomes very cumbersome and

302
00:18:23.810 --> 00:18:26.330
achieving these KPIs
will be quite difficult.

303
00:18:27.470 --> 00:18:31.730
Something else I want to
bring to your attention here.

304
00:18:31.730 --> 00:18:35.186
And I'm not doing this because I know
there's a question in the sample paper

305
00:18:35.186 --> 00:18:39.340
about this, but I do know there's
a question in the sample paper about this.

306
00:18:39.340 --> 00:18:42.490
But I want you to be very careful
about making assumptions.

307
00:18:44.120 --> 00:18:49.262
Do not assume that if you don't
adhere to a particular policy that

308
00:18:49.262 --> 00:18:55.357
there are going to be fines or warnings,
to do with a specific nonadherence.

309
00:18:55.357 --> 00:19:02.220
Or anything to do with, maybe you'd be
stripped of certification or whatever.

310
00:19:02.220 --> 00:19:06.150
When it comes to aproaching
your tests just please be very,

311
00:19:06.150 --> 00:19:09.190
very careful that you don't
make any assumptions.

312
00:19:09.190 --> 00:19:13.740
And if it doesn't say that you're going
to get a fine because of a policy,

313
00:19:13.740 --> 00:19:16.650
then don't assume that you are, okay?

314
00:19:16.650 --> 00:19:18.485
That's just a little tip for

315
00:19:18.485 --> 00:19:23.236
your examination there that I thought
I'd throw in at this point in time.

316
00:19:23.236 --> 00:19:26.908
Another CSF is that we can account for
the money that we spent.

317
00:19:26.908 --> 00:19:31.472
Well, yes, we need to be able to know
how much money we have spent, okay?

318
00:19:31.472 --> 00:19:36.360
And that we can charge if we need to,
and it says where appropriate.

319
00:19:36.360 --> 00:19:38.640
And in terms of appropriateness,

320
00:19:38.640 --> 00:19:43.240
well that's down to the agreement
that you have with the organization.

321
00:19:45.720 --> 00:19:50.970
One of the biggest challenges that we
have got to financial management, and

322
00:19:50.970 --> 00:19:53.720
I'm looking at all of these
challenges underneath here and

323
00:19:53.720 --> 00:19:57.460
things like charging might be
difficult and balancing the cost.

324
00:19:57.460 --> 00:20:01.640
The biggest challenge that we have got to
financial management is actually finding

325
00:20:01.640 --> 00:20:04.750
somebody with the right skills.

326
00:20:04.750 --> 00:20:06.170
That's the biggest challenge.

327
00:20:06.170 --> 00:20:11.030
Financial management is going to be very,
very difficult if we don't have someone

328
00:20:11.030 --> 00:20:15.230
that understands both finances and
IT as well.

329
00:20:15.230 --> 00:20:18.560
We can't just bring in an accountant and
expect them to know, nor

330
00:20:18.560 --> 00:20:23.630
can we give this role to an IT person and
expect them to know accounting policies.

331
00:20:23.630 --> 00:20:27.400
We do have to have somebody
with the right mix of skills.

332
00:20:27.400 --> 00:20:30.206
As it says it's difficult
to control financial data.

333
00:20:30.206 --> 00:20:33.830
It's difficult to know where to
find some financial data, okay?

334
00:20:33.830 --> 00:20:36.850
So we've got to be very, very careful.

335
00:20:36.850 --> 00:20:40.020
And we've got to ensure that we've got
somebody with the right skills to be able

336
00:20:40.020 --> 00:20:40.540
to do this.

337
00:20:41.550 --> 00:20:45.936
And once we've implemented
financial management, well,

338
00:20:45.936 --> 00:20:51.612
we need to make sure that we keep that
dedicated financial management person,

339
00:20:51.612 --> 00:20:54.975
okay, that we keep it
as a dedicated process.

340
00:20:54.975 --> 00:20:59.020
And even though it's already managed
at enterprise level as it says there,

341
00:20:59.020 --> 00:21:01.510
it's still managed separately within IT.

342
00:21:01.510 --> 00:21:06.031
Because our expenditure is completely
different to the expenditure in

343
00:21:06.031 --> 00:21:07.999
the rest of the organization.

344
00:21:07.999 --> 00:21:08.607
You see,

345
00:21:08.607 --> 00:21:13.720
it says there that a lack of financial
management may lead to penalties.

346
00:21:13.720 --> 00:21:17.270
May, just remember that may, okay?

347
00:21:17.270 --> 00:21:21.800
But ultimately, as I've said,
we've still got to maintain

348
00:21:21.800 --> 00:21:26.830
the skills within IT to be able
to manage our own IT finances.

349
00:21:28.250 --> 00:21:34.860
Now, I know that all of that [LAUGH] has
been quite a lot of information for you.

350
00:21:34.860 --> 00:21:40.532
Certainly, there are a lot of definitions
there, such as cost models and

351
00:21:40.532 --> 00:21:45.670
charging models and
cost types and depreciation, etc.

352
00:21:45.670 --> 00:21:49.690
Well, I want to ensure that
you have a good grasp of this.

353
00:21:49.690 --> 00:21:53.170
And so there is an exercise in
your materials that I would

354
00:21:53.170 --> 00:21:58.190
like you to undertake right
now to help you understand

355
00:21:58.190 --> 00:22:03.590
this financial management and
the last two episodes that we've covered.

356
00:22:03.590 --> 00:22:07.590
So please take the time to go away and
look at this exercise.

357
00:22:07.590 --> 00:22:10.744
It'll take you probably around
about 30 to 45 minutes.

358
00:22:11.795 --> 00:22:14.595
We are available in the forum,
in the chat.

359
00:22:14.595 --> 00:22:20.255
So if you do have any issues, if you do
have any questions, then please come back.

360
00:22:20.255 --> 00:22:24.525
And I'll be more than happy to help
you with anything that you may have.

361
00:22:24.525 --> 00:22:26.225
>> All right, Jo, thank you again for

362
00:22:26.225 --> 00:22:30.590
helping us out here as we take a look at
this part two of the financial management.

363
00:22:30.590 --> 00:22:33.300
We did talk about the budgeting,
accounting, and

364
00:22:33.300 --> 00:22:37.180
charging in those activities
that we need to undertake.

365
00:22:37.180 --> 00:22:41.210
As well as the triggers that help us and
what we're expecting on

366
00:22:41.210 --> 00:22:46.000
the inputs into the triggers, as well as
the outputs for the financial management.

367
00:22:46.000 --> 00:22:50.920
The interfaces, the critical success
factors, as well as the KPIs that we have.

368
00:22:50.920 --> 00:22:52.433
And even the challenges and

369
00:22:52.433 --> 00:22:57.080
risks that we all must undertake as we
actually face financial management.

370
00:22:57.080 --> 00:23:00.060
But this is a great place for
us to also end this episode.

371
00:23:00.060 --> 00:23:03.870
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

372
00:23:03.870 --> 00:23:04.910
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

373
00:23:04.910 --> 00:23:09.502
>> Stay tuned right here for more of the
ITIL Intermediate Service Strategy shows.

374
00:23:09.502 --> 00:23:15.265
[MUSIC]

375
00:23:15.265 --> 00:23:18.370
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo look into the demand management.  Jo helps us understand some of the ways to manage demands by influencing and anticipating user behavior.  She also tells us that we use activities like differential charging or workload balancing to insure that we meet the demand without increasing idle capacity.  Lastly, she reviews the CSFs and KPI as well as the Challenges and Risks to Demand Management.
episodes.title: Demand Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:03.567
Welcome to ITProTV,

2
00:00:03.567 --> 00:00:08.294
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.294 --> 00:00:12.180
>> You're watching IT Pro TV.

4
00:00:12.180 --> 00:00:15.565
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

5
00:00:15.565 --> 00:00:19.420
You're watching the ITIL
Intermediate Service Strategy Show.

6
00:00:19.420 --> 00:00:20.960
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and

7
00:00:20.960 --> 00:00:24.940
today we're gonna be taking
a look at demand management.

8
00:00:24.940 --> 00:00:26.940
And here to help us out
of course is gonna be,

9
00:00:26.940 --> 00:00:31.150
well, our ITIL royalty herself,
Jo Peacock.

10
00:00:31.150 --> 00:00:33.560
Jo, welcome back to the show.

11
00:00:33.560 --> 00:00:34.550
>> Thank you very much.

12
00:00:34.550 --> 00:00:37.430
I'm loving the sort of role
connotations that come with

13
00:00:37.430 --> 00:00:38.650
service strategy by the way.

14
00:00:38.650 --> 00:00:39.564
I'm just saying this.

15
00:00:39.564 --> 00:00:40.910
>> I will try even more.

16
00:00:40.910 --> 00:00:44.684
So there's plenty of landed titles out
there I believe that we can just abscond

17
00:00:44.684 --> 00:00:45.720
with anyway.

18
00:00:45.720 --> 00:00:49.690
So nobody's really gonna know
too much about this right here.

19
00:00:49.690 --> 00:00:53.710
But as we start to move into
in the service strategy and

20
00:00:53.710 --> 00:00:57.520
now demand management, Jo,
this is not as simple as it sounds.

21
00:00:57.520 --> 00:01:01.160
I just tell you what I want and
that's all that it takes, right?

22
00:01:01.160 --> 00:01:01.898
Demands?

23
00:01:01.898 --> 00:01:06.590
>> Absolutely not [LAUGH], and in fact,
this is everybody's misconception about

24
00:01:06.590 --> 00:01:08.228
demand management
>> Okay.

25
00:01:08.228 --> 00:01:10.430
>> It's all about supply and
demand isn't it?

26
00:01:10.430 --> 00:01:13.720
>> Right.
>> Not quite, actually demand management

27
00:01:13.720 --> 00:01:17.390
is, well, we use it in conjunction
with capacity management.

28
00:01:17.390 --> 00:01:20.820
And yes, it is all about
understanding demand from people, but

29
00:01:20.820 --> 00:01:24.470
it's also about influencing
their behavior.

30
00:01:24.470 --> 00:01:28.050
So yes, we understand their demand, but

31
00:01:28.050 --> 00:01:32.280
we also want to influence their
behavior in order to meet their demand.

32
00:01:33.570 --> 00:01:35.682
Well, that sounds a little bit strange,
doesn't it?

33
00:01:35.682 --> 00:01:38.340
I'm gonna give you an example and
we're gonna start off with an example.

34
00:01:38.340 --> 00:01:39.740
Put it into perspective.

35
00:01:39.740 --> 00:01:43.730
And then once we've done that, then it's
fairly obvious what demand management is.

36
00:01:43.730 --> 00:01:48.190
So let's imagine just for a moment
that it's the week before Christmas.

37
00:01:48.190 --> 00:01:49.200
>> All right.

38
00:01:49.200 --> 00:01:52.230
>> And you are trying to
book a flight to go home and

39
00:01:52.230 --> 00:01:54.499
see your family on Christmas Eve.

40
00:01:57.042 --> 00:01:59.470
How much you gonna pay for that flight?

41
00:01:59.470 --> 00:02:01.360
>> You're gonna pay a lot for that flight.

42
00:02:01.360 --> 00:02:05.548
>> Okay, and
do you get any special service?

43
00:02:05.548 --> 00:02:06.440
>> You'll get a seat.

44
00:02:06.440 --> 00:02:07.701
[LAUGH]
>> You'll get a seat.

45
00:02:07.701 --> 00:02:12.205
Where it will be leather clad seat,
a very comfortable seat in first

46
00:02:12.205 --> 00:02:16.200
class that reclines right the way back so
you can lay down?

47
00:02:16.200 --> 00:02:17.640
>> You won't even get a pillow.

48
00:02:17.640 --> 00:02:19.390
>> You won't even get a pillow.

49
00:02:19.390 --> 00:02:22.390
What about then champagne
when you first get on board?

50
00:02:22.390 --> 00:02:23.625
>> Only if you bring it with you.

51
00:02:23.625 --> 00:02:26.013
>> [LAUGH] I don't think you're
allowed to do that any more, are you?

52
00:02:26.013 --> 00:02:27.480
>> I don't think so either.

53
00:02:27.480 --> 00:02:29.833
>> No, you're going to get the same
bag of peanuts [INAUDIBLE].

54
00:02:29.833 --> 00:02:30.668
>> That's true, right.

55
00:02:30.668 --> 00:02:34.052
>> Probably just a little bit
faster cuz it's Christmas Eve and

56
00:02:34.052 --> 00:02:36.890
everybody wants to get home, right?

57
00:02:36.890 --> 00:02:43.800
But yet, if you were to travel the week
before, what difference would there be?

58
00:02:43.800 --> 00:02:47.590
>> The price difference would be
much lower is what I would see.

59
00:02:47.590 --> 00:02:49.160
>> Right, why do you think that is?

60
00:02:50.200 --> 00:02:54.921
>> Not as many people would be traveling
that week as the week of Christmas.

61
00:02:54.921 --> 00:02:58.530
>> Right, it's something that we
call differential challenging.

62
00:02:58.530 --> 00:03:03.140
And it's a technique that we use in demand
management to influence people's behavior.

63
00:03:04.570 --> 00:03:06.500
Let me elaborate on this
a little bit further.

64
00:03:06.500 --> 00:03:09.287
So you travel the week before Christmas.

65
00:03:09.287 --> 00:03:12.660
Now we know, sorry, the day before
Christmas, on Christmas Eve.

66
00:03:12.660 --> 00:03:18.240
And we know that there is going
to an increased demand for

67
00:03:18.240 --> 00:03:20.960
seats on a plane the day before Christmas.

68
00:03:20.960 --> 00:03:24.950
Because everybody wants to get home and
spend Christmas with their family.

69
00:03:24.950 --> 00:03:29.537
So airlines will charge
an additional fee for that.

70
00:03:29.537 --> 00:03:32.620
And it's something, it's a technique
we call differential charging.

71
00:03:32.620 --> 00:03:37.250
Because we know that the week beforehand
that the airlines will charge a lower

72
00:03:37.250 --> 00:03:41.110
fee for exactly the same seat
on exactly the same plane.

73
00:03:42.528 --> 00:03:46.660
They know that they're gonna have an
increased amount the day before Christmas.

74
00:03:46.660 --> 00:03:48.740
And they've got two choices.

75
00:03:48.740 --> 00:03:52.280
They can either increase capacity,

76
00:03:52.280 --> 00:03:56.390
that's one choice, which is why I say
this is tied in with capacity management.

77
00:03:56.390 --> 00:04:01.780
We can increase capacity and
we can buy in more planes,

78
00:04:01.780 --> 00:04:03.460
which means that we bring in more pilots.

79
00:04:03.460 --> 00:04:05.210
Which means we bring in more cabin crew.

80
00:04:05.210 --> 00:04:06.790
Which means we've got
to find somewhere for

81
00:04:06.790 --> 00:04:10.660
those planes to sit when they're not
being used for the rest of the year.

82
00:04:11.840 --> 00:04:15.570
And we've got to find something for those
pilots to do when they're not flying for

83
00:04:15.570 --> 00:04:16.500
the rest of the year.

84
00:04:16.500 --> 00:04:17.340
And both the planes and

85
00:04:17.340 --> 00:04:20.900
the pilots have got to do a minimum
number of air miles per year.

86
00:04:20.900 --> 00:04:24.440
And we've also got to find something
to do with our cabin crew for

87
00:04:24.440 --> 00:04:26.520
the rest of the year as well.

88
00:04:26.520 --> 00:04:30.040
So that means that we have a lot
of spare capacity if we do that.

89
00:04:31.100 --> 00:04:34.130
The other option is this
differential charging.

90
00:04:34.130 --> 00:04:39.330
In that we increase the price of
the seat the day before Christmas.

91
00:04:39.330 --> 00:04:43.380
Because what we want to do is try and
encourage people

92
00:04:43.380 --> 00:04:48.290
to fly the week before when we
do have some spare capacity.

93
00:04:49.620 --> 00:04:52.950
This is, as I've said, a technique
that we call differential charging.

94
00:04:52.950 --> 00:04:54.754
Charging a different amount for

95
00:04:54.754 --> 00:04:57.903
exactly the same service
based on certain parameters.

96
00:04:57.903 --> 00:05:00.780
In this case, the time of the year.

97
00:05:00.780 --> 00:05:05.220
This is all about identifying peaks and
troughs.

98
00:05:05.220 --> 00:05:07.870
Knowing that there is an increased
demand the day before Christmas.

99
00:05:08.890 --> 00:05:09.930
And what we want to try and

100
00:05:09.930 --> 00:05:12.950
do is we want to try and
even out those peaks and troughs.

101
00:05:12.950 --> 00:05:16.440
So instead of being like this,
it's more like this.

102
00:05:17.680 --> 00:05:23.950
Which allows us then to purchase
capacity at a set rate.

103
00:05:25.030 --> 00:05:29.870
If we were to purchase capacity at
this rate, then when we have a trough,

104
00:05:29.870 --> 00:05:33.050
we've got a huge amount
of spare capacity there.

105
00:05:33.050 --> 00:05:34.580
And that's expensive.

106
00:05:34.580 --> 00:05:35.510
It's a waste of money.

107
00:05:36.520 --> 00:05:41.630
So we do what we call analyze PBAs,
or patterns of business activity.

108
00:05:41.630 --> 00:05:44.170
It's analyzing peaks and troughs.

109
00:05:44.170 --> 00:05:49.890
And we do that so that we can then
influence customer and user behavior.

110
00:05:49.890 --> 00:05:53.645
In other words, we can try and
encourage people, in this instance,

111
00:05:53.645 --> 00:05:55.411
to travel the week beforehand.

112
00:05:55.411 --> 00:05:59.020
Now this is a technique that we
use in IT as well, by the way.

113
00:05:59.020 --> 00:06:03.270
If we know that we have Monday morning.

114
00:06:03.270 --> 00:06:06.850
Everybody comes in and
everybody wants to download their emails.

115
00:06:06.850 --> 00:06:10.450
And we know that there's an increased
bandwidth usage on Monday morning,

116
00:06:10.450 --> 00:06:13.272
because everybody's
downloading their emails.

117
00:06:13.272 --> 00:06:18.500
Problem being, of course, that,
well, it slows the network down.

118
00:06:18.500 --> 00:06:21.300
But we've got a sales team that
we know need to get out and

119
00:06:21.300 --> 00:06:23.990
about and
get out on the road at 8 AM one morning.

120
00:06:23.990 --> 00:06:30.270
Well, in that case then, what we might
choose to do is to use user profiles, use

121
00:06:30.270 --> 00:06:37.130
their profile to give them priority on the
network before 8 AM on a Monday morning.

122
00:06:37.130 --> 00:06:39.820
And so we slow everyone else's access.

123
00:06:39.820 --> 00:06:41.230
Again, using user profiles,

124
00:06:41.230 --> 00:06:46.360
we slow everybody else's access down until
after the sales team have left the office.

125
00:06:47.610 --> 00:06:51.891
And again, that's a technique we use,
workload balancing,

126
00:06:51.891 --> 00:06:54.734
a technique we use in demand management.

127
00:06:54.734 --> 00:06:57.640
You see, the other option is
that we increase the bandwidth.

128
00:06:57.640 --> 00:07:01.415
But then again, by 10 AM on Monday, well,

129
00:07:01.415 --> 00:07:06.260
we've freed up a lot of bandwidth
because that need is no longer there.

130
00:07:06.260 --> 00:07:10.600
So we would have spare capacity on our
bandwidth for the rest of the week.

131
00:07:10.600 --> 00:07:13.010
So we don't want to buy in more bandwidth.

132
00:07:13.010 --> 00:07:16.125
And we use this technique not just for
bandwidth and it's not just for

133
00:07:16.125 --> 00:07:21.410
airlines but we also use it for storage
basics, etc., as well, and for memory too.

134
00:07:22.870 --> 00:07:27.920
So the objective of demand
management is actually to, well,

135
00:07:27.920 --> 00:07:32.210
as it says on our slides here,
identify patterns of business activity.

136
00:07:32.210 --> 00:07:36.200
So as to understand and
anticipate customer demand.

137
00:07:36.200 --> 00:07:40.210
But then influence customer
demand using user profiling or

138
00:07:40.210 --> 00:07:43.560
something like differential charging,
for instance.

139
00:07:43.560 --> 00:07:49.713
So we work with capacity management
to prevent and manage demands, okay.

140
00:07:49.713 --> 00:07:53.966
What we want to do is ensure
that we have enough demand but

141
00:07:53.966 --> 00:07:57.140
we don't want to have too much capacity.

142
00:07:57.140 --> 00:08:01.830
So we have enough capacity to
meet the demand but not too much.

143
00:08:01.830 --> 00:08:06.950
