Well, we're starting to take people in a
standby list that perhaps we will be able

373
00:23:08.119 --> 00:23:11.700
to recommend that they actually
fly a little bit earlier.

374
00:23:11.700 --> 00:23:15.140
Because there is no guarantee
they're going to get a seat.

375
00:23:15.140 --> 00:23:17.440
And even though the seat
is really expensive,

376
00:23:17.440 --> 00:23:20.860
perhaps they need to rethink
their traveling plans, okay?

377
00:23:21.990 --> 00:23:25.990
We've gotta have a strong interface with
capacity management of course because

378
00:23:25.990 --> 00:23:32.130
patterns of business activity we defined
these to analyze our usage of capacity.

379
00:23:32.130 --> 00:23:36.140
And then that we will
decide that we want to

380
00:23:36.140 --> 00:23:41.290
Implement demand management techniques
to meet our capacity requirements.

381
00:23:41.290 --> 00:23:42.626
Well, we might not want to.

382
00:23:42.626 --> 00:23:45.065
We might just want to increase capacity.

383
00:23:45.065 --> 00:23:48.950
We've got to work hand in hand
with capacity management and

384
00:23:48.950 --> 00:23:51.752
we have to make these decisions together.

385
00:23:51.752 --> 00:23:57.022
So capacity management will be continually
monitoring utilization rates And

386
00:23:57.022 --> 00:24:01.729
at some point in time we'll be sitting
down with demand management and

387
00:24:01.729 --> 00:24:04.870
saying okay,
we're near a breach right now.

388
00:24:05.930 --> 00:24:10.860
And, if it carries on and our capacity
usage and our capacity forecasts

389
00:24:10.860 --> 00:24:15.850
carry in the way that they are,
we're going to be subject to a breach.

390
00:24:15.850 --> 00:24:21.020
So therefore we've got to look at
another way to meet those requirements,

391
00:24:21.020 --> 00:24:22.230
we've got to.

392
00:24:22.230 --> 00:24:25.780
Now bottom CSF about the ability
to deal with service demand,

393
00:24:25.780 --> 00:24:31.770
we've got to be able to deliver all
of the demands of our service but

394
00:24:31.770 --> 00:24:34.810
we don't wanna spend too much
money in doing it, okay?

395
00:24:34.810 --> 00:24:37.230
We don't want to have too much capacity.

396
00:24:38.380 --> 00:24:40.809
We can't do this without
information from the business.

397
00:24:41.890 --> 00:24:46.600
Business relationship management is going
to help us a huge amount with this, and

398
00:24:46.600 --> 00:24:49.500
we can't do it without
information from them.

399
00:24:49.500 --> 00:24:55.180
And we can't do it without understanding
what services we not only have right now,

400
00:24:55.180 --> 00:24:59.230
but what services we're going
to bring in the future.

401
00:24:59.230 --> 00:25:01.630
And it's exactly the same going forward.

402
00:25:01.630 --> 00:25:06.720
You know, the risk to demand management
working as an ongoing basis is

403
00:25:06.720 --> 00:25:11.560
not having that right information and
also not having the commitment from

404
00:25:11.560 --> 00:25:14.630
the business that they're willing
to accept demand management.

405
00:25:14.630 --> 00:25:18.800
In which case,
then we have to increase capacity and

406
00:25:18.800 --> 00:25:22.600
we run the risk of having
spare capacity around.

407
00:25:22.600 --> 00:25:29.410
Now demand management seemed like a fairly
short process and we cover a lot of demand

408
00:25:29.410 --> 00:25:33.810
management also when we look at capacity
management in service design, too.

409
00:25:35.290 --> 00:25:38.630
So what I'd like you to do now is
I'd like you just to take some time.

410
00:25:38.630 --> 00:25:42.770
Take sort of 30 minutes or so
just to review the notes that you've made

411
00:25:42.770 --> 00:25:47.440
about the demand management process, and
if you feel that you have any questions or

412
00:25:47.440 --> 00:25:51.180
any concerns at all about this, then
please feel free to come back to us via

413
00:25:51.180 --> 00:25:53.660
the forum and
I'll be happy to help out where I can.

414
00:25:54.940 --> 00:25:56.740
>> All right, Jo, thank you again for

415
00:25:56.740 --> 00:26:00.780
helping us to understand this
idea of demand management.

416
00:26:00.780 --> 00:26:05.100
I appreciated the very fact where you
talked about the whole goal behind this is

417
00:26:05.100 --> 00:26:08.320
to be able influence what
the user actually is doing and

418
00:26:08.320 --> 00:26:12.800
anticipate what's going on so
that we can help meet that demand as well.

419
00:26:12.800 --> 00:26:15.500
There's a lot of great information
here as you settle down and

420
00:26:15.500 --> 00:26:17.270
think more about demand management.

421
00:26:17.270 --> 00:26:21.670
Make sure you take advantage of what
Joe said, review these concepts This is

422
00:26:21.670 --> 00:26:25.680
the one that is easily misunderstood,
so take some time to review that.

423
00:26:25.680 --> 00:26:26.480
All right.

424
00:26:26.480 --> 00:26:28.780
This is a great place for
us to end this episode.

425
00:26:28.780 --> 00:26:31.951
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

426
00:26:31.951 --> 00:26:33.132
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

427
00:26:33.132 --> 00:26:37.950
>> Stay tuned right here for more
ITIL Intermediate Service Strategy shows.

428
00:26:37.950 --> 00:26:43.849
[MUSIC]

429
00:26:43.849 --> 00:26:46.967
Thank you for watching IT Pro TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo take a look into the business relationship management.  Jo explains the need of BRM to be proactively recommending improvements and delivering values.  She explains that a key point is to manage customer expectations.  We do this best by understanding and mediating the customers needs and delivering customer satisfaction.
episodes.title: Business Relationship Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:03.998
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.998 --> 00:00:11.447
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:11.447 --> 00:00:14.704
>> Welcome to another great
episode here at ITProTV.

4
00:00:14.704 --> 00:00:19.580
You're watching
the ITIL Intermediate Strategy Show.

5
00:00:19.580 --> 00:00:21.018
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

6
00:00:21.018 --> 00:00:24.470
And today, we're diving into
business relationship management.

7
00:00:24.470 --> 00:00:27.984
And here to help us out is gonna be,

8
00:00:27.984 --> 00:00:32.721
well our IT lady herself,
dame, Jo Peacock.

9
00:00:32.721 --> 00:00:34.771
>> [LAUGH]
>> Jo, welcome to the show.

10
00:00:34.771 --> 00:00:37.320
>> Now, why do I always
associate the title dame with

11
00:00:37.320 --> 00:00:39.698
somebody who's an octogenarian or?

12
00:00:39.698 --> 00:00:41.270
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Well,

13
00:00:41.270 --> 00:00:43.693
that was not the intention there.

14
00:00:43.693 --> 00:00:46.148
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now, [LAUGH] so moving on,

15
00:00:46.148 --> 00:00:50.629
[LAUGH] here as we start to talk
about here the business relationship

16
00:00:50.629 --> 00:00:52.960
management in service strategy.

17
00:00:52.960 --> 00:00:55.686
This seems like a very
appropriate topic for

18
00:00:55.686 --> 00:00:59.672
the idea of getting strategies set
up in the way that you need to.

19
00:00:59.672 --> 00:01:04.433
And really an important topic, because
it really is, it seemed like joining

20
00:01:04.433 --> 00:01:09.180
that idea of the business,
as what we're talking about with service.

21
00:01:09.180 --> 00:01:13.167
And I think it's something that maybe some
of us in IT kinda missed the boat on.

22
00:01:13.167 --> 00:01:16.531
>> What we tend to do in IT,
and what's happened, and

23
00:01:16.531 --> 00:01:21.011
I suppose in one respect, it's easy for
me to see the value in this.

24
00:01:21.011 --> 00:01:26.157
Because I come from this background,
and I've been working with ITIL for

25
00:01:26.157 --> 00:01:31.723
a number of years now, which does actually
make me an octogenarian [INAUDIBLE].

26
00:01:31.723 --> 00:01:35.920
[LAUGH] But,
there's a huge amount value to this.

27
00:01:35.920 --> 00:01:41.210
We can't just take business
requirements and try and translate them

28
00:01:41.210 --> 00:01:44.790
into something that we think the business
will win, and then deliver that.

29
00:01:44.790 --> 00:01:47.670
That's one of the biggest
mistakes that we make in IT,

30
00:01:47.670 --> 00:01:51.130
is really just not understand
in our organization enough.

31
00:01:51.130 --> 00:01:54.443
Business relationship management
is really pretty much exactly

32
00:01:54.443 --> 00:01:55.894
as it says on the can really.

33
00:01:55.894 --> 00:01:58.946
It's about managing
the relationship with our business.

34
00:01:58.946 --> 00:02:03.360
Now, one of the biggest misconceptions
about business relationship management is

35
00:02:03.360 --> 00:02:07.700
that, it's a one off exercise that you
do maybe every two to three months.

36
00:02:07.700 --> 00:02:09.550
And we'll tell you that absolutely not.

37
00:02:09.550 --> 00:02:12.194
And in fact,
your business relationship manager,

38
00:02:12.194 --> 00:02:15.936
whilst they're part of IT, they should
be sat in with the organization.

39
00:02:15.936 --> 00:02:20.743
You see, business relationship
management is a role that

40
00:02:20.743 --> 00:02:26.430
should be partly proactive and
should be partly reactive.

41
00:02:26.430 --> 00:02:28.730
Yes, we should be listening
to the organization.

42
00:02:28.730 --> 00:02:33.480
We should be listening when they say,
I'd really like a technique that, or

43
00:02:33.480 --> 00:02:37.160
I'd really like a tool that
could help me to do this.

44
00:02:37.160 --> 00:02:41.330
I'm not very good at taking payments for
instance over the telephone.

45
00:02:41.330 --> 00:02:45.780
I'm not very good at being able to talk
at the same time and hold my phone and

46
00:02:45.780 --> 00:02:47.090
type at the same time.

47
00:02:47.090 --> 00:02:49.070
I'd really like something
that could help me out.

48
00:02:50.360 --> 00:02:55.400
We shouldn't be the ones
listening when somebody says that.

49
00:02:55.400 --> 00:02:56.999
What we should be doing is that,

50
00:02:56.999 --> 00:03:01.212
a business relationship manager should be
straight away looking at you and saying,

51
00:03:01.212 --> 00:03:05.363
hang on a minute, you're trying to balance
a telephone, you're trying to type,

52
00:03:05.363 --> 00:03:08.186
it doesn't look very comfortable,
can I help you out?

53
00:03:09.879 --> 00:03:13.950
And that's where business relationship
management really comes into what it's

54
00:03:13.950 --> 00:03:18.170
for, and that's what business
relationship management should be doing.

55
00:03:18.170 --> 00:03:24.920
We should be proactively recommending
improvements to our organization.

56
00:03:24.920 --> 00:03:27.390
We should be proactively looking for

57
00:03:27.390 --> 00:03:30.750
ways that we can deliver
value to the organization.

58
00:03:30.750 --> 00:03:32.570
We should be proactively looking for

59
00:03:32.570 --> 00:03:36.340
ways that we can facilitate
the organization's outcomes.

60
00:03:37.380 --> 00:03:40.370
Sure, we should be
responding to their request,

61
00:03:40.370 --> 00:03:42.880
because we know we're gonna
get request from them.

62
00:03:42.880 --> 00:03:47.350
Let's face it, the business never consults
us when they're making any changes.

63
00:03:47.350 --> 00:03:51.950
They never ask our permission
before they go and

64
00:03:51.950 --> 00:03:55.270
merge with another organization or
make acquisitions.

65
00:03:55.270 --> 00:03:59.798
But you see, if we wait, if we sit
in our own little bubble here in IT,

66
00:03:59.798 --> 00:04:04.720
in our own little room, in our own
little team, and we don't interact with

67
00:04:04.720 --> 00:04:09.211
the business then we can only be reactive,
we can't be proactive.

68
00:04:09.211 --> 00:04:14.062
And there's so much more value to be
in proactive than just the perception

69
00:04:14.062 --> 00:04:18.834
because you, I saw the look on your
face and when I say to you, well look,

70
00:04:18.834 --> 00:04:20.810
how about I'm watching you.

71
00:04:20.810 --> 00:04:26.140
And I say, here, let me do this for
you, you're quite impressed, okay.

72
00:04:26.140 --> 00:04:29.915
But it's not just about that, because
you see, if I've seen you struggle,

73
00:04:29.915 --> 00:04:33.982
as a business relationship manager, I have
seen you struggle with something, and

74
00:04:33.982 --> 00:04:37.556
I've looked it this and I saw,
I'm sure it can do something for Ronnie.

75
00:04:37.556 --> 00:04:41.851
I go back to IT, and
I say to IT, here's my customer,

76
00:04:41.851 --> 00:04:46.820
this is the problem that he's having,
can we help him out?

77
00:04:46.820 --> 00:04:48.140
And guess what?

78
00:04:48.140 --> 00:04:50.650
Everyone in the service
provider is prepared.

79
00:04:51.700 --> 00:04:56.530
So I go to you and I say to you,
hey, I can help you with this.

80
00:04:56.530 --> 00:04:59.490
And you're impressed because
I'm being proactive but

81
00:04:59.490 --> 00:05:02.450
even more so,
because IT you're already prepared for

82
00:05:02.450 --> 00:05:05.670
this, because they already have
a solution in mind for you.

83
00:05:06.670 --> 00:05:10.970
So it doesn't take us so
long to implement that solution,

84
00:05:10.970 --> 00:05:14.470
because it's something that
we've already been prepared for.

85
00:05:14.470 --> 00:05:19.748
Whereas if I sat back, and I sat in IT and
I waited for you to come to me, well,

86
00:05:19.748 --> 00:05:25.030
you're gonna carry on with the discomfort
of trying to work your phone,

87
00:05:25.030 --> 00:05:26.030
and do all of this.

88
00:05:26.030 --> 00:05:29.310
And you're probably gonna carry on for
a few months doing that before you finally

89
00:05:29.310 --> 00:05:32.410
come to me and say, hey,
do you reckon, you can help me?

90
00:05:32.410 --> 00:05:36.360
You might even not come to me, you might
even might sort of get on to the Internet

91
00:05:36.360 --> 00:05:40.150
and take a look to see what there is
available, and maybe you might try and

92
00:05:40.150 --> 00:05:43.750
buy something yourself that
might be able to help you.

93
00:05:43.750 --> 00:05:47.720
Well look at what I have just done,
just by sitting next to you and

94
00:05:47.720 --> 00:05:51.768
by being proactive,
I've really increased the value that, I,

95
00:05:51.768 --> 00:05:55.764
as a representative of IT,
are delivering to you the business.

96
00:05:55.764 --> 00:06:00.630
I can't understand the business
if I'm not in with the business.

97
00:06:00.630 --> 00:06:03.450
And I can't understand
the challenges you face and

98
00:06:03.450 --> 00:06:07.800
the outcomes that you want to achieve,
unless I'm there with you.

99
00:06:07.800 --> 00:06:11.310
And you know what,
some of the most important conversations

100
00:06:11.310 --> 00:06:13.198
are the ones that are held
by the water cooler.

101
00:06:13.198 --> 00:06:18.098
And they're the ones where we hear
everything about what's happening with IT.

102
00:06:18.098 --> 00:06:22.895
And we also hear the rumors about what's
happening with the future strategy of

103
00:06:22.895 --> 00:06:24.065
the business too.

104
00:06:24.065 --> 00:06:27.500
And not gives us a heads off.

105
00:06:27.500 --> 00:06:31.660
Okay, some of these rumors are not
necessarily the truth, and

106
00:06:31.660 --> 00:06:36.210
we cannot sort of divides the whole
service strategy based on the rumor.

107
00:06:36.210 --> 00:06:40.960
Yes, okay, we know all that, but
nevertheless, it does give us a heads up.

108
00:06:40.960 --> 00:06:45.500
And I wonder how many times there's
been a conversation by the water cooler

109
00:06:45.500 --> 00:06:49.470
that actually is happened after
a conversation with the service desk.

110
00:06:49.470 --> 00:06:52.250
You know the ones, where the service
desk team so we're user and

111
00:06:52.250 --> 00:06:54.090
said, is everything okay?

112
00:06:54.090 --> 00:06:54.930
Are you happy?

113
00:06:54.930 --> 00:06:56.260
And the users says, yeah.

114
00:06:56.260 --> 00:06:58.120
Yeah, I'm fine, thank you very much.

115
00:06:58.120 --> 00:07:02.099
And they put the phone down and then they
stood by the water cooler talking to

116
00:07:02.099 --> 00:07:04.832
a colleague, and actually,
they're not happy.

117
00:07:04.832 --> 00:07:06.630
And that's when you hear the truth,

118
00:07:06.630 --> 00:07:10.800
that's when you hear about the fact that
I've just spoken to the service desk.

119
00:07:10.800 --> 00:07:14.290
It took me way too long to get
an answer on the telephone.

120
00:07:14.290 --> 00:07:16.270
And although the person was nice and

121
00:07:16.270 --> 00:07:20.280
polite, and they will resolve my issue
once I've managed to speak to them.

122
00:07:20.280 --> 00:07:22.485
But that queue is way too long.

123
00:07:22.485 --> 00:07:26.254
Well, we don't hear that unless
we're there by the water cooler.

124
00:07:26.254 --> 00:07:30.371
So the key to business relationship
management is building up that

125
00:07:30.371 --> 00:07:33.670
relationship, it's building up that trust.

126
00:07:33.670 --> 00:07:35.399
Look at the first bullet point here,
look at the purpose.

127
00:07:35.399 --> 00:07:39.448
It's establishing and
maintaining a relationship, and

128
00:07:39.448 --> 00:07:44.620
identifying business needs, and
managing customer expectations.

129
00:07:44.620 --> 00:07:47.506
You are much more likely to pay for
something if you see value in it.

130
00:07:47.506 --> 00:07:51.399
If I've been proactive in
recommending it to you,

131
00:07:51.399 --> 00:07:57.745
then if you're having to wait and for me
to react to requests that you've given me.

132
00:07:57.745 --> 00:08:01.914
This is about understanding the customer
perspective, and keeping our customers

133
00:08:01.914 --> 00:08:05.022
happy, and maintaining all of
that positive relationship.

134
00:08:05.022 --> 00:08:08.090
It's about liaising with our customers.

135
00:08:09.270 --> 00:08:11.050
Now I wanna bring
something else in as well.

136
00:08:12.240 --> 00:08:16.280
I want to bring in that sort of,
last two bullet points, really.

137
00:08:16.280 --> 00:08:19.440
Which are about formal complaints and
escalation procedures, but

138
00:08:19.440 --> 00:08:24.550
also about conflicts for
resolving conflicts, conflict resolution.

139
00:08:26.540 --> 00:08:31.890
I will mention, and I will talk at length
about this in service design as well.

140
00:08:31.890 --> 00:08:36.593
But I will mention, when we talk about
service metrics and service measurements

141
00:08:36.593 --> 00:08:40.881
and we talk about the SLAM charts that
exist in Service Level Management,

142
00:08:40.881 --> 00:08:45.257
these are our inputs into our service
review meetings with our customers.

143
00:08:45.257 --> 00:08:48.681
And of course, we covered this in
our foundation material as well, but

144
00:08:48.681 --> 00:08:51.460
we'll go into more depth
in service design.

145
00:08:51.460 --> 00:08:54.130
Well, when I talk about these SLAM charts,

146
00:08:54.130 --> 00:08:58.850
I always ask one question,
what color I wanna see in a slam chart.

147
00:08:58.850 --> 00:09:02.390
Cuz they're displayed in red,
amber, green, they're RAG charts.

148
00:09:02.390 --> 00:09:03.770
I never, ever want to see green.

149
00:09:04.790 --> 00:09:09.717
Because you see, green might tell me that
I am meeting my service level targets.

150
00:09:09.717 --> 00:09:14.235
But I'll guarantee, as an external person,
that if your SLAM charts are all green,

151
00:09:14.235 --> 00:09:18.313
I'll go to any one of your customers and
ask them if they're truly happy, and

152
00:09:18.313 --> 00:09:21.560
they won't be completely
100% happy with the service.

153
00:09:23.150 --> 00:09:27.057
So, seeing a green SLAM chart to me
just tells me that we're not measuring

154
00:09:27.057 --> 00:09:28.136
the right targets.

155
00:09:28.136 --> 00:09:34.207
And the service review meter, where the
Service Level Manager and the customer sit

156
00:09:34.207 --> 00:09:39.625
down and they talk about the achievement
of those service level targets.

157
00:09:39.625 --> 00:09:41.208
Well, that shouldn't be a fight.

158
00:09:41.208 --> 00:09:44.818
And yet, time after time I'm told that
it is, and I've witnessed this so

159
00:09:44.818 --> 00:09:46.462
many times where this is a fight.

160
00:09:46.462 --> 00:09:50.227
Where the Service Level Manager
sits there and says, hey look,

161
00:09:50.227 --> 00:09:52.530
we've achieved all our targets.

162
00:09:52.530 --> 00:09:54.030
And the customer turned around and

163
00:09:54.030 --> 00:09:59.520
said, so what about that hours ourage
that we had just a week ago, okay?

164
00:09:59.520 --> 00:10:03.820
This is why we have the Business
Relationship Manager, to build trust and

165
00:10:03.820 --> 00:10:06.730
to build confidence with the user.

166
00:10:06.730 --> 00:10:11.922
So that the customer feels as though
they have somebody on their side

167
00:10:11.922 --> 00:10:18.500
who is working with them and is working on
their behalf, but who also understands IT.

168
00:10:18.500 --> 00:10:23.829
And that's why we talk about mediating
conflicts, and conflict resolution,

169
00:10:23.829 --> 00:10:28.310
and dealing with complaints,
and escalation point as well.

170
00:10:28.310 --> 00:10:32.370
If a customer's got or a user has got
an outstanding incident and they don't

171
00:10:32.370 --> 00:10:36.960
know who to escalate to, that's why we
have the Business Relationship Manager.

172
00:10:36.960 --> 00:10:40.600
It's about relationship,
and the BRM works for

173
00:10:40.600 --> 00:10:45.700
both internal and
also external service providers, too.

174
00:10:45.700 --> 00:10:48.704
We're concerned with meeting
customer requirements.

175
00:10:48.704 --> 00:10:51.876
But then take a look at the table at
the bottom, and I just want to bring

176
00:10:51.876 --> 00:10:54.893
in the difference between
Business Relationship Management and

177
00:10:54.893 --> 00:10:56.229
Service Level Management.

178
00:10:56.229 --> 00:10:59.360
Cuz I've just mentioned
the service review meetings.

179
00:10:59.360 --> 00:11:02.691
Business Relationship Management
is about a relationship, and

180
00:11:02.691 --> 00:11:05.788
it's about satisfaction, and
it's at a strategic level.

181
00:11:05.788 --> 00:11:10.123
We're identifying new services,
we're identifying opportunities for

182
00:11:10.123 --> 00:11:14.330
improvement, and we're also performing
that mediation of conflict.

183
00:11:14.330 --> 00:11:19.540
With service level management,
that's at an operational level.

184
00:11:19.540 --> 00:11:25.130
We're managing our services and
delivering them to agreed targets.

185
00:11:25.130 --> 00:11:29.570
So Service Level Management are going
to be looking at the instances where

186
00:11:29.570 --> 00:11:31.020
targets have been breached.

187
00:11:31.020 --> 00:11:33.520
We're going to negotiate these targets,
and

188
00:11:33.520 --> 00:11:36.580
we're looking at the operational
perspective of a service.

189
00:11:36.580 --> 00:11:40.960
Business Relationship Management is not
just looking at an individual service, but

190
00:11:40.960 --> 00:11:45.660
it's looking at the relationship as
a whole between the business unit and

191
00:11:45.660 --> 00:11:47.170
the IT service provider.

192
00:11:49.410 --> 00:11:53.390
Now, it talks about ensuring that
the customer gets what they need.

193
00:11:53.390 --> 00:11:57.732
It's about building up a level of trust,
because sometimes we can't deliver

194
00:11:57.732 --> 00:12:02.073
everything that the customer wants, but
we want to ensure that the customer is

195
00:12:02.073 --> 00:12:04.600
satisfied and
that we are delivering value.

196
00:12:04.600 --> 00:12:09.056
Very, very early on,
in our episodes where we looked

197
00:12:09.056 --> 00:12:13.230
at service strategy, I talked about value.

198
00:12:13.230 --> 00:12:17.316
And I talked about value as
being a mixture of outcomes and

199
00:12:17.316 --> 00:12:19.622
preferences and perceptions.

200
00:12:19.622 --> 00:12:24.134
And in fact, I'm sure you've watched
the episode where we looked at value

201
00:12:24.134 --> 00:12:28.160
proposition, and where I actually
made a proposition to Ronnie.

202
00:12:28.160 --> 00:12:33.354
I offered him some money, [LAUGH] and
I asked him if he would change his

203
00:12:33.354 --> 00:12:38.740
preferences on the basis of me
giving him a particular subsidy.

204
00:12:38.740 --> 00:12:40.050
And he did.

205
00:12:40.050 --> 00:12:45.490
And in that particular role in
that particular moment in time,

206
00:12:45.490 --> 00:12:49.810
I was undertaking the role of
the Business Relationship Manager.

207
00:12:49.810 --> 00:12:54.330
I was understanding Ronnie's
requirements and his preferences, but

208
00:12:54.330 --> 00:12:57.845
I was offering a solution
that still kept him happy but

209
00:12:57.845 --> 00:13:01.930
that allowed us as a service provider
to be able to meet his needs.

210
00:13:03.490 --> 00:13:07.470
You see, Business Relationship Manager,
I like to think of it as a translator but

211
00:13:07.470 --> 00:13:09.160
a lot more than that.

212
00:13:09.160 --> 00:13:11.726
It's not just about articulating
the needs of the customer.

213
00:13:11.726 --> 00:13:17.160
It's understanding the customer so
well that you are able to,

214
00:13:17.160 --> 00:13:21.465
not just influence their behavior,
but you are,

215
00:13:21.465 --> 00:13:26.180
in terms of demand management,
but you are also able to

216
00:13:26.180 --> 00:13:31.800
understand their requirements and
suggest alternatives.

217
00:13:31.800 --> 00:13:34.362
If we cannot give them
everything that they want,

218
00:13:34.362 --> 00:13:36.501
perhaps we can give them an alternative.

219
00:13:36.501 --> 00:13:39.945
If we have that trust built
up with that customer,

220
00:13:39.945 --> 00:13:44.090
then they are willing to
accept that alternative.

221
00:13:44.090 --> 00:13:48.090
Then they're willing to look at
alternatives because they know that we

222
00:13:48.090 --> 00:13:51.750
are acting on their best interests.

223
00:13:51.750 --> 00:13:55.170
We're not just acting
on our best interests.

224
00:13:55.170 --> 00:13:59.010
And this is why Business Relationship
Management is a key role,

225
00:13:59.010 --> 00:14:02.580
because we're building up
a relationship with the business.

226
00:14:02.580 --> 00:14:06.990
We want to ensure customer satisfaction.

227
00:14:06.990 --> 00:14:09.660
Business Relationship Management is
not just a one-off exercise that

228
00:14:09.660 --> 00:14:11.330
happens in strategy.

229
00:14:11.330 --> 00:14:13.840
As we've already said,
yes we're looking for

230
00:14:13.840 --> 00:14:19.450
new opportunities in service strategy
to add value to the organization.

231
00:14:19.450 --> 00:14:23.900
But we're also acting as a liaison
point with service design and

232
00:14:23.900 --> 00:14:30.590
helping with scoping out new services and
the actual specifications of new services.

233
00:14:30.590 --> 00:14:35.798
During transition,
we're involving our customers in testing,

234
00:14:35.798 --> 00:14:41.285
and during service operation,
we are acting as an escalation point.

235
00:14:41.285 --> 00:14:45.448
And also in, sorry,
continual [LAUGH] service improvement,

236
00:14:45.448 --> 00:14:50.331
we wanna make sure that the customer
perspective is always considered in

237
00:14:50.331 --> 00:14:54.670
opportunities for improvement and
improvement initiatives.

238
00:14:57.020 --> 00:15:02.972
So let's take a look here on, well, what
keeps our customers and our users happy.

239
00:15:02.972 --> 00:15:08.040
Well, remember that customers, well,
these are the people that are,

240
00:15:08.040 --> 00:15:11.129
well, they hold the purse strings, okay?

241
00:15:11.129 --> 00:15:14.014
These are the people that had
the accountability for the money.

242
00:15:14.014 --> 00:15:18.820
Whereas users are concerned with,
well, the warranty aspects.

243
00:15:18.820 --> 00:15:24.802
They're concern of the usability
of any process on any service.

244
00:15:24.802 --> 00:15:29.720
So Business Relationship Management is
going to understand the alternate views,

245
00:15:29.720 --> 00:15:33.860
as we have here just an example,
of customers and users.

246
00:15:33.860 --> 00:15:38.436
And Business Relationship Management
helps to mediate between the two.

247
00:15:38.436 --> 00:15:42.216
Now, you could turn around and say that,

248
00:15:42.216 --> 00:15:47.940
surely that's something to do
with our organization itself.

249
00:15:47.940 --> 00:15:50.075
Surely that's something to do
with the business, is it not?

250
00:15:50.075 --> 00:15:52.957
I mean, a customer were there
in the business, and a user,

251
00:15:52.957 --> 00:15:54.119
there in the business.

252
00:15:54.119 --> 00:15:57.144
So why are BRM getting involved in this?

253
00:15:57.144 --> 00:16:01.200
Because I am talking about delivering
value through service provision.

254
00:16:01.200 --> 00:16:05.770
I am talking about delivering
value through our services.

255
00:16:05.770 --> 00:16:11.130
And what that actually means is,
we have to deliver value to everybody.

256
00:16:11.130 --> 00:16:16.950
Earlier on in our episodes,
when we first looked at value perception

257
00:16:16.950 --> 00:16:23.070
through service strategy, I asked
Ronnie what he perceived as valuable.

258
00:16:23.070 --> 00:16:27.040
But I also, gave Ronnie
the example of the coffee shop.

259
00:16:27.040 --> 00:16:27.860
Do you remember, Ronnie?

260
00:16:27.860 --> 00:16:30.180
You took your family into a coffee shop,
didn't you?

261
00:16:30.180 --> 00:16:31.260
You did.

262
00:16:31.260 --> 00:16:36.520
And I asked you whether the coffee
shop is interested in what

263
00:16:36.520 --> 00:16:40.430
you considered of the service, whether
you were impressed by the service, or

264
00:16:40.430 --> 00:16:44.460
whether your family were impressed
by the way their coffee tasted.

265
00:16:44.460 --> 00:16:47.540
And of course we worked out that
actually they're interested in both.

266
00:16:47.540 --> 00:16:48.730
>> Right.

267
00:16:48.730 --> 00:16:51.470
>> Because, quite simply,
>> If

268
00:16:51.470 --> 00:16:54.660
your family aren't interested in
the coffee, they don't like the coffee,

269
00:16:54.660 --> 00:16:57.800
then you're not gonna go back there for
another one.

270
00:16:57.800 --> 00:17:00.010
And it's exactly the same in IT.

271
00:17:00.010 --> 00:17:04.390
And you could say that, well,
we should be interested in

272
00:17:04.390 --> 00:17:08.490
just the customers because the customers
are paying for the services.

273
00:17:08.490 --> 00:17:09.820
But we're not.

274
00:17:09.820 --> 00:17:12.160
We're interested in the users as well,

275
00:17:12.160 --> 00:17:16.010
because the users will
influence our customers.

276
00:17:16.010 --> 00:17:17.840
So look down our left-hand column and

277
00:17:17.840 --> 00:17:20.940
you'll see what our
customers are interested in.

278
00:17:20.940 --> 00:17:24.440
Well, it's to do with pricing,
it's to do with profitability,

279
00:17:24.440 --> 00:17:27.280
it's to do with impact to the services.

280
00:17:27.280 --> 00:17:31.721
Whereas our users are interested in ease
of use, they're interested in quality and

281
00:17:31.721 --> 00:17:32.995
performance.

282
00:17:32.995 --> 00:17:35.440
And of course there's
a conflict between them and

283
00:17:35.440 --> 00:17:39.520
it's really up to us to
mediate between the two.

284
00:17:40.920 --> 00:17:44.600
It's not up to them to try and mediate
between the two because let's face it,

285
00:17:44.600 --> 00:17:50.240
they don't understand the services, and
they're certainly not technical people.

286
00:17:50.240 --> 00:17:55.040
So it really is up to us as business
relationship managers to mediate

287
00:17:55.040 --> 00:17:59.960
between customers and users and their
different requirements, if they have any.

288
00:18:01.430 --> 00:18:04.840
So as we see here,
business relationship management,

289
00:18:04.840 --> 00:18:10.980
will help to articulate the value
of a service throughout it's life.

290
00:18:10.980 --> 00:18:15.540
Through service design,
through service transition and

291
00:18:15.540 --> 00:18:18.190
through service operation as well.

292
00:18:18.190 --> 00:18:19.340
Okay.

293
00:18:19.340 --> 00:18:21.390
Now I really like the next bullet point.

294
00:18:21.390 --> 00:18:25.300
If we look at the second
half of the slide here okay.

295
00:18:25.300 --> 00:18:26.310
You know what?

296
00:18:26.310 --> 00:18:31.430
Customers will quite often come to us and
they will tell us exactly what they want.

297
00:18:32.820 --> 00:18:36.010
In other words, you'll always get
a customer that comes to us and

298
00:18:36.010 --> 00:18:39.340
says, I want a tablet.

299
00:18:39.340 --> 00:18:44.010
What they are really saying to us is what
I need is something that's portable and

300
00:18:44.010 --> 00:18:45.450
something that's light weight.

301
00:18:46.640 --> 00:18:51.510
But what they do is they come to us with
that solution or with a specification and

302
00:18:51.510 --> 00:18:54.120
say I want this.

303
00:18:54.120 --> 00:18:58.182
What they really need to be doing is
coming to us with their needs, but

304
00:18:58.182 --> 00:19:02.808
not an ambiguous description but a very
precise description of their needs and

305
00:19:02.808 --> 00:19:05.912
the benefits that they want
to see from these needs.

306
00:19:05.912 --> 00:19:09.451
So you see,
those bottom four numbers there,

307
00:19:09.451 --> 00:19:12.640
we need to find the balance between them.

308
00:19:12.640 --> 00:19:17.770
And the problem is,
the customer doesn't generally know.

309
00:19:17.770 --> 00:19:19.502
And that's the challenge that we have and

310
00:19:19.502 --> 00:19:21.840
this is why we have business
relationship management.

311
00:19:21.840 --> 00:19:25.495
Because right back at
the start of this session,

312
00:19:25.495 --> 00:19:28.266
I identified that Ronnie had a need.

313
00:19:28.266 --> 00:19:33.070
Now in that particular instance,
Ronnie came to me with the need and

314
00:19:33.070 --> 00:19:35.780
he didn't know how to fill that need.

315
00:19:35.780 --> 00:19:40.470
He didn't know how to resolve
the challenge that he had.

316
00:19:40.470 --> 00:19:44.580
And quite often, as I've already said,
a customer will come to us with

317
00:19:44.580 --> 00:19:48.690
a very definite answer because
they've seen a commercial on TV.

318
00:19:48.690 --> 00:19:52.160
Or because they've seen a colleague
with something similar and

319
00:19:52.160 --> 00:19:56.420
they've decided that they need that
particular piece of equipment or

320
00:19:56.420 --> 00:19:59.580
they need that particular service or
that piece of software.

321
00:20:00.950 --> 00:20:05.040
So you see, business relationship
management is really about negotiation.

322
00:20:05.040 --> 00:20:07.260
It's about that relationship.

323
00:20:07.260 --> 00:20:10.340
It's about me being able to
sit down with Rodney and say,

324
00:20:10.340 --> 00:20:14.930
okay, I understand the technicalities,
you can articulate what you want and

325
00:20:14.930 --> 00:20:16.800
we're gonna work this out together.

326
00:20:17.830 --> 00:20:20.530
That's what business relationship
management is about.

327
00:20:20.530 --> 00:20:22.520
It's a strategic partnership.

328
00:20:24.270 --> 00:20:25.170
You know what?

329
00:20:25.170 --> 00:20:29.740
We wanna be a service provider that
is critical to the organization.

330
00:20:29.740 --> 00:20:34.280
We want to be a service provider that
is recognized as being a major part of

331
00:20:34.280 --> 00:20:39.610
the organization, that's recognized as
being somebody we can't live without.

332
00:20:40.640 --> 00:20:41.940
That's what we want to be.

333
00:20:43.310 --> 00:20:46.370
Bearing in mind, that as it says
in the bottom bullet point,

334
00:20:46.370 --> 00:20:51.490
legal confidentiality issues
need to be considered.

335
00:20:51.490 --> 00:20:55.290
Especially if we're dealing with
external service providers.

336
00:20:55.290 --> 00:20:59.817
We need to consider that there are going
to be points in time when as a business

337
00:20:59.817 --> 00:21:01.305
relationship manager,

338
00:21:01.305 --> 00:21:05.437
they maybe called an account manager
if it's an external provider.

339
00:21:05.437 --> 00:21:09.731
Then we may have access to information
that actually could be of some use to

340
00:21:09.731 --> 00:21:12.220
the organization's competitors.

341
00:21:12.220 --> 00:21:17.012
In which case, then we have to ensure that
the appropriate non-disclosure agreements

342
00:21:17.012 --> 00:21:21.364
are in place but it's very, very difficult
to build up trust in that instance.

343
00:21:21.364 --> 00:21:25.510
So we gotta make sure that we do
actually have that level of trust.

344
00:21:27.510 --> 00:21:32.282
So on our next slide, we actually take
a look at the interactions between

345
00:21:32.282 --> 00:21:34.866
business relationship management and

346
00:21:34.866 --> 00:21:39.421
all of the other life cycle phases and
the other processes, as well.

347
00:21:39.421 --> 00:21:43.967
Now what I would like you to do at this
point in time before we move further into

348
00:21:43.967 --> 00:21:47.395
our next episode on business
relationship management.

349
00:21:47.395 --> 00:21:52.730
I would like you to go to your notes,
the materials that you have downloaded.

350
00:21:52.730 --> 00:21:57.119
And you will see that you have an exercise
that is geared towards helping

351
00:21:57.119 --> 00:21:59.472
you understand these interactions.

352
00:21:59.472 --> 00:22:03.010
So I would like you to
undertake this exercise.

353
00:22:03.010 --> 00:22:07.814
I would also like you to review the notes
from the previous slide, where we looked

354
00:22:07.814 --> 00:22:12.210
at the conflicts between customer
requirements and user requirements.

355
00:22:13.550 --> 00:22:16.341
At this point in time,
when you've completed the exercise or

356
00:22:16.341 --> 00:22:20.001
whilst you're undertaking the exercise,
then we're available on our forum.

357
00:22:20.001 --> 00:22:24.740
So if you do have any questions, then
please come back to me and let me know and

358
00:22:24.740 --> 00:22:27.350
I will be happy to help
out in any way I can.

359
00:22:28.950 --> 00:22:32.690
>> All right Jo, well thank you again for
helping us, once again,

360
00:22:32.690 --> 00:22:36.900
understand this idea here of
the business relationship management.

361
00:22:36.900 --> 00:22:40.730
When we start to take a look at the idea
of the customer's expectation and

362
00:22:40.730 --> 00:22:45.730
get to know what the customer's needs
are so well that we can identify those.

363
00:22:45.730 --> 00:22:50.300
Well, that actually gives us that
advantage that we have as well, okay,

364
00:22:50.300 --> 00:22:54.900
to be able to deliver what we actually
want to to the customer's satisfaction,

365
00:22:54.900 --> 00:22:57.900
as well as provide everything
that we need to the users too.

366
00:22:57.900 --> 00:23:01.650
Take advantage of what Jo told you as
well, to take a little bit of time,

367
00:23:01.650 --> 00:23:05.975
get all these concepts amended
in by doing that activity.

368
00:23:05.975 --> 00:23:08.234
That's a great place for
us to end this episode then.

369
00:23:08.234 --> 00:23:12.120
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

370
00:23:12.120 --> 00:23:13.081
>> And I'm Joy Peacock.

371
00:23:13.081 --> 00:23:18.646
>> Stay tuned right here for more of
the ITIL Intermediate Strategy show.

372
00:23:18.646 --> 00:23:24.021
[MUSIC]

373
00:23:24.021 --> 00:23:26.641
Thank you for watching IT Pro TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo work through the business relationship management process.  Jo describes the triggers as well as what inputs and outputs of BRM.  She also shows the other phases and process that it influences.  She reminds us to keep the CSFs and KPIs simple and scale up as needed and reviews the challenges and risks to BRM.

00:14:45.450 --> 00:14:48.740
Now sometimes what will happen
is we'll bring a BRM in, or

252
00:14:48.740 --> 00:14:54.320
we'll bring the BRM role in as
a solution because we've had

253
00:14:54.320 --> 00:14:59.260
pretty bad credibility
within the organization.

254
00:14:59.260 --> 00:15:03.610
And so we bring BRM in to try and
smooth over that relationship.

255
00:15:03.610 --> 00:15:06.520
Well, we're starting off on
the back foot as we would say.

256
00:15:06.520 --> 00:15:09.744
We're starting off in a negative position,
so

257
00:15:09.744 --> 00:15:12.576
that's gonna be a challenge for any BRM.

258
00:15:12.576 --> 00:15:16.189
And just to ensure that there's
a difference and that you understand

259
00:15:16.189 --> 00:15:20.990
the difference between the BRM role, in
other words, the person and the process.

260
00:15:20.990 --> 00:15:25.904
The process that I undertake does
not define me, I'm still me.

261
00:15:25.904 --> 00:15:30.949
The BRM role is about the relationship,
whereas the process involves me

262
00:15:30.949 --> 00:15:36.150
taking ideas for new services,
it involves me managing complaints.

263
00:15:36.150 --> 00:15:41.279
However, the role is a role where I am
visible to you and I'm available to you.

264
00:15:42.390 --> 00:15:47.410
Be careful because I am very closely
related to all other processes,

265
00:15:47.410 --> 00:15:50.440
because I have to act
as an escalation point.

266
00:15:50.440 --> 00:15:54.590
So therefore I have to be involved
with all other processes.

267
00:15:54.590 --> 00:15:57.970
And so I have to be integrated
with other processes, and

268
00:15:57.970 --> 00:16:02.870
with the service managers as well as with
the process managers and process owners.

269
00:16:02.870 --> 00:16:09.930
But at the same time, I still have to be
the person that the customer can trust.

270
00:16:09.930 --> 00:16:13.730
So it is a very,
very fine balancing act with BRM.

271
00:16:15.040 --> 00:16:17.610
So now that we've looked at
business relationship management,

272
00:16:17.610 --> 00:16:23.190
all of our last two episodes,
what I'd like you to do now is,

273
00:16:23.190 --> 00:16:27.830
I'd like you to undertake the exercise
that you have in your course materials for

274
00:16:27.830 --> 00:16:29.980
business relationship management.

275
00:16:29.980 --> 00:16:32.190
Now that will take you
around about an hour to do,

276
00:16:32.190 --> 00:16:37.470
and what I'd like you to do is really
to do that exercise right now.

277
00:16:37.470 --> 00:16:41.930
If you have any questions at all,
then please feel free to reach out

278
00:16:41.930 --> 00:16:47.250
via the forum and I will be here for you
to answer any queries that you may have.

279
00:16:47.250 --> 00:16:48.580
>> All right, Jo, thank you for

280
00:16:48.580 --> 00:16:51.840
helping us out here in the business
relationship management.

281
00:16:51.840 --> 00:16:52.730
We've talked, of course,

282
00:16:52.730 --> 00:16:56.070
about the idea of the triggers
as well as inputs and outputs.

283
00:16:56.070 --> 00:16:59.328
We took a look briefly at
the interfaces as well as

284
00:16:59.328 --> 00:17:04.600
the CSF, Critical Success Factors.

285
00:17:04.600 --> 00:17:07.220
I don't know why it's a tongue twister for
me but it is.

286
00:17:07.220 --> 00:17:09.850
And then of course at the challenges and
risks.

287
00:17:09.850 --> 00:17:14.180
Remember, take advantage of the activity
that Jo has actually just assigned you.

288
00:17:14.180 --> 00:17:18.600
It is worth it because it all comes down
to you really getting this cemented into

289
00:17:18.600 --> 00:17:22.740
your brain as you prepare for
whatever is coming next in ITIL.

290
00:17:22.740 --> 00:17:25.390
So that's a great place for
us to sign off as well.

291
00:17:25.390 --> 00:17:28.080
For ITProTV, I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

292
00:17:28.080 --> 00:17:29.160
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

293
00:17:29.160 --> 00:17:33.229
>> Stay tuned right here for more
ITIL Intermediate Service Strategy shows.

294
00:17:33.229 --> 00:17:39.273
[MUSIC]

295
00:17:39.273 --> 00:17:42.749
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo discuss the governance in ITIL.  Jo describes the governance activities of evaluation, direct, and monitor to help provide the value.  Also we look at how governance is top down: from who defines governance, fulfills it and who enforces it.
episodes.title: Governance
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.052 --> 00:00:03.627
Welcome to IT Pro TV,

2
00:00:03.627 --> 00:00:08.202
I'm your host [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:08.202 --> 00:00:12.062
>> You're watching IT PRO TV.

4
00:00:12.062 --> 00:00:15.304
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

5
00:00:15.304 --> 00:00:19.070
You're watching the ITIL
Intermediate Service Strategy Show.

6
00:00:19.070 --> 00:00:20.410
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and

7
00:00:20.410 --> 00:00:23.300
today we're gonna be taking
a look at governance.

8
00:00:23.300 --> 00:00:28.650
And here to help us out is gonna be our
ITIL time lord herself, Miss Jo Peacock.

9
00:00:28.650 --> 00:00:30.693
Jo, welcome back to the show.

10
00:00:30.693 --> 00:00:32.236
>> Just call me Dr. Who.

11
00:00:32.236 --> 00:00:33.495
>> All right, Dr. Who.

12
00:00:33.495 --> 00:00:37.518
>> No, no, no, we've always said
the next Dr. Who should be a woman.

13
00:00:37.518 --> 00:00:40.290
>> There you go, and
we have her right here.

14
00:00:40.290 --> 00:00:41.530
So Jo, here we are.

15
00:00:41.530 --> 00:00:45.290
We're taking a look now at
the idea of governance.

16
00:00:45.290 --> 00:00:48.640
Whenever I think about governance,
I'm not normally thinking about rules and

17
00:00:48.640 --> 00:00:50.390
regulations a lot of times.

18
00:00:50.390 --> 00:00:53.740
But is that what we're really talking
about here, are rules and regulations?

19
00:00:55.230 --> 00:00:58.700
>> I hate to use the word rules, because-
>> [LAUGH]

20
00:00:58.700 --> 00:01:00.250
>> We're not particularly prescriptive

21
00:01:00.250 --> 00:01:01.000
in ITIL.

22
00:01:01.000 --> 00:01:04.600
Now, that's not to say that you shouldn't
have any rules, yes you should,

23
00:01:04.600 --> 00:01:08.770
but you should have policies
within which you work.

24
00:01:08.770 --> 00:01:10.800
So governance is really
about setting policies.

25
00:01:10.800 --> 00:01:13.070
Governance is about setting direction for

26
00:01:13.070 --> 00:01:17.840
the way that we're going to go with ITIL
and also with our service management.

27
00:01:17.840 --> 00:01:20.708
Now, as I've said I'm not
really into the word rules,

28
00:01:20.708 --> 00:01:22.905
I don't like to be too prescriptive.

29
00:01:22.905 --> 00:01:26.780
ITIL is is not going to be descriptive,
we're gonna give you a framework.

30
00:01:26.780 --> 00:01:30.080
And really what we are going to
talk about in this section is just

31
00:01:30.080 --> 00:01:34.340
how we set policies and
how we come up with all of our policies.

32
00:01:35.420 --> 00:01:38.660
We base them on our
organization of course.

33
00:01:38.660 --> 00:01:42.180
Our organization will give us policies for
the way that we manage,

34
00:01:42.180 --> 00:01:46.960
suppliers, and for the way that we
manage our finances for instance.

35
00:01:46.960 --> 00:01:52.070
And also our organization will give us
a vision and a direction and a strategy.

36
00:01:52.070 --> 00:01:55.570
Whether they want to grow whether they
want to maintain the status quo or

37
00:01:55.570 --> 00:01:56.859
whether they want to transform.

38
00:01:58.340 --> 00:02:03.110
So governance really what we're
doing is here we're taking what

39
00:02:03.110 --> 00:02:09.366
the organization setting as a direction
and we are translating that into IT.

40
00:02:09.366 --> 00:02:14.090
>> All right, so Jo where are we going
to begin when you start talking about

41
00:02:14.090 --> 00:02:16.205
this idea of governance them?

42
00:02:16.205 --> 00:02:21.140
>> But, as I have already said,
we take what the organization, or

43
00:02:21.140 --> 00:02:23.590
setting as governance policies themselves,
and

44
00:02:23.590 --> 00:02:26.260
what they're setting as their
direction and their strategy.

45
00:02:26.260 --> 00:02:31.730
And we translate that into something that
here, we in IT can actually work with.

46
00:02:31.730 --> 00:02:35.050
And so that will help us set our
directions and set our strategies.

47
00:02:36.830 --> 00:02:40.050
It tells us on this first slide,
right at the very bottom there,

48
00:02:40.050 --> 00:02:44.070
that many of our service management
initiatives fail because

49
00:02:44.070 --> 00:02:46.420
we're not aligned with the organization.

50
00:02:46.420 --> 00:02:49.750
Because we don't understand
the governance of the organization.

51
00:02:49.750 --> 00:02:52.550
And so we try to do what we think is best.

52
00:02:52.550 --> 00:02:55.550
And best practice will tell us that
it's not about what we want to do,

53
00:02:55.550 --> 00:03:01.480
it should be about what the organization
is telling us that we need to do.

54
00:03:01.480 --> 00:03:06.240
Because we need to be aligned with their
strategies and with their direction.

55
00:03:06.240 --> 00:03:08.390
So our strategy sets direction.

56
00:03:08.390 --> 00:03:12.422
And our policies well, it's got that rules
word in there, Ronnie, that I don't like.

57
00:03:12.422 --> 00:03:15.790
>> [LAUGH]
>> But it is a direction on boundaries and

58
00:03:15.790 --> 00:03:17.190
how decisions are made.

59
00:03:17.190 --> 00:03:19.990
And the plans are what we actually do.

60
00:03:19.990 --> 00:03:24.650
Now there are three main activities
within governance, as we like to call it.

61
00:03:24.650 --> 00:03:28.170
And those activities, we'll start off and
we're gonna go through them over the next

62
00:03:28.170 --> 00:03:32.190
few slides where we evaluate
where we are right now.

63
00:03:32.190 --> 00:03:37.330
We direct, in other words we set
our strategies and our policies and

64
00:03:37.330 --> 00:03:41.708
say, okay, we're going in this direction
and this is how we're doing it.

65
00:03:41.708 --> 00:03:44.189
And we monitor how we're performing.

66
00:03:45.300 --> 00:03:46.440
We do this at a high level.

67
00:03:46.440 --> 00:03:48.153
This is at a governance level.

68
00:03:48.153 --> 00:03:49.811
We monitor how we're performing,

69
00:03:49.811 --> 00:03:53.578
we evaluate if we're going in the right
direction, how we're doing right now.

70
00:03:53.578 --> 00:03:57.230
And then we direct, and then we monitor.

71
00:03:57.230 --> 00:03:59.900
And this is iterative.

72
00:03:59.900 --> 00:04:01.510
It's an iterative process.

73
00:04:01.510 --> 00:04:04.550
And it's just really a case of making

74
00:04:04.550 --> 00:04:07.790
sure that we are aligned to
the needs of the organization.

75
00:04:07.790 --> 00:04:09.010
So business relationship,

76
00:04:09.010 --> 00:04:13.540
management process, that's gonna help us
with this, as well as strategy management.

77
00:04:13.540 --> 00:04:16.200
They're going to be performing
a lot of this for us.

78
00:04:16.200 --> 00:04:19.239
So let's look a little bit more
in-depth at what evaluate means.

79
00:04:20.240 --> 00:04:23.760
And evaluate just simply means
looking at where we are right now.

80
00:04:25.340 --> 00:04:28.410
Now, we talked about assessments
in previous episodes.

81
00:04:28.410 --> 00:04:31.750
We looked at assessment of our processes,
for instance.

82
00:04:31.750 --> 00:04:35.980
And if we look at continual service
improvement as a lifecycle phase,

83
00:04:35.980 --> 00:04:40.160
you'll see a lot more in
terms of assessments.

84
00:04:40.160 --> 00:04:43.920
And how we actually undertake assessments
and looking at tools like CMMI, for

85
00:04:43.920 --> 00:04:46.950
instance, for assessing against maturity.

86
00:04:46.950 --> 00:04:50.950
And an evaluation is just
understanding where we are in terms of

87
00:04:50.950 --> 00:04:52.590
our processes within IT.

88
00:04:52.590 --> 00:04:56.830
In terms of our alignment with
the needs of the organization.

89
00:04:56.830 --> 00:05:00.930
And also in terms of where
we are in alignment and

90
00:05:00.930 --> 00:05:05.900
in comparison with maybe industry trends
for instance in our industry sector.

91
00:05:07.120 --> 00:05:12.570
And regulations that there may be for
us in our particular industry sector.

92
00:05:12.570 --> 00:05:16.900
So we're going to evaluate
where we are within IT.

93
00:05:16.900 --> 00:05:21.590
Remember I said right at the very start in
an earlier episode in service strategy,

94
00:05:21.590 --> 00:05:24.460
that we've got to assume
that we've got competition.

95
00:05:25.470 --> 00:05:29.650
We can't assume that we are the only
person that can do our role for

96
00:05:29.650 --> 00:05:30.945
our organization.

97
00:05:30.945 --> 00:05:35.078
So we have to understand the direction
that our organization is going in and

98
00:05:35.078 --> 00:05:36.332
what their vision is.

99
00:05:36.332 --> 00:05:41.390
And that means that we have to
enable them to meet their vision.

100
00:05:41.390 --> 00:05:45.100
Now if we don't there's always somebody
knocking on the door of the CEO offering

101
00:05:45.100 --> 00:05:49.240
to do our role for
less money and higher quality.

102
00:05:49.240 --> 00:05:53.130
So we need to evaluate where we
are as a IT service provider, but

103
00:05:53.130 --> 00:05:55.560
also where our organization is too.

104
00:05:55.560 --> 00:06:00.700
Because you see as an IT service
provider given that IT is so

105
00:06:00.700 --> 00:06:07.070
entwined with the organization, well,
we could be holding the organization back.

106
00:06:07.070 --> 00:06:10.120
Or we could be trying to
force the organization to run

107
00:06:10.120 --> 00:06:12.780
before it could walk for instance.

108
00:06:12.780 --> 00:06:19.070
So we'll evaluate on aspects
such as financial performance,

109
00:06:19.070 --> 00:06:23.510
looking at these projects that we
have in our pipeline right now.

110
00:06:23.510 --> 00:06:29.090
Where we are right now, things like CMMI,
looking at our processes, etc.

111
00:06:29.090 --> 00:06:33.540
Look at our opportunities, we could do
SWAT analysis, strengths, weaknesses,

112
00:06:33.540 --> 00:06:35.210
opportunities and threats.

113
00:06:35.210 --> 00:06:38.730
And again if you want to know more
about that type of assessment,

114
00:06:38.730 --> 00:06:43.060
then please go to the continuous service
improvement life cycle phase, and

115
00:06:43.060 --> 00:06:47.150
you will see a lot more on assessments and
how we do this.

116
00:06:47.150 --> 00:06:53.000
We'll also evaluate things like proposals
from our managers and our shareholders.

117
00:06:53.000 --> 00:06:56.620
Now that's very much
an organizational type of evaluation.

118
00:06:56.620 --> 00:07:01.310
But we want to know what direction
the organization wants to go in because we

119
00:07:01.310 --> 00:07:02.280
have to support that.

120
00:07:02.280 --> 00:07:06.170
And so, of course we take into
consideration feedback and

121
00:07:06.170 --> 00:07:10.120
also our existing contracts
with our suppliers, too.

122
00:07:10.120 --> 00:07:13.810
>> Now, Jo, I have a question here
about this idea of evaluation.

123
00:07:13.810 --> 00:07:17.570
It's easy for a company internally
to take a look at this and say,

124
00:07:17.570 --> 00:07:20.100
hey, we need to evaluate where we are.

125
00:07:20.100 --> 00:07:25.770
But we also understand that it's also
easy for me if I'm doing that to just

126
00:07:25.770 --> 00:07:31.700
center in, pigeon hole in, on some of
those areas that I want to emphasize.

127
00:07:31.700 --> 00:07:33.740
And not so much from the areas we need to.

128
00:07:33.740 --> 00:07:37.520
So is this a better process and
evaluation if we think about bringing in

129
00:07:37.520 --> 00:07:40.750
a third party or
an outside to help us to do that better?

130
00:07:40.750 --> 00:07:44.823
Or is this something that we can try and
just figure out how to balance it better?

131
00:07:44.823 --> 00:07:48.433
>> Well this goes back to a topic
that actually we continue our service

132
00:07:48.433 --> 00:07:52.495
improvement, is looking the difference
between internal assessment and

133
00:07:52.495 --> 00:07:54.195
external assessment.

134
00:07:54.195 --> 00:07:58.568
Now, an internal assessment when
it's completed internally- Well,

135
00:07:58.568 --> 00:08:01.877
you know your organization
better than anybody else.

136
00:08:01.877 --> 00:08:09.290
So you're able to give an assessment based
on your understanding of our direction.

137
00:08:09.290 --> 00:08:12.565
However, your assessment could be biased,

138
00:08:12.565 --> 00:08:16.495
your assessment could be made
with a certain aim in mind.

139
00:08:16.495 --> 00:08:19.155
Maybe you want to show that
we're not doing so well, or

140
00:08:19.155 --> 00:08:21.625
maybe you want to show
that we are doing so well.

141
00:08:21.625 --> 00:08:25.445
So you're going to be looking for
opportunities to demonstrate or

142
00:08:25.445 --> 00:08:28.595
to prove your direction.

143
00:08:28.595 --> 00:08:34.320
So we can't be assured of an impartiality
of an internal assessment,

144
00:08:34.320 --> 00:08:38.440
but we do have the skills of our
environment, we have that experience.

145
00:08:38.440 --> 00:08:42.400
Now an external assessment, yeah,
we can guarantee impartiality.

146
00:08:42.400 --> 00:08:44.650
And the other thing with
an external assessment is,

147
00:08:44.650 --> 00:08:48.920
that an external assessor
will have the details and

148
00:08:48.920 --> 00:08:53.830
the information to allow us to
compare against other organization.

149
00:08:53.830 --> 00:08:58.290
However, an external assessment
will not have that knowledge

150
00:08:58.290 --> 00:09:01.170
of the organization itself.

151
00:09:01.170 --> 00:09:03.900
So we have to compare the two and

152
00:09:03.900 --> 00:09:10.540
work out which one would be most suitable
given the situation that we're in.

153
00:09:10.540 --> 00:09:14.580
Now, I would always advise that we start
off with an internal assessment and

154
00:09:14.580 --> 00:09:19.200
then we go to an external assessment,
that would always be my advice.

155
00:09:19.200 --> 00:09:22.660
However, we have to do that only
understanding that internal assessment is

156
00:09:22.660 --> 00:09:26.830
never going to be impartial, and
it doesn't matter what good faith we enter

157
00:09:26.830 --> 00:09:32.460
into an internal assessment with, there's
always an element of, I want to show this.

158
00:09:32.460 --> 00:09:33.410
>> Right.

159
00:09:33.410 --> 00:09:36.260
>> And it's just natural,
and it's not wrong.

160
00:09:36.260 --> 00:09:40.770
And I don't like to see organizations
where they beat themselves up about

161
00:09:42.050 --> 00:09:44.740
internal efforts etc.,
on things like these.

162
00:09:44.740 --> 00:09:48.080
There's nothing wrong with that, we just
have to accept that this is the way that

163
00:09:48.080 --> 00:09:52.600
it is and It won't necessarily be
as impartial as we would like.

164
00:09:52.600 --> 00:09:57.020
So start off with an internal assessment,
it'll totally give you a starting point.

165
00:09:57.020 --> 00:10:00.750
But an internal assessment, or
an evaluation, as we call it here,

166
00:10:00.750 --> 00:10:04.740
is not going to give us the full breadth
of knowledge of the outside world.

167
00:10:06.230 --> 00:10:08.580
>> All right, so, Jo,
where are we heading next?

168
00:10:08.580 --> 00:10:11.710
>> Well, what we'll do now is
after we've done the assessment,

169
00:10:11.710 --> 00:10:16.870
then we make decisions as to where we're
going, which is what we call direct.

170
00:10:16.870 --> 00:10:20.590
So we come up with the strategies and
our governance policies and

171
00:10:20.590 --> 00:10:22.050
then we communicate.

172
00:10:22.050 --> 00:10:24.170
And that includes as we said here,

173
00:10:24.170 --> 00:10:27.450
delegation of authority coz you
can't do everything yourself,

174
00:10:27.450 --> 00:10:32.480
our steering committees, and our vision
statements, and our mission statements.

175
00:10:32.480 --> 00:10:35.200
Now this has to be done top down and

176
00:10:35.200 --> 00:10:38.706
this is why governance is set
here at service strategy.

177
00:10:38.706 --> 00:10:46.640
It is no good just communicating
our strategies at a lower level.

178
00:10:46.640 --> 00:10:51.080
The communication of strategy has
to have senior management buy-in.

179
00:10:51.080 --> 00:10:55.060
It has to have support from our
management, from our steering groups,

180
00:10:55.060 --> 00:11:00.540
etc., and it has to come down
through our management hierarchies,

181
00:11:00.540 --> 00:11:04.039
because you see everybody wants
to know what's in it for them.

182
00:11:05.060 --> 00:11:09.520
And so, the CIO will be able to
communicate to the steering group

183
00:11:09.520 --> 00:11:11.518
exactly what it means to them.

184
00:11:11.518 --> 00:11:12.440
On the steering group,

185
00:11:12.440 --> 00:11:17.410
will be able to communicate to the process
managers exactly what's in it for them.

186
00:11:17.410 --> 00:11:18.550
On the process managers,

187
00:11:18.550 --> 00:11:23.766
will be able to communicate to their own
analyst exactly what's in it for them.

188
00:11:23.766 --> 00:11:28.870
And we have to have ongoing
visible commitment and

189
00:11:28.870 --> 00:11:30.720
support from management as well.

190
00:11:31.770 --> 00:11:35.160
This is not just a one off exercise,
you've already seen in a previous slide

191
00:11:35.160 --> 00:11:40.510
that this is iterative, this is not just
something that happens in a one off basis.

192
00:11:40.510 --> 00:11:45.880
So, we have to have, as I said, visible
ongoing commitment from senior management.

193
00:11:45.880 --> 00:11:48.720
And then once we have a strategy
that's been communicated,

194
00:11:48.720 --> 00:11:51.820
we have our governance policies,
then we monitor.

195
00:11:51.820 --> 00:11:55.110
And we monitor to see whether
we are complying with or

196
00:11:55.110 --> 00:11:59.175
whether we're adhering to and
whatever words you want to use.

197
00:11:59.175 --> 00:12:04.620
Are we actually going along with the
strategy, or are we deviating somewhere

198
00:12:04.620 --> 00:12:10.100
along the way, are we adhering to our
policies, or are we ignoring our policies?

199
00:12:10.100 --> 00:12:11.880
If we're ignoring our policies,

200
00:12:11.880 --> 00:12:15.710
then please don't think that this
is a terrible thing and we need to

201
00:12:15.710 --> 00:12:19.109
implement some sort of disciplinary
action in order to adhere to this.

202
00:12:20.690 --> 00:12:23.220
If we are not adhering to our policies,

203
00:12:23.220 --> 00:12:26.150
there's one of two things
that's gone wrong.

204
00:12:26.150 --> 00:12:30.140
The first is one is that we didn't
convince everybody of the need to change,

205
00:12:30.140 --> 00:12:34.280
and in which case, then it wasn't
communicated effectively, and

206
00:12:34.280 --> 00:12:35.830
we didn't get everybody on board.

207
00:12:35.830 --> 00:12:40.470
And again, I would refer everybody back
to continuous service improvement and

208
00:12:40.470 --> 00:12:42.520
look at Kotter's 8 steps for

209
00:12:42.520 --> 00:12:47.850
organizational change, transformational
change, we need to get everybody on board.

210
00:12:47.850 --> 00:12:51.860
But again, if we didn't, if we're
not getting adherence to policies,

211
00:12:51.860 --> 00:12:54.900
well, it's not to do with
organizational change,

212
00:12:54.900 --> 00:12:57.790
then it's got to be something to do with
the fact that the policies aren't right.

213
00:12:59.510 --> 00:13:04.140
We don't wanna use a baseball bat to
try and enforce policy adherence.

214
00:13:04.140 --> 00:13:08.510
What we want to do is encourage policy
adherence, so we're going to get that

215
00:13:08.510 --> 00:13:15.040
naturally, if the policies
are appropriate and if the policies work.

216
00:13:15.040 --> 00:13:17.410
Governance is not just
about the baseball bat, and

217
00:13:17.410 --> 00:13:22.140
this is why I don't like the word rules,
because this is not the approach we want.

218
00:13:22.140 --> 00:13:26.760
If the governance is relevant and
the governance has been

219
00:13:26.760 --> 00:13:30.860
created in a way where we have
consulted all of our stakeholders, and

220
00:13:30.860 --> 00:13:36.170
where everybody sees the need,
then it's not a rules-based policy at all.

221
00:13:36.170 --> 00:13:40.030
It's actually a policy that
everybody adheres to naturally,

222
00:13:40.030 --> 00:13:42.310
because it's the common sense thing to do.

223
00:13:43.490 --> 00:13:49.190
But we will assess whether we are adhering
to the policies, of course we will.

224
00:13:49.190 --> 00:13:52.240
So we'll do things like monitor our KPIs,

225
00:13:52.240 --> 00:13:56.080
and we may do risk assessments or
compliance ordinance, even,

226
00:13:56.080 --> 00:14:00.910
to see whether people are complying, and
we'll do capability analysis as well.

227
00:14:00.910 --> 00:14:07.130
Now capability analysis is just really
assessing whether we are capable,

228
00:14:07.130 --> 00:14:11.120
whether we have the right skills,
to be able to adhere to the policies.

229
00:14:11.120 --> 00:14:15.580
Because again, and I'll go back to
Kotter's 8 steps about creating the need

230
00:14:15.580 --> 00:14:20.670
for change, and ensuring that everybody
has the right skills to be able to

231
00:14:20.670 --> 00:14:24.320
deliver that change, or
to adhere to that policy.

232
00:14:24.320 --> 00:14:27.480
So this is why we would do
the capability analysis.

233
00:14:27.480 --> 00:14:31.520
You see we have to have what we
call a governance framework and

234
00:14:31.520 --> 00:14:36.420
a governance framework is just really
a structure to the way that we work.

235
00:14:36.420 --> 00:14:38.010
It's a structure to our policies,

236
00:14:38.010 --> 00:14:42.270
it's a structure to our strategies,
it's a structure to the way that we work.

237
00:14:42.270 --> 00:14:45.720
Now there is an international standard,

238
00:14:45.720 --> 00:14:50.730
ISO/IEC 38500-6 which actually

239
00:14:50.730 --> 00:14:55.820
looks at the principles of corporate
governance, and we can apply that to us.

240
00:14:55.820 --> 00:14:58.960
Now, I'm not telling everybody
that you got to go out and

241
00:14:58.960 --> 00:15:02.000
you got to adhere to
an international standard.

242
00:15:02.000 --> 00:15:06.425
What I am saying is that there
are frameworks out there

243
00:15:06.425 --> 00:15:08.427
that can help us with this.

244
00:15:08.427 --> 00:15:12.805
l hate to say this, and
is a big like financial management,

245
00:15:12.805 --> 00:15:17.545
when you strategy is the particular
life cycle phase that a lot of IT people

246
00:15:17.545 --> 00:15:21.385
like to run away from,
because it's all about corporate.

247
00:15:21.385 --> 00:15:24.035
It's all about the vision,
it's all about strategies,

248
00:15:24.035 --> 00:15:29.030
a very much to have seen their
management level, at CIO level.

249
00:15:29.030 --> 00:15:32.680
But we got a lot of tools that can help
us so we shouldn't run away from it,

250
00:15:32.680 --> 00:15:36.950
we shouldn't be scared of it, we should
embrace the tools that we have, and so

251
00:15:36.950 --> 00:15:38.620
there's an international
standard out there.

252
00:15:38.620 --> 00:15:43.610
I'm not telling you, you have to go and
complete an international standard audit.

253
00:15:43.610 --> 00:15:46.410
But what you can do is look
at the elements within

254
00:15:46.410 --> 00:15:50.100
that international standard and say,
okay, we can apply some of these.

255
00:15:50.100 --> 00:15:51.958
I mean, look how sensible they are.

256
00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:56.776
Establishing responsibilities, meet
the organization's objectives, acquire,

257
00:15:56.776 --> 00:16:01.060
in other words, when you purchase
anything, do it for a reason.

258
00:16:01.060 --> 00:16:02.817
Don't do just because you feel like it.

259
00:16:02.817 --> 00:16:07.129
In short, performance and
conformance with the rules and

260
00:16:07.129 --> 00:16:10.910
respect human factors, respect resistance.

261
00:16:10.910 --> 00:16:14.505
The resistance is going to be there so
you have to acknowledge it,

262
00:16:14.505 --> 00:16:18.985
you have to respect it and
then look for ways to manage it.

263
00:16:18.985 --> 00:16:22.615
Rather than just pretend it's going to
go away if you get the baseball bat out,

264
00:16:22.615 --> 00:16:25.005
because that's not going to work.

265
00:16:25.005 --> 00:16:30.235
So don't run away from governance,
embrace it and

266
00:16:30.235 --> 00:16:36.015
use the tools that are available to us, to
be able to formulate a governance policy.

267
00:16:37.048 --> 00:16:38.990
We start off with governors,

268
00:16:38.990 --> 00:16:42.240
right at the very very top
level within our organization.

269
00:16:42.240 --> 00:16:46.260
And the governors are people that are
responsible for the corporate governance.

270
00:16:46.260 --> 00:16:47.720
This aren't our executive board.

271
00:16:47.720 --> 00:16:51.250
These are people like the company's
secretary, or the chairperson,

272
00:16:51.250 --> 00:16:53.170
or corporate offices.

273
00:16:53.170 --> 00:16:56.560
And then underneath that we'll
have the executive board,

274
00:16:56.560 --> 00:17:01.430
which are our CEO and
our CFO and our CIO as well.

275
00:17:01.430 --> 00:17:07.090
And then underneath that, we have within
IT we have our IT steering group.

276
00:17:07.090 --> 00:17:10.240
And our IT steering group
takes the strategy and

277
00:17:10.240 --> 00:17:15.290
the governance that's been set by
the executive and the governors.

278
00:17:15.290 --> 00:17:21.935
And we will apply that to our IT
organizations, to our IT service provider.

279
00:17:21.935 --> 00:17:25.450
Strategy for the organization,
is strategy for the organization.

280
00:17:28.320 --> 00:17:33.120
But guess what, that includes us,
we are part of the organization.

281
00:17:33.120 --> 00:17:37.010
And whether we are an internal or
an external service provider.

282
00:17:37.010 --> 00:17:41.340
We have to meet the needs of the
organization and we have to work in a way

283
00:17:41.340 --> 00:17:47.340
that is ethically adhered to the strategy
and the direction of the organization.

284
00:17:47.340 --> 00:17:49.920
Even as an external service provider, so

285
00:17:49.920 --> 00:17:54.680
we have a responsibility to ensure
that we work in the same way.

286
00:17:54.680 --> 00:17:57.740
That our service portfolio has the right

287
00:17:57.740 --> 00:18:02.350
mix of services to enable the organization
to achieve their strategy.

288
00:18:02.350 --> 00:18:05.880
That we're managing our finances
in exactly the same way as

289
00:18:05.880 --> 00:18:07.620
the organization does.

290
00:18:07.620 --> 00:18:09.060
Sure, there are gonna be anomalies.

291
00:18:09.060 --> 00:18:12.230
And we looked at that in a previous
section when we looked at financial

292
00:18:12.230 --> 00:18:16.390
management because financial management
was all about cost models and

293
00:18:16.390 --> 00:18:18.120
cost types, etc.

294
00:18:18.120 --> 00:18:21.750
And we've got different cost types
to the organization because we've

295
00:18:21.750 --> 00:18:23.430
got computer equipment.

296
00:18:23.430 --> 00:18:28.810
But we still have the same policies and
we still have the same guidelines.

297
00:18:28.810 --> 00:18:33.290
And you know demand management looks
at the demand that's coming from

298
00:18:33.290 --> 00:18:38.995
the organization, but ultimately,
business relationship management.

299
00:18:38.995 --> 00:18:43.505
The key to helping us define our
strategy because it's business

300
00:18:43.505 --> 00:18:44.975
relationship management.

301
00:18:44.975 --> 00:18:50.230
As we looked at in a couple of episodes
previously within service strategy

302
00:18:50.230 --> 00:18:54.680
well they are the people that
sit within the organization and

303
00:18:54.680 --> 00:18:58.870
these are the people that actually
translate the business requirements and

304
00:18:58.870 --> 00:19:04.090
the business strategy and the business
vision into something that we can

305
00:19:04.090 --> 00:19:10.300
actually work with and that enables
us to facilitate their requirements.

306
00:19:10.300 --> 00:19:13.030
So governance is not something
that we should ran away from.

307
00:19:13.030 --> 00:19:18.182
Governance is something that we
should embrace because it enables

308
00:19:18.182 --> 00:19:23.611
us to set a direction and it enables
us to work with the organization and

309
00:19:23.611 --> 00:19:27.121
be completely aligned to the organization.

310
00:19:27.121 --> 00:19:30.596
And without governance, well we just
carry on doing what we want to do.

311
00:19:30.596 --> 00:19:34.596
And you know what happens to the IT
organization that just carries on doing

312
00:19:34.596 --> 00:19:36.200
what they want to do.

313
00:19:36.200 --> 00:19:37.230
Well eventually,

314
00:19:37.230 --> 00:19:41.010
the business will find somebody who's
going to help them achieve their goals.

315
00:19:41.010 --> 00:19:43.000
Cuz it's not about our goals.

316
00:19:43.000 --> 00:19:46.540
Our goal should always be to
deliver value to the business.

317
00:19:47.800 --> 00:19:48.510
>> Alright Jo.

318
00:19:48.510 --> 00:19:53.710
Once again, thank you for helping us to
understand this idea of governance better.

319
00:19:53.710 --> 00:19:56.630
In this episode, remember we talked
about a few different things here that

320
00:19:56.630 --> 00:19:58.810
governance is not necessarily about rules.

321
00:19:58.810 --> 00:20:02.910
Or is not the prescription of what we have
to do, but really setting that framework

322
00:20:02.910 --> 00:20:07.050
for the things that we talk about in terms
of how to set those policies as well.

323
00:20:07.050 --> 00:20:12.670
Also Jo described the activities here to
evaluate, to direct and monitor of course,

324
00:20:12.670 --> 00:20:15.540
to make sure everything is actually
working the way that we want them to.

325
00:20:15.540 --> 00:20:21.610
And then of course she also helped us
by looking into the other services and

326
00:20:21.610 --> 00:20:23.090
life cycles.

327
00:20:23.090 --> 00:20:25.350
Actually I think that's
just processes aren't they?

328
00:20:25.350 --> 00:20:27.980
The management side of things,

329
00:20:27.980 --> 00:20:32.190
to make sure that we understood where
it also took a role in that as well.

330
00:20:32.190 --> 00:20:35.610
That's a great place for
us to end this episode then.

331
00:20:35.610 --> 00:20:39.550
Signing off for ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

332
00:20:39.550 --> 00:20:40.540
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

333
00:20:40.540 --> 00:20:44.273
>> Stay tuned right here for more
ITIL Intermediate Service Strategy shows.

334
00:20:44.273 --> 00:20:50.430
[MUSIC]

335
00:20:50.430 --> 00:20:53.485
>> Thank you, for watching, ITPRO.TV.

Now it says up here on

00:01:55.350 --> 00:01:59.380
Quite often, we're in a position where,

Maybe we've already got some

When was the last time we

Back in the 1980s probably.

47

We've already got

48
00:02:28.720 --> 00:02:32.260
Now we've already got a network

00:02:35.280 --> 00:02:39.170
we've already got an organizational
infrastructure in place.

00:02:39.170 --> 00:02:42.010
So we never start off with
a blank piece of paper.

52
00:02:42.010 --> 00:02:44.150
So whilst is says it's a new vision.

That's what we're looking at we're looking

00:03:07.295 --> 00:03:10.320
