00:18:52.060 --> 00:18:54.484
And they look for
opportunities for new services.

305
00:18:54.484 --> 00:18:59.332
And we expect our expect our business
relationship manager remember to

306
00:18:59.332 --> 00:19:01.220
be proactive.

307
00:19:01.220 --> 00:19:05.949
Now, the person who is carrying it
out business relationship manager,

308
00:19:05.949 --> 00:19:10.524
may often carry out other process
activities too, such as conducting

309
00:19:10.524 --> 00:19:15.118
customer surveys to service level
management, defining strategy.

310
00:19:15.118 --> 00:19:18.343
Or advising on strategy for
strategy management.

311
00:19:18.343 --> 00:19:22.975
So business relationship
management really,

312
00:19:22.975 --> 00:19:28.230
they are our main and
key link with the business.

313
00:19:28.230 --> 00:19:33.380
And they are the person that well, as we
said in business relationship management

314
00:19:33.380 --> 00:19:37.690
episode, they're the person that builds
the trust with the organization.

315
00:19:38.870 --> 00:19:43.990
And we've got our strategy
management process owner and

316
00:19:43.990 --> 00:19:47.020
again, they're gonna work with all of
the other process owners because they

317
00:19:47.020 --> 00:19:51.760
are responsible for
setting the direction for IT.

318
00:19:51.760 --> 00:19:55.930
And we've got a process manager there
who is actually the person that

319
00:19:55.930 --> 00:20:00.770
compiles all of the strategies,
that compiles our policies,

320
00:20:00.770 --> 00:20:04.340
that educates our customers,
educates our users.

321
00:20:04.340 --> 00:20:08.900
And also will monitor
whether we are actually

322
00:20:08.900 --> 00:20:12.260
adhering to our policies and
our strategies.

323
00:20:12.260 --> 00:20:14.710
Then we've got our
portfolio process owner and

324
00:20:14.710 --> 00:20:18.450
our portfolio process owner,
what they take accountability.

325
00:20:18.450 --> 00:20:21.460
And that's the word we always look for
with a process owner.

326
00:20:21.460 --> 00:20:26.480
They take accountability to make sure
that portfolio management happening.

327
00:20:26.480 --> 00:20:31.550
And the process manager, well the process
manager is the person that will

328
00:20:31.550 --> 00:20:35.920
work with business relationship management
to identify new opportunities and

329
00:20:35.920 --> 00:20:37.260
new services.

330
00:20:37.260 --> 00:20:41.130
They will work with continuous
service improvement to identifying

331
00:20:41.130 --> 00:20:43.060
new opportunities.

332
00:20:43.060 --> 00:20:45.620
And they will also work with our

333
00:20:45.620 --> 00:20:50.080
organization to make
sure that we are actually

334
00:20:50.080 --> 00:20:55.080
delivering the right mix of services
to meet the needs of the organization.

335
00:20:55.080 --> 00:20:59.220
So of course, the process manager for
the portfolio is responsible for

336
00:20:59.220 --> 00:21:02.330
evaluating all of the services
in our portfolio.

337
00:21:03.445 --> 00:21:08.175
Now financial management process
are not again takes accountability for

338
00:21:08.175 --> 00:21:10.045
financial management.

339
00:21:10.045 --> 00:21:16.245
So they will work with the organization
to set the direction and to translate

340
00:21:16.245 --> 00:21:21.105
those directional policies from
the organization into policies for IT.

341
00:21:22.555 --> 00:21:26.940
Whereas the process manager,
they're the people that manages the other

342
00:21:26.940 --> 00:21:31.360
person rather than manages financial
management on a day to day basis.

343
00:21:31.360 --> 00:21:32.980
So they produce the budgets.

344
00:21:32.980 --> 00:21:34.990
They produce the accounting records.

345
00:21:34.990 --> 00:21:39.470
They're the person that will
manage any charging for instance.

346
00:21:39.470 --> 00:21:40.906
Produces all of the reports.

347
00:21:40.906 --> 00:21:45.063
And then we have the demand
management process owner.

348
00:21:45.063 --> 00:21:49.210
And again, we're talking about
accountability for demand management.

349
00:21:49.210 --> 00:21:55.025
Ensuring that we understand
the demand of the organization.

350
00:21:55.025 --> 00:22:00.495
Whereas the process manager, they're
responsible for defining the patterns

351
00:22:00.495 --> 00:22:04.785
of business activity, liaising with
capacity management to look for

352
00:22:04.785 --> 00:22:09.195
innovative ways to meet
capacity requirements.

353
00:22:09.195 --> 00:22:13.545
Remember with demand management, it's
not just about putting in more capacity.

354
00:22:13.545 --> 00:22:15.885
It's not just about buying more planes.

355
00:22:15.885 --> 00:22:20.260
It's actually about trying
to even out the peaks and

356
00:22:20.260 --> 00:22:23.380
troughs so that we don't need
to buy more planes, okay?

357
00:22:23.380 --> 00:22:27.690
So it's working very,
very closely with capacity management.

358
00:22:27.690 --> 00:22:30.097
Now one thing I want to tell
you about the process owner and

359
00:22:30.097 --> 00:22:32.519
the process manager role is
to think about scalability.

360
00:22:32.519 --> 00:22:34.920
With a large scale organization,

361
00:22:34.920 --> 00:22:40.980
you probably gonna have one process
owner and multiple process managers.

362
00:22:40.980 --> 00:22:45.610
With a small organization, then it's quite
possible that the process owner role and

363
00:22:45.610 --> 00:22:48.780
the process manager role will be combined.

364
00:22:49.940 --> 00:22:52.070
Always think about scalability.

365
00:22:52.070 --> 00:22:54.690
There is no right or wrong way to do this.

366
00:22:54.690 --> 00:22:56.410
This is not prescriptive.

367
00:22:56.410 --> 00:23:01.800
We are just telling you the processes
that we need to have in place.

368
00:23:01.800 --> 00:23:03.740
But who performs these processes, and

369
00:23:03.740 --> 00:23:08.720
what your organizational chart looks like,
well that's completely up to you.

370
00:23:10.100 --> 00:23:13.220
>> All right Jo, well thank you again for
helping us out and

371
00:23:13.220 --> 00:23:17.340
taking a look at this idea of organizing
for our service strategy here.

372
00:23:17.340 --> 00:23:19.980
We do wanna make sure that we
understand those different stages.

373
00:23:19.980 --> 00:23:21.780
Make sure you go back through.

374
00:23:21.780 --> 00:23:26.550
And also, the homework that Jo actually
assigned you important to integrate and

375
00:23:26.550 --> 00:23:29.950
to understand all of those
different elements combined.

376
00:23:29.950 --> 00:23:33.320
Well, this is a great place for
us to go ahead and end this episode then.

377
00:23:33.320 --> 00:23:35.670
Signing off for ITProTV.

378
00:23:35.670 --> 00:23:37.090
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

379
00:23:37.090 --> 00:23:38.090
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

380
00:23:38.090 --> 00:23:41.872
>> Stay tuned right here for more of the
ITIL Intermediate Service Strategy shows

381
00:23:41.872 --> 00:23:46.691
[MUSIC]

382
00:23:46.691 --> 00:23:51.368
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo talk about where the implementation of service strategy begins.  Jo discusses that it begins with the perspective, positions, plans and patterns.  This helps us to implement activities to help with the other lifecycle stages to make sure we provide a directed and consistent path that aligns with our organization.
episodes.title: Implementing Service Strategy
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:02.875
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:02.875 --> 00:00:04.732
>> Coming at you live from San Francisco,

3
00:00:04.732 --> 00:00:05.411
California.

4
00:00:05.411 --> 00:00:07.923
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:07.923 --> 00:00:12.205
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

6
00:00:12.205 --> 00:00:15.597
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITPro.TV.

7
00:00:15.597 --> 00:00:19.300
You're watching the ITIL
Intermediate Service Strategy show.

8
00:00:19.300 --> 00:00:20.790
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

9
00:00:20.790 --> 00:00:25.940
And today we're gonna be taking a look at
implementing service strategy in ITIL.

10
00:00:25.940 --> 00:00:27.390
And here to help us out is gonna be,

11
00:00:27.390 --> 00:00:32.070
of course, well,
our ITIL empress herself, Jo Peacock.

12
00:00:32.070 --> 00:00:33.350
Jo, welcome to the show.

13
00:00:33.350 --> 00:00:34.540
>> Thank you very much.

14
00:00:34.540 --> 00:00:36.550
Yet again I need the robe.

15
00:00:36.550 --> 00:00:38.730
Well, once again, here you are.

16
00:00:38.730 --> 00:00:41.800
But you're now back with
us on planet Earth.

17
00:00:41.800 --> 00:00:43.180
>> I'm not time-traveling anymore.

18
00:00:43.180 --> 00:00:46.050
>> No longer time-traveling,
no longer intergalactic.

19
00:00:46.050 --> 00:00:49.480
You are right here at the center
of the universe of course.

20
00:00:49.480 --> 00:00:50.800
And that means it's time for

21
00:00:50.800 --> 00:00:55.030
us to talk about the Implementation
here of service strategy.

22
00:00:55.030 --> 00:00:57.130
So Jo, where do we begin?

23
00:00:57.130 --> 00:00:57.849
>> Well.

24
00:00:57.849 --> 00:01:00.912
>> [LAUGH]
>> First thing we've gotta do is work out

25
00:01:00.912 --> 00:01:02.090
where we begin.

26
00:01:02.090 --> 00:01:04.820
And that's a key one
with service strategy.

27
00:01:04.820 --> 00:01:07.900
Quite often you think,
it's service strategy, and therefore,

28
00:01:07.900 --> 00:01:09.405
it can't be that difficult.

29
00:01:09.405 --> 00:01:14.100
But actually, service strategy is what
sets the direction for the rest of IT.

30
00:01:14.100 --> 00:01:16.590
So we're starting at the very beginning,

31
00:01:16.590 --> 00:01:20.825
because apparently I've heard that
that's a very good place to start.

32
00:01:20.825 --> 00:01:22.153
>> At least with the number one.

33
00:01:22.153 --> 00:01:23.530
>> [LAUGH] Exactly, so

34
00:01:23.530 --> 00:01:29.220
we start off by looking right in the very
start in our service directory class.

35
00:01:29.220 --> 00:01:32.310
We looked at our four Ps,
our four Ps of service strategy.

36
00:01:32.310 --> 00:01:36.310
And we're gonna start off by
looking at those four Ps here.

37
00:01:36.310 --> 00:01:41.460
And this is where we will
start with service strategies.

38
00:01:41.460 --> 00:01:44.230
Understanding our organization.

39
00:01:44.230 --> 00:01:48.091
So the first thing we are going to do is
we are going to allocate somebody with

40
00:01:48.091 --> 00:01:50.374
the responsibility for service strategy.

41
00:01:50.374 --> 00:01:54.680
And what they're going to do,
is they're going to analyze the business.

42
00:01:54.680 --> 00:01:58.010
They're going to look at the perspective,
and the positions, and the plans, and

43
00:01:58.010 --> 00:01:58.960
the patterns.

44
00:01:58.960 --> 00:02:03.960
Now for anybody that missed the session
where we looked at our four Ps,

45
00:02:03.960 --> 00:02:07.880
well that was probably quite
some time ago now, okay.

46
00:02:07.880 --> 00:02:10.120
Well our four Ps are very simply this.

47
00:02:10.120 --> 00:02:14.990
Our perspective for our organization
is what is our organization doing,

48
00:02:14.990 --> 00:02:16.290
what is their vision?

49
00:02:16.290 --> 00:02:17.480
What is their perspective?

50
00:02:17.480 --> 00:02:19.750
Are they going to just run the business?

51
00:02:19.750 --> 00:02:20.970
Is that what they want to do?

52
00:02:22.200 --> 00:02:24.646
Treading water,
maintaining the status quo.

53
00:02:24.646 --> 00:02:27.890
Or do they want to grow their business?

54
00:02:27.890 --> 00:02:30.092
Or do they want to transform
their business, and

55
00:02:30.092 --> 00:02:35.940
transform means growing outside of
their particular industry sector.

56
00:02:35.940 --> 00:02:40.960
Now, don't assume that running the
business is a bad thing, because it's not.

57
00:02:40.960 --> 00:02:44.596
Running the business actually means
that they simply want to maintain their

58
00:02:44.596 --> 00:02:45.745
status quo for a while.

59
00:02:45.745 --> 00:02:48.873
Now, organizations such as
government departments,

60
00:02:48.873 --> 00:02:53.430
they will maintain a strategy or
a perspective of running the business.

61
00:02:53.430 --> 00:02:55.215
Organizations such as not for

62
00:02:55.215 --> 00:03:00.060
profits may maintain a strategy
of just running the business.

63
00:03:00.060 --> 00:03:04.640
And some organizations who've had a rapid
period of growth, well they may also

64
00:03:04.640 --> 00:03:08.580
maintain a strategy of just running
the business for a period of time.

65
00:03:09.930 --> 00:03:15.630
So we have then within our organization
what we call a strategic perspective.

66
00:03:15.630 --> 00:03:20.570
And we have to translate that into
a strategic perspective for us.

67
00:03:20.570 --> 00:03:25.210
Because what we need to do is be aligned
with the needs of the organization and

68
00:03:25.210 --> 00:03:28.080
facilitate their strategy.

69
00:03:28.080 --> 00:03:32.310
So that top box in the middle
there on this diagram,

70
00:03:32.310 --> 00:03:36.550
it says it depends on type one,
two or three, and it does.

71
00:03:36.550 --> 00:03:40.650
An internal service provider, which is
a type one, well if it's internal to

72
00:03:40.650 --> 00:03:44.870
the business unit we want to be completely
aligned with the business unit.

73
00:03:44.870 --> 00:03:48.558
Now a type two service provider
is a shared service provider.

74
00:03:48.558 --> 00:03:52.650
Now different business units
may have different strategies.

75
00:03:52.650 --> 00:03:56.540
And then a type three service provider,
now there's your challenge.

76
00:03:56.540 --> 00:04:01.060
Because a type three service provider,
you are external to the organization, and

77
00:04:01.060 --> 00:04:03.490
you may have other customers.

78
00:04:03.490 --> 00:04:08.100
Which means that when you are meeting
the needs of this particular organisation,

79
00:04:08.100 --> 00:04:12.740
your strategy must reflect
this organization.

80
00:04:12.740 --> 00:04:17.240
But, you may have the added challenge
of when you are meeting the needs of

81
00:04:17.240 --> 00:04:21.375
another organization, then your strategy
may have to reflect that organization.

82
00:04:22.410 --> 00:04:26.330
Now as an external service provider,
you might find yourself in the position

83
00:04:26.330 --> 00:04:31.200
where you are simply running one
business but growing another business,

84
00:04:31.200 --> 00:04:34.490
and perhaps even transforming
another business.

85
00:04:34.490 --> 00:04:37.370
Now when we looked at
that particular section,

86
00:04:37.370 --> 00:04:40.830
when we looked at the episode
where we analyzed our four Ps,

87
00:04:40.830 --> 00:04:44.560
we saw what those four Ps meant for
the service provider.

88
00:04:45.840 --> 00:04:49.120
And here in service strategy when
we're talking about implementation,

89
00:04:49.120 --> 00:04:51.130
this is where we've got to start.

90
00:04:51.130 --> 00:04:56.530
Understanding the four Ps for the
organization, and what that means to us.

91
00:04:56.530 --> 00:04:59.154
What is our strategic position?

92
00:04:59.154 --> 00:05:05.030
Now based on our understanding of
the perspective, where are we right now?

93
00:05:05.030 --> 00:05:09.570
What customers do we serve, and
what market spaces can we serve?

94
00:05:10.930 --> 00:05:12.470
So what is our position?

95
00:05:12.470 --> 00:05:13.410
What are we going to do?

96
00:05:13.410 --> 00:05:15.960
What are we going to grow into?

97
00:05:15.960 --> 00:05:19.470
And that should then
lead into specific plans,

98
00:05:19.470 --> 00:05:23.867
and then patterns of behavior,
or patterns of execution.

99
00:05:23.867 --> 00:05:28.610
So the key is to start off with
our strategic perspective.

100
00:05:28.610 --> 00:05:31.100
Understand who our organization is.

101
00:05:31.100 --> 00:05:33.120
What it is they want to achieve.

102
00:05:33.120 --> 00:05:38.000
And then translate that into something
that is meaningful for us, okay.

103
00:05:39.660 --> 00:05:42.043
The third bullet point down is
a really important one, and

104
00:05:42.043 --> 00:05:44.145
it's sometimes somewhere
where we all get stuck.

105
00:05:44.145 --> 00:05:47.682
And it says there that the traditional
service providers will allow their

106
00:05:47.682 --> 00:05:49.520
technology to influence the market.

107
00:05:49.520 --> 00:05:53.750
In other words, what we do right now will,
and what we have in front of us

108
00:05:53.750 --> 00:05:57.590
influences our market and
influences the directions that we go in.

109
00:06:00.190 --> 00:06:03.660
I just had an online conversation,
as it were,

110
00:06:03.660 --> 00:06:10.020
with somebody not too long ago where I
actually did exactly the same thing.

111
00:06:10.020 --> 00:06:14.241
And I said, I simply made the statement,
well, I couldn't come and

112
00:06:14.241 --> 00:06:16.110
work for an organization like that,

113
00:06:16.110 --> 00:06:19.710
because the technology is
different to that which I prefer.

114
00:06:20.990 --> 00:06:27.284
Now, there's a statement that a lot of
service providers will actually make.

115
00:06:27.284 --> 00:06:32.040
Well, I can't go into that market
space because this is not within my

116
00:06:32.040 --> 00:06:33.607
realm of experience.

117
00:06:33.607 --> 00:06:38.426
I cannot make this offering to our
customer because this is not In

118
00:06:38.426 --> 00:06:42.170
line with the technology that we support.

119
00:06:42.170 --> 00:06:44.840
Or we want to innovate
in this direction and

120
00:06:44.840 --> 00:06:47.150
the customer wants to
go in that direction.

121
00:06:48.420 --> 00:06:52.599
We are here to provide
value to our organization.

122
00:06:54.240 --> 00:06:57.010
I have said previously,
and I will say it again,

123
00:06:57.010 --> 00:07:01.606
that there's always somebody knocking on
the door of your CEO offering to do your

124
00:07:01.606 --> 00:07:04.939
job to a higher quality, and
potentially for less money.

125
00:07:04.939 --> 00:07:09.670
And so we have to acknowledge that
we in IT have competition out there.

126
00:07:09.670 --> 00:07:11.550
Whether we're an internal
service provider or

127
00:07:11.550 --> 00:07:15.930
whether we're an external service
provider, we have competition.

128
00:07:15.930 --> 00:07:20.210
And it's our role to align ourselves
with the needs of the organization.

129
00:07:20.210 --> 00:07:23.048
So where do we start when we're
implementing service strategy?

130
00:07:23.048 --> 00:07:26.744
Well, we go and
see what the organization are doing, and

131
00:07:26.744 --> 00:07:29.985
we understand how we can
align ourselves to them.

132
00:07:29.985 --> 00:07:33.253
So we'll do a current state assessment and

133
00:07:33.253 --> 00:07:38.900
we will do a target state assessment for
the implementation, okay?

134
00:07:38.900 --> 00:07:42.950
Where are we right now, and where do
we want to be, and what are the gaps?

135
00:07:44.220 --> 00:07:46.680
And then we create a project.

136
00:07:46.680 --> 00:07:50.084
We estimate how long that project is going
to take to implement service strategy.

137
00:07:50.084 --> 00:07:53.780
And then we will consolidate that project.

138
00:07:53.780 --> 00:07:56.833
In other words,
what we will do is we will create tasks.

139
00:07:56.833 --> 00:07:59.879
And we will create activity streams and

140
00:07:59.879 --> 00:08:05.320
then we will consolidate each
of those activity streams.

141
00:08:05.320 --> 00:08:09.220
Now, we've all seen a project Gantt
chart and we need to do something very,

142
00:08:09.220 --> 00:08:13.600
very similar when we're implementing
service strategy, it is a project.

143
00:08:13.600 --> 00:08:17.630
As we implement service management,
it's a project.

144
00:08:17.630 --> 00:08:22.050
It's not something that you can just wave
magic wand over and it will just happen.

145
00:08:22.050 --> 00:08:26.290
We have to have a consistent,

146
00:08:26.290 --> 00:08:31.200
we have to have a documented,
formalized approach.

147
00:08:31.200 --> 00:08:34.610
This is not something
that we can do ad hoc.

148
00:08:34.610 --> 00:08:37.810
So the first thing that we need to do is,
well, we need to design it.

149
00:08:37.810 --> 00:08:41.050
We need to design what our processes
are going to look like and

150
00:08:41.050 --> 00:08:46.630
we need to design all of our
measurements for our processes as well.

151
00:08:46.630 --> 00:08:49.390
What tools do we need for our processes?

152
00:08:49.390 --> 00:08:52.820
Who is actually going to
perform our processes?

153
00:08:52.820 --> 00:08:56.390
And what skills do we need for
those processes as well?

154
00:08:56.390 --> 00:08:59.220
What about the actual services themselves?

155
00:08:59.220 --> 00:09:04.250
We're defining a service strategy
that will bring in new services.

00:09:04.250 --> 00:09:06.870

157
00:09:06.870 --> 00:09:08.770
What type of services are we looking for?

161

Service portfolio management ensures that

00:10:31.610 --> 00:10:36.020

board of directors, well,

00:10:40.070 --> 00:10:41.890
we don't expect them to
be technical people.

They just see a challenge.

00:10:43.740 --> 00:10:46.430
And it's quite possible as in this case.

183
00:10:46.430 --> 00:10:51.540
The one business case was approved to

00:10:51.540 --> 00:10:55.610

00:10:55.610 --> 00:10:59.370

they were both approved and

187
00:11:04.500 --> 00:11:09.060

service portfolio management in place.

188
00:11:09.060 --> 00:11:11.140
Because we don't want
to make that mistake.

189
00:11:12.650 --> 00:11:15.610
So then we have to build
all of our processes.

190
00:11:15.610 --> 00:11:19.120

00:11:21.680 --> 00:11:25.340

00:11:25.340 --> 00:11:27.820

we test all of these tools, and

194
00:11:27.820 --> 00:11:29.820
we test that the processes work.

195
00:11:29.820 --> 00:11:33.620
And that means giving people
the right amount of training.

196
00:11:33.620 --> 00:11:35.910
And then once we've
implemented any process,

197
00:11:35.910 --> 00:11:39.950

198
00:11:39.950 --> 00:11:42.520
Because, let's face it,
that's what we're designing it to be.

199
00:11:43.840 --> 00:11:49.000

processes in an ongoing basis,

200
00:11:49.000 --> 00:11:50.840
think about CMMI,

201
00:11:50.840 --> 00:11:56.750

202
00:11:56.750 --> 00:12:01.950
And if you're not sure about CMMI
techniques, then I would please ask you to

203
00:12:01.950 --> 00:12:07.500

service improvement section.

00:12:07.500 --> 00:12:10.950
The continual,
CSI class as we like to call it.

00:12:10.950 --> 00:12:14.180
Take a look there and

206
00:12:14.180 --> 00:12:19.079
the CMMI approach for
maturity of processes.

207
00:12:20.500 --> 00:12:23.440
Now we're not telling you that you
need to be a level five with all of

208
00:12:23.440 --> 00:12:24.200

209
00:12:24.200 --> 00:12:27.990
When you first implement a process

210
00:12:27.990 --> 00:12:31.640
But you don't need to be at level zero or
a level one either,

211
00:12:31.640 --> 00:12:33.560
which is an ad hoc process.

212
00:12:33.560 --> 00:12:38.250
We've already talked about designing
a process, and transitioning a process,

213
00:12:38.250 --> 00:12:40.650
implementing it and testing that it works.

214
00:12:40.650 --> 00:12:45.150
So make sure that we need
to be at least at level

215
00:12:45.150 --> 00:12:47.860
three to four when we implement a process.

216
00:12:47.860 --> 00:12:52.046
And if we've tested it correctly for
efficiency and defectiveness and

217
00:12:52.046 --> 00:12:54.278
it's consistent and it's managed,

218
00:12:54.278 --> 00:12:58.268
then we'll achieve that without
any problems whatsoever, okay.

219
00:12:58.268 --> 00:13:00.267
So here in service operations, and

that these processes work.

221

management is coming up with ideas for

222
00:13:07.891 --> 00:13:08.816
new services.

223
00:13:08.816 --> 00:13:12.702
The business cases are being approved and
they are being compiled,

224

some business cases are rejected,
and that's okay.

225
00:13:16.880 --> 00:13:21.730
And that the right level of services
can be found in the service catalog.

226
00:13:21.730 --> 00:13:24.940
That we don't have too much
duplication in our services, and

227
00:13:24.940 --> 00:13:29.190
the services are being
retired when they need to be.

228
00:13:29.190 --> 00:13:33.590
And then, of course, CSI plays
a really big part in service strategy,

229
00:13:33.590 --> 00:13:36.249
because CSI recommends improvements.

230
00:13:37.560 --> 00:13:42.640
CSI is that life cycle phase
that will come along and

231
00:13:42.640 --> 00:13:45.590
will measure whether our
processes are working.

232
00:13:45.590 --> 00:13:50.170
It will also measure whether our
tools are functioning correctly and

233
00:13:50.170 --> 00:13:57.240
whether we are actually measuring
the right parts of our processes as well.

234
00:13:57.240 --> 00:14:00.850
They will evaluate if our strategy,
as a whole,

235
00:14:00.850 --> 00:14:04.850
is meeting the objectives and
meeting the needs of the organization.

236
00:14:07.080 --> 00:14:09.300
So what does strategy do then?

237
00:14:09.300 --> 00:14:13.230
We know that strategy
defines the strategy for

238
00:14:13.230 --> 00:14:18.240
the whole of the IT service
provider organization.

239
00:14:18.240 --> 00:14:22.270
Which means the strategy sets
our policies in service design.

240
00:14:22.270 --> 00:14:27.640
It sets the policies for what is
considered to be customer satisfaction.

241
00:14:27.640 --> 00:14:31.927
It actually defines how we're going
to achieve customer satisfaction and

242
00:14:31.927 --> 00:14:34.275
it sets design boundaries, as well.

243
00:14:34.275 --> 00:14:37.635
So strategy tells us what we can buy and
what we can't buy.

244
00:14:37.635 --> 00:14:41.435
Strategy will tell us what is beyond
the realms of possibility and

245
00:14:41.435 --> 00:14:43.835
what's perfectly feasible.

246
00:14:43.835 --> 00:14:47.475
In another of your episode, I told you
about the organization that I worked with,

247
00:14:47.475 --> 00:14:55.040
that actually moved from a Windows
environment to an Apple-based environment.

248
00:14:55.040 --> 00:14:58.980
Now, service strategy, well,
they get involved because they set that

249
00:14:58.980 --> 00:15:01.971
direction and they will tell us
whether that's possible or not.

250
00:15:01.971 --> 00:15:06.810
Is it something that we want to achieve or
is it something that actually

251
00:15:06.810 --> 00:15:10.180
does not align ourselves with
the vision of the organization and

252
00:15:10.180 --> 00:15:12.070
therefore it's not
something that we can do.

253
00:15:12.070 --> 00:15:15.810
And even if we had the request
in to use those products,

254
00:15:15.810 --> 00:15:18.860
then maybe it's not something
that aligns with the vision.

255
00:15:20.210 --> 00:15:23.790
Strategy also tells us how we transition.

256
00:15:23.790 --> 00:15:28.970
Now, strategy, we talk policies a lot
in service transition cuz we talk about

257
00:15:28.970 --> 00:15:32.450

we talk about change policies.

258
00:15:32.450 --> 00:15:36.650
These policies are directed
by service strategy.

259
00:15:37.980 --> 00:15:42.260
They are not defined for service strategy.

260
00:15:42.260 --> 00:15:44.330
Policies for change and the policies for

261
00:15:44.330 --> 00:15:47.848
releasing deployment manager
are defined by the process owners.

262
00:15:47.848 --> 00:15:51.685
But nevertheless,
service strategy sets the direction.

263
00:15:51.685 --> 00:15:56.767
So service strategy will tell us what's
acceptable and what's not acceptable.

264
00:15:56.767 --> 00:16:01.835
And service strategy gives us
the boundaries within which to work.

265
00:16:01.835 --> 00:16:06.690
And service strategy also gives
us the boundaries within which

266
00:16:06.690 --> 00:16:11.543

have been deployed into the live

267
00:16:11.543 --> 00:16:15.130
environment at the end
of early life support.

268
00:16:16.380 --> 00:16:17.850

269
00:16:17.850 --> 00:16:23.780

00:16:23.780 --> 00:16:26.120

271
00:16:26.120 --> 00:16:30.640
Service level management, we define

274
00:16:37.792 --> 00:16:42.770

275
00:16:42.770 --> 00:16:45.910
Until at the end of early
life support it's signed and

276
00:16:45.910 --> 00:16:51.550

agreement within service operation.

277
00:16:51.550 --> 00:16:56.400

we'll conduct a service review meeting

279
00:17:02.100 --> 00:17:04.300
How often do we have these meetings?

280
00:17:04.300 --> 00:17:06.340
Service strategy can help us with that.

281
00:17:06.340 --> 00:17:11.880
Service strategy defines how often we
should have service review meetings.

282
00:17:11.880 --> 00:17:14.910
Service strategy may even define
something that says, well,

283
00:17:14.910 --> 00:17:17.570

284
00:17:17.570 --> 00:17:21.880

embedded into the live environment and

285
00:17:21.880 --> 00:17:23.990
our customers become happy and

286
00:17:23.990 --> 00:17:29.197

will conduct service review meetings.

287
00:17:29.197 --> 00:17:34.100
Maybe every two months, and
after a year, maybe every three months.

288
00:17:34.100 --> 00:17:39.470
Those policies are directed
by service strategy.

289
00:17:39.470 --> 00:17:43.740
Now, I'm not saying that service strategy
actually define the exact policies for

290
00:17:43.740 --> 00:17:48.650

they will give us a direction.

291
00:17:48.650 --> 00:17:51.120
That's what strategy's all about, okay?

292
00:17:51.120 --> 00:17:52.070
It gives us a direction.

293

00:17:58.800 --> 00:18:04.230

what direction we're heading in.

295
00:18:04.230 --> 00:18:09.410
And CSI has a responsibility to
ensure that everything that we do

296
00:18:09.410 --> 00:18:13.050

aligns us with that direction.

297
00:18:13.050 --> 00:18:18.580

298
00:18:18.580 --> 00:18:21.929

299

continual service improvement even,

300
00:18:29.537 --> 00:18:35.224
[LAUGH] exactly what we need

301

302
00:18:40.414 --> 00:18:47.340

a result of CSI activities.

303
00:18:47.340 --> 00:18:49.810
So the two are very, very close.

304
00:18:49.810 --> 00:18:52.490

305
00:18:53.940 --> 00:18:58.422

>> [LAUGH]
>> Where do you start?

309
00:19:02.740 --> 00:19:06.363
>> We start with

organization, and that's the full piece

00:19:11.110 --> 00:19:16.000

00:19:16.000 --> 00:19:18.440

00:19:22.800 --> 00:19:27.610

00:19:34.790 --> 00:19:39.940

317
00:19:39.940 --> 00:19:46.440

318
00:19:46.440 --> 00:19:49.720

new ideas for

00:19:49.720 --> 00:19:52.810

320
00:19:52.810 --> 00:19:57.348

279
00:18:31.250 --> 00:18:33.630
But if their strategy
is to run the business,

280
00:18:33.630 --> 00:18:35.750
then we should not be trying to grow.

281
00:18:37.510 --> 00:18:41.350
Be careful about design and
operating risks.

282
00:18:41.350 --> 00:18:45.390
And design risks, operating risks,
just make sure that we deliver in value.

283
00:18:45.390 --> 00:18:48.860
That we're not designing
what we want to design, and

284
00:18:48.860 --> 00:18:52.930
we are not operating how
we think we should operate.

285
00:18:52.930 --> 00:18:56.780
This is about understanding
what the organization wants and

286
00:18:56.780 --> 00:18:59.610
being aligned to the organization.

287
00:18:59.610 --> 00:19:06.946
Remember, and I've said this in previous
sessions, your organization has a choice.

288
00:19:06.946 --> 00:19:11.355
They have a choice whether to use you or
whether to use an external or

289
00:19:11.355 --> 00:19:13.580
an alternate service provider.

290
00:19:15.310 --> 00:19:20.290
What you have to do is ensure that
your strategy aligns with their needs.

291
00:19:20.290 --> 00:19:25.730
So that you have that unique selling
point to your organization that

292
00:19:25.730 --> 00:19:33.550
they are able to identify that you meet
their needs better than anybody else.

293
00:19:33.550 --> 00:19:37.760
We have to have the right
people with the right amount of

294
00:19:37.760 --> 00:19:42.230
skills within service
strategy to be able to align

295
00:19:42.230 --> 00:19:46.650
our strategic direction with
the organization's strategic direction.

296
00:19:47.700 --> 00:19:51.430
And we have to have the right amount
of support from senior management

297
00:19:52.430 --> 00:19:56.940
to allow us to undertake strategy tasks.

298
00:19:56.940 --> 00:20:00.790
Such as coming up with the new ideas for
new services.

299
00:20:01.950 --> 00:20:04.640
Undertaking business
relationship management,

300
00:20:04.640 --> 00:20:07.800
valuing that relationship
with the business.

301
00:20:07.800 --> 00:20:11.980
And making sure that we are continually
aligned to the needs of the business.

302
00:20:11.980 --> 00:20:17.560
And we keep our tools up to date,
such as our service catalog.

303
00:20:17.560 --> 00:20:22.440
I don't know about you, but when I log
onto a catalog and I'm looking for

304
00:20:22.440 --> 00:20:27.003
something online, because we do
everything online nowadays, and

305
00:20:27.003 --> 00:20:29.501
I'm looking for something online.

306
00:20:29.501 --> 00:20:33.590
If the provider's website that
I log onto isn't working,

307
00:20:33.590 --> 00:20:38.110
I'm gonna go somewhere else,
I'm not gonna give it another go.

308
00:20:39.320 --> 00:20:43.830
If I log onto a particular website and I
get an error message, or that page is slow

309
00:20:43.830 --> 00:20:48.240
in loading, I'm not gonna give it
another go, I'm an impatient person.

310
00:20:48.240 --> 00:20:50.670
I'm gonna go somewhere else,
and I'm gonna try and

311
00:20:50.670 --> 00:20:53.830
find the same thing somewhere else.

312
00:20:53.830 --> 00:20:57.220
Your customers have that
same level of expectation.

313
00:20:58.560 --> 00:21:03.010
And I wonder how many times
I've heard end users and

314
00:21:03.010 --> 00:21:06.760
customers within a business sit
down in front of their screens and

315
00:21:06.760 --> 00:21:09.310
say, well I can do a lot more
at home than I can do here.

316
00:21:10.620 --> 00:21:11.449
You know what that tells me?

317
00:21:11.449 --> 00:21:15.560
That our strategy's not aligned
with the needs of the business.

318
00:21:15.560 --> 00:21:19.690
Because quite simply, we aren't providing
the technology we want to provide, and

319
00:21:19.690 --> 00:21:22.755
when we're not providing
the technology that they need to see.

320
00:21:24.170 --> 00:21:25.896
And if you're hearing that, and

321
00:21:25.896 --> 00:21:29.120
the person that listens to that is
business relationship management, and if

322
00:21:29.120 --> 00:21:34.290
you're hearing that in your organization,
then it's time to rethink your strategy.

323
00:21:34.290 --> 00:21:37.170
Because your organization is probably

324
00:21:37.170 --> 00:21:40.310
already rethinking the value
that you provide to them.

325
00:21:42.200 --> 00:21:44.710
We might think of strategy as
being an afterthought, and

326
00:21:44.710 --> 00:21:46.180
I'm sure that we sometimes do.

327
00:21:47.360 --> 00:21:50.930
But to be perfectly honest,
without service strategy,

328
00:21:50.930 --> 00:21:54.630
then IT ends up doing what IT wants to do.

329
00:21:54.630 --> 00:21:58.770
And that's when we lose sight
of the organization, and

330
00:21:58.770 --> 00:22:03.430
that's when we lose that synergy
that we have with our organization.

331
00:22:03.430 --> 00:22:05.240
And we don't want to do that,

332
00:22:05.240 --> 00:22:08.840
ultimately what we want to do is to
deliver value to the organization.

333
00:22:09.870 --> 00:22:13.640
So right now, you have some
exercises that you need to do.

334
00:22:13.640 --> 00:22:18.810
You've probably got about an hour's
worth of exercises to do, that looks at

335
00:22:18.810 --> 00:22:24.025
the structures and organizational
structures of service management.

336
00:22:24.025 --> 00:22:28.415
That looks at automation, and
it looks at the challenges and

337
00:22:28.415 --> 00:22:31.805
critical success factors
of service strategy.

338
00:22:31.805 --> 00:22:35.785
So I'd like you to go away and
do those exercises.

339
00:22:35.785 --> 00:22:39.285
They will take you probably about
an hour to an hour and a half.

340
00:22:39.285 --> 00:22:45.020
And feel free, if you have any questions
or any queries, to join us in the forum,

341
00:22:45.020 --> 00:22:49.150
and we'll be happy to help with
any questions that you may have.

342
00:22:49.150 --> 00:22:52.840
Once you've completed that exercise,
then what I would like you to do

343
00:22:52.840 --> 00:22:57.970
is take a look at our
session on exam preparation.

344
00:22:57.970 --> 00:23:03.450
And I would like you to undertake sample
paper one, which is in your materials.

345
00:23:03.450 --> 00:23:05.470
And then come back and join me for

346
00:23:05.470 --> 00:23:10.440
our review session as we go over
the sample paper one test paper.

347
00:23:11.560 --> 00:23:14.090
>> All right Jo, thank you again for
helping us out here and

348
00:23:14.090 --> 00:23:17.620
talking about the ideas of automation and
the challenges that are there.

349
00:23:17.620 --> 00:23:20.610
As well as the critical
success factors and

350
00:23:20.610 --> 00:23:24.875
even the risks that we need to understand
as we continue to move forward.

351
00:23:24.875 --> 00:23:28.065
Remember that if you're watching this
in the sequence of the entire show

352
00:23:28.065 --> 00:23:31.255
that you've been watching, this is also
the point for you to go through and

353
00:23:31.255 --> 00:23:33.325
make sure you do that sample paper.

354
00:23:33.325 --> 00:23:36.435
Getting ready, of course, for
the next session that is coming along.

355
00:23:36.435 --> 00:23:39.035
But if you've just started here,
make sure you go back and

356
00:23:39.035 --> 00:23:41.025
review all those other episodes well.

357
00:23:41.025 --> 00:23:44.220
If not, the sample paper's gonna be
much more difficult than you think.

358
00:23:44.220 --> 00:23:46.890
So this is a great place for
us to end this episode then.

359
00:23:46.890 --> 00:23:50.420
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

360
00:23:50.420 --> 00:23:51.510
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

361
00:23:51.510 --> 00:23:55.362
>> Stay tuned right here for more
ITIL Intermediate Service Strategy shows.

362
00:23:55.362 --> 00:24:01.956
[MUSIC]

363
00:24:01.956 --> 00:24:04.486
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo review some of the different techniques and details when sitting for your ITIL Intermediate exam.  They recommend downloading the sample paper for review.  Jo reviews the details on scoring of the exam.  She also has solid exam advice for delegates preparing for an exam.
episodes.title: Exam Review Introduction
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.200 --> 00:00:06.134
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.134 --> 00:00:08.006
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.006 --> 00:00:12.030
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.030 --> 00:00:15.340
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

5
00:00:15.340 --> 00:00:19.510
You're watching the ITIL Intermediate
Exam Review Introduction.

6
00:00:19.510 --> 00:00:22.904
I'm your host Ronnie Wong,
and if you've come this far,

7
00:00:22.904 --> 00:00:27.758
it means you have successfully reviewed
all the materials, you've taken a look at

8
00:00:27.758 --> 00:00:31.600
all those case studies, and
gotten in the hours that you need to.

9
00:00:31.600 --> 00:00:35.680
And that means now you are ready
to prepare for the exam as well.

10
00:00:35.680 --> 00:00:40.540
And here to help us of course, is gonna
be our ITIL wiz kid, it's Jo Peacock.

11
00:00:40.540 --> 00:00:42.140
Jo, welcome back to the show.

12
00:00:42.140 --> 00:00:45.030
>> Thank you very much,
Ronnie, it's great to be here.

13
00:00:45.030 --> 00:00:48.180
>> All right, Jo, now again,
what I said is true, right?

14
00:00:48.180 --> 00:00:50.560
The very fact is that
they've gotten to this point,

15
00:00:50.560 --> 00:00:53.630
they now need to really
focus in on the exam.

16
00:00:53.630 --> 00:00:57.720
Learning the material of course is
foremost and key but getting ready for

17
00:00:57.720 --> 00:00:59.860
the exam is a big part of this as well.

18
00:00:59.860 --> 00:01:01.430
So where are we gonna begin?

19
00:01:01.430 --> 00:01:04.060
>> So, yes, you're right,
we've completed a class.

20
00:01:04.060 --> 00:01:10.000
Congratulations everybody, you've put
in the prerequisite 21 hours worth of

21
00:01:10.000 --> 00:01:15.000
contact time as we say in the course
syllabus with both me and

22
00:01:15.000 --> 00:01:18.970
a predated instructor and also by going to

23
00:01:18.970 --> 00:01:23.790
the materials that you have been given and
provided with your course materials.

24
00:01:23.790 --> 00:01:26.910
So now it's time for the exam.

25
00:01:26.910 --> 00:01:30.180
And I know, Ronnie, that's a dreaded
word for some people, right?

26
00:01:30.180 --> 00:01:31.690
>> Right.
>> But don't worry.

27
00:01:31.690 --> 00:01:33.090
I'm here to guide you through it.

28
00:01:34.230 --> 00:01:37.870
I can't promise that I'm gonna give you
a pass on this, but I'll tell you what.

29
00:01:37.870 --> 00:01:42.250
If you listen to everything that I say,
and if you follow all the instructions and

30
00:01:42.250 --> 00:01:45.950
make sure that you read the question,
then you should find it really,

31
00:01:45.950 --> 00:01:47.020
really straight forward.

32
00:01:47.020 --> 00:01:50.460
So please don't worry,
now's the time that actually to relax,

33
00:01:50.460 --> 00:01:53.230
because you've done all your learning,
okay.

34
00:01:53.230 --> 00:01:55.900
So the first thing that
I want you to do is,

35
00:01:55.900 --> 00:02:00.250
I want you to go away and
to ensure that you have downloaded

36
00:02:00.250 --> 00:02:04.930
the sample papers that were given to
you as part of the course materials.

37
00:02:04.930 --> 00:02:08.830
Now, if you didn't receive them as
part of the course materials or

38
00:02:08.830 --> 00:02:13.210
you feel that you might want to
check out the AXELOS website,

39
00:02:13.210 --> 00:02:17.025
which obviously Axelos
are the people that own ITIL now.

40
00:02:17.025 --> 00:02:23.825
Then please feel free to go to
their website at www.axelos.org.

41
00:02:23.825 --> 00:02:27.825
And if you type in the search
there ITIL Intermediate.

42
00:02:27.825 --> 00:02:31.719
And you can download a sample
paper from that website.

43
00:02:32.790 --> 00:02:36.710
So what are going to do over the next
few moments is I'm gonna take you to

44
00:02:36.710 --> 00:02:38.680
some exam technique.

45
00:02:38.680 --> 00:02:43.390
And then I'going to ask you to go way and
attempt sample paper one.

46
00:02:43.390 --> 00:02:45.935
Once you've completed sample paper one.

47
00:02:45.935 --> 00:02:47.440
I'm gonna go over it with you.

48
00:02:47.440 --> 00:02:51.700
And I'm gonna make sure that you have
picked out all the salient points and all

49
00:02:51.700 --> 00:02:55.880
of the relevant point and everything that
you need in order to get the right answer.

50
00:02:56.910 --> 00:03:01.250
Yeah, talking about the right answer,
take a look at this slide, okay.

51
00:03:01.250 --> 00:03:05.820
There is no right answer,
there is no wrong answer,

52
00:03:05.820 --> 00:03:09.260
what you've got is a best fit answer.

53
00:03:09.260 --> 00:03:14.030
Now I know that way, way back at
the introduction to our class, I very,

54
00:03:14.030 --> 00:03:17.535
very briefly mentioned
the exam at the end of this.

55
00:03:17.535 --> 00:03:18.550
Okay.
And

56
00:03:18.550 --> 00:03:24.120
I said to you that it was complex
multiple choice exam, and they looked at,

57
00:03:24.120 --> 00:03:28.370
I think the word that we used at the very
start of the class is most correct?

58
00:03:28.370 --> 00:03:31.465
And I used the words best fit,
and that's what I like to use.

59
00:03:31.465 --> 00:03:34.880
Okay.
The best fit answer is five points.

60
00:03:34.880 --> 00:03:37.090
Your second best answer is three points.

61
00:03:37.090 --> 00:03:40.560
And your first, your third best
answer will give you one point.

62
00:03:40.560 --> 00:03:43.560
And then we've got this
distractor that I mentioned.

63
00:03:43.560 --> 00:03:45.960
And boy, is that there to distract.

64
00:03:45.960 --> 00:03:49.400
The distractor will quite often
use some nice, pretty words,

65
00:03:49.400 --> 00:03:52.450
the words that you find in
your ITIL publications.

66
00:03:52.450 --> 00:03:54.320
And you think gee, no, that sounds great.

67
00:03:54.320 --> 00:03:58.930
Cuz it's mentioned all of these processes
and it's mentioned all of these functions

68
00:03:58.930 --> 00:04:03.370
and its mentioned all of these activities,
that's got to be the right answer, right?

69
00:04:03.370 --> 00:04:07.800
No, because the right answer,
the best fit answer is got to be

70
00:04:07.800 --> 00:04:13.120
completely relevant to the scenario,
completely relevant.

71
00:04:13.120 --> 00:04:16.180
So sometimes the best fit
answer doesn't actually

72
00:04:16.180 --> 00:04:19.560
use any of the ITIL wording at all so
be careful.

73
00:04:19.560 --> 00:04:23.710
That distractor is called
the distractor for a reason, right?

74
00:04:23.710 --> 00:04:24.560
So the exam.

75
00:04:24.560 --> 00:04:26.620
Let me you a little bit about it then.

76
00:04:26.620 --> 00:04:27.300
You get 90 minutes.

77
00:04:27.300 --> 00:04:30.830
That's an hour and
a half you get to complete this exam, and

78
00:04:30.830 --> 00:04:34.320
you will be given eight
multiple choice questions.

79
00:04:35.360 --> 00:04:36.970
So you get two booklets.

80
00:04:36.970 --> 00:04:41.410
Okay, you get a scenario booklet and
you get a question booklet.

81
00:04:42.850 --> 00:04:45.490
Now, be very, very careful, okay.

82
00:04:45.490 --> 00:04:48.290
The Scenario Booklet as it says there,
sets the scene and

83
00:04:48.290 --> 00:04:51.510
the Question Booklet asks the question,
okay.

84
00:04:51.510 --> 00:04:53.610
Fairly straightforward, not really.

85
00:04:54.625 --> 00:04:58.905
First thing that I want you to check
when you see your question booklet.

86
00:04:58.905 --> 00:05:01.825
Is it the top of every single question.

87
00:05:01.825 --> 00:05:03.445
And boy, is this important.

88
00:05:03.445 --> 00:05:04.955
Don't forget this.

89
00:05:04.955 --> 00:05:11.035
At the top of every single question
it says, refer to scenario X.

90
00:05:12.500 --> 00:05:17.590
Sometimes, not all the time, not in
every paper, and in fact it's a rarity

91
00:05:17.590 --> 00:05:22.760
I'll admit, but sometimes you've
got one scenario for two questions.

92
00:05:22.760 --> 00:05:26.670
In other words two questions
refer to just that one scenario.

93
00:05:28.400 --> 00:05:32.910
Best way to ascertain whether that's
the case in your particular exam

94
00:05:32.910 --> 00:05:36.370
is scroll through to the end
of the scenario booklet.

95
00:05:36.370 --> 00:05:37.740
Look at the end of the scenario booklet.

96
00:05:37.740 --> 00:05:38.670
See how many you've got.

97
00:05:38.670 --> 00:05:42.740
If you're running on seven,
then that means that somewhere

98
00:05:42.740 --> 00:05:46.800
in your question booklet,
you've got two questions for one scenario.

99
00:05:46.800 --> 00:05:50.300
This is not the norm,
it's not in every single paper, but

100
00:05:50.300 --> 00:05:52.160
it's one definitely
worth watching out for.

101
00:05:52.160 --> 00:05:53.810
Okay, so always look at them.

102
00:05:53.810 --> 00:05:59.480
Right at the very, very top, take a look,
see what scenario it refers to.

103
00:06:00.880 --> 00:06:04.930
You've gotta get a total of 28 points out

104
00:06:04.930 --> 00:06:09.750
of 40 in order to pass the ITIL
Intermediate, the lifecycle phase.

105
00:06:09.750 --> 00:06:10.280
Okay?

106
00:06:10.280 --> 00:06:12.960
So think about this, okay?

107
00:06:12.960 --> 00:06:17.020
You can't get all threes,
all right, that's not going to work.

108
00:06:17.020 --> 00:06:18.840
You have to get some five pointers, okay?

109
00:06:19.860 --> 00:06:23.610
Obviously what I'd like you to do is
to get all five pointers, okay, and

110
00:06:23.610 --> 00:06:26.750
40 out of 40 by the way is not impossible.

111
00:06:26.750 --> 00:06:28.660
It really, really isn't impossible and

112
00:06:28.660 --> 00:06:34.930
I have quite a few the delegates [LAUGH]
that do actually achieve that, okay.

113
00:06:34.930 --> 00:06:39.160
So, what am I gonna ask you to do
then when it comes to this test?

114
00:06:40.210 --> 00:06:43.125
Well, I've got an acronym for
you and it's not one, I guess,

115
00:06:43.125 --> 00:06:45.765
I'm supposed to give you but
I'm gonna give you anyway.

116
00:06:45.765 --> 00:06:49.476
RTFQ.

117
00:06:49.476 --> 00:06:50.869
RTFQ.

118
00:06:50.869 --> 00:06:53.076
Ronnie, do you have any
idea what that means?

119
00:06:53.076 --> 00:06:53.764
>> No, I don't.

120
00:06:53.764 --> 00:06:54.884
>> Good.

121
00:06:54.884 --> 00:06:57.560
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm pleased [LAUGH].

122
00:06:57.560 --> 00:07:05.440
It means, read the full question,
>> Read the full question.

123
00:07:05.440 --> 00:07:08.890
Really, really, really important.

124
00:07:08.890 --> 00:07:13.360
There is not one word in that
question that is not relevant.

125
00:07:13.360 --> 00:07:16.940
Every single word is completely relevant.

126
00:07:18.070 --> 00:07:22.640
If you try and skim read, bear it in
mind that this test is not a race, okay.

127
00:07:22.640 --> 00:07:25.740
You're not gonna get any points for
finishing in 20 minutes, okay?

128
00:07:25.740 --> 00:07:31.140
You're not gonna get any prices for
that and nobody is gonna recognize you for

129
00:07:31.140 --> 00:07:34.560
being the fastest person
ever to finish an ITIL test.

130
00:07:34.560 --> 00:07:35.960
So please don't try it, okay?

131
00:07:35.960 --> 00:07:40.880
It's not gonna get you anything
additional over your school.

132
00:07:40.880 --> 00:07:45.130
Read the full question, take the time to
read the full question, read every single

133
00:07:45.130 --> 00:07:49.110
word, and that applies to the scenario
as well, read the scenario.

134
00:07:50.410 --> 00:07:54.890
You're looking for keywords, but you're
also looking for small words as well,

135
00:07:54.890 --> 00:08:00.289
words like, all and words like,
might and could, and should, and must.

136
00:08:01.340 --> 00:08:02.040
Please, please,

137
00:08:02.040 --> 00:08:07.060
please pick out those words cuz they
are incredibly important, okay?

138
00:08:07.060 --> 00:08:08.980
First thing that I want you
to do is read the question.

139
00:08:10.700 --> 00:08:13.700
The question can generally be very,

which is now a distractor.

532
00:33:45.673 --> 00:33:50.590
The biggest issue is these for practices.

533
00:33:50.590 --> 00:33:54.884
And in order to unify this, we must first
implement service portfolio management.

534
00:33:54.884 --> 00:33:56.188
Why?

535
00:33:56.188 --> 00:34:00.127
[LAUGH] I'm not sure what service
portfolio management has got to do

536
00:34:00.127 --> 00:34:01.250
with this.

537
00:34:01.250 --> 00:34:05.020
Service portfolio management is where
we have a list of our services in

538
00:34:05.020 --> 00:34:07.700
the catalog, and
our ideas in the pipeline and

539
00:34:07.700 --> 00:34:14.085
our retired services in the retired
services portion, so I'm not sure why.

540
00:34:14.085 --> 00:34:17.545
In order to actualize service assets and
connect them to customer face and

541
00:34:17.545 --> 00:34:21.115
services, and account for
the capital and non-capital cost.

542
00:34:21.115 --> 00:34:24.483
We haven't worked out what we're
going to categorize as capital and

543
00:34:24.483 --> 00:34:27.470
non-capital expenditure yet.

544
00:34:27.470 --> 00:34:30.580
Because we haven't got a consistent
way of looking at this,

545
00:34:30.580 --> 00:34:34.000
we've just got disparate ways of
doing this, so we can't do that.

546
00:34:35.540 --> 00:34:40.460
And that's used then for establishing
a chart of accounts, budget line items and

547
00:34:40.460 --> 00:34:41.330
costing accounts.

548
00:34:43.130 --> 00:34:47.430
No, this wont provide
the sought-after financial feature.

549
00:34:47.430 --> 00:34:50.770
What this will do is just
confuse matters most.

550
00:34:50.770 --> 00:34:52.590
We don't need portfolio management.

551
00:34:52.590 --> 00:34:57.150
What we need to do is we need to look at
the accounts that we have right now, and

552
00:34:57.150 --> 00:35:01.180
see how we can combine
them into a consistent,

553
00:35:01.180 --> 00:35:07.190
a standard chart that we can understand
the information that we have.

554
00:35:08.660 --> 00:35:13.510
So to me, this particular question is
fairly obvious that the five pointer here

555
00:35:13.510 --> 00:35:19.540
is D, because D is the only one that
actually goes, well, follows the right

556
00:35:19.540 --> 00:35:24.410
route down the CSI approach but it's the
only one that really answers the question.

557
00:35:25.680 --> 00:35:29.160
Pay very, very careful attention
to what the question is,

558
00:35:29.160 --> 00:35:30.510
that you are being answered.

559
00:35:30.510 --> 00:35:33.770
And please remember to answer
the question you're being asked,

560
00:35:33.770 --> 00:35:36.440
rather than the one you
think you're being asked.

561
00:35:37.755 --> 00:35:42.765
So that's it for part one for
our first half of our exam review.

562
00:35:42.765 --> 00:35:47.757
So please join us again in next
episode where we will take a look

563
00:35:47.757 --> 00:35:52.661
at part two of our sample paper review for
service strategy.

564
00:35:52.661 --> 00:35:58.340
[SOUND]

episodes.description: Exam review for ITIL Intermediate - Service Strategy
episodes.title: Exam Review Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.050 --> 00:00:05.090
[SOUND] So
welcome back to Part 2 of our sample

2
00:00:05.090 --> 00:00:09.324
paper review for service strategy.

3
00:00:09.324 --> 00:00:14.750
So let's get straight on and
take a look at question number 5 then.

4
00:00:14.750 --> 00:00:19.690
And question number 5,
well, you are a consultant

5
00:00:19.690 --> 00:00:23.130
engaged by the CIO to provide advice.

6
00:00:23.130 --> 00:00:25.370
Well, on what strategy?

7
00:00:25.370 --> 00:00:28.110
We've got four factories in Europe.

8
00:00:28.110 --> 00:00:30.820
Now first thing that I want you to
think about is the fact then we've got

9
00:00:30.820 --> 00:00:33.440
different languages, and
we've got different cultures.

10
00:00:33.440 --> 00:00:36.680
The head office is based in a large
city close to one of the factories.

11
00:00:36.680 --> 00:00:37.875
It doesn't say where.

12
00:00:37.875 --> 00:00:41.800
All four factories have got
administration offices,

13
00:00:41.800 --> 00:00:45.120
supporting purchasing,
sales, distribution.

14
00:00:45.120 --> 00:00:48.190
And shared services
are based at head office.

15
00:00:48.190 --> 00:00:51.979
The customers are either large car
manufacturers, who have ongoing

16
00:00:51.979 --> 00:00:56.040
requirements for standard parts that
are planned a long time in advance.

17
00:00:56.040 --> 00:01:00.450
It's fairly secure,
brings in steady, low margin income.

18
00:01:00.450 --> 00:01:04.290
We've got car repairers, who have
a mixture of those steady requirements and

19
00:01:04.290 --> 00:01:06.115
some ad hoc ones.

20
00:01:06.115 --> 00:01:08.970
And they require their parts
on relatively short notice.

21
00:01:08.970 --> 00:01:12.120
So it's based on medium and
short term contracts.

22
00:01:12.120 --> 00:01:15.440
And this strong competition and

23
00:01:15.440 --> 00:01:19.280
the level of service responsiveness
is a differentiator.

24
00:01:19.280 --> 00:01:21.863
And then we've got car manufacturers and
specialists,

25
00:01:21.863 --> 00:01:23.919
who've got specific one off requirements.

26
00:01:23.919 --> 00:01:27.981
And they're willing to pay a lot of money,
and they're willing to wait for delivery.

27
00:01:27.981 --> 00:01:31.742
And they can lead to lucrative
long term contracts.

28
00:01:31.742 --> 00:01:34.390
All customers are supplied
by their local factory,

29
00:01:34.390 --> 00:01:37.270
but large customers can be
supplied by more than one.

30
00:01:38.770 --> 00:01:40.237
As most of the services and

31
00:01:40.237 --> 00:01:44.441
management head office by a central IT
unit with smaller, local unit serve

32
00:01:44.441 --> 00:01:48.328
each of the factories with
infrastructure management and support.

33
00:01:48.328 --> 00:01:51.165
And the services for the factories and

34
00:01:51.165 --> 00:01:56.842
the sales run on distributed IT
infrastructure and are supported locally.

35
00:01:56.842 --> 00:02:01.192
The CIO's been asked by the CEO
to reduce the cost of IT, and

36
00:02:01.192 --> 00:02:07.123
he's decided to investigate a strategy
of consolidation and centralization.

37
00:02:07.123 --> 00:02:10.700
Okay, so the question, again,
then, you are the consultant.

38
00:02:10.700 --> 00:02:14.600
What's the best advice on the strategy?

39
00:02:14.600 --> 00:02:18.878
Now he wants to look at consolidation and
centralization.

40
00:02:18.878 --> 00:02:21.621
So let's take a look
then at our five pointer.

41
00:02:21.621 --> 00:02:23.774
And our five pointer actually says, well,

42
00:02:23.774 --> 00:02:27.870
it's difficult to determine where
consolidation would be most effective.

43
00:02:27.870 --> 00:02:31.857
And that's a fair statement to make,
because based on the information I have

44
00:02:31.857 --> 00:02:35.801
in that scenario, I would say well,
I don't really know enough right now.

45
00:02:35.801 --> 00:02:42.080
It's likely that some would be cost
effective through sharing resources, etc.

46
00:02:42.080 --> 00:02:45.210
But it would be more appropriate to
consider the dependencies between

47
00:02:45.210 --> 00:02:48.540
the services,
how the services is deployed, and

48
00:02:48.540 --> 00:02:51.640
evaluate user costs and IT costs.

49
00:02:51.640 --> 00:02:56.230
And then determine whether consolidation
of any aspects of the service would be

50
00:02:56.230 --> 00:02:57.120
cost effective.

51
00:02:58.310 --> 00:03:00.000
Okay, so in other words,

52
00:03:00.000 --> 00:03:04.540
what they say it is, we need to think
about how the services hang together.

53
00:03:04.540 --> 00:03:08.860
That's the best thing to do right now,
is look at how they hang together.

54
00:03:08.860 --> 00:03:14.320
Now I have mentioned to you in previous
session that we want to focus on value,

55
00:03:14.320 --> 00:03:15.370
as well as cost.

56
00:03:15.370 --> 00:03:18.313
However, in this particular scenario,

57
00:03:18.313 --> 00:03:22.441
we are told that this is part
of a cost-cutting exercise.

58
00:03:22.441 --> 00:03:29.820
So we have to demonstrate a willingness
and an approach that will cut costs.

59
00:03:29.820 --> 00:03:32.030
That's the answer,
that's what we have to look for.

60
00:03:33.550 --> 00:03:36.088
So D says, well,
it's gonna be difficult right now.

61
00:03:36.088 --> 00:03:41.490
Okay, C, well, it says here in C,
which is your three pointer,

62
00:03:41.490 --> 00:03:45.800
it's possible that there
are aspects of all services

63
00:03:45.800 --> 00:03:50.290
supporting all end customer types that
would be capable of consolidation.

64
00:03:52.000 --> 00:03:55.930
It kind of makes an assumption, but the
fact that it says that it's possible then

65
00:03:55.930 --> 00:03:59.100
suggests ambiguity and
doesn't commit to anything.

66
00:03:59.100 --> 00:04:03.580
So I'm kind of all right with that, but
I don't really like the wording of it.

67
00:04:03.580 --> 00:04:07.100
It would be appropriate to investigate
further a service model for

68
00:04:07.100 --> 00:04:13.060
each of the IT service types with at least
matching existing levels of utility and

69
00:04:13.060 --> 00:04:14.730
warranty at a lower cost.

70
00:04:14.730 --> 00:04:18.110
Now there's an assumption that I don't
like, that the assumption there is that

71
00:04:18.110 --> 00:04:22.090
you can match existing levels of
utility and warranty at a lower cost.

72
00:04:22.090 --> 00:04:26.790
You might not be able to, and you've
missed out the fact that we've probably

73
00:04:26.790 --> 00:04:29.530
got a lot of shared
components of these services.

74
00:04:29.530 --> 00:04:33.540
That we could put some
efficiencies in place there,

75
00:04:33.540 --> 00:04:37.330
which is why D is your five pointer,
and it looks at the relationships.

76
00:04:37.330 --> 00:04:39.490
Because that looks at
the shared components,

77
00:04:39.490 --> 00:04:43.090
and it looks at adding in efficiencies
in those shared components.

78
00:04:44.412 --> 00:04:48.130
Whereas C just looks
immediately at each service,

79
00:04:48.130 --> 00:04:53.660
trying to keep it in a silo, and that's
not going to help us with efficiency.

80
00:04:53.660 --> 00:04:58.160
Actually looking at consolidation will
help us better with efficiencies.

81
00:04:58.160 --> 00:05:01.160
So let's look at B, B is your one pointer.

82
00:05:01.160 --> 00:05:05.944
Well, the IT services support the ad
hoc cost requirement provide important

83
00:05:05.944 --> 00:05:08.360
business differentiation.

84
00:05:08.360 --> 00:05:12.010
So, it's important that
these are serviced locally.

85
00:05:12.010 --> 00:05:13.150
Is it?

86
00:05:13.150 --> 00:05:14.390
Is it really?

87
00:05:14.390 --> 00:05:17.070
If I go back to my scenario, it says,

88
00:05:17.070 --> 00:05:21.470
in number three there, well, they've
got specific one off requirements, for

89
00:05:21.470 --> 00:05:26.060
which they're willing to pay a high
premium and wait for delivery.

90
00:05:26.060 --> 00:05:29.630
Well, if they wait for delivery, then
it doesn't have to be serviced locally.

91
00:05:29.630 --> 00:05:32.020
They could be serviced centrally.

92
00:05:33.910 --> 00:05:37.030
And these should not be consolidated and
centralized?

93
00:05:37.030 --> 00:05:40.760
Actually, these are the ones
that could be consolidated and

94
00:05:40.760 --> 00:05:42.770
centralized, out of all of them.

95
00:05:44.150 --> 00:05:48.713
Instead, the services that are similar
across multiple different situations

96
00:05:48.713 --> 00:05:51.241
should be considered for centralization.

97
00:05:51.241 --> 00:05:54.649
Now I've got nothing wrong with
saying we should consider those for

98
00:05:54.649 --> 00:05:58.475
centralization as well, but to dismiss
the ones that are fairly obvious for

99
00:05:58.475 --> 00:06:00.590
centralization would be a huge mistake.

100
00:06:02.580 --> 00:06:04.622
And don't forget we're talking
about IT services as well.

101
00:06:04.622 --> 00:06:09.481
We're not necessarily
talking about the customers.

102
00:06:09.481 --> 00:06:14.650
We're not necessarily talking
about the car parts themselves.

103
00:06:14.650 --> 00:06:19.549
But if our services are on site,
where those car parts are produced, and

104
00:06:19.549 --> 00:06:23.160
the car parts are, well,
as it says in the scenario,

105
00:06:23.160 --> 00:06:25.910
the car parts are one off requirements.

106
00:06:25.910 --> 00:06:30.502
And they're willing to wait for
delivery, then the IT services,

107
00:06:30.502 --> 00:06:34.450
it's not so urgent that the IT
services be on site there.

108
00:06:37.330 --> 00:06:41.596
So B seems take us down the wrong path,
and that's always a little bit worrying,

109
00:06:41.596 --> 00:06:43.940
but then that's why it's the one pointer.

110
00:06:43.940 --> 00:06:48.190
And then let's look at our 0.2,
or our distractor.

111
00:06:49.190 --> 00:06:53.830
The services that support contracts with
manufacturers are a good candidate for

112
00:06:53.830 --> 00:06:56.490
consolidation and centralization,

113
00:06:56.490 --> 00:07:01.640
which will bring cost savings through
sharing resources and infrastructure.

114
00:07:01.640 --> 00:07:06.620
And they're the ones that have been
planned a long time in advance.

115
00:07:08.430 --> 00:07:10.420
And it's a long term contract.

116
00:07:11.580 --> 00:07:14.860
Okay, there's an assumption there.

117
00:07:14.860 --> 00:07:19.510
It doesn't say that they are willing
to wait for delivery on this.

118
00:07:19.510 --> 00:07:24.860
it doesn't say that there are any
time constraints on here or

119
00:07:24.860 --> 00:07:27.270
that there aren't any
time constraints on this.

120
00:07:27.270 --> 00:07:30.290
Just that they planned
a long time in advance.

121
00:07:32.290 --> 00:07:35.520
Since the business services that
they support are low value and

122
00:07:35.520 --> 00:07:40.468
high volume, it would make good
business sense to consolidate them and

123
00:07:40.468 --> 00:07:45.270
provide them centrally.

124
00:07:45.270 --> 00:07:50.280
Just because they have low value and
they're high volume doesn't

125
00:07:50.280 --> 00:07:54.847
necessarily mean that we don't
get a lot of money from them.

126
00:07:54.847 --> 00:08:00.415
Because if they form the bulk of
our work and the bulk of our sales,

127
00:08:00.415 --> 00:08:05.071
then actually,
just because they have In all, well,

128
00:08:05.071 --> 00:08:08.916
low value,
well there could be a lot of them,

129
00:08:08.916 --> 00:08:13.799
it says high volume,
that could make up all of our sales.

130
00:08:13.799 --> 00:08:16.010
So be careful about making assumption.

131
00:08:16.010 --> 00:08:19.460
This answer here is almost
one huge big assumption.

132
00:08:19.460 --> 00:08:23.140
So be incredibly carefull
about making that assumption.

133
00:08:24.580 --> 00:08:27.760
We don't want to
consolidate something that

134
00:08:27.760 --> 00:08:32.000
is actually bringing in steady income.

135
00:08:32.000 --> 00:08:34.270
If it's bringing in steady income and

136
00:08:34.270 --> 00:08:39.950
it's bringing in high volume income
then do we really want to disrupt that?

137
00:08:39.950 --> 00:08:45.530
Because we don't want to have
any negative effect on value.

138
00:08:45.530 --> 00:08:50.190
And the ideal candidate in this
instance is actually number three.

139
00:08:50.190 --> 00:08:53.200
They are the ideal candidate for
consolidation.

140
00:08:53.200 --> 00:08:57.920
Which of the car manufacturers and
specialists with one off requirements

141
00:08:57.920 --> 00:09:01.218
that are willing to pay a high premium and
wait for delivery.

142
00:09:01.218 --> 00:09:07.860
That's your perfect candidate for
consolidation.

143
00:09:07.860 --> 00:09:12.990
However, at this stage, it's really,
really difficult to make any assumptions.

144
00:09:12.990 --> 00:09:16.370
And I don't like making any without

145
00:09:16.370 --> 00:09:18.670
looking at the dependencies
between the services.

146
00:09:20.050 --> 00:09:22.470
So we going for the answer here.

147
00:09:22.470 --> 00:09:23.500
And we have to go for

148
00:09:23.500 --> 00:09:28.290
the best fit answer here that says,
you need to investigate further.

149
00:09:28.290 --> 00:09:31.550
Because this is going to have
a huge impact on the organization.

150
00:09:31.550 --> 00:09:33.000
And therefore,

151
00:09:33.000 --> 00:09:37.040
we need to make sure that the decision
that we make is going to be the right one.

152
00:09:37.040 --> 00:09:40.030
So we need to ensure that we've
got all of the information to hand

153
00:09:40.030 --> 00:09:42.050
before we make any decisions.

154
00:09:42.050 --> 00:09:45.440
And we don't do it with any assumptions.

155
00:09:45.440 --> 00:09:49.410
And that's why D is your five-pointer.

156
00:09:49.410 --> 00:09:50.960
So let's take a look at number six then.

157
00:09:50.960 --> 00:09:53.990
And we've got a rather large
scenario here with number six.

158
00:09:53.990 --> 00:09:57.307
And we're looking at
governance here in number six.

159
00:09:57.307 --> 00:10:02.137
Which was a section that
we cover towards the end of

160
00:10:02.137 --> 00:10:05.712
our episode with service strategy.

161
00:10:05.712 --> 00:10:11.330
So which one of these proposed ways is
the best to address governance issues?

162
00:10:11.330 --> 00:10:14.060
So we've got a global
manufacturing company.

163
00:10:14.060 --> 00:10:19.220
We've been opening new locations and
acquiring competitors.

164
00:10:19.220 --> 00:10:21.810
Even though they're having
issues with the acquisitions,

165
00:10:21.810 --> 00:10:26.320
with integrating business services
under the single IT department.

166
00:10:26.320 --> 00:10:30.490
So we've not achieved benefits
quickly with the integration,

167
00:10:30.490 --> 00:10:35.010
well as quickly as we want,
and we've had hidden costs.

168
00:10:35.010 --> 00:10:39.330
We're struggling to meet demand using the
same resources that are now spread across

169
00:10:39.330 --> 00:10:41.220
more locations.

170
00:10:41.220 --> 00:10:45.720
And the acquired company's IT
resources are not aligning culturally

171
00:10:45.720 --> 00:10:46.760
as anticipated.

172
00:10:46.760 --> 00:10:50.500
And that looks to me like we need
to consider organizational change

173
00:10:50.500 --> 00:10:51.840
management here.

174
00:10:51.840 --> 00:10:55.140
So they need further effort
to adopt corporate ways

175
00:10:55.140 --> 00:10:57.380
while still remaining productive.

176
00:10:58.890 --> 00:11:03.350
Service level targets and
customer satisfaction is declining.

177
00:11:03.350 --> 00:11:05.980
And the CEO wants something done.

178
00:11:06.980 --> 00:11:12.330
CIO's asked for more money to
implement better governance and

179
00:11:12.330 --> 00:11:14.878
a better acquisition strategy.

180
00:11:14.878 --> 00:11:18.343
And the CIOs realize that
increased attention, well,

181
00:11:18.343 --> 00:11:22.335
would allowed the company to
position the integration better.

182
00:11:22.335 --> 00:11:25.990
And some choices might have
been made differently.

183
00:11:25.990 --> 00:11:29.470
The CEO however, felt that we
already got corporal governance.

184
00:11:29.470 --> 00:11:33.190
And IT governance is really
just a reporting structure.

185
00:11:33.190 --> 00:11:37.690
And so, it doesn't need any more money and
hasn't given us any more money.

186
00:11:37.690 --> 00:11:39.935
Now, we've convinced the CEO
of the governances needed.

187
00:11:39.935 --> 00:11:46.485
And we're going to address the declining
social issues by creating policies and

188
00:11:46.485 --> 00:11:50.360
mandate that support
staffing to use a ratios.

189
00:11:50.360 --> 00:11:55.780
It's gonna address the demand
on IT resources and

190
00:11:55.780 --> 00:11:58.380
assist with faster cultural adoption.

191
00:11:59.380 --> 00:12:04.510
Okay, the result should be stronger
customer centric focused and

192
00:12:04.510 --> 00:12:07.910
more collegial attitudes towards,
amongst there.

193
00:12:07.910 --> 00:12:10.960
So we'll give them more money and
they're gonna be nicer to each other,

194
00:12:10.960 --> 00:12:12.240
this is what we're saying.

195
00:12:12.240 --> 00:12:17.950
And a general sense of guided direction so
they've given us some money.

196
00:12:17.950 --> 00:12:18.528
And guess what?

197
00:12:18.528 --> 00:12:20.550
You're the one that's gonna sort this out.

198
00:12:20.550 --> 00:12:25.950
So which one is the best option
